provisions.provision: Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments regarding Article III, Section 1(2): by adding the words "Enewetak and" immediately prior to the word "Ujelang" and wherever the word "Ujelang" appears in this section so that it reads "Enewetak im Ujelang"? (Proposal 24)

Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments regarding Article IV, Section 2(1): by including Enenkio Island as part of the electoral district with which it is closely associated in the Republic of the Marshall Islands to read, in part, as follows: "... Ņadikdik, Erikup, Jemo̧, Taka, Bikar, Bokak, Enenkio, Rongrik and Ailinginae shall each be included in the electoral district with which it is most closely associated, pursuant to the customary law or any traditional practice."? (Proposal 21)

Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments to Article IV Section 4, and Article XIV, relating to qualifications of Nitijela candidates by adding a new subsection to read as follows: "Any person who is qualified to be a candidate must have land rights by birth and be a natural born citizen." "natural born citizen" means a person who, at the time of birth, either his/her mother or father has a jowi and is a citizen pursuant to subparagraph (a) of paragraph 2 of Section 1 of Article XI? (Proposal 19D2)

Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments regarding Article VII Section 3, The Attorney General and Article VII, by adding new Section 12, and Article XII, Section 2(2), The Ombudsman: To amend subsection (3) of Artilcle VII, by transferring the duties between the Ombudsman to that of the Attorney General (Proposal 17D2) and to insert a new Section 12 of Article VII, to provide for the establishment of an Ombusdman, the duties and responsibilities of the Ombudsman, the manner of appointment and removal, tenure and compensation? (Proposal 18D3)

Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments regarding Article VI Section 4(3) and Article VI Section 2(2): The Traditional Rights Court: To amend these Sections to confer original jurisdiction in the Traditional Rights Courts to determine controversies relating to the customary law, traditional practices, land rights and titles or other related customary or traditional matters? (Proposal 16ND2)

Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments regarding Article III, Section 1(2): to increase the membership of the Council of Irooj from the electoral districts of the Ratak Chain to include another Iroojlaplap from Mile atoll? (Proposal 14)

Do you approve the 2017 constitutional amendments regarding Article XI Section 2(b) and Article XIV Section 1: Limiting Eligibility for Citizenship by Registration and Restricting "that he/she has been a resident in the Republic for no less than ten (10) years, is the parent of a child who is a citizen of the Republic, and is married to the parent of that child, whose parent is also a citizen of the Republic"? (Proposal 1 & 22D2)

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

government_functions.details: Executive branch - headed by the Prime Minister, who is appointed by the Diet and formally designated by the Emperor. Implements laws, manages foreign policy, and oversees government administration. Legislative branch (National Diet) - composed of the House of Representatives (lower house) and House of Councillors (upper house), in charge of making laws, approving budgets, ratifying treaties, and appointing the Prime Minister. Judicial branch - composed of the Supreme Court and lower courts, in charge of interpreting laws and ensuring their constitutionality and resolving legal disputes. Judges are appointed, and Supreme Court judges face periodic "retention referenda."

voting_methods.instructions: The voter must present an ID and a document provided by the overseas voting management officer of the relevant embassy that can prove that the applicant has not acquired foreign nationality, such as a permanent resident certificate or visa. Overseas voters present their ID card to verify their identity. They then sign or stamp the ballot paper receipt confirmation machine (signature input machine or unmanned input machine) and receive the ballot paper and return envelope. Lastly, they select one candidate or one party on the ballot paper using the marking tool provided at the polling station, mark it, put it in the return envelope, seal it, and then put it in the ballot box.

Home voters mark the ballot paper received from the competent election commission, put the ballot paper into the envelope for return, seal the envelope, and then dispatch the envelope by registered mail. For shipboard voters, the shipmaster sets the date and location for voting, informs the crew, and sets up the voting area with necessary equipment, including a facsimile machine to transmit votes. Voters receive and sign their ballots in the presence of the shipmaster and observers, then mark their choice and send the ballot by fax to the relevant election commission. The original ballots are sealed and kept by the shipmaster, who later forwards them along with voting records to the election commission, either upon return to Korea or via international mail.

The voter presents an ID and provides a handprint or signature input. They are given ballot papers and mark the ballot papers in a booth at the polling station (marking the column of the candidate they vote for on the ballot, where names of candidates are printed in advance) and insert the ballots in sealed ballot boxes.

The voter presents an ID and provides a handprint or signature input. They are given ballot papers and mark the ballot papers in a booth at the polling station (marking the column of the candidate they vote for on the ballot, where names of candidates are printed in advance) and insert the ballots in sealed ballot boxes.

government_functions.details:
Executive Branch: Headed by the President, who is the head of state and commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The President is responsible for implementing laws, directing foreign policy, and overseeing government administration through various ministries. The Prime Minister, appointed by the President with the National Assembly's consent, assists in coordinating government functions and can act as the President’s deputy.
 
Legislative Branch: The National Assembly is a unicameral parliament composed of elected representatives. It makes laws, approves the national budget, ratifies treaties, and oversees the executive branch. It also has the authority to impeach public officials, including the President.
 
Judicial Branch: The judiciary ensures the constitutionality of laws and delivers justice. It includes the Supreme Court, the highest ordinary court, and the Constitutional Court, which rules on constitutional matters like impeachment and political party dissolution.

government_functions.details:
Portugal has a semi-presidential system.
 
Executive Branch: Headed by the Prime Minister, who is responsible for implementing laws and running the day-to-day affairs of the country. The government includes the Prime Minister, ministers, and secretaries of state.
 
Legislative Branch: the Assembly of the Republic, responsible for making laws. It consists of 230 deputies elected for four-year terms through a closed-list proportional system.
 
Judiciary Branch: Composed of the Constitutional Court, the Supreme Court, Courts of Appeal, First-Instance Courts, Administrative and Fiscal Courts, and Auditors Courts. The branch interprets and applies the law, ensuring justice is administered fairly.
 
President of the Republic: elected by direct popular vote, the President acts as a mediator and has some significant powers, including appointing the Prime Minister and other key officials.

Except as otherwise provided by this Constitution or by law, any citizen who has attained the age of 18 years shall have the right of being elected in accordance with law.
The provisions of Articles 130 of the Constitution shall cease to apply.

government_functions.details: Taiwan has a semi-presidential system, with a president as the head of state and a premier as the head of government. The president is elected directly by the people for a four-year term, and the premier is appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan, the unicameral parliament.  The Executive Yuan, also known as the Cabinet, is the executive branch of the government. It is responsible for carrying out the policies and decisions made by the president and premier. The Executive Yuan is headed by the premier, who is assisted by a vice premier and a number of ministers.  The Legislative Yuan is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the activities of the government. It has 113 members, who are elected from single-member districts (73), multimember constituencies by single nontransferable voting, exclusively for people with indigenous status (6) and party-list proportional representation (34).  The Judicial Yuan is the judicial branch of the government. It is responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that it is applied fairly.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

voting_methods.instructions: Follows the same instructions for mail in voting. Out of country voting is conducted by mail only and the voters use the same special ballot. Ballots must be returned to Elections Ottawa by 6 PM on election day. Canada keeps an International Register of Electors, which Canadians newly abroad can apply to be added to.

Must apply to vote by special ballot by Tuesday, April 22 at 6 pm. The ballot will not have names of candidates; the voter must write in the candidate's first and last name to be counted. The party can be listed but is not required, and a vote for a party with no candidate name will not be counted. The ballot is placed in an unmarked, sealed inner envelope; that enveloped is then placed in a second envelope which the voter signs and dates. The outer envelope has pre-paid postage.
Advanced polling days, which are distinct fvrom special early voting procedures, are offered at certain locations. This process is unique from the special ballot process at Elections Canada offices.

Early voting takes place by special ballot at any Elections Canada office (location search here: https://www.elections.ca/content2.aspx?section=vote&dir=locate&document=index&lang=e). The special ballot is the same as for mail-in voting. The ballot will not have names of candidates; the voter must write in the candidate's first and last name to be counted. The party can be listed but is not required, and a vote for a party with no candidate name will not be counted. The ballot is placed in an unmarked, sealed inner envelope; that enveloped is then placed in a second envelope which the voter signs and dates. It is then placed in the box at the Elections Canada Office.

On election day, voters go to their assigned polling station. They present am ID with their name and address (full list of acceptable ID forms available) and are given a paper ballot to fill out. Individuals without an ID can still vote if someone vouches for them. Individuals whose registration information is out of date can update this information at the polling station. Election officials give a folded ballot to the voter, who goes behind a privacy screen to mark the ballot. The voter returns the re-folded ballot to the election worker, who tears a tab off of the ballot and gives it back to the voter; this ensures the ballot is anonymous. The voter places the ballot in the ballot box.

government_functions.details:
The monarchy is hereditary. The Governor General is appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister for a 5-year term. The Governor General designates the Prime Minister, who is generally the leader of the majority party or coalition.  
All 338 members of the House of Commons are directly elected by plurality/majority vote. Seats are redistristributed after each decennial census on the basis of population between the 10 states and 3 provinces, which may also change the overall number of seats. Members serve 5-year terms.  
All 105 members of the Senate are appointed by the Governor General on behalf of the Monarch. Seats are equally allocated between the following four divisions: Ontario, Quebec, the Maritime Provinces/Nova Scotia and New Brunswick/Prince Edward Island, and the Western Provinces of Manitoba/British Columbia/Saskatchewan/Alberta. Members of the Senate serve for life, with a mandatory retirement age of 75.

institution.institution_name: Trinidad and Tobago House of Representatives

voting_methods.instructions: For the first time, special early voting windows were allotted for offshore workers on April 16th and 17th.

Members of the police, defense forces, prison service, election officials, candidates and their spouse, patients in hospital, inmates, flight crews, and offshore oil operation personnel are eligible to apply to vote early if they know they will not be able to vote in their poll station on election day. They must apply for each election, between election notice and nomination day. They will then be placed on a list of early electors and cannot subsequently vote on election day. They will collect their ballot with a return envelope and identity form from the special polling stations, advertised in the Gazette. The early voters place their ballot in an box labelled "special ballot box" .

Upon entering the poll station, the elector (voter) presented their identification card to be checked against the register. If a voter does not have their identification card, they can provide their name and address to be checked against the register, and swear an oath. The elector signs or marks their poll card with ink on a directed finger (with protocols for individuals who may not have the finger). The presiding officer supplies the ballot to the voter with his/her intiials and the poll station number. The voter marks with a stamp or otherwise an X on the ballot to the right of the name of the candidate of their choice in privacy, and then folds the ballot so that the mark is not visible but the presiding officer's initials and the poll number are. After inspection that it is folded correctly and is the same ballot paper oroginally given, the voter dips their finger in election ink before placing the ballot in the ballot box.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting by proxy is permitted for diplomats, their spouses, and dependents when they are on duty out of the country. A proxy can only serve in this capacity for one person in an election. There is a written application for the out of country voter to submit ahead of election day.

On election day, a voter at the polls presents an ID card and states their name nad address. Their name is announced and anyone can object to their identity. Once confirmed or not objected to, voters dip their right forefinger up to the first knuckle in "indelible ink". They receive a ballot with the presiding initials on the back; the ballot lists candidate names, colors, and symbols as previously advertised. They mark one choice, and fold the ballot. They must show the presiding officer their initials on the back before placing it in the box.

voting_methods.instructions: Overseas voters must meet residency standards and can register to vote by mail or at one of 10 overseas polling locations.

"The voter must bring along his original or digital NRIC (or identity cards issued by the Ministry of Defence, Singapore Police Force or Singapore Civil Defence Force for uniformed personnel) or passport to the polling station. Photocopies of these identification documents are not allowed. Bringing along the poll or ePoll card card will facilitate checks.
 
The voter should mark his choice clearly with an "X" in one of the empty boxes on the ballot paper. In order to maintain voting secrecy, a voter should observe the following:
DON'T sign or make any marks on the ballot paper that may identify him;
DON'T show his ballot paper to anyone else in the polling station.
 
After the voter has marked his choice on his ballot paper, he should fold his ballot paper into half, proceed to drop his ballot paper in the ballot box without delay and leave the polling station."

voting_methods.instructions: For the election of the president and deputies or for referenda, polling stations are set up at diplomatic and consular offices. Unclear which countries would be enabling residents to vote.

Voters registered at the polling station and in possession of their voter ID can cast their ballot. In absence of the voter ID card, voters might also be authorized to vote by presenting their national ID or passport and confirming their registration at that specific polling station. The voter goes to a voting booth and places the ballot with their choice in the "vote" envelope and all other ballots in the compartment marked "trash." The voter then shows the president of the polling station that they are carrying only one envelope and presents their voter card or other accepted documents. The president calls out loud the voter and passes their voter card to the first vice-president, who checks it and passes it to the first rapporteur. The president then lets the voter place the envelope in the ballot box. The voter signs their name on the voter list, and the second rapporteur affixes the date stamp in the appropriate box on the voter's card and marks the voter with indelible ink.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is the Head of State and must be "the guarantor of national independence, territorial integrity, and respect for international agreements and treaties." The Legislative is composed of the National Assembly (deputies, directly elected for 5-year terms) and the Senate (senators, indirectly elected for 5-year terms). The Judiciary is composed of the Constitutional Court, judicial courts, administrative courts, financial courts, the High Court of Justice, the Court of Justice of the Republic, and other exceptional courts.

voting_methods.instructions: Same as domestic voters: The voter hands their ID to the polling station chair and a poll worker verifies their eligibility. Once verified, the voter signs the list and marks it with their fingerprint. The polling station chair grabs a ballot, shows to all people present that it is unmarked (except for poll worker and party agents' signatures and fingerprints on the back to guarantee its authenticity), and hands it to the voter. The voter takes the ballot to the secrecy booth, marks it with their preference, folds it, and places it in the ballot box. The voter then receives their ID back and proof of voting.

government_functions.details:
Bolivia's government is composed of:
Executive branch: headed by the President, tasked with leading foreign policy, administering national laws and public policy, managing the armed forces, issuing decrees and regulations, and appointing ministers and high public officials.
Legislative branch (Plurinational Legislative Assembly): composed of the Chamber of Deputies (lower house) and the Chamber of Senators (upper house), tasked with enacting, amending, and repealing laws, approving the national budget and public spending, ratifying international treaties, appointing key state officials, and overseeing the executive branch.
Judicial branch: composed of the Supreme Court of Justice, the Constitutional Court, the Agro-Environmental Court, and the Council of the Magistracy, tasked with interpreting and applying the law, ensuring the protection of rights, settling disputes, and reviewing the constitutionality of laws and government actions.

voting_methods.instructions: "You are required to show the witness your ballot papers before you fill them out. You will then write your secret answer on the postal vote certificate and mark or sign the certificate. The witness will then sign and date the certificate. You can then fill out your ballot papers. The witness needs to see you filling out your ballot papers but not see how you voted."
Voters can vote in person at Australian Embassies, Consultates, and High Commissions or by mail.

In order to vote, you will be asked the following questions:
Question 1: 'What is your full name?' This enables the polling official to look up your name on the certified list which is a copy of the electoral roll for that division. If your name is on the certified list, you will be asked the next question.
 
Question 2: 'Where do you live?' If the address given is the same as that shown on the certified list you will be asked the next question.
 
Question 3: 'Have you voted before in THIS election?' If you have not voted before in this election, you will be issued with ballot papers – one for the House of Representatives and one for the Senate.
 
If you have voted, you are not entitled to cast another vote and will not be issued with ballot papers.
 
To cast your vote, the polling official will initial each ballot paper on the front near the top right-hand corner. The polling official will give you your ballot papers when there is a vacant polling booth available so you may mark the ballot paper in secret.
 
You will be advised to: proceed ALONE to a vacant polling booth; read the instructions printed on the ballot papers; fill in the ballot papers; fold the ballot papers to conceal your vote; put each ballot paper separately in the appropriate ballot box; leave the polling place when finished; and be aware that assistance is available if required.

Results source: Vote Counts: Australian Electoral Commission; Seat Counts: Australian Electoral Commission
*Party vote counts reflect first preference votes. Only parties which recieved seats or over 1% of the vote are listed.

government_functions.details:
Australia is a parliamentary democracy that is a part of the British Commonwealth. As such, the chief of state is the British Monarch. The monarchy is hereditary. The monarch appoints an in-country representative called a governor on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party or majority coalition in government. 

Australian parliament is bicameral, with a 76-seat Senate and a 151-seat House of Representatives. Both houses are directly elected. The Senate is comprised of six senators for each original state (per the Constitution), with a provision that additional seats can be apportioned should new state be recognized. Senators serve six-year terms. The House of Representatives is intende to comprise twice the number of Senators. Seats in the House are apportioned by population.

The highest court in Australia is the High Court of Australia. Additionally, there are a variety of state and territory courts.

basic_data.election_commission_name: Autoritatea Electorala Permanenta / Permanent Electoral Authority

voting_methods.instructions:
Voting abroad occurs on the Friday and Saturday immeditaely before election day, from 7 AM to 9 PM local time on both days. Voters while will be abroad on election day must register to do so, which they can do via a form on the Eleciton Commission's website, as per Emergency Ordinance 1 of 16 January 2025.. To register, one must provide their name, locality, and a copy of their identity documents showing that they reside outside of Romania. They must have resided outside of Romania fo 90 days ot qualify. Military personnel, police officers, and Romanian civil staff working abroad with defense, public order, and national security can vote in any polling station in their mission country, according to Article 82.
Overseas voters can vote by mail or in person. At designated polling stations, voters present their ID to operators who input their data into the Voter Turnout Monitoring System to verify eligibility and prevent duplicate voting. Once cleared, voters are given a ballot and a stamp marked ‘VOTED’ to cast their vote in a private booth.

On election day, voters must go to their designated polling station and present a valid identification document to the officials. After having their ID verified against the electoral roll, eligible voters will be allowed to sign the roll and receive the ballot papers stamped with "VOTED." They will then proceed to a private voting booth, where they can mark their choice on the ballot by stamping next to their preferred candidate or party list. After marking their vote in secrecy, voters must fold the ballot to conceal their choice and insert it into the sealed ballot box. Voters unable to sign can have an official make a note. Those not on the rolls at that station but eligible can be added to a supplementary list before voting. Stringent procedures are followed to prevent double voting or ineligible persons from casting ballots. Once done, the voter must return the "VOTED" stamp to officials who will mark their ID before they exit.
See Article 81-85, Law No. 208/2015.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

voting_methods.instructions: Must have lived in the Federal Republic for at least 3 months, uniterrupted, since reaching the age of 14 and within the last 25 years, OR are otherwise affected by the political situation in the Federal Republic. Expats must apply for entry into the voter register by 21 days before the election (Feb. 2, 2025). Must register for each election.
Applications for postal ballots deadline 3 PM Friday Feb 21 (2 days before the elections) to the municipal authority.

Registered voters with a polling card may vote in person one time in the constituency where they are registered. Voting by proxy is not permitted. Voters may vote by paper ballot, folded and inserted into a ballot box, or by voting machine, the latter regulated by the Federal Voter Machine Ordinance.

government_functions.details: The prime minister is the head of government and the commander in chief of the armed forces. The president is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system for a 5 year-term. The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislature. The Supreme Court is the highest court in appeal. The president of the Supreme Court is nominated by the president of Croatia and elected by Croatian Sabor (parliament) for a 4-year term. Other Supreme Court justices are appointed by national judicial council with a mandatory retirement age of 70. The parliament's (Sabor) powers include enactment and amendment of the constitution and laws, adoption of the government budget, declarations of war and peace, defining national boundaries, and calling referenda and elections. The assembly has 151 members elected through a closed-list proportional representation system.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters can cast a ballot online, by mail, or in-person.

SEC. 44. Voting Procedures. - The following shall be the procedure when the voters present themselves to vote:
(a) The Poll Clerk shall: (1) Verify if the name of the voter is in the EDCVL to establish that the voter is assigned in that polling place. If the voter's name is not in the EDCVL, the voter shall be directed to the VAD to check his/her assigned precinct. (2) If the voter's name is found, check, without touching the voter, the fingernails, for any indelible ink stain. If stained, it shall be a conclusive presumption that the voter already cast his/her vote. As such, the voter shall be directed to leave the polling place after informing him/her the reason thereof. This fact, including the name and the precinct of the voter, shall be recorded by the Poll Clerk in the Minutes; (3) If the fingernail is not stained, establish the identity of the voter through the following: Voter's photograph or specimen signature in the EDCVL. In case the identity of the voter cannot be determined with certainty in the EDCVL, the EB may require the voter to present any valid identification document, except barangay certificate or community tax certificate; or In the absence of any of the above mentioned proof of identity, any member of the EB or any registered voter of the precinct/clustered precinct may identify under oath the voter, and such fact shall be reflected in the Minutes.

government_functions.details:
The Philippines is a constitutional republic with three separate brances of government, Executive, Legislative and Judicial.
 
The President of the Philippines is elected in a FPTP race and can serve one six-year term. They serve as both the head of state and the head of government.
 
The Legislature consists of a Senate and a House of Representatives. The Senate is comprised of 24 Senators, half elected every three years; Senators can serve up to two consecutive six-year terms. Members of the House of Representatives are elected every three years and can serve up to three terms. Senators are elected in a block voting process whereby voters can vote for up to 12 candidates - the 12 highest vote getters win. The House of Representatives is elected through a mixed system with 80% elected in single-member FPTP districts and 20% through party-lists.
 
The Supreme Court of the Philippines is the highest court, and is composed of 15 Justices appointed by the president on the recommendation of the Judicial and Bar Council.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters can vote by mail, online, or in person.

SEC. 44. Voting Procedures. - The following shall be the procedure when the voters present themselves to vote:
(a) The Poll Clerk shall: (1) Verify if the name of the voter is in the EDCVL to establish that the voter is assigned in that polling place. If the voter's name is not in the EDCVL, the voter shall be directed to the VAD to check his/her assigned precinct. (2) If the voter's name is found, check, without touching the voter, the fingernails, for any indelible ink stain. If stained, it shall be a conclusive presumption that the voter already cast his/her vote. As such, the voter shall be directed to leave the polling place after informing him/her the reason thereof. This fact, including the name and the precinct of the voter, shall be recorded by the Poll Clerk in the Minutes; (3) If the fingernail is not stained, establish the identity of the voter through the following: Voter's photograph or specimen signature in the EDCVL. In case the identity of the voter cannot be determined with certainty in the EDCVL, the EB may require the voter to present any valid identification document, except barangay certificate or community tax certificate; or In the absence of any of the above mentioned proof of identity, any member of the EB or any registered voter of the precinct/clustered precinct may identify under oath the voter, and such fact shall be reflected in the Minutes.

government_functions.details:
The Philippines is a constitutional republic with three separate brances of government, Executive, Legislative and Judicial.
 
The President of the Philippines is elected in a FPTP race and can serve one six-year term. They serve as both the head of state and the head of government.
 
The Legislature consists of a Senate and a House of Representatives. The Senate is comprised of 24 Senators, half elected every three years; Senators can serve up to two consecutive six-year terms. Members of the House of Representatives are elected every three years and can serve up to three terms. Senators are elected in a block voting process whereby voters can vote for up to 12 candidates - the 12 highest vote getters win. The House of Representatives is elected through a mixed system with 80% elected in single-member FPTP districts and 20% through party-lists.
 
The Supreme Court of the Philippines is the highest court, and is composed of 15 Justices appointed by the president on the recommendation of the Judicial and Bar Council.

voting_methods.instructions: Citizens living outside the country can either vote by: (1) Absentee ballot by mail - See mail in voting instructions; (2) absentee voting using special polling places - Request to vote either in SPP-Guam or SPP-Honolulu by February 2, 2025.

Absentee voting by mail. Request to vote using an absentee ballot by mail must be made from October 5, 2024 to January 23, 2025. An absentee ballot by mail includes the following: an official ballot, a ballot envelop, an affidavit prescribed by the National Election Director, and a covering reply envelop. The absentee voter shall mark the ballot in the usual manner provided by law and in such manner that no person can see or know how the ballot is marked. The absentee voter shall then deposit the ballot in the envelop and securely seal the same. The absentee voter shall then complete and execute the affidavit. The ballot envelop and the affidavit shall then be enclosed and sealed in the covering reply envelop. Absentee ballots and affidavits must be received by the national election commissioner of the state issuing the absentee ballot no later than the established closing hour of the polls on election day.

(1) Absentee voting for travellers. Any registered voter wishing to vote by absentee ballot must submit a written request using the form from February 2, 2025 to March 3, 2025. Upon meeting the conditions, the traveler voter will be provided with same voting materials that are issued to absentee voters by mail. The same procedures for marking, returning, and disposition of absentee ballots by mail applies (please see details below for voting by mail). (2) Voting at a mobile voting place. Written requests to vote on a mobile voting place using the form should be submitted from November 4, 2024 to March 3, 2025.

Voters must first report their full name to the election board at the polling place. If they have a Voter Identification Card, they must present it; otherwise, they need to provide other proof of identity. The election board checks the Signature List to verify if the voter is registered in the Congressional Election District and Municipality. Once confirmed, the voter signs next to their name on the list and receives an official ballot. If the voter’s name is missing from the list but they have a valid Voter ID showing they haven’t voted yet, or if their name is on the National Voter Registry but not on the correct Signature List, they may still vote after signing a supplemental list. Challenges to a voter’s identity or eligibility can be raised by election officials or poll watchers, and any disallowed voters and the reasons for disqualification are recorded in the polling place’s logbook.

government_functions.details: The President of Micronesia serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Congress from among four senators-at-large.   The Micronesian legislature is composed of a unicameral Congress with 14 seats. All members of Congress are directly elected. 10 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 2-year terms. An additional “at large” member is elected from each of the four Micronesian states by proportional representation vote, and these members serve 4-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Micronesian judiciary and consists of up to six judges split into two divisions. These judges are nominated by the President and confirmed by a two-thirds vote of Congress. Judges may serve for life.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1. Article 111 of the Constitution of Liechtenstein.

voting_methods.instructions: In terms of voting by mail, the municipality may deliver the voting card and the official voting material to voters abroad. This requires a written request to the municipality of residence no later than three weeks before the election or voting day. However, this only applies to Liechtenstein citizens temporarily staying abroad. To vote in elections and referendums, ordinary residence in Liechtenstein continues to be required.

The Determination for the 2025 Parliamentary Elections in Liechtenstein explains that voting by mail is permitted from any location in Germany and abroad once the official voting materials have been delivered. For postal voting, the voting envelope and voting card must be in the officially pre-printed form specially for the State Election 2025. Voters confirm with the Signature of the declaration pre-printed on the voting card that the vote is in accordance with the will of the respective corresponds. The delivery envelope can be handed over to the post office without postage within Switzerland or handed in personally to the municipality or by a representative. The delivery envelope must be received by Friday, February 7, 2025 at the latest.5:00 p.m., arrive or be handed in at the municipality.With the revision of the law in 2004, Liechtenstein introduced the general right to vote by post, which was applied for the first time in the 2005 parliamentary elections. Since then, all eligible voters have had the option of casting their ballot either in person at the ballot box or by mail.

According to the People's Right Act, after entering the polling station, the voter must submit his/her voting card to the electoral commission for registration and then place the official ballot paper in the voting envelope into the ballot box. Ballot papers not placed in an envelope shall be rejected.Voting booths must be set up in the polling station to enable voters to fill out their ballot papers unsupervised. Voters who are disabled due to physical disabilities may, with the approval of the electoral commission, take a trusted person with them into the voting booth to assist them.

government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

voting_methods.instructions: Registration: Citizens with the right to vote outside of Kosovo have to apply and register for voting in a diplomatic representation or through mail. Voting Method Options: Voters can choose among 3 options during registration (1) voting physically in the diplomatic representations, (2) by sending their ballot by mail directly to the post office mailbox of the CEC in Kosovo; (3) by sending the ballot by mail to a mailbox outside Kosovo.

Citizens living overseas must apply to vote outside Kosovo by completing the Voter Registration Form, which can be downloded from the CEC website. They submit the form along with a copy of their ID within the deadline set by mail, e-mail or fax. If the application is accepted, they will receive the confirmation from the CEC along with the ballot. They then fill in the ballot, put it in the envelop, which should have no mark, and then put that envelop in the other envelop. In the return envelop with the CEC address, enclose a valid copy of the identification document and a note containing the name, surname, parent's name and date of birth. The package could be sent to the mailbox of the CEC either in Kosovo or outside Kosovo.

Voters are first checked for ink marks on their fingers before entering the polling station; those with marks are not allowed to vote. Eligible voters proceed to the identification officer, where their name is verified on the voter list. If listed, they sign next to their name before being issued a ballot, with their thumb marked with ink. Voters who refuse to sign or have their thumb marked are disqualified from voting. After receiving the ballot, voters cast their vote in secrecy within a voting booth. Damaged ballots can be replaced by returning them to the polling station chairperson, who documents the incident. Once voting is complete, voters fold their ballot and place it in the correct ballot box under the supervision of polling station officials, who ensure proper procedures are followed.

government_functions.details: The executive branch is composed of the President who is the head of state. He is elected by the members of the Assembly for a 5-year term and can only be reelected once. The government consists of the Prime Minister, deputy prime minister(s) and ministers.They are responsible for the day-to-day executory tasks of the government. The legislative branch, the Assembly, is composed of the 120 deputies elected for a 4-year term. Of this number, 20 are guaranteed for representation of communities that are not in majority in Kosovo. In the judicial branch, the Supreme Court of Kosovo is the highest judicial authority. The President appoints the judges upon the proposal of the Kosovo Judicial Council.

government_functions.details: Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term.   Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly.   The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions: The Democracy Code of Ecuador foresees that Ecuadorians abroad have the right to elect the president and vice president of the Republic, Andean parliamentarians, counselors of the Council for Citizen Participation and Social Control, national assembly members and assembly members of the constituency of the abroad, through the mechanisms determined in the law and other applicable regulations and may be elected for any position with the requirements established by the law.The diplomatic representations and consular offices of Ecuador, under the coordination of the National Electoral Council, will be responsible for the dissemination and promotion of the electoral processes and the change of the electoral domicile in an attempt to strengthen the active participation of Ecuadorians abroad. . Likewise, they will be responsible for the legitimacy of the electoral processes regulated by this Law, and will have the obligation to report, through the governing entity in human mobility, the constitutional and legal violations that occur during them. The voting receiving boards abroad will be made up of Ecuadorian citizens registered in the Electoral Registry of the corresponding Consulate. The vote receiving boards will be temporary and will be made up of a minimum of three members and a maximum of five. If a second electoral round is required, the foreign vote receiving boards will be integrated, as far as possible, with the same members who acted in the first round. Once the election day has concluded, the Consular Office, within a maximum period of one day, will send all the documents of the electoral process to the Special Electoral Board Abroad, for the scrutiny and proclamation of results. This period may be extended, in the case of force majeure, prior approval of the National Electoral Council. Apart from the specific details associated to voting abroad, the voting process itself is the same for in-person voting.

The Electoral Calendar foresees early voting for people who are detained but have not yet been convicted. The general provisions of in-person voting would apply, though polling stations will be established in prisons and voting will occur two days before in-person voting for most citizens.

The voter will present his identity card, passport or consular identity document to the secretary and once the registration in the registry is verified, the ballots will be provided and the voter will register his vote in a reserved manner. After depositing the ballots in the ballot boxes, you will sign the register; those who are unable to do so will print their fingerprint; Once the civic duty of voting has been fulfilled, you will receive the voting certificate. To express his or her will, in the case of single-person elections, the voter will mark the box of the candidate or binomial of his or her preference. In the elections for representatives to the National Assembly and the Andean Parliament, as well as for regional councillors, municipal councilors and members of rural parish councils, the vote will be on a closed and blocked list. Voters will check the box on the list of the political organization or alliance of their preference.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

government_functions.details: Belarus is a presidential republic with a bicameral parliament. The President of Belarus, elected for a five-year term, is the head of state and Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. The president is directly elected by an absolute majority of the votes cast (if not, a second round is held) and if more than half of the registered voters have taken part in the voting (if not, a new election is held). Executive power is nominally exercised by the government, at its top sits a ceremonial prime minister, appointed directly by the President.  Legislative power is de jure vested in the bicameral parliament, the National Assembly. The 110 members of the lower House of Representatives are directly elected for five-year terms under a majoritarian system in single-member constituencies. The Council of the Republic is the upper chamber of territorial representation, its members elected at meetings of the local councils of deputies and the City of Minsk, plus eight members appointed by the President of the Republic.  The Constitutional Court is the highest court in Belarus which deals with matters involving the Constitution and legality of certain laws passed by the government. The Supreme Court is the highest court of general jurisdiction that deals with matters of civil and criminal law.

voting_methods.instructions: Citizens living abroad must apply to the Principal Electoral Officer by filling up forms in order to be added to the overseas electoral list.

The draft regulation on voting procedure for the January 14, 2025, elections introduces transitional measures, invoking Section 135 of the Electoral Act No. 16 of 2023.
 
Under these transitional regulations, the following are the procedures for casting a vote:
a. Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter is issued a ballot paper.
b. The voter must immediately proceed to a polling booth.
c. Inside the booth, the voter selects their choice by placing the ballot paper bearing the name and symbol of their chosen candidate in an envelope provided. All other ballot papers must remain in the booth.
d. The voter presents the sealed envelope to the presiding officer or polling assistant, who verifies (without handling it) that only one envelope is being submitted.
e. The voter then places the verified envelope into the ballot box.
f. After depositing the envelope, the voter leaves the polling station.

government_functions.details: The legislative branch consists of a single chamber called the Parliament, which has 52 seats. Members of the Parliament serve four-year terms. Under the legislative branch is the Malvatumauri Council of Chiefs, which shall be composed of custom chiefs elected by their peers sitting in District Councils of Chiefs. In the executive branch, the executive power is vested in the Prime Minister, who holds most executive authority and appoints the cabinet, is chosen by Parliament from among its members. The Head of State is the President. They are elected to serve a five-year term by an electoral college consisting of Parliament and the President of the Provincial Government Councils. The judiciary branch is composed of the Island Courts, Magistrates' Courts, Supreme Court and Court of Appeal. The Chief Justice is appointed by the President after consultation with the Prime Minister and the leader of the opposition; while the rest if the judiciary are appointed by the President on the advice of the Judicial Service Commission.

government_functions.details: Executive power of the federal government is vested in the president, assisted by three vice presidents. The president serves as head of state and government and is directly elected in nationwide elections to serve a five-year term, renewable once. Each vice president serves a five-year term and represents one of the three islands.   The unicameral legislature consists of the Assembly of the Union; members are elected to five-year terms. Slightly more than half the members are directly elected, with the remainder selected by the islands’ local governments.   Changes brought about by the 2001 constitution granted the three main islands partial autonomy, and each elects its own governor and legislative assembly. The government of each island is free to administer its own affairs so long as its actions do not infringe upon the rights of the other islands or otherwise threaten the state of the federal union.

government_functions.details: The President is elected for a 5-year term. The President designates a candidate for the post of Prime Minister and appoints the Government on the basis of a vote of confidence from Parliament.  The Parliament is composed of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate who are elected for 4-year terms. The current Parliament has 136 senators and 330 deputies.  The High Court of Cassation and Justice is the highest court in the judicial system.

government_functions.details: The Executive Branch is led by the Governor and the Lieutenant Governor of American Samoa, which are popularly elected. The Governor shall have the power to issue executive regulations not in conflict with laws of the United States applicable to American Samoa, laws of American Samoa, or with the Constitution. The Governor shall have general supervision and control of all executive departments, agencies and instrumentalities of the Government of American Samoa.  The Legislature consists of a Senate and a House of Representatives. The Legislature shall have the authority to pass legislation with respect to subjects of local application. However, no such legislation may be inconsistent with this Constitution or the laws of the United States applicable in American Samoa; no such legislation may conflict with treaties or international agreements of the United States.  The Judicial power shall be vested in a High Court, the District Courts and such other courts as may from time to time be created by law. The judicial branch of the Government of American Samoa shall be independent of the executive and legislative branches.

government_functions.details: The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister.   Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected.   The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

The third member of the polling station ensures, without taking the ballot paper in hand, that it bears the signature of the chairman of the main polling station and has the voter put the ballot paper in the ballot box. government_functions.details: Part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, Aruba has full autonomy on all internal affairs with the exception of defense, foreign affairs, and some judicial functions. The constitution was enacted in January 1986. Executive power rests with a governor, while a prime minister heads an eight-member Cabinet. The governor is appointed for a 6-year term by the monarch and the prime minister and deputy prime minister are elected by the legislature, or Staten, for 4-year terms. The Staten is made up of 21 members elected by direct, popular vote to serve 4-year terms. Aruba's judicial system, mainly derived from the Dutch system, operates independently of the legislature and the executive. Jurisdiction, including appeal, lies with the Common Court of Justice of Aruba and the Supreme Court of Justice in the Netherlands.

voting_methods.instructions:
A. Instructions for vote by post: 
 Once the voter has submitted the relevant form and documentation, it will receive a set of voting documents comprising:– ballot papers;– receipt for the ballot papers;– an envelope in which to put the marked ballot papers; and– a larger envelope for sending back the voting documents to the relevant returning officer. To vote:– The voter must mark a ‘1’ in the box beside the first choice candidate and, if the voter wishes, a ‘2’ in the box beside the second choice candidate, a ‘3’ in the box beside the third choice candidate, and so on. For each ballot paper the voter must make sure to start with ‘1’ then ‘2’ then ‘3’ and so on.– Put the marked ballot papers into the envelope marked “Ballot Paper Envelope” and seal it;– Put this envelope together with the completed receipt for the ballot paper into the large envelope addressed to the returning officer, seal it and post it at once;– The ballot paper must be posted and cannot be handed to the returning officer.
B. Instructions to vote as a sepcial voter:
At an election or referendum, the voter will be notified of the day and approximate time (am/pm) when a special presiding officer will call at the hospital, nursing home, mental health facility or similar institution. The special presiding officer will carry evidence of identity and an appointment warrant which they will present to the voter for inspection on arrival. The special presiding officer will be accompanied by a Garda whose role is to guard the ballot papers (in the same way as in a polling station) and to act as an independent witness to ensure that the voting procedure is carried out properly. Only the presiding officer and the Garda may be present when the vote is cast. The presiding officer will give the voter a declaration of identity which they will witness. The voter will then mark the ballot paper in secret, place it in the special envelope provided, close the envelope and give it to the presiding officer. If assistance in voting is required, it will be provided by the special presiding officer in the same way as at a polling station. officer can apply special voting procedures such as issuing a postal vote to the special voters affected.

When you arrive at the polling station, you will be asked to state your name and address and should have your identification ready for inspection. If the presiding officer is satisfied with your identity, and your name is on the Register of Electors, the presiding officer will stamp a ballot paper and give it to you. You will then go into a voting compartment. The names of the candidates in the election appear in alphabetical order on the ballot paper along with an indication of their political party, if any. A photograph of the candidate and/or a party emblem may also appear on the ballot paper. It is a secret ballot, which means that if you take selfies or post pictures online that reveal who you, or someone else, voted for, you could be prosecuted. You must indicate the order of your choice of candidates by writing “1” or “one” in the box beside the photograph of your first choice of candidate and, if you wish, “2” or “two” beside the photograph of your second choice of candidate, “3” or “three” beside the photograph of your third choice and so on. This allows for your vote to be transferred from your first choice to your second choice if your number one candidate has been eliminated or already elected. You can read more about how proportional representation works. If you want to vote for one candidate only, you should mark the number “1” or the word “one” in the box next to the candidate’s name. You should not tick or mark the box with an X. Pencils will be provided at polling stations, but you can bring your own pen or pencil if you wish. Once you have made your choice or choices, simply fold up the ballot paper and post it into the ballot box.

government_functions.details: The Executive Branch is led by the President of ireland (uachtarán na hÉireann), who shall take precedence over all other persons in the state and who shall exercise and perform the powers and functions conferred on the President by this constitution and by law. The Legislative Branch rests in the oireachtas which shall consist of the President and two houses, viz.: a house of representatives to be called dáil Éireann and a senate to be called seanad Éireann. the sole and exclusive power of making laws for the state is hereby vested in the Oireachtas: no other legislative authority has power to make laws for the state. On the other hand, Justice shall be administered in courts established by law by judges appointed in the mannerprovided by the constitution, and, save in such special and limited cases as may be prescribed by law, shall be administered in public. The Courts shall comprise the Court of First Instance, a Court of Appeal, and a Court of Final Appeal.

government_functions.details: Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term.   Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly.   The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is the Head of State and must be "the guarantor of national independence, territorial integrity, and respect for international agreements and treaties." The President is elected for seven years by direct universal suffrage (absolute majority or majority at runoff) and can be re-elected once. The Legislative is composed of the National Assembly (deputies, directly elected for 5-year terms) and the Senate (senators, indirectly elected for 5-year terms). The Judiciary is composed of the Constitutional Court, judicial courts, administrative courts, financial courts, the High Court of Justice, the Court of Justice of the Republic, and other exceptional courts.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting overseas is foreseen in the general section of early voting. Early voting outside Iceland shall take place at the office of an Icelandic embassy, the office of an Icelandic consulate or the office of an Icelandic honorary consul, as further decided by the minister with the portfolio for foreign affairs. The same minister may also decide that voting shall take place at other overseas locations. The minister with the portfolio for foreign affairs shall advertise where and when overseas voting may take place and shall also notify the National Electoral Commission thereof. However, considering the parliamentary elections is a snap election, the instructions on the website of the National Electoral Commission explain that voters must contact embassies or consuls in the country concerned to ascertain where and when to vote.

The early voting procedure follows the next steps:1. A voter wishing to cast a ballot in early voting shall identify him- or herself to the presiding officer by producing a personal identification document bearing the voter’s name, personal identification number and photograph, such as a passport, driving licence or identity card, or by other means deemed satisfactory by the presiding officer. The presiding officer shall make a mark in the electoral register indicating who is casting a vote at the presiding officer’s station.2. Following the recording thereof, the voter shall be given the voting materials. The voter shall then, without assistance and without anyone seeing, write his or her vote on the ballot paper.3. The voter shall then place the ballot in the ballot envelope and carefully glue the top flap together. Next, the voter shalladdress and sign the covering letter in the presence of the presiding officer, who shall witness the casting of the vote by signing the covering letter and, if applicable, stamp it with anofficial seal.4. Voters are entitled to be assisted when casting their ballots. Such assistance shall be provided by the presiding officer or an assistant accompanying the voter to the polling station. Assistance shall only be given if the voter him- or herself can tell the person providing the assistance how the voter wishes to cast the ballot. The voter’s assistant must abide by the instructions of the voter and shall be bound by a duty of confidentiality not to disclose what passes between the assistant and the voter in the polling booth. A candidate or a candidate’s spouse, children, siblings and parents are not permitted to assist with voting. A voter’s assistant is not permitted to become an assistant to more than three voters in the same poll.5. Finally, the ballot paper envelope together with the covering letter shall be placed inside the sending envelope, which shall then be carefully closed. The envelope shall then be addressed to the electoral commission in the municipality where the voter believes he or she is registered on the electoral register. The voter’s personal identification number shall be written on the back of the postal envelope. Instead of a personal identification number, a special label containing the voter’s personal identification number may be placed on the envelope.

The Election Board receives the voter and requests the address and identification, such as a driver license or passport, but the voter can also identify him/herself in another adequate manner acceptable to the Election Board. A digital driver´s license can be presented. The Election Board marks the voter on the Election Register and provides a ballot. The voter takes the ballot to the voting booth where one can vote without anyone seeing. In the voting booth the voter marks an X with a writing instrument into a box before the choice he/she wishes to make. Cards with braille are made available to read and mark on the ballot. When the voter has voted, the ballot is folded, the voter leaves the voting booth, and the ballot is inserted into the ballot box outside the booth.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is elected by direct, secret ballot, by those who have the right to vote in parliamentary elections. The President is the Head of State. The Executive Power is exercised by the Government.  However, the Legislative Power is vested in both the Parliament and the President. The Legislative Power is comprised through 63 representatives through six constituencies elected through proportional representation in elections celebrated every four years.  The Judicial Power lies in the Supreme Court, Court of Appeal and district courts. The Judiciary is indepndent of the Executive and the Legislative. The Supreme Court of Iceland shall be composed of seven judges, commisioned for an indefinite period of time by the President of Iceland as proposed by the Minister of Justice.

government_functions.details:
The President of the Republic of Moldova is the head of state. The executive branch of the Republic of Moldova is headed by the President, who is elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote. The government, led by the Prime Minister, is nominated by the President after consulting parliamentary factions, and it requires a vote of confidence from the Parliament.
The legislative branch consists of the Parliament, and it is composed of 101 deputies elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote for a four-year term.
The judicial branch of Moldova is composed of the Supreme Court of Justice, courts of appeal, and other courts as established by law. Judges are appointed by the President of the Republic, based on the proposal of the Superior Council of Magistracy, until they reach the age limit

institution.term_details: Presidents may serve a maximum of two terms.

voting_methods.instructions: In the elections for the President of the Republic of Croatia, voters who happen to be outside the borders of the Republic of Croatia at the time of the election are guaranteed the right to vote in diplomatic and consular missions and foreign offices of the Republic of Croatia.

Every voter who wants to vote at a polling station must first identify themselves, as a rule, by means of an identity card, passport, driver's license or any other public document with a photo, on the basis of which the identity of the voter can be established beyond doubt. If, on election day, a voter goes to vote at a polling station determined by their place of residence, and the polling committee determines that the voter is not listed in the extract from the list of voters for that polling station, the polling committee will not allow them to vote, but will refer them to the nearest administrative body of the county where can obtain a certificate for voting (the so-called blue certificate). After obtaining the voting certificate, the voter can return to their polling station, submit the voting certificate to the polling committee and exercise their right to vote. Voting is carried out in person, by ballot. The ballot is filled in by circling the serial number in front of the name of the candidate being voted for.

government_functions.details: The prime minister is the head of government and the commander in chief of the armed forces. The president is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system for a 5 year-term. The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislature. The Supreme Court is the highest court in appeal. The president of the Supreme Court is nominated by the president of Croatia and elected by Croatian Sabor (parliament) for a 4-year term. Other Supreme Court justices are appointed by national judicial council with a mandatory retirement age of 70. The parliament's (Sabor) powers include enactment and amendment of the constitution and laws, adoption of the government budget, declarations of war and peace, defining national boundaries, and calling referenda and elections. The assembly has 151 members elected through a closed-list proportional representation system.

voting_methods.instructions: To  vote abroad, a Japanese citizen must register on the overseas electoral roll either through their home municipality before departure or at a Japanese embassy or consulate. Once registered, there are three ways to vote: (1) at embassies or consulates, (2) by post, and (3) by returning temporarily to Japan. In order to vote by post, one must send the necessary document to the election administration commission where a voter is registered to request for a ballot, then sending it back by post.

The early voting system can be used by those who cannot vote on the day of the election due to work, illness, injury, pregnancy, disability; residing in an area with poor transportation, natural disasters; are seafarers. Voting hours vary by location.

At a polling station, a voter is given two ballots to fill in. On one, they choose one of the candidates standing for the single-seat constituency in which they live. On the other, they select a political party for the proportional representation section.

government_functions.details: Executive branch - headed by the Prime Minister, who is appointed by the Diet and formally designated by the Emperor. Implements laws, manages foreign policy, and oversees government administration.Legislative branch (National Diet) - composed of the House of Representatives (lower house) and House of Councillors (upper house), in charge of making laws, approving budgets, ratifying treaties, and appointing the Prime Minister.Judicial branch - composed of the Supreme Court and lower courts, in charge of interpreting laws and ensuring their constitutionality and resolving legal disputes. Judges are appointed, and Supreme Court judges face periodic "retention referenda."

voting_methods.instructions: Applications must be made to the returning officer no earlier than the 7th day and no later than the 14th day after the election order is published, using the prescribed form. If approved, the returning officer will send the postal voter a ballot paper, declaration of identity form, a ballot box envelope and a bigger envelope for the return of the said documents by post. The returning officer prepares a postal voters' list with these voters' details. Postal voters mark their choice on the ballot paper, enclose it in the provided envelopes along with the declaration, and return it by post. It is an offense for postal voters to vote in person or for unauthorized supply, sale or purchase of official poll cards.

Before voting, there is a three-step process. First, the voter shows ID to verify their identity with an officer. Second, the voter gives their official poll card to another officer who checks the name against the voter register, announces the name and number out loud, and directs the voter to the next station. Third, an officer examines the voter's left little finger, inks it with an indelible marker and issues the voter a ballot. For the actual voting, the law states the voter must go to a private compartment and secretly mark their ballot following the instructions provided. The voter folds the ballot to conceal their vote, shows the unmarked side with the official mark to the presiding officer, and then puts the folded ballot into the ballot box in front of that officer.

government_functions.details: The Government of Sri Lanka is a semi-presidential democratic republic with a unitary state structure. The executive branch is led by the President, who is the head of state, commander-in-chief, and head of government. The President appoints a cabinet of ministers from elected members of parliament and can serve up to two five-year terms. The Prime Minister, as the President's deputy, leads the ruling party in parliament and shares domestic responsibilities. The legislative branch is a unicameral 225-member parliament, with 196 members elected from multi-seat constituencies and 29 through proportional representation. All members serve five-year terms through universal suffrage. The parliament holds the power to make laws, while the President can summon, suspend, or dissolve sessions. The judicial branch consists of the Supreme Court as the highest court, a Court of Appeal, High Courts, and subordinate courts. The legal system blends British criminal law, Roman civil law, and customary laws. Judges are appointed by the President, with a judicial service commission managing lower court judges.
