government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

government_functions.details: Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term.   Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly.   The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
Each voter shall declare before the Receiving Commission his name and, if he remembers it, the series and number of his registration. If he/she has his/her credential with him/her, it shall be sufficient to show it. The Commission shall verify whether the voter corresponds to the circuit and whether he has already voted before the Commission. If the conditions imposed by article 78 have been met, his vote shall be admitted. If it is ascertained that the voter has already voted before the Commission, his vote shall be rejected and his preventive arrest shall be ordered.

The voter shall immediately take an open voting envelope from the box containing them and shall show the members of the Commission the number printed on it. The voter's order number, the number of the ballot paper, the series and number of the voter's registration, as well as the voter's first and last name, shall then be entered on the ordinal list. The voter shall then be invited to enter the secret room to place the ballot paper in the envelope. Upon entering the secret room, the voter shall close the door behind him and immediately place the ballot paper in the envelope and close it. The voter shall not remain in the secret room for more than two minutes. After this time, the presiding officer shall open the door of the secret room and, without entering it, shall order the voter to leave. Upon leaving the secret room, the voter shall go to the polling place, detach the slip from the envelope and hand it to the Chairman of the Commission. The voter then introduces the ballots on the ballot box.

government_functions.details: The new constitution submitted to referendum largely reproduces the text of the 1996 Constitution. Unlike the 2018 Constitution, the latter benefits from a better image, being the fruit of numerous consultations that led to a consensus during the Sovereign National Conference organised in 1993.  The text of this new fundamental law - the eleventh since the country's independence in 1960 - marks a return to a semi-presidential system, replacing the presidential system of 2018 by confirming the restoration of the post of Prime Minister as head of government accountable to the National Assembly, distinct from the role of Head of State of the President of the Republic. The President's term of office will be reduced from six to five years, always renewable once consecutively. The minimum age for presidential candidates is lowered from 40 to 35. The draft constitution also ratifies the existence of the Senate, which was theoretically created by the 2018 constitution but has never yet been set up, as well as the division of the country into 23 regions, or provinces.  The text is also notable for its objective of restoring a number of rights, concepts and democratic institutions that had been removed from the 1996 text by a succession of constitutional revisions under the presidency of Idriss Déby. Independence of the judiciary has been consolidated by assigning the chairmanship of the High Council of the Judiciary not to the President of the Republic but to the President of the Supreme Court, who was previously second vice-president. The High Court of Justice, placed under the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in 2018, has also regained its independence as an institution, and the sole power to try for high treason the President of the Republic, those of other institutions, as well as members of the government and their possible accomplices.The same applies to the Constitutional Council, which regains its independence from the Supreme Court and exercises sole control over the constitutionality of laws, organic laws, decrees and international treaties.Its review is carried out automatically before they are promulgated, but also a posteriori on the basis of a dispute referred to the Council by an ordinary court.The Council also judges electoral disputes and administers the oath of office to the newly elected President of the Republic.  In terms of military justice, a Court of Appeal was created, in addition to the military courts and the Supreme Court.

government_functions.details:

The Speaker is elected by the Maneaba and is not counted as a member of the Parliament.

The executive branch consists of a president (te Beretitenti), a vice president, and a cabinet. The President is both the Chief of State and Head of Government.

The judicial system consists of the Court of Appeal, the High Court and Magistrates' Courts. The president makes all judicial appointments.

voting_methods.instructions: In the elections for national representatives, Bulgarian citizens who meet the conditions to vote (18 years or older, possessing a permanent address in the Republic of Bulgaria, not deprived of legal capacity, not serving a prison sentence) may vote on October 27, 2024 in any polling station outside the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of their choice, regardless of whether the country is a member of the European Union. For these elections, polling stations are opened outside the diplomatic and consular representations of the Republic of Bulgaria in countries that are not members of the European Union.  The places and countries where polling stations are opened and voting can be done outside the country are announced on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs after their final determination by the Central Election Commission - by May 18, 2024. Voters wishing to cast their votes outside of Bulgaria may pre-register for their preferred polling location via a form on the CEC website or vote at any polling station abroad without prior registration upon showing their Bulgarian ID documents and declaring that they have not voted and will not vote elsewhere.

Voters vote in person at their designated polling station. However, polling commission members and security officers are allowed to vote at the polling station of their duty; students are entitled to vote in the  municipality where they study; and persons with disabilitiles may vote in any suitable polling station of their choice without submitting a prior request. Up until 14 days before election day, candidates, higher level election officials, and accredited observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency. Up until 14 days before election day, any voter can request inclusion in the voter lists at the place of their current (temporary) registered residence. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. In polling stations with at least 300 registered voters, the voters have the option to use either paper ballot voting or direct recording electronic voting machines.  If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting screen and in private marks the square of the candidate list of his/her choice and if so wishes, also marks the circle of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, leaves the screen and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list and if he/she chooses, also for a candidate on the list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and the voted ballot is printed and the voter proceeds to cast the printed ballot in the same way as the paper ballots are cast. The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

Voters who will be 70 years old on the day of the election, disabled voters, persons who care for or look after (provide assistance to) the disabled at home, or who are temporarily unable to work due to illness, who have filled out form P6 approved by the Central Election Commission and are included in the list of voters voting at home, will be able to vote at home. Voters who are temporarily staying in the territory of a specific electoral district and are not included in the list of voters of this electoral district will vote at home during specified times. Voters can submit requests to vote at home to precinct election commissions by phone, e-mail, or on the Voter Page portal.
Voters who come to vote at the polling station will have to present a document confirming their personal identity to the election organizers.

government_functions.details: Lithuania is a parliamentary democracy and a decentralised unitary state. The Lithuanian Parliament is called the Seimas. The 141 members of the Seimas are elected by a mixed system: 71 members are elected in single-member constituencies using a two-round system, and the other 70 members are elected in multi-member constituencies using a proportional representation system. All members serve 4-year terms, and there are no term limits. The Prime Minister serves as the head of government and is nominated by the President and confirmed by the Seimas.  The President serves as the head of state and is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.

government_functions.details: The Executive Power shall be exercised by a Governor, who shall be elected by direct vote in each general election. The Governor shall hold office for a term of four years from the second day of January of the year following the year of his election until his successor is elected and takes office.  The Legislative Power shall be exercised by a Legislature, consisting of two Houses, the Senate and the House of Representatives, whose members shall be elected by direct ballot at each general election. The Senate shall be composed of twenty-seven Senators and the House of Representatives of fifty-one Representatives. For the purpose of electing members to the Legislative Assembly, Puerto Rico shall be divided into eight senatorial districts and forty representative districts. Each senatorial district shall elect two Senators and each representative district shall elect one Representative. Additionally, eleven Senators and eleven Representatives are elected through an aggregate formula.  The Judicial power of Puerto Rico will be exercised by a Supreme Court, and by those other courts established by law. The Supreme Court will be the court of last resort in Puerto Rico and will be composed of a presiding judge and four associate judges. The judges will be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

government_functions.details: Iran has a unique system of government known as an Islamic Republic, a combination of democratic and theocratic elements, as outlined in its Constitution established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. The political structure is characterized by a dual sovereignty: the Supreme Leader, who holds the highest state authority, and the elected President, along with the Parliament. It blends aspects of a parliamentary democracy with Islamic theocracy, guided by the principles of Shia Islam.  The executive branch is headed by the President, who is elected for a four-year term and can serve a maximum of two consecutive terms. The President is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the country, including the implementation of laws, overseeing the economy, and conducting foreign policy. However, the President's powers are subject to the oversight and approval of the Supreme Leader, who is the highest-ranking religious and political authority in Iran. The Supreme Leader, appointed for life by the Assembly of Experts, holds significant influence over all branches of government, including the military and judiciary, and has the final say in matters of state and religion.  The legislative branch consists of the Islamic Consultative Assembly, or Majlis, a unicameral body whose members are elected by the public. The Majlis drafts legislation, ratifies international treaties, and approves the national budget. However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

government_functions.details: Kazakhstan is a unitary state with a presidential form of government. The President is the head of the state and is directly elected by simple majority popular vote for a 7 year term. The Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Ministers are approved by the lower house of parliament following nomination by the President.   Kazakh parliament is a bicameral system that consists of the 50-sear Senate and the 98-seat Mazhilis. 40 Senate members are indirectly elected by oblast-level assemblies and 10 members are appointed by decree of the President. Members of the Mazhilis are directly elected.   The highest levels of the judiciary are comprised of the Supreme Council of the Republic (44 members) and the Constitutional Council (7 members, including a chairperson).

government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

government_functions.details: France has a semi-presidential system of government. The President serves as the head of state and is elected by an absolute majority. He/she serves for 5 years and cannot hold office for more than 2 consecutive terms. He appoints the Prime Minister, can dissolve the National Assembly, leads foreign policy, serves as commander-in-chief of the armed forces, and can call for referendums on certain issues. The Prime Minister serves as the head of government and is responsible for domestic policy and day-to-day administration. The Parliament is composed of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly has 557 members who are directly voted and serve for 5 years. The Senate ensures the representation of the territorial communities. There are 348 Senators. They are elected every 6 years. The High Council of the Judiciary consists of a section with jurisdiction over judges and a section with jurisdiction over public prosecutors. The former is presided over by the Chief President of the Cour de Cassation and the latter by the Chief Public Prosecutor at the Cour de Cassation.

voting_methods.instructions:
To vote from abroad, voters must register on the consular electoral list to vote for deputies in constituencies of French nationals abroad. They may cast their votes in person at an embassy or consulate, or select a proxy to vote in their place.
Online voting is also available for voters abroad. The voter needs to give their email address and phone number when registering. A voter can vote online via the internet if the following conditions are complied with: (1) they live abroad, (2) they are registered in a consular voter list, (3) they have provided an email address and a phone number. Updating of contact details can be done directly until June 16, 2024 midnight (Paris time).

The staff checks if the voter is registered at the polling station. The voter's identity is verified. The voter then goes to the voting booth and votes by selecting the number that corresponds to his/her choice (list, candidate, blank vote). He/she then signs the attendance list. Finally, the election date is affixed to the voter card which is returned to the voter.

However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Election of a representative in the 1st stage depends on receiving a majority of at least 1/4 of the total vote. In the 2nd stage and in mid-term elections, it is by obtaining a relative majority by any measure. If no candidate secures at least 1/4 of the total votes in the 1st round, the top candidates, amounting to double the number of required representatives, advance to the 2nd round. These candidates are chosen based on having the highest vote counts in the 1st round.

government_functions.details: Iran has a unique system of government known as an Islamic Republic, a combination of democratic and theocratic elements, as outlined in its Constitution established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. The political structure is characterized by a dual sovereignty: the Supreme Leader, who holds the highest state authority, and the elected President, along with the Parliament. It blends aspects of a parliamentary democracy with Islamic theocracy, guided by the principles of Shia Islam.  The executive branch is headed by the President, who is elected for a four-year term and can serve a maximum of two consecutive terms. The President is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the country, including the implementation of laws, overseeing the economy, and conducting foreign policy. However, the President's powers are subject to the oversight and approval of the Supreme Leader, who is the highest-ranking religious and political authority in Iran. The Supreme Leader, appointed for life by the Assembly of Experts, holds significant influence over all branches of government, including the military and judiciary, and has the final say in matters of state and religion.  The legislative branch consists of the Islamic Consultative Assembly, or Majlis, a unicameral body whose members are elected by the public. The Majlis drafts legislation, ratifies international treaties, and approves the national budget. However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

government_functions.details: North Macedonia is a parliamentary republic in which legislative power rests in a unicameral parliament elected to a four-year term. Executive authority is vested in a government composed of a prime minister and ministers. The president, who has limited executive authority, is directly elected through a majoritarian system and may serve no more than two five-year terms. The 120 members of parliament (MPs) representing 6 in-country territorial constituencies are elected under a proportional representation system, using closed lists, and 3 additional MPs may be elected in elections for a single, out-of-country district.

Independent candidates must pass constituency electoral quota to receive a seat.

voting_methods.instructions: In the elections for national representatives, Bulgarian citizens who meet the conditions to vote (18 years or older, possessing a permanent address in the Republic of Bulgaria, not deprived of legal capacity, not serving a prison sentence) may vote on June 9, 2024 in any polling station outside the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of their choice, regardless of whether the country is a member of the European Union. For these elections, polling stations are opened outside the diplomatic and consular representations of the Republic of Bulgaria in countries that are not members of the European Union.  The places and countries where polling stations are opened and voting can be done outside the country are announced on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs after their final determination by the Central Election Commission - by May 18, 2024. Voters wishing to cast their votes outside of Bulgaria may pre-register for their preferred polling location via a form on the CEC website or vote at any polling station abroad without prior registration upon showing their Bulgarian ID documents and declaring that they have not voted and will not vote elsewhere.

Voters vote in person at their designated polling station. However, polling commission members and security officers are allowed to vote at the polling station of their duty; students are entitled to vote in the  municipality where they study; and persons with disabilitiles may vote in any suitable polling station of their choice without submitting a prior request. Up until 14 days before election day, candidates, higher level election officials, and accredited observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency. Up until 14 days before election day, any voter can request inclusion in the voter lists at the place of their current (temporary) registered residence. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. In polling stations with at least 300 registered voters, the voters have the option to use either paper ballot voting or direct recording electronic voting machines.  If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting screen and in private marks the square of the candidate list of his/her choice and if so wishes, also marks the circle of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, leaves the screen and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list and if he/she chooses, also for a candidate on the list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and the voted ballot is printed and the voter proceeds to cast the printed ballot in the same way as the paper ballots are cast. The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

government_functions.details:
Executive power is exercised by the government led by the Prime Minister. The President is the head of state and the formal head of the executive, though with very limited powers. The president is elected by direct popular vote, under a two-round system, for a five-year term.

The members of the 150-seat parliament (National Council) are elected for a four-year term under a proportional representation system, within a single nationwide constituency, with a 5% threshold for parties, 7% for coalitions of two or three parties, and 10% for coalitions of more than four parties. Following National Council elections, the leader of the majority party or coalition is usually appointed prime minister by the president.

The Supreme Court is the country's highest appellate court, the judges of which are elected by the National Council; below that are regional, district, and military courts. The Constitutional Court rules on constitutional issues; its 13 members are appointed by the president from a slate of candidates nominated by the parliament. The 18-member Judicial Council nominates common court judges and is responsible for appointing a disciplinary committee in cases of judicial misconduct.

government_functions.details: The legislative branch consists of a single chamber called the Parliament, which has 52 seats. Members of the Parliament serve four-year terms. Under the legislative branch is the Malvatumauri Council of Chiefs, which shall be composed of custom chiefs elected by their peers sitting in District Councils of Chiefs. In the executive branch, the executive power is vested in the Prime Minister, who holds most executive authority and appoints the cabinet, is chosen by Parliament from among its members. The Head of State is the President. They are elected to serve a five-year term by an electoral college consisting of Parliament and the President of the Provincial Government Councils. The judiciary branch is composed of the Island Courts, Magistrates' Courts, Supreme Court and Court of Appeal. The Chief Justice is appointed by the President after consultation with the Prime Minister and the leader of the opposition; while the rest if the judiciary are appointed by the President on the advice of the Judicial Service Commission.

voting_methods.instructions: Electors cast their vote at a specified polling station in the locality of their domicile where they are registered for national elections. Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter should submit a certificate of his/her registration and present his/her nationality certificate which is then stamped with a special seal. The voter must also present a civil identification card that shows the person's address. If the certificate of registration was lost, provided the voter's name is on the voter list, he/she can vote. The head of the polling committee hands each voter a ballot paper and the voters goes to one of the areas designated for voting in secret inside the polling hall. After the voter marks the ballot, he/she returns it to the chairperson who puts it in the ballot box. The polling clerk then enters a mark in the voter list in front of the name of the voter who cast his/her ballot to indicate the voter has voted.  A voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot can state his/her choice orally so that only the members of the polling committee can hear it (or just the chairperson) and the chairperson marks the voter's choice on the ballot paper and puts it in the ballot box.

government_functions.details: Kuwait is a hereditary emirate. The chief of state is the Amir, who is chosen from within the ruling family and confirmed by the National Assembly. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Amir, as is the Crown Prince, who also must be approved by the National Assembly. The Crown Prince is also designated as the Heir Apparent and the National Assembly must swear fealty to the Crown Prince.   Kuwait has a unicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Umma), which has 50 members and 15 ex-officio seats reserved for cabinet ministers. Per the Constitution, there may be more ministers (and thus ex-officio members) so long as the number of ministers does not exceed one-third of the total assembly.   The highest courts in Kuwait are the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. All judges are appointed by the Amir on the recommendation of the Supreme Judicial Council.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

government_functions.details: In Finland, the President serves as chief of state, and the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 6-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by Parliament and formally appointed by the President.  Finland has a unicameral Parliament (Eduskunta) with 200 seats. 199 members are directly elected in single and multi-seat constituencies via proportional representation vote. The remaining member, who represents the autonomous region of Åland, is directly elected by plurality vote. All members serve 4-year terms.   The Finnish judiciary has two high courts: the Supreme Court (civil and criminal cases) and Supreme Administrative Court (government cases). The Supreme Court consists of 19 judges, while the Supreme Administrative Court has 21 judges. All high court judges are appointed by the President and may serve until age 68.

voting_methods.instructions: Applications must be made to the returning officer within 10 days of the election order being published, using the prescribed form. If approved, the returning officer will send the postal voter a ballot paper, declaration of identity form, and envelopes to return their marked ballot paper by post. The returning officer prepares a postal voters' list with these voters' details. Postal voters mark their choice on the ballot paper, enclose it in the provided envelopes along with the declaration, and return it by post. It is an offense for postal voters to vote in person or for unauthorized supply, sale or purchase of official poll cards.

Before voting, there is a three-step process. First, the voter shows ID to verify their identity with an officer. Second, the voter gives their official poll card to another officer who checks the name against the voter register, announces the name and number out loud, and directs the voter to the next station. Third, an officer examines the voter's left little finger, inks it with an indelible marker, and issues the voter a ballot. For the actual voting, the law states the voter must go to a private compartment and secretly mark their ballot following the instructions provided. The voter folds the ballot to conceal their vote, shows the unmarked side with the official mark to the presiding officer, and then puts the folded ballot into the ballot box in front of that officer.

government_functions.details: The Government of Sri Lanka is a semi-presidential democratic republic with a unitary state structure. The executive branch is led by the President, who is the head of state, commander-in-chief, and head of government. The President appoints a cabinet of ministers from elected members of parliament and can serve up to two five-year terms. The Prime Minister, as the President's deputy, leads the ruling party in parliament and shares domestic responsibilities. The legislative branch is a unicameral 225-member parliament, with 196 members elected from multi-seat constituencies and 29 through proportional representation. All members serve five-year terms through universal suffrage. The parliament holds the power to make laws, while the President can summon, suspend, or dissolve sessions. The judicial branch consists of the Supreme Court as the highest court, a Court of Appeal, High Courts, and subordinate courts. The legal system blends British criminal law, Roman civil law, and customary laws. Judges are appointed by the President, with a judicial service commission managing lower court judges.

government_functions.details: Mauritius is a parliamentary representative democratic system. The Executive branch is headed by the President and the Prime Minister. The President is the ceremonial head of state and is elected by the National Assembly for a five-year term. S/he appoints the Prime Minister and other key officials. The real executive power rests with the Prime Minister, who is the leader of the majority party or coalition in the National Assembly. The Prime Minister and the Cabinet, which he or she leads, are responsible for the day-to-day administration of government and the implementation of legislation. The Legislature is unicameral, consisting of the National Assembly with 70 members, 62 of whom are elected from 21 constituencies. The remaining eight are appointed from among the best losing candidates to ensure representation of ethnic minorities, a process known as the "Best Loser System." The judicial system is headed by the Supreme Court, which has unlimited jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters and also acts as an appellate court from decisions of lower courts and tribunals.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Article 12 of the Electoral Act of Montserrat

voting_methods.instructions:
Every voter, upon entering the polling station, shall declare his name, residence and occupation. The poll clerk shall then ascertain if the name of the voter appears on the official list of voters used at the polling station. When it has been ascertained that the applicant voter is qualified to vote at the polling station, his name, address and occupation shall be entered in the poll book to be kept by the poll clerk, a number corresponding to the consecutive number allotted to the voter on the official list of voters being prefixed to the voter’s name in the appropriate column of the poll book, and the voter shall be immediately allowed to vote, unless an election officer or any agent of a candidate present at the polling station desires that he be first sworn.

Each voter shall receive from the presiding officer a ballot paper on which such officer has previously put his initials, that when the ballot paper is folded the said initials can be seen without opening it, and on the counterfoil of which he has placed a number corresponding to the consecutive number on the official list of voters and entered in the poll book opposite the name of such voter. The presiding officer shall instruct the voter how to make his mark, and shall properly fold the voter’s ballot paper, directing him to return it, when marked, folded as shown, but without inquiring or seeing for whom the voter intends to vote, except when the voter is unable to vote in the manner prescribed by this Act on account of illiteracy, blindness or other physical incapacity.

The voter on receiving the ballot paper shall forthwith enter one of the polling compartments in the polling station and there mark his ballot paper by marking with a black lead pencil and not otherwise a cross within the space opposite the name of the candidate for whom he intends to vote, and he shall then fold the ballot paper as directed so that the initials and the numbers on the counterfoil can be seen without opening it, and hand the paper to the presiding officer who shall, without unfolding it, ascertain by examination of the initials and numbers appearing thereon that it is the same paper as that delivered to the voter and, if the same, he shall in full view of the voter and of all others present remove the counterfoil and deposit the ballot in the ballot box.

government_functions.details: The Tunisian government has three branches the executive, legislature, and the judiciary.  The president, prime minister, and the cabinet make up the Tunisian executive. The president appoints both the prime minister and cabinet members. The president is the head of state while the prime minister is the head of government. The president is elected through a two-round system and must attain more than 50% of the total votes cast to win in the first round. The elected president serves for up to two five-year terms. voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Article 67 of the Constitution of Botswana

voting_methods.instructions: The Electoral Act of Botswana foresees that, for purposes of registration and elections to be conducted outside Botswana, the Commission shall establish polling stations outside Botswana at all Botswana Embassies and Consular Missions; and at such other places as the Commission may consider necessary. There is no excuse required, according to the law. The law explains that whenever a registration period is appointed the Secretary of the Independent Electoral Commission shall cause a notice to be published in a foreign newspaper in a foreign country circulating in the area of the country where citizens of Botswana are resident calling upon every citizen entitled to be registered as a voter in terms of this Act to apply for registration during the registration period on such date, time and place as may be specified in the notice. The registration officer shall, on completion of a registration of any person, forward the completed voter's registration record card to the Secretary who shall incorporate the registration in the roll of the voters in the constituency of that person.

Where election officers, police officers and other personnel entitled to vote are unable or likely to be unable to vote on the date of the poll by reason of not having been assigned to the polling stations in respect of which they are registered, the Secretary shall, for the purpose of enabling such officers to vote fix such times, places and days, not earlier than 15 days before the date for the taking of any poll. During the advance voting, Election officers and police officers are issued with a ballot paper for the National Assembly and an envelope, followed by the Local Government to mark, fold, put it in the envelope and seal it and deposit into a ballot box. All the votes from advance and diaspora polls are kept sealed until general poll. During counting they are mixed with the general poll votes and counted.

The Electoral Act explains that the steps required to vote in person are:

1. Every voter desiring to record his vote shall present himself at the polling station in respect of which he is registered to vote, and shall produce his voter's registration card and his identity card to the presiding officer. The presiding officer, after satisfying himself that the name of such voter appears on his copy of the election roll for that constituency and in the section thereof relating to that polling station; that such voter has not already voted at that election; and that such voter has not become disqualified from voting, shall deliver, to the voter, a ballot paper.

2. Immediately before the presiding officer delivers a ballot paper to any person, the number and name of the voter, as stated in the election roll, shall be called out; a mark shall be made on the copy of the election roll against the number of such voter to show that he has been issued with a ballot paper; the voter's registration card shall be marked by the presiding officer with the date and his initials.

3. A voter on receiving a ballot paper shall go immediately into a polling booth and there secretly mark his paper and fold it up so as to conceal his vote.

4. He shall then show the presiding officer the back of the paper, so as to disclose the official mark, and put the ballot paper so folded up into the ballot box in the presence of the presiding office.

government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

election_issues.issues: Economy; foreign policy; democracy

institution.term_details: From Article 92 of the Constitution: "No one may serve more than two consecutive or discontinuous terms. In the event a presidential term is interrupted because of resignation or any other reason, the term is considered complete."

voting_methods.instructions:
Per Article 9 of the Electoral Code of 2012: "..., Algerian citizens living abroad and registered with Algerian diplomatic and consular representations may request their registration:

1- On the electoral list of one of the following communes, with regard to the elections of the communal and wilaya popular assemblies:

- commune of birth of the person concerned,

- commune of the last domicile of the person concerned,

- commune of birth of one of the ascendants of the person concerned.

2 - On the electoral list of the Algerian diplomatic and consular representations located in the country of residence of the elector, with regard to presidential elections, referendum consultations and legislative elections."
Algeria does not have mail-in voting and instead uses proxy voting methods. More information can be found here: Article 53 of the Electoral Code 2012.

From Article 30 of the 2012 Election Code: "... the Minister of the Interior may, by decree, authorize Walis, at their request, to advance by a maximum of 72 hours the opening date of the vote in municipalities where the voting process cannot take place on a single day of the vote for technical reasons related to the remoteness of the polling station, the dispersal of populations and for any exceptional reason in a given municipality..."

Upon entering the room and after proving their identity by producing a legal document to the members of the polling station, the voter takes an envelope and a ballot paper and, without leaving the room, goes to the polling booth and puts their ballot into the envelope. They then show to the president of the polling station that he is carrying only one envelope. After that, the latter allows the voter to insert the envelope into the ballot box. The vote of all voters is recorded by affixing, on the signing sheet, the print of the left index finger, in indelible ink, next to their surname and first name, and this, in front of the members of the polling station. The voter card is stamped using a wet stamp specifying the date of the vote. In the absence of a voter card, any voter can exercise their right to vote if they are registered on the electoral list. They must be in possession of a national identity card or any other official document proving their identity.

government_functions.details: The President is the head of the state. He is elected by an absolute majority vote and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The legislative power is exercised by a Parliament, consisting of two Chambers, the People’s National Assembly and the Council of the Nation. The members of the People’s National Assembly are elected by universal, direct, and secret suffrage. Two-thirds (2/3) of the Members of the Council of the Nation are elected by indirect and secret suffrage, with two seats per Wilaya, among members of the People’s Communal Assemblies and members of the People’s Wilaya Assemblies. One-third (1/3) of the members of the Council of the Nation are appointed by the President among national personalities and qualified experts from scientific, professional, economic, and social fields. The People’s National Assembly is elected for a period of 5 years. The mandate of the Council of the Nation is limited to 6 years. Half the members of the Council of the Nation are renewed every 3 years. No one can serve more than 2 terms in Parliament. The Algerian judicial system is composed of the following: (1) the Supreme Court, (2) the State Council - a regulating organ of the jurisdiction activity under the judicial power, (3) the Superior Council of Magistrature - headed by the President, it sees to it that the public office statutes are respected and controls discipline among magistrates.

government_functions.details:
The President of the Republic of Moldova is the head of state. The executive branch of the Republic of Moldova is headed by the President, who is elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote. The government, led by the Prime Minister, is nominated by the President after consulting parliamentary factions, and it requires a vote of confidence from the Parliament.
The legislative branch consists of the Parliament, and it is composed of 101 deputies elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote for a four-year term.
The judicial branch of Moldova is composed of the Supreme Court of Justice, courts of appeal, and other courts as established by law. Judges are appointed by the President of the Republic, based on the proposal of the Superior Council of Magistracy, until they reach the age limit

voting_methods.instructions:
Moldovan citizens abroad must register on the electoral lists to ensure their right to vote. This can be done at the diplomatic missions and consular offices of the Republic of Moldova. In some cases, voting at polling stations abroad may be conducted over two days (Saturday and Sunday) to facilitate the participation of a large number of voters. This decision is made by the Central Electoral Commission at least 25 days before election day. Polling stations abroad are organized by the diplomatic missions and consular offices of the Republic of Moldova.

Moldovan citizens must present one of the following valid documents to vote: passport, national ID card, or seaman's book. The voter presents themselves at the polling station and provides their identification document. The electoral official verifies the voter in the electoral lists and confirms their right to vote. The voter receives a ballot, goes to the voting booth to vote in secret, and places the ballot in the ballot box.

Each voter must vote personally. Voting on behalf of someone else is not allowed. Voters must present an ID (national ID, provisional national ID, or passport, including expired passports) to the polling station's electoral bureau for registration and verification. Voters must then sign the electoral list and receive the ballot paper. Voters mark the circle of the chose candidate on the ballot in a secret booth. Photographing or removing the ballot from the polling place is prohibited. Voters may request a replacement ballot if they make a mistake.

voting_methods.instructions:
According to the Electoral Act, in order to enable persons temporarily outside Namibia to be registered as voters and to take part in an election of the President or of members of the National Assembly, the Commission may establish temporary registration points outside Namibia at any Namibian diplomatic mission, or where possible, at the other convenient places as may be determined by the Commission in consultation with the Minister responsible for foreign affairs.
 
The Electoral Act explains that the voting process outside Namibia must be held 14 days before election day. In the instance of persons who are on board any vessel within the waters of the territorial sea of Namibia, the contiguous zone of Namibia and the exclusive economic zone of Namibia, must be held at a harbour town within Namibia during a period determined by the Commission by notice in the Gazette, which period may not be longer than 30 days and not shorter than 14 days, and in the instance of persons who are members of the police force, defence force and correctional services and who are required to be on duty within or outside Namibia, must be held during a period determined by the Commission with concurrence of the Security Commission. The voting process is the same as the one foreseen for in-person voting.

The Electoral Act explains that the steps required to vote in person are:
 
1. A voter may only vote in an election if the voter produces his or her voter registration card for the election concerned to the presiding officer or a polling officer.
 
2. The presiding officer or a polling officer must ascertain by examining and by asking relevant questions relating to the particulars appearing on the voter registration card that the voter is the person whose name, photograph and other particulars appears on the voter registration card; and the voter registration card is a voter registration card officially issued according to the Electoral Act. The presiding officer must also ascertain that the voter has not already voted in the election concerned.
 
3. The presiding officer or a polling officer must require the voter, and the voter when so required, is obliged to cause his or her fingers to be examined by the presiding officer or the polling officer.
 
4. If upon an examination referred to in the last Section no finger or fingers of the voter display the identification mark so approved and determined as contemplated in subsections (12) and (13) of the Electoral Act, the voter is presumed not to have already voted in the election concerned. On the other hand, if upon an examination referred to in the last Section, a finger or fingers of the voter display the identification mark, the presiding officer must give to every election agent who is present an opportunity to observe the identification mark; and may not permit the voter to vote. If any person has been prohibited from voting, the presiding officer must endorse the relevant voters’ register to the effect that the person was so prohibited.
 
5. After verifying its identification status, the presiding officer or polling officer must return the voter registration card to the voter concerned. Afterward, the voter must in the presence and in accordance with the instructions of the presiding officer or a polling officer place the identification mark on the finger or fingers of his or her left hand or of his or her right hand, as may be determine, by the Chief Electoral Officer for the purposes of the election concerned; or cause it to be placed thereon by the presiding officer or the polling officer.
 
6. If a voter refuses that the prescribed identification mark be applied to his or her finger or fingers, the voter may not be issued with a ballot paper, the voter is not permitted to vote, either by way of a ballot paper or by way of a voting machine. The presiding officer or polling officer must record in the Occurrence Book at the polling station the fact that the voter refuses that the prescribed identification mark be applied to his or her finger, request the police officer in charge of the polling station or any other police officer on duty at the polling station to remove the voter concerned from the polling station.
 
7. If the voter complied with the provisions concerning identification, the presiding officer or polling officer must in the case of voting by way of a ballot paper, enter the voter registration number of the voter in the ballot paper book on the counterfoil of a ballot paper which bears on the back thereof the official mark, and detach the ballot paper from its counterfoil and deliver it to the voter; or in the case of voting by way of a voting machine, enter the voter registration number of the voter in a voting machine book, as determined by the Commission.
8. Upon receiving the ballot paper, or if the voter is voting by way of a voting machine, the voter must enter a polling booth provided at the polling station, and secretly record in the case of voting by way of a ballot paper, his or her vote on the ballot paper by marking in the case of an election on party lists, the ballot paper with a mark in or next to the space opposite the name of the political party or organisation for which he or she desires to vote; or in the case of an election otherwise than on party lists, the ballot paper with a mark in or next to the space opposite the name of the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote. In the case of voting by way of a voting machine, his or her vote on the voting machine by selecting in the case of an election on party lists, in or next to the space opposite the name of the political party or organisation for which he or she desires to vote; or in the case of an election otherwise than on party lists, in or next to the space opposite the name of the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote.
 
9. While still in the polling booth, fold the ballot paper in a way that the official mark is visible; and the names of the political parties or candidates and the mark signifying his or her vote are not visible, leave the polling booth and display the ballot paper to the presiding officer or polling officer in a way that the official mark can be seen; and in the presence of the presiding officer or polling officer, drop, the ballot paper in the ballot box for ordinary ballot papers.

government_functions.details:
According to the Constitution of Namibia, the President shall be the Head of State and of the Government and the Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Force. The executive power of the Republic of Namibia shall vest in the President and the Cabinet. The President’s term of office shall be five (5) years unless he or she dies or resigns before the expiry of the said term or is removed from office. A person shall hold office as President for not more than two terms. As the Head of State, the President shall uphold, protect and defend the Constitution as the Supreme Law, and shall perform with dignity and leadership all acts necessary, expedient, reasonable and incidental to the discharge of the executive functions of the Government, subject to the overriding terms of the Constitution and the laws of Namibia, which he or she is constitutionally obliged to protect to administer and to execute.
 
The legislative power of Namibia shall be vested in the National Assembly with the power to pass laws with the assent of the President as provided in this Constitution subject, where applicable, to the powers and functions of the National Council as set out in this Constitution. The members of the National Assembly shall be representative of all the people and shall in the
performance of their duties be guided by the objectives of this Constitution, by the public interest and by their conscience. Every National Assembly shall continue for a maximum period of five (5) years, but it may before the expiry of its term be dissolved by the President by Proclamation.
 
The judicial power shall be vested in the Courts of Namibia, which shall consist of a Supreme Court of Namibia; a High Court of Namibia; Lower Courts of Namibia. The Courts shall be independent and subject only to this Constitution and the law. No member of the Cabinet or the Legislature or any other person shall interfere with Judges or judicial officers in the exercise of their judicial functions, and all organs of the State shall accord such assistance as the Courts may require to protect their independence, dignity and effectiveness, subject to the terms of this Constitution or any other law.

institution.term_details: Article 29, Section 3, of the Namibian Constitution foresees that a person shall hold office as President for not more than two terms.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Parties must receive at least 5% of valid votes cast or 20% of valid votes cast in 4 constituencies to receive a seat. Independent candidates must meet an electoral quotient to receive a seat.
basic_data.election_commission_name: Autoritatea Electorala Permanenta / Permanent Electoral Authority

voting_methods.instructions: Voters domiciled or residing abroad can exercise their right to vote at any polling station set up abroad (Article 84.3). To vote, they must present one of the approved identification documents valid on election day, such as a regular passport mentioning their country of domicile (Article 83.3). Only voters residing outside of Romania may vote in-person from overseas. They will sign an electronic device at the polling station instead of a paper electoral roll (Article 84.4g).

On election day, voters must go to their designated polling station and present a valid identification document to the officials. After having their ID verified against the electoral roll, eligible voters will be allowed to sign the roll and receive the ballot papers stamped with "VOTED." They will then proceed to a private voting booth, where they can mark their choice on the ballot by stamping next to their preferred candidate or party list. After marking their vote in secrecy, voters must fold the ballot to conceal their choice and insert it into the sealed ballot box. Voters unable to sign can have an official make a note. Those not on the rolls at that station but eligible can be added to a supplementary list before voting. Stringent procedures are followed to prevent double voting or ineligible persons from casting ballots. Once done, the voter must return the "VOTED" stamp to officials who will mark their ID before they exit.

government_functions.details: The President is elected for a 5-year term. The President designates a candidate for the post of Prime Minister and appoints the Government on the basis of a vote of confidence from Parliament.  The Parliament is composed of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate who are elected for 4-year terms. The current Parliament has 136 senators and 330 deputies.  The High Court of Cassation and Justice is the highest court in the judicial system.

institution.term_details: 2 terms

voting_methods.instructions: Romanian citizens living abroad can participate in early voting on the Friday and Saturday before the official Sunday election day. Voting hours are from 12:00 to 21:00 local time on Friday and from 7:00 to 21:00 local time on Saturday. At designated polling stations, voters present their ID to operators who input their data into the Voter Turnout Monitoring System to verify eligibility and prevent duplicate voting. Once cleared, voters are given a ballot and a stamp marked ‘VOTAT’ to cast their vote in a private booth. The process ensures the integrity of the vote with the system checking each voter's eligibility, including whether they have previously voted or voted by correspondence. After voting, ballot boxes are sealed and the premises secured until the next voting period, ensuring the security and confidentiality of the early voting process.

On voting day, a voter must go to their designated polling station during the scheduled voting hours. Upon arrival, they will need to present an approved identity document to the electoral officials. After their identity is verified against the electoral roll, they will be allowed to sign the roll and receive a ballot paper stamped with "VOTED." The voter then proceeds to a private voting booth, where they can mark their choice on the ballot in secret by stamping next to their preferred candidate. Once done, the voter folds the ballot and inserts it into the sealed ballot box before leaving. Specific accommodations like voting at different polling stations or with an assistant are allowed for voters with reduced mobility or others requiring assistance. Stringent checks are in place to prevent repeat voting or ineligible persons from casting ballots.

electoral_rights.source: Articles 85 (10), Law No. 208/2015; Article 36 (2) Constitution

institution.term_details: The president is limited to two consecutive terms, however there is no limit on the total number of terms that can be served.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters must be registered with a Chadian consulate or embassy and provide an accepted form of national ID.

Members of the military vote one day early.  Members of nomadic communities vote at whichever polling station they are nearest to, and they may vote on either election day or the day preceding election day.

Voter identification requirements are the same as those of in-person voting on election day.
Voters must present voter card, student ID, birth certificate or in situ identification by witnesses

government_functions.details: The new constitution submitted to referendum largely reproduces the text of the 1996 Constitution. Unlike the 2018 Constitution, the latter benefits from a better image, being the fruit of numerous consultations that led to a consensus during the Sovereign National Conference organised in 1993.  The text of this new fundamental law - the eleventh since the country's independence in 1960 - marks a return to a semi-presidential system, replacing the presidential system of 2018 by confirming the restoration of the post of Prime Minister as head of government accountable to the National Assembly, distinct from the role of Head of State of the President of the Republic. The President's term of office will be reduced from six to five years, always renewable once consecutively. The minimum age for presidential candidates is lowered from 40 to 35. The draft constitution also ratifies the existence of the Senate, which was theoretically created by the 2018 constitution but has never yet been set up, as well as the division of the country into 23 regions, or provinces.  The text is also notable for its objective of restoring a number of rights, concepts and democratic institutions that had been removed from the 1996 text by a succession of constitutional revisions under the presidency of Idriss Déby. Independence of the judiciary has been consolidated by assigning the chairmanship of the High Council of the Judiciary not to the President of the Republic but to the President of the Supreme Court, who was previously second vice-president. The High Court of Justice, placed under the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in 2018, has also regained its independence as an institution, and the sole power to try for high treason the President of the Republic, those of other institutions, as well as members of the government and their possible accomplices.The same applies to the Constitutional Council, which regains its independence from the Supreme Court and exercises sole control over the constitutionality of laws, organic laws, decrees and international treaties.Its review is carried out automatically before they are promulgated, but also a posteriori on the basis of a dispute referred to the Council by an ordinary court.The Council also judges electoral disputes and administers the oath of office to the newly elected President of the Republic.  In terms of military justice, a Court of Appeal was created, in addition to the military courts and the Supreme Court.

voting_methods.instructions: 2016 Election Law, Article 37 – Every voter shall exercise his/her right to vote as follows: When the voter appears before the polling and counting committee, the committee shall verify his/her identity and make sure that his/her name is registered in the final voter list for that district by checking the computer and the hard-copies of the list. The list shall be marked electronically and by hand to indicate that the voter has exercised his/her right to vote. The chair of the polling and counting committee or one of its two members shall give the actual voter a ballot paper. The actual voter shall: mark in the designated place the name, number or emblem of one of the lists standing or election in that electoral district; mark in the designated place of one or more of the candidate names in that specific list. The actual voter shall put the ballot paper in the designated ballot box, which must be visible to the committee and to all persons present. The actual voter shall put his/her finger in the designated ink.

government_functions.details: Jordan is a constitutional, hereditary monarchy with a parliamentary government. The king remains the country’s ultimate authority and wields power over the executive, legislative, and judicial branches. The king appoints the prime minister who then chooses a cabinet.  Both the prime minister and cabinet appointments must be approved by the parliament.  Jordan has a bicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Ummah), with a Senate (Majlis al-Aʿyan) as its upper chamber, and a House of Representatives (Majlis al-Nuwwāb) as its lower chamber. Members of the Senate are appointed by the king for four-year terms, while members of the House of Representatives are elected every four years. A small number of seats in the House of Representatives are reserved for Christians and Circassians.  Judges are appointed and dismissed by royal decree following a decision made by the Justices Council. There are three categories of courts. The regular courts, including those of magistrates, courts of first instance, and courts of appeals and cassation in Amman, hear appeals passed on from lower courts. The constitution also provides for a Special Council, which interprets the laws and determines their constitutionality. There are also religious courts and special courts which deal with particular matters such as land, taxes, and customs.
