voting_methods.instructions: Voters may request to vote by mail if they will leave Palau (including seafaring) before election day.  To request to vote by mail, voters must submit "a written and signed request for an absentee ballot, including the voter’s name, voting precinct, election district, reason(s) for being absent, and address to which the ballot should be forwarded" by mail or email to the Palau Election Commission.  Requests must be received by the Commission at least seven days before the election.  Voters will receive their ballots by mail, fill them out and sign a corresponding affidavit, and mail them back to the Commission.  Completed ballots must be postmarked no later than the day of the election and reach the Election Commission not later than the established closing hour of business on the seventh day after the election.

The Election Commission shall, prior to an election, provide to any person who may be entitled to vote by absentee ballot, and who requests the same, an official ballot, a ballot envelope, an affidavit, and a covering reply envelope. The absentee voter shall mark the ballot in the usual manner provided by law and in such manner that no person can see or know how the ballot is marked except as provided in section 1522 of this chapter. The absentee voter shall then complete and execute the affidavit. The ballot envelope and the affidavit shall then be enclosed and sealed in the covering reply envelope and in order to be valid must be postmarked no later than the day of the election and reach the Election Commission not later than the established closing hour of business on the seventh day after the election, except as provided in section 1522 of this chapter.

The voter present their full name and address to the election officials, who then check the register to confirm the voter's registration.Once confirmed, voter is given ballot which must be filled up in secret.

electoral_rights.source: Section 1522 and 1604 of the Voting Rights Act (1981)

government_functions.details:
The President is the chief executive of the national government (Sect 1). He enforces the law, conducts foreign affairs, makes treaties with the advice and consent of the Olbiil Era Kelulau, appoints ambassadors and other national officers with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoints judges from a list submitted by the Judicial Nominating Commission, grants pardons and reprieves, spends money pursuant to appropriations, collects taxes, represents the national government in legal actions, and proposes an annual budget (Sec 7).

The Olbiil Era Kelulau or the legislative branch consists of two houses: the House of Delegates and the Senate (Sec 1). It has the power to enact legislation, levy taxes, borrow money, regulate commerce, establish a monetary and banking system, ratify treaties, and provide for the national defense, among other powers (Sec 5). To overturn a presidential veto, a bill must be approved by not less than two-thirds of the members of each house (Sec 15).

The judicial power is vested in a unified judiciary, consisting of a Supreme Court, a National Court, and other courts established by law (Sec 1). The Supreme Court has a trial division and an appellate division (Sec 2). It has original and exclusive jurisdiction over matters affecting ambassadors, public ministers, consuls, admiralty and maritime cases, and cases in which the national government or a state government is a party (Sec 5).

The appellate division of the Supreme Court has jurisdiction to review all decisions of the trial division and lower courts (Sec 6).

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The members of the House of Representatives are elected through an electoral system that provides for three types of representation: by district, by at-large and additional or minority party representation. The representation by district and at-large follows a FPTP formula while the minority party representation follows a proportional representation formula.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1. Article VI, Section 4, of Constitution of Puerto Rico.  2. Article 5.3, of the Electoral Code of Puerto Rico.

voting_methods.instructions: The Statal Electoral Commission must issue regulations concerning absentee voting. However, the Electoral Code foresees that in cases of absentee votes to be cast on paper and mail ballots, these types of ballots must be sent to the absent voter through the US Postal Service or a postal company authorized to operate within the United States of America, or transmitted through email. In this case, the voter must return his or her voted ballots to the Commission through the US Postal Service or a postal company authorized to operate within the United States of America with a postmark postcard dated no later than the day of the vote or General Election. They will only be considered for counting those validly cast votes that are received by mail in the Commission, on or before the last day of the general scrutiny of the electoral event. It is prohibited to requires notarization or witnesses to be able to exercise the right to vote through Absentee Voting. Any voter who completes and submits to the Commission an Absentee Vote application and is accepted, it will appear on the printed list of voters or in the “Electronic Poll Book” of the college of your registration, with a code representing that you voted by Absentee Vote and, under no circumstances circumstance or allegation, you will be allowed to vote at the college.

The Statal Electoral Commission must issue regulations concerning absentee voting. However, the Electoral Code foresees that in cases of absentee votes to be cast on paper and mail ballots, these types of ballots must be sent to the absent voter through the US Postal Service or a postal company authorized to operate within the United States of America, or transmitted through email. In this case, the voter must return his or her voted ballots to the Commission through the US Postal Service or a postal company authorized to operate within the United States of America with a postmark postcard dated no later than the day of the vote or General Election. They will only be considered for counting those validly cast votes that are received by mail in the Commission, on or before the last day of the general scrutiny of the electoral event. It is prohibited to requires notarization or witnesses to be able to exercise the right to vote through Absentee Voting. Any voter who completes and submits to the Commission an Absentee Vote application and is accepted, it will appear on the printed list of voters or in the “Electronic Poll Book” of the college of your registration, with a code representing that you voted by Absentee Vote and, under no circumstances circumstance or allegation, you will be allowed to vote at the college. In sum, there is a combination of absentee voting using mail and electronic means.

Article 9.10 of the Electoral Code, cited above, mentions the voting instructions printed on the ballots for all voting processes; while the election calendar gives the dates for submitting requests of early voting and the dates for sending and recieving the electoral materials.

The first step is to verify the identity of the voter through the voter list and using its identification document. Once the voter´s identity is verified, its finger is marked with ink. Afterward, the voter receives the ballots or the access to the electronic voting methods, depending on the method used for that election. The vote must mark the ballots fulfilling three principles: independent, secret, and private. After marking the ballots, the voter must introduce them in the electronic voting system to confirm that he/she has voted. Voters may receive assistance to vote.

results.results_notes: Results source: Puerto Rico State Commission on Elections

electoral_rights.source: Article 5.5 of the Electoral Code of Puerto Rico.

government_functions.details: The Executive Power shall be exercised by a Governor, who shall be elected by direct vote in each general election. The Governor shall hold office for a term of four years from the second day of January of the year following the year of his election until his successor is elected and takes office.  The Legislative Power shall be exercised by a Legislature, consisting of two Houses, the Senate and the House of Representatives, whose members shall be elected by direct ballot at each general election. The Senate shall be composed of twenty-seven Senators and the House of Representatives of fifty-one Representatives. For the purpose of electing members to the Legislative Assembly, Puerto Rico shall be divided into eight senatorial districts and forty representative districts. Each senatorial district shall elect two Senators and each representative district shall elect one Representative. Additionally, eleven Senators and eleven Representatives are elected through an aggregate formula.  The Judicial power of Puerto Rico will be exercised by a Supreme Court, and by those other courts established by law. The Supreme Court will be the court of last resort in Puerto Rico and will be composed of a presiding judge and four associate judges. The judges will be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: 16 members of the Senate are elected in 8 two-seat constituencies, and 11 members are elected at large, all via plurality vote. If the minority party elects fewer than 9 Senators, Puerto Rico’s Constitution provides for the enlargement of the body through “add-on” Senators selected via a proportional representation formula.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1. Sections 3101 of Chapter 3 of the Guam Code Annotated Election.
voting_and_voters.registered_voters_source:
1. Registered voters of Guam published in Official Election Results. Link: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ksvvfFqE7rHMcUR0I70xripf6nlDbXND/view

2. 2024 Important Dates published by the Guam Election Commission. Link: https://gec.guam.gov/index.php/gec-2018-election-important-dates/

voting_methods.instructions: Out of country voting applies amid the absentee voting procedure. However, Section 10106 foresees that when the Commission is requested to mail an absent voter’s ballot to an elector, and the address to which said ballot is to be mailed is a point outside of Guam, the Commission shall mail the absent voter’s ballot to the elector by airmail as soon as the request is received, provided that the ballots are printed, and, if by any law of the United States official election ballots may be mailed without the payment of postage, it shall so comply. Absentee ballots shall be mailed or transmitted by email to absentee voters in the manner requested, within forty-eight (48) hours of request or within forty-eight (48) hours, except Sundays, of certification of the ballots, whichever is later.

1. Application for an absentee ballot shall be made following the guidelines set by Section 10103 of the Guam Code Annotated Election. Any applicant who fails to complete and document his or her application for a ballot in accordance with Commission regulations shall be denied a ballot, and his or her name will be stricken from the register of qualified voters.

2. When the Commission is requested to mail an absent voter’s ballot to an elector, and the address to which said ballot is to be mailed is a point outside of Guam, the Commission shall mail the absent voter’s ballot to the elector by airmail as soon as the request is received, provided that the ballots are printed, and, if by any law of the United States official election ballots may be mailed without the payment of postage, it shall so comply.

3. A voter who (1) is eligible for an absentee ballot; (2) wants to execute an affidavit or form for voter registration; and (3) is absent from Guam or is an active member of the Armed Forces of the United States, including National Guard or Reserve Units, or an overseas voter as defined by the Federal Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, is not required to sign the affidavit or form in the presence of a person authorized to administer an oath, and the affidavit or form need not be signed by such an oath administrator. The Commission shall inform the voter that no signature other than that of the voter is required on the affidavit or form and that a voter who makes a false statement on the affidavit or form is subject to the penalties of perjury.

4. Absentee ballots shall be mailed or transmitted by email to absentee voters in the manner requested, within forty-eight (48) hours of request or within forty-eight (48) hours, except Sundays, of certification of the ballots, whichever is later.

5. Notwithstanding the conditions prescribed in § 10101 of this Chapter, the Commission shall deliver a ballot to any qualified voter applying in person at the office of said Commission; provided, however, that such applicant shall complete and subscribe the application and affidavit heretofore prescribed in this Section; provided further, that said application shall be made not more than thirty (30) days nor less than five (5) days before the date of the election for which the vote is being cast. It is provided further, that said ballot shall be immediately marked, enclosed in the ballot envelope, placed in the return envelope with the proper affidavit enclosed, and immediately returned to the Commission.

6. The absentee ballot may, but need not be, in the same form as the regular ballot used in the election. For off-island absentee voters, uniformed and overseas citizens voting absentee, the Commission shall inform such absentee voters of the option to request to receive an absentee ballot electronically by email transmission and provide electronic mail and cost-free telephonic contact information to such voters so that those voters may make the request to the Guam Election Commission.

7.  It shall be the duty of the Commission to furnish the absentee voter with a blank ballot in an unmarked ballot envelope. The voter, on receipt of said ballot, shall, in the presence of the officer administering the oath and of no other person, mark such ballot or set of ballots, but in such manner that said officer would not see or know how said ballot is marked.

1. Application for an absentee ballot shall be made following the guidelines set by Section 10103 of the Guam Code Annotated Election.

2. Any applicant who fails to complete and document his or her application for a ballot in accordance with Commission regulations shall be denied a ballot, and his or her name will be stricken from the register of qualified voters.

3. A voter who (1) is eligible for an absentee ballot; (2) wants to execute an affidavit or form for voter registration; and (3) is absent from Guam or is an active member of the Armed Forces of the United States, including National Guard or Reserve Units, or an overseas voter as defined by the Federal Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, is not required to sign the affidavit or form in the presence of a person authorized to administer an oath, and the affidavit or form need not be signed by such an oath administrator. The Commission shall inform the voter that no signature other than that of the voter is required on the affidavit or form and that a voter who makes a false statement on the affidavit or form is subject to the penalties of perjury.

4. Absentee ballots shall be mailed or transmitted by email to absentee voters in the manner requested, within forty-eight (48) hours of request or within forty-eight (48) hours, except Sundays, of certification of the ballots, whichever is later.

5. Notwithstanding the conditions prescribed in § 10101 of this Chapter, the Commission shall deliver a ballot to any qualified voter applying in person at the office of said Commission; provided, however, that such applicant shall complete and subscribe the application and affidavit heretofore prescribed in this Section; provided further, that said application shall be made not more than thirty (30) days nor less than five (5) days before the date of the election for which the vote is being cast. It is provided further, that said ballot shall be immediately marked, enclosed in the ballot envelope, placed in the return envelope with the proper affidavit enclosed, and immediately returned to the Commission.

6. The absentee ballot may, but need not be, in the same form as the regular ballot used in the election. For off-island absentee voters, uniformed and overseas citizens voting absentee, the Commission shall inform such absentee voters of the option to request to receive an absentee ballot electronically by email transmission and provide electronic mail and cost-free telephonic contact information to such voters so that those voters may make the request to the Guam Election Commission.

7.  It shall be the duty of the Commission to furnish the absentee voter with a blank ballot in an unmarked ballot envelope. The voter, on receipt of said ballot, shall, in the presence of the officer administering the oath and of no other person, mark such ballot or set of ballots, but in such manner that said officer would not see or know how said ballot is marked.

1. A person desiring to vote shall state his or her full name and address to the precinct officials at the polling place and shall present a validly issued photo identification card issued by a federal, state, Guam secondary school, Guam post-secondary school or government of Guam entity to the precinct official or other authorized election official.

2. After verifying the person’s identity and determining that the person’s name appears as a registered voter on the precinct roster, the precinct officials shall clearly and loudly announce the person’s name. If no person challenges the person’s right to vote, or if, after a challenge, the precinct board determines that the challenged person is entitled to vote, the person shall be required to sign the roster and then be permitted to vote. In the case of a person who is unable to sign the roster, a precinct official shall so note that fact on the roster, and two (2) other precinct board members shall initial the entry. The person shall then be permitted to vote. Any person whose right to vote is denied by the precinct board may immediately appeal the decision to the Commission and, if unsuccessful, to the Superior Court of Guam.

3. Upon receiving a ballot or set of ballots, the voter shall forthwith, and without leaving the enclosed area, proceed alone to one (1) of the designated places, booths or tables provided to prepare his or her ballot.

4. In voting, the voter shall place the appropriate mark in the voting oval or other defined space provided adjacent to the name of any nominee for whom he or she intends to vote, or shall vote for a candidate or person whose name is not printed on the ballot by writing in a name for that office in the blank line-space provided, and clearly marking the adjacent voting oval or other space provided.

electoral_rights.source: 1. Sections 10101 and 10107.1  of Chapter 10 of the Guam Code Annotated Election.

government_functions.details: The Governor of Guam, together with the Lieutenant Governor, shall be elected by a majority of the votes cast by the people who are qualified to vote for the members of the Legislature of Guam in each general election. The Governor shall have general supervision and control of all the departments, bureaus, agencies, and other instrumentalities of the executive branch of the government of Guam.  Legislative power in Guam is vested in a single house, composed of 15 members, directly elected for a two-year term. In addition, Guam appoints at the polls a delegate to the U.S. Congress, who will be responsible for defending Guam's interests before the federal government. This delegate has a voice but no vote in the U.S. House. The legislative power of Guam shall extend to all rightful subjects of legislation not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act and the laws of the United States applicable to Guam.  The judicial authority of Guam shall be vested in a court established by Congress designated as the “District Court of Guam”, and a judicial branch of Guam which branch shall constitute a unified judicial system and include an appellate court designated as the “Supreme Court of Guam”, a trial court designated as the “Superior Court of Guam”, and such other lower local courts as may have been or shall hereafter be established by the laws of Guam.

voting_methods.instructions:
In terms of procedure, the first step was the request for absentee ballot.

(a) Any person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (1) may request an absentee ballot in writing from the Chief Election Officer. In addition, such person may transmit such request by mail, electronically, or by facsimile, and designate the preferred means of return transmission whether by mail, electronically, or by facsimile. Any such person may request an absentee ballot not earlier than January 1st of the year of the election for which the absentee ballot is requested, and not later than 4:30 p.m. the 15th day prior to the election. The request shall include any information that will facilitate the location of his voting district, the establishment of his right to a ballot, and the address where he wants his ballot forwarded.

(b) Any person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (2) may request an absentee ballot in person or in writing from the Chief Election Officer not earlier than the day that ballots are printed and available and not later than 4:30 p.m. on the day prior to the election. Ballots shall not be mailed, and such qualified electors must vote in person before they travel outside the Territory.
(...)

(d) Certification of absentee ballots shall be closed not later than 1:30 p.m. on election day.

The second step is the delivery of the ballots.
Immediately upon receipt of a request within the time limits specified in 6.1102, the Chief Election Officer shall examine the records to ascertain whether or not the qualified elector is lawfully entitled to vote as requested. As soon as official ballots are printed and available, the Chief Election Officer shall:

(a) for those persons entitled to vote under 6.1101(c)(1), mail in a forwarding envelope, via airmail, an official ballot and other materials prescribed in 6.1104. All requests postmarked by the 15th day prior to the election shall be processed, and ballots mailed to the qualified electors requesting them as soon as reasonably practicable, but in no event later than 24 hours after receipt of the request;

(b) for those persons entitled to vote under 6.1101(c)(1)(iv) and (v), and who are voting in an election for the Delegate to the U.S. House of Representatives, the Chief Election Officer shall establish procedures by which such absent voters may designate the preferred method of absentee ballot transmission and the Chief Election Officer shall, in accordance with adopted procedures, transmit blank absentee ballots by mail, electronically, and by facsimile as designated by the absent voter; and,

(c) for those person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (2) and (3), deliver an official ballot to enable such persons to vote at the designated absentee polling place or in a manner prescribed by rules adopted by the Chief Election Officer.

The return of the ballot through the envelope shall be:

(1) mailed and must be received by the Chief Election Officer not later than 1:30 p.m. on election day; or
(2) delivered other than by mail to the Chief Election Officer not later than 1:30 p.m. on election day.

(b) for those persons entitled to vote under 6.1101(c)(1)(iv) and (v), and who are voting in an election for the Delegate to the U.S. House of Representatives, the Chief Election Officer shall establish procedures by which such absent voters may designate the preferred method of absentee ballot transmission and the Chief Election Officer shall, in accordance with adopted procedures, transmit blank absentee ballots by mail, electronically, and by facsimile as designated by the absent voter.

(1) mailed and must be received by the Chief Election Officer not later than 1:30 p.m. on election day; or
(2) delivered other than by mail to the Chief Election Officer not later than 1:30 p.m. on election day.

In terms of procedure, the first step was the request for absentee ballot.

(a) Any person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (1) may request an absentee ballot in writing from the Chief Election Officer. In addition, such person may transmit such request by mail, electronically, or by facsimile, and designate the preferred means of return transmission whether by mail, electronically, or by facsimile. Any such person may request an absentee ballot not earlier than January 1st of the year of the election for which the absentee ballot is requested, and not later than 4:30 p.m. the 15th day prior to the election. The request shall include any information that will facilitate the location of his voting district, the establishment of his right to a ballot, and the address where he wants his ballot forwarded.

(b) Any person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (2) may request an absentee ballot in person or in writing from the Chief Election Officer not earlier than the day that ballots are printed and available and not later than 4:30 p.m. on the day prior to the election. Ballots shall not be mailed, and such qualified electors must vote in person before they travel outside the Territory.

(c) Any person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (3) may request an absentee ballot in person or in writing from the Chief Election Officer not earlier than on the 30th day prior to the election and not later than 4:30 p.m. on the day prior to the election.

(d) Certification of absentee ballots shall be closed not later than 1:30 p.m. on election day.

The second step is the delivery of the ballots.

Immediately upon receipt of a request within the time limits specified in 6.1102, the Chief Election Officer shall examine the records to ascertain whether or not the qualified elector is lawfully entitled to vote as requested. As soon as official ballots are printed and available, the Chief Election Officer shall:

(a) for those persons entitled to vote under 6.1101(c)(1), mail in a forwarding envelope, via airmail, an official ballot and other materials prescribed in 6.1104. All requests postmarked by the 15th day prior to the election shall be processed, and ballots mailed to the qualified electors requesting them as soon as reasonably practicable, but in no event later than 24 hours after receipt of the request;

(b) for those persons entitled to vote under 6.1101(c)(1)(iv) and (v), and who are voting in an election for the Delegate to the U.S. House of Representatives, the Chief Election Officer shall establish procedures by which such absent voters may designate the preferred method of absentee ballot transmission and the Chief Election Officer shall, in accordance with adopted procedures, transmit blank absentee ballots by mail, electronically, and by facsimile as designated by the absent voter; and

(c) for those person entitled to vote under 6.1101 (c) (2) and (3), deliver an official ballot to enable such persons to vote at the designated absentee polling place or in a manner prescribed by rules adopted by the Chief Election Officer.

1. Every person upon applying to vote shall sign his name in the poll book prepared for that purpose. This requirement may be waived by any district official if for reasons of illiteracy or blindness or other physical disability the qualified elector is unable to write. Every person shall provide identification if so requested by a district official.

2. After signing the poll book and receiving his ballot, the qualified elector shall proceed to the voting booth to vote according to the voting system in use in his district. The district official may, and upon request shall, explain to the qualified elector the mode of voting.

3. No person shall look at or ask to see the contents of the ballot of any qualified elector, except as provided for assistance of illiterate or disables voters, nor shall any person within the polling place attempt to influence a qualified elector in regard to whom or what he shall vote for. When a qualified elector is in the voting booth for the purpose of marking or casting his ballot, no other person shall, except as provided for assistance of illiterate or disabled voters, be allowed to enter the booth or to be in a position from which he can observe how the qualified elector marks or casts his ballot.

4. All elections of members of the House of Representatives shall be by secret ballot. At each polling place there shall be a voting shelf or compartment at which each voter can mark his ballot in complete privacy, and such other election supplies as are necessary.

5. In those districts using paper ballots or cards, no person shall take a ballot out of the polling place. After voting, the qualified elector shall leave the voting booth and deliver his ballot to the district official in charge of the ballot boxes. The district official shall make certain that he has received the correct ballot and no other and then shall drop the ballot into the ballot box. If any person having received a ballot leaves the polling place without first delivering the ballot to the district official as provided above, or willfully exhibits his ballot, except as provided for illiterate or disabled voters, after the ballot has been marked, shall forfeit his right to vote, and the district officials shall cause a record to be made of the proceeding.

6. A qualified elector shall be allowed to remain in the voting booth for 5 minutes, and having voted the qualified elector shall at once emerge and leave the voting booth. If he refuses to leave when so requested by a majority of district officials after the lapse of 5 minutes, he shall be removed by the district officials. Once a qualified elector has completed his voting and emerged from the booth, he shall not be permitted to reenter.

government_functions.details: The Executive Branch is led by the Governor and the Lieutenant Governor of American Samoa, which are popularly elected. The Governor shall have the power to issue executive regulations not in conflict with laws of the United States applicable to American Samoa, laws of American Samoa, or with the Constitution. The Governor shall have general supervision and control of all executive departments, agencies and instrumentalities of the Government of American Samoa.  The Legislature consists of a Senate and a House of Representatives. The Legislature shall have the authority to pass legislation with respect to subjects of local application. However, no such legislation may be inconsistent with this Constitution or the laws of the United States applicable in American Samoa; no such legislation may conflict with treaties or international agreements of the United States.  The Judicial power shall be vested in a High Court, the District Courts and such other courts as may from time to time be created by law. The judicial branch of the Government of American Samoa shall be independent of the executive and legislative branches.

government_functions.details:
In Mauritania, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and has no term limit.

Mauritania has a unicameral National Assembly (Al Jam'iya Al Wataniya) with 176 seats. 88 members are elected via absolute majority vote (up to two rounds) in a single, nationwide constituency. The remaining 88 members are elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-member constituencies, including 4 overseas constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. Out of the 88 nationwide constituency seats, 20 seats are reserved for women, and 11 are reserved for youth (aged 25 to 30). 

The Mauritanian judiciary is composed of the Supreme Court (21 judges), the Constitutional Council (9 judges), and the High Court of Justice (9 judges). Judges within these institutions are all appointed by either the President, the Prime Minister, or members of the National Assembly.

election_issues.issues: Economy, public debt, security, illegal mining (galamsey), corruption, accountability

voting_methods.instructions: A voter must apply to be included in the Special Voters List not later than 42 days before the polling day. He/she must have a certificate from his/her employer stating that (i) the applicant is registered at a polling station in the constituency of the returning officer to whom the application is made; and (ii) the applicant’s duties will prevent the applicant from being present on polling day at the polling station where the applicant is registered.

On election day, voters visit their designated Polling Station with their Voter ID card. Officials verify the voter's identity and details against the electoral roll. The voting process begins with the presidential election, followed by the parliamentary vote. For each, voters receive a ballot paper, proceed to a private voting screen, and select one candidate by placing a thumbprint in the box next to their chosen candidate's name. After marking, voters fold the ballot vertically and then horizontally for privacy. They then leave the voting area and deposit the folded presidential ballot into the box marked "Presidential," and later, the parliamentary ballot into the box marked "Parliamentary." This process ensures each voter casts one vote for a presidential candidate and one for a parliamentary candidate while maintaining the secrecy of their choices. Once both votes are cast, the voting process is complete.

government_functions.details: The President is the head of state, government, and the armed forces. He is elected by majority vote by a two-round system. A president's term is 4 years and can only be reelected once. Ghana has a unicameral Parliament currently composed of 275 members from single-member constituencies that are elected by FPTP for a term of four years.  The judiciary consists of the Supreme Court (composed of the Chief Justice and not less than 9 Justices), the Court of Appeal (composed of the Chief Justice and not less than 10 Justices of the Court of Appeal), and the High Court (composed of the Chief Justice and not less than 20 Justices) and Regional Tribunals (composed of the Chief Justice, one chairman and members who may or may not be lawyers designated to sit as panel members of a Regional Tribunal)

voting_methods.instructions:
Each voter shall declare before the Receiving Commission his name and, if he remembers it, the series and number of his registration. If he/she has his/her credential with him/her, it shall be sufficient to show it. The Commission shall verify whether the voter corresponds to the circuit and whether he has already voted before the Commission. If the conditions imposed by article 78 have been met, his vote shall be admitted. If it is ascertained that the voter has already voted before the Commission, his vote shall be rejected and his preventive arrest shall be ordered.

The voter shall immediately take an open voting envelope from the box containing them and shall show the members of the Commission the number printed on it. The voter's order number, the number of the ballot paper, the series and number of the voter's registration, as well as the voter's first and last name, shall then be entered on the ordinal list. The voter shall then be invited to enter the secret room to place the ballot paper in the envelope. Upon entering the secret room, the voter shall close the door behind him and immediately place the ballot paper in the envelope and close it. The voter shall not remain in the secret room for more than two minutes. After this time, the presiding officer shall open the door of the secret room and, without entering it, shall order the voter to leave. Upon leaving the secret room, the voter shall go to the polling place, detach the slip from the envelope and hand it to the Chairman of the Commission. The voter then introduces the ballots on the ballot box.

government_functions.details: The Legislative Power is exercised by the General Assembly which is composed of two Houses: one of Representatives and the other of Senators, whose members are directly elected by the people. The House of Representatives is composed of ninety-nine (99) members and the House of Senators of thirty (30). The Executive Power shall be exercised by the President of the Republic acting with the respective Minister or Ministers, or with the Council of Ministers, in accordance with the provisions of this Section and other concordant provisions.

government_functions.details: The President functions as head of state, head of government, commander-in-chief, and symbol of national unity. The Prime minister convenes and chairs the Council of Ministers, advises the president and assists him in governing the country, and coordinates the functions of the other ministers.  The President is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system for a 5-year-term. The Prime minister is appointed by the president.  The Supreme Court is the highest court in Mozambique. The Constitutional Council reviews the constitutionality of laws.  Supreme Court judges are elected by legislature and Constitutional Council judges are appointed by the president and the legislature.  The Legislative Assembly of the Republic serves as the unicameral legislative body of Mozambique.  Members are elected through a closed-list proportional representation system and 2 members are elected in single-member constituencies for a term of 5 years

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The candidate who gains more than half of the votes cast shall be elected President of the Republic. If none of the candidates obtains an absolute majority, there shall be a second round between the two candidates receiving the most votes.

election_issues.issues: Conflict in the north; public health (cholera)

institution.term_details: The President of the Republic may be re-elected only once. A President of the Republic who has been elected on two consecutive occasions may be a candidate for further presidential elections only five years after the end of his last term of office.

Same ID requirements as in-country voting.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: According to the XXVI Amendment, the right of citizens of the United States, who are eighteen years of age or older, to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of age.

voting_methods.instructions:
Each year, the voter must submit a completed Federal Post Card Application (FPCA) to the voter's local election officials. They will confirm the voter's eligibility to vote and put its name on a list to receive absentee ballots for any elections held that calendar year, and they will send the voter a blank absentee ballot electronically or by mail. According to the United States Department of State Bureau of Consular Affairs, forty-five days before November general elections, each state will send voter abroad a blank ballot either electronically or via mail at the address you provided on the Federal Post Card Application (FVAP). Each voter must return the ballot complying with the deadlines set by each state.

Overseas voters have a number of options for returning completed ballots:
1. Local mail – If you have a reliable mail service to the United States, put your ballot in the mail with appropriate international postage.
2. U.S. Embassy Diplomatic Pouch – The voter or another person can drop off your ballot request or completed ballot at the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate for return to the United States. It must be addressed to the local election officials and have sufficient U.S. postage, or be in a postage-paid envelope. A postage-paid envelope is available on the FVAP website. Contact the U.S. embassy voting assistance officer or visit the embassy’s website for specific instructions.
3. Fax, Email, or Internet – Some states permit electronic transmission of completed ballots. Consult the Voting Assistance Guide for options in the voter's state.
4. Express Courier Service – If time is short or local mail unreliable, the voter can use professional courier services such as FedEx, DHL, or UPS at the voters' own expense.

If the voter completed all required steps but have not received the ballot 30 days before an election, it must submit a completed Federal Write-in Absentee Ballot (FWAB). The voter must contact the voting assistance officer at the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate for help, or visit the Foreign Voting Assistance Program website  to complete an FWAB using the online assistant. Write in the candidates of your choice, then print, sign, and send the FWAB to the local election officials. If the regular absentee ballot arrives after submitting a FWAB, it should still complete and return it. The voter's FWAB will be counted only if its regular ballot does not reach local election officials by the voter's state’s deadline. This will not invalidate the vote or result in casting two votes.

Instructions vary from state to state. For example, in New York, once a voter receives the ballot, it should mark the ballot according to its choices for each office following the instructions on the ballot. Once it has completed marking the ballot it must fold it up and place it in the Security Envelope, sign and date the outside of the Security Envelope, and seal the Security Envelope. All early mail ballots include a pre-paid Return Envelope, the voter must place the Security Envelope in the Return Envelope. The Return Envelope does not require any additional postage. Finally, the voter must seal the Return Envelope.

In Indiana, the voter will receive an absentee-by-mail ballot via the United States Postal Service. When the voter receives the ballot, it must read all instructions that accompany the ballot in the envelope. Ensure the precinct is correct and the ballot has two sets of initials on the back. The precinct can be found on the bottom-right corner of the ballot. The voter must make selections on the ballot for each contest in which it wishes to vote, sign the secrecy envelope, and return the absentee ballot to the Election Board in the postage-paid envelope. It may also hand deliver the ballot to the City-County Building, Election Service Center, or any Early Voting location. The voter can also drop off the marked ballot at any Vote Center before 6:00 p.m. on Election Day.

The early voting procedure is set by each state. For example, in New York, early voting is just like voting on Election Day. Early voters privately mark and scan their ballot. Early voting results are counted, tabulated and included in (unofficial) election night totals.

In Texas, when voting early, when you arrive at the polling place, you will be asked to present one of the seven acceptable forms of photo identification, unless you are a voter with a permanent exemption on your voter registration certificate. If you do not possess a form of acceptable photo identification and you cannot reasonably obtain one, show a supporting form of identification to the election official and execute a Reasonable Impediment Declaration. The election official will ask if you have moved and then ask you to sign the list of people who have voted in the precinct. Depending on the type of election – local, statewide, national, or combination – you will be handed: A paper ballot on which you will select your choices and which will be counted by hand; A paper ballot on which you will select your choices by darkening an oval, completing an arrow, or “marking” with the aid of a voting machine; or, a slip of paper with a numerical access code or, in some counties, a ballot activator card. In the next available voting booth, enter your code or card and let the on-screen instructions guide you through the process of electronic voting.

In Georgia, when you arrive at your early voting location, you'll need to bring a valid photo ID such as a driver's license, passport, or voter identification card. The polls offer audio ballots for voters who are blind or have low vision, and booths for voters in wheelchairs. If you need help with your ballot, you can ask a family member or friend to come with you to the polls and fill the ballot in with your choices. If you can’t vote in person – either early or on Election Day – you also have the option to request an absentee ballot to vote by mail.

According to the U.S. Election Assistance Commission, when a voter arrives at the voting location, he/she will be asked for its name and  may need to provide its address, date of birth, or signature. If the voters is in a state that requires
ID to vote, or if it is a first-time voter, it may be asked to show his/her ID. After verifying its registration,
the poll worker will give the voter a ballot based on its address and political party affiliation (if voting in a primary election). After voting, it will place your ballot in a ballot box or tabulator. In most states, if the poll worker cannot verify its registration, the voter will be offered a provisional ballot. Several states also allow the voter to register or update its registration the same day. It is the right of the voter to vote privately and independently.

electoral_rights.source: Americans with Disabilities Act; Voter Rights Act of 1965; Voting Accessibility for the Elderly and Handicapped Act of 1984; National Voter Registration Act of 1993; Help America Vote Act of 2002

government_functions.details: The President serves as both head of state and head of government. The President is elected indirectly through the Electoral College, a body made up of electors with each state receiving the number of electors equal to the size of their delegation in both house  of Congress. Generally, the electors give their votes to the candidate who won the state. The President is elected to four-year terms with an absolute two-term limit.  The legislature is a bicameral Congress consisting of the Senate and the House of Representatives. In the Senate, 100 members are elected by plurality vote (2 members per state) to serve 6-year terms. One-third of Senate seats are up for election every 2 years. In the House of Representatives, 435 members are elected by plurality vote in single-member constituencies to serve 2-year terms.  The Supreme Court is the highest court in the US judiciary. The court consists of nine justices, each nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Justices serve lifetime appointments. The federal court system also includes 13 regional courts of appeal and 94 district courts.

institution.term_details:
The XXII Amendment to the Constitution of the United States foresees that no person shall be elected to the office of the
President more than twice, and no person who has held the of- fice of President, or acted as President, for more than two years of a term to which some other person was elected President shall be elected to the office of the President more than once.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1. Section 7 of Article 1 of the Act of Law 247/1995 Coll., on elections to the Parliament of the Czech Republic

voting_methods.instructions:
Each polling station in any special election district must be equipped with a ballot box, a sufficient amount of ballot papers, a sufficient amount of official envelopes, pens, excerpts from special lists and this act of law. The text of the act of law shall be made available to any voter upon his/her request. Each polling station must also be furnished with a large state symbol located on a dignified place and feature special sections for the completion of ballot tickets separated in a way warranting compliance with the principle of secret ballot. Taking into account the number of voters in his/her special election district, the head of each embassy shall specify how many sections are to be provided. Ballot tickets marked as “samples” and all statements of withdrawal or resignation delivered at least 48 hours before the date of the elections must be posted at a clearly visible place of every polling station.

The law foresees that any voter not living within the territory of the Czech Republic and taking part in the elections to the Senate shall submit his/her electoral card issued by an embassy in compliance with the Act of Law 247/199 concerning election to the Parliament of the Czech Republic to a district election commission after his/her arrival in the polling station. His/her electoral card shall be attached to an excerpt from a special list.

The district election commission will send 2 of its members to the voter: portable ballot box, official envelope, and ballots. The members will come to the voter, give him an official envelope and possibly also ballots. Members will leave room for voters to vote by secret ballot. The voter then places the official envelope with the selected ballot into the ballot box.

1. After receiving an official envelope and ballot tickets – where applicable – each voter shall enter the section designated for the completion of ballot tickets.

2. After leaving the section designated for the completion of ballot tickets, each voter shall place the envelope containing his/her ballot ticket into a ballot box before the district election commission or special district election commission. If a voter is unable to place the envelope containing his/her ballot ticket into a ballot box, he/she may ask any other voter, except for the members of the district election commission and special district election commission, to do so on his/her behalf.

3. The voters who do not enter the section designated for the completion of ballot tickets shall not be permitted to vote by the district election commission or special district election commission.

results.results_notes: Results Source: Czech Ministry of the Interior

electoral_rights.source: Section 6 of Article 19 of the  Act of Law 247/1995 Coll., on elections to the Parliament of the Czech Republic.

government_functions.details: The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister.   Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected.   The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 120 members of parliament (MPs)  are elected under a proportional representation system, using closed lists, and 3 additional MPs are elected in elections for a single, out-of-country district.

election_issues.issues: EU Accession; Climate change and natural hazards; Country name controversy

voting_methods.instructions: Out of country voters must cast their votes at the diplomatic and consular offices of North Macedonia abroad, one day before the official Election Day in North Macedonia.

The Electoral Code allows incapacitated and ill persons, those in institutions for non-family care; voters termporarily working or residing abroad; and prisoners to to vote in their home one day prior to the polling day. There is no specific time of start or end but the president of the Municipal Election Commission to give notification.

If a voter is unable to vote at the polling station due to incapacity or illness (as per the State Election Commission’s instructions), they can still vote. The voter must notify the Municipal Election Commission (specifically, the Election Commission of the City of Skopje) no later than seven days before Election Day. The notification can also be submitted through a proxy. The Election Board enables the voter to vote at their home one day before Election Day, ensuring voting secrecy. A special ballot box is taken empty to the voter’s home for this purpose. The Election Board records this home voting in the protocol. The president of the Municipal Election Commission notifies the representatives of the list submitters in writing regarding the date and time of this home voting. Voters under detention or pre-trial house arrest shall vote in the penitentiary institutions or in the place of detention or the place where they are detained.

Once a voter’s identity has been verified and they have signed the voter’s list, they will receive a ballot. The voter should then circle the ordinal number corresponding to their chosen candidate and place the ballot into the ballot box.

government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

voting_methods.instructions: For a person to vote at a voting station, the voter must present their identity document to the presiding officer or voting officer at the voting station, and the voter´s name must appear in the certified segment of the voters´ roll for the voting district concerned. After the voter presents their identification to the presiding officer, the latter must examine the identity document and determine whether the voter is the person described in the identity document, if the voter´s name is in the verified segment of the voters´ roll for the voting district concerned, and if the voter has not already voted in the election. The presiding officer may require that the voter´s fingerprints be taken. Afterward, the officer must record that the voter is regarded to have voted in the election, mark the hand of the voter, mark the back of a ballot paper for that election, and hand the ballot paper to the voter. Once the voter has received a ballot paper marked in the manner described before, the voter must enter an empty voting compartment, mark the ballot paper for the registered party or candidate of his preference, fold the ballot paper to conceal the voter´s vote, take the ballot paper to a ballot box for the election and show it to the presiding officer in a way that the officer can see the mark made that confirms that the voter has voted, place the ballot paper in the ballot box, and leave the voting station.

For voters outside of South Africa on election day, the voter can cast a ballot in person at an embassy, consulate, or high commission. When the voter arrives, an elections official will mark the hand of the voter and hand them a ballot to cast their vote. When the voter is done, they seal it in an unmarked envelope, which is then placed in another envelope.

In cases of requests of special voting due to physical infirmity, disability, or pregnancy, the voter must be visited by at least two voting officers at an address within the voting district on the date or dates stated in the election timetable. The applicant must produce an identity document and provided it is verified, the elections official will mark the document and the voter's hand in the manner prescribed in regulation 18 of Election Regulations. Subsequently, they are handed a ballot paper, marked on the back for that election, the applicant is allowed to mark the ballot paper in secret and to place and seal it in an unmarked envelope which is in turn placed and sealed in another envelope which is marked on the outside with the applicant´s name, identity number and the voting district number. The voting officers must take the marked envelope to the office of the presiding officer where the applicant´s name on the voter´s roll is marked with the letters SV to indicate that he or she has cast a special vote, and the envelope is placed and securely kept in a sealed ballot box for special votes. There are additional procedures for voters with disabilities who will be voting outside of their voting district. 

In cases of election officers, security services members, and others who informed the EMB of their absence from the voting district, an election official will verify the identity of the voter, mark the voter roll with 'SV' after the voter's name, and the hand them a ballot paper. The voter then can mark the ballot paper in secret, place it in an unmarked envelope, which is then sealed and placed in another envelope.

government_functions.details:
The Parliament consists of the National Assembly and the National Council of Provinces. Both institutions participate in the legislative process. The National Assembly is elected to represent the people and to ensure government by the people under the Constitution. It does this by choosing the President, by providing a national forum for public consideration of issues, by passing legislation, and by scrutinizing and overseeing executive action. The National Council of Provinces represents the provinces to ensure that provincial interests are taken into account in the national sphere of government. It does this mainly by participating in the national legislative process and by providing a national forum for public consideration of issues affecting the provinces. The National Assembly consists of no fewer than 350 and no more than 400 women and men elected through proportional representation. The National Council of Provinces is composed of a single delegation from each province consisting of ten delegates.

The President is the Head of State and the head of the national executive. The President is responsible for assenting to and signing bills, implementing together with other members of the Cabinet national legislation except where the Constitution or and Act of Parliament provides otherwise, and developing and implementing national policy. The President is elected by the National Assembly at its first sitting.

The judicial authority of the Republic is vested in the courts. The courts are independent and subject only to the Constitution and the law, which they must apply impartially. The courts are: the Constitutional Court, the Supreme Court of Appeal, the High Court of South Africa, the Magistrates´ Courts, and any other court established by an Act of Parliament. The President of the Republic, after consulting with the Judicial Service Commission and the leaders of the parties represented in the National Assembly, appoints the Chief Justice and the Deputy Chief Justice, and, after consulting the Judicial Service Commission, appoints the President and Deputy President of the Supreme Court of Appeal. The judges of the Constitutional Court are appointed by the President, as head of the national executive, after consulting the Chief Justice and the leaders of the parties represented in the National Assembly. With regards to the judges of all other courts, the President has the faculty to appoint them on the advice of the Judicial Service Commission.

voting_methods.instructions: To cast a vote, an elector must first present personal identification documents to the election officials to verify their identity. Once verified, the elector is issued a ballot,  then  selects a candidate from among those contesting in the election and marks a tick opposite the candidate's name on the ballot. This action is to be carried out inside a voting booth located in the voting area. After marking the ballot, the elector deposits it in the ballot box. It is important that the elector votes without delay upon receiving the ballot and leaves the voting area promptly after casting their vote. Additionally, voters are strictly prohibited from photographing, recording audio, or video using a mobile phone or any other device within the voting area under all circumstances.

government_functions.details:
Rwanda is a multiparty republic. Under the 2003 Constitution, the president, who serves as head of state, was directly elected to a seven-year term, renewable once. In 2015 the Constitution was amended to allow the president at the time, Paul Kagame, to run for a third consecutive seven-year term in 2017 and, after that, for presidents to serve a five-year term renewable once. The president selects a prime minister, who serves as the head of government.

Legislative power is exercised by a bicameral parliament, which consists of the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate. Deputies serve five-year terms. About two-thirds are directly elected. The rest of the deputies are indirectly elected: two are elected by the National Youth Council; one is elected by the Federation of the Association of the Disabled; and the remaining seats are allocated to female representatives elected by local government bodies. Senators serve nonrenewable eight-year terms; under the 2015 amended Constitution, that will change to a five-year term, renewable once, beginning after 2019. Twelve are elected by local government bodies; two are elected from among lecturers and researchers of universities and institutions of higher education, one from public universities and one from private universities; eight are selected by the president; and four are selected by the Forum of Political Organizations (a regulatory body).

voting_methods.instructions: The diplomatic representations and consulates of the Republic of Azerbaijan should facilitate the implementation of the rights of citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan residing outside the Republic of Azerbaijan, which are enshrined in Articles 3 and 56 of the Constitution of the Republic of Azerbaijan, with regard to the holding of elections and referendums. Citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan who are in a foreign country where no Azerbaijani Diplomatic Representation or Consulate exist, or where no Precinct Election Commission has been established at the Azerbaijani Diplomatic Representation or Consulate according to Article 35.6 of this Code, shall not participate in voting. No voting shall be held for municipal elections or elections of deputies to the Milli Majlis for the citizens of the Republic of Azerbaijan in a foreign country on Voting Day. Election precincts, which are established for the collection and counting of votes of voters outside the country on Voting Day, shall be created by the heads of diplomatic representations or consulates of the Republic of Azerbaijan at least 30 days prior to Voting Day, in the territories where such voters reside, provided the number of voters registered with the consulate is more than 50. Such polling stations may only be created during referendums and Presidential elections.
Early voting is only permitted for sailors on ships at sea under the Azerbaijani flag and residents of very remote communities unreachable by roads.

A ballot paper shall be provided to a voter upon presentation of his/her identification or substitute document. After the voter receives the ballot paper, the serial and batch number of his/her identification or substitute document shall be recorded in the Voter List. The voter shall check correctness of the records and sign upon receiving the ballot paper. If the voter is not able to receive a ballot paper independently, he/she may use the help of other persons, except members of Precinct Election Commission and observers. The person who helps the voter should put down his/her surname and initials and sign in the column “signature of voters on receipt of ballot paper” in the Voter List.

Every voter shall vote in person and alone. To vote in place
of other persons shall be prohibited. Ballot papers shall be marked in a room or booth where nobody is authorized to enter and equipped with special technical to ensure the secrecy of the vote. A voter with disability who is not able to mark the ballot paper without assistance may invite any other person into the voting booth or room, except members of Precinct Election Commissions or observers. The surname and initials of this person shall be indicated with the voter’s signature on receipt of the ballot paper in the Voter’s List.

voting_methods.instructions:
Overseas voters may vote in-person, by mail, or online. To vote in person, voters must go to a listed consulate or embassy on 2 June and cast their vote via a voting machine.

Voters must request a postal ballot by 31 December 2023. Ballot packets will be mailed to overseas voters in the first week of May. Ballot envelopes must be mailed back and reach Mexico by 1 June.

Overseas voters who elect to vote online will receive an email showing how to access the online voting system by 3 May 2024, and they may vote from 18 May to 2 June.

Voting by mail (within Mexico) is only available for registered voters with disabilities.

Voters must request a postal ballot by 31 December 2023.

Voters must obtain a voting credential before election day.  Voting credentials can be obtained by presenting three documents at a local INE office: a document that proves nationality (birth certificate or naturalization certificate), a photo ID (passport, driver's license, etc.), and proof of residency (lease, utility bill, paystub, etc.).  Prospective voters who do not have some or all of the required documents may bring two registered voters to vouch for the identity of the prospective voter.

government_functions.details: North Macedonia is a parliamentary republic in which legislative power rests in a unicameral parliament elected to a four-year term. Executive authority is vested in a government composed of a prime minister and ministers. The president, who has limited executive authority, is directly elected through a majoritarian system and may serve no more than two five-year terms. The 120 members of parliament (MPs) representing 6 in-country territorial constituencies are elected under a proportional representation system, using closed lists, and 3 additional MPs may be elected in elections for a single, out-of-country district.

Executive Power is vested in the Lhengye Zhungtshog which shall consist of the Ministers headed by the Prime Minister and shall protect and strengthen the sovereignty of the Kingdom, provide good governance, and ensure peace, security, well-being, and happiness of the people. The number of Ministers shall be determined by the number of Ministries required to provide efficient and good governance. The creation of an additional ministry or reduction of any ministry shall be approved by Parliament.   The Legislative Branch consists of the Druk Gyalpo (monarch), the National Council, and the National Assembly which shall ensure that the Government safeguards the interests of the nation and fulfills the aspirations of the people through public review of policies and issues, bills and other legislations and scrutiny of State functions.  The judicial authority of Bhutan is vested in the Royal Courts of Justice comprising the Supreme Court, the High Court, the Dzongkhag Court, the Dungkhag Court, and such other Courts and Tribunals as may be established from time to time by the Druk Gyalpo on the recommendation of the National Judicial Commission.  Source: Bhutan 2008 Constitution - Article 10, Sections 1 and 2, Article 20, Sections 1 and 2, Article 21, Sections 1 and 2

government_functions.details:
Portugal has a semi-presidential system.
 
Executive Branch: Headed by the Prime Minister, who is responsible for implementing laws and running the day-to-day affairs of the country. The government includes the Prime Minister, ministers, and secretaries of state.
 
Legislative Branch: the Assembly of the Republic, responsible for making laws. It consists of 230 deputies elected for four-year terms through a closed-list proportional system.
 
Judiciary Branch: Composed of the Constitutional Court, the Supreme Court, Courts of Appeal, First-Instance Courts, Administrative and Fiscal Courts, and Auditors Courts. The branch interprets and applies the law, ensuring justice is administered fairly.
 
President of the Republic: elected by direct popular vote, the President acts as a mediator and has some significant powers, including appointing the Prime Minister and other key officials.

government_functions.details: Iran has a unique system of government known as an Islamic Republic, a combination of democratic and theocratic elements, as outlined in its Constitution established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. The political structure is characterized by a dual sovereignty: the Supreme Leader, who holds the highest state authority, and the elected President, along with the Parliament. It blends aspects of a parliamentary democracy with Islamic theocracy, guided by the principles of Shia Islam.  The executive branch is headed by the President, who is elected for a four-year term and can serve a maximum of two consecutive terms. The President is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the country, including the implementation of laws, overseeing the economy, and conducting foreign policy. However, the President's powers are subject to the oversight and approval of the Supreme Leader, who is the highest-ranking religious and political authority in Iran. The Supreme Leader, appointed for life by the Assembly of Experts, holds significant influence over all branches of government, including the military and judiciary, and has the final say in matters of state and religion.  The legislative branch consists of the Islamic Consultative Assembly, or Majlis, a unicameral body whose members are elected by the public. The Majlis drafts legislation, ratifies international treaties, and approves the national budget. However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

voting_methods.instructions: No special grounds are required for voting abroad; citizens of the Republic of Uzbekistan who are outside the country can vote at polling stations located at diplomatic missions. On election day, voting at polling stations established at the diplomatic and other representative offices of the Republic of Uzbekistan in foreign countries is conducted from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM local time.

A voter who is unable to be present on election day must submit an application indicating the reason for their absence (such as vacation, business trip, travel abroad, etc.) and receive a ballot for early voting from the relevant precinct election commission. The voter will receive a ballot for early voting, fill out the ballot in the booth for secret voting, and place the completed ballot into the ballot box for early voting.

If a voter, due to health reasons or other valid circumstances, cannot arrive at the polling station, the respective precinct election commission, upon the voter's request, organizes voting at the voter's place of residence. These applications must be submitted before election day, and the voting is conducted before election day in the presence of at least two members of the precinct election commission with a portable ballot box. f a voter, due to health reasons or other valid circumstances, cannot arrive at the polling station, the respective precinct election commission, upon the voter's request, organizes voting at the voter's place of residence. These applications must be submitted before election day, and the voting is conducted before election day in the presence of at least two members of the precinct election commission with a portable ballot box.

The voter should arrive at the polling station on election day between 8:00 AM and 8:00 PM. The precinct election commission informs voters about the time and place of voting no later than ten days before the election
Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter presents a document verifying their identity to a member of the precinct election commission. The voter signs the voter list and receives a ballot.
After receiving the ballot, the voter fills it out in a booth or room for secret voting. No other persons are allowed to be present during the filling out of the ballot, except for the voter. The voter places a mark (“+”, “✓”, or “x”) in the empty square opposite the candidate's name or political party they are voting for. The completed ballot is then placed by the voter into the ballot box.

government_functions.details: In Uzbekistan, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister serves as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 7-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the majority party in the Supreme Assembly and appointed by the President.   Uzbekistan has a bicameral Supreme Assembly consisting of a 100-seat Senate and a 150-seat Legislative Chamber. Members of the Senate are indirectly elected by regional councils (84 members) or appointed by the president (16 members). All members serve 5-year terms. All 150 members of the Legislative Chamber are directly elected by absolute majority vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court and Constitutional Court are the highest judicial bodies of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Court has 67 judges, while the Constitutional Court has only 7. Judges for both institutions are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Judges may serve one term of 10 years.

All those eligible to vote will receive an electoral certificate by mail.  If the certificate is lost or damaged, voters may request a replacement by visiting the State Elections Office.  Voters must present their electoral certificate and a photo ID (national identification card, passport, etc.).  If a voter lacks photo ID, they may be admitted to vote if identified by the president of the polling place or two voters also registered at that polling place.

Voters cast both list and preferential votes.  Voters indicate the list of their preference by drawing a mark on the list name or in the rectangle surrounding it.  Voters resident in San Marino may cast a preferential vote for up to three candidates, while non-resident voters may cast a preferential vote for only one candidate.  Preferential votes are cast by writing the name and/or list number of preferred candidates on the appropriate lines in the center of the ballot.

Voters who cannot travel to polling places due to a medical condition may request to vote from home by submitting a request and a medical certificate from the state health service (ISS) to the State Elections Office at least 15 days before election day.
