government_functions.details: The political, administrative and legal systems The Constitution Austria is a democratic republic. The territory of the Federal Republic consists of nine federal states or provinces (Bundesland, Land; plural: Bundesländer, Länder). Vienna is the federal capital and the seat of the supreme federal authorities. Since 1995, Austria is a member state of the European Union.   Elections All political institutions established by the Constitution derive their powers either directly or indirectly from elections by secret, personal and equal ballot.  Austrian citizens elect  the National Assembly (Nationalrat, the people’s chamber of Parliament) – every five years the Provincial Parliament (Landtag, Parliament of a Province) – every five or six years the Municipal Council (EU citizens resident in the municipality can also vote) – every five or six years the Austrian Members of the European Parliament (citizens of other EU countries with their main residence in Austria have the right to vote) the Federal President – every six years Other instruments of democracy are the referendum or plebiscite (Volksbefragung, Volksabstimmung, Volksbegehren).  All Austrians (and some citizens of other EU member states) who reach age 16 before the appointed date can vote.  The Parliament The Austrian Parliament consists of two chambers: the National Assembly (Nationalrat) and the Federal Council (Bundesrat).  The National Assembly is the main legislative body. The preparation and implementation of legislation takes place in the Federal Government or in the Provincial Governments. Legislative tasks are carried out at federal level by the National Assembly in conjunction with the Federal Council.  The Federal Council represents the interests of the provinces in Parliament. Provincial Assemblies (Landtage) represent the interests of citizens in the individual provinces. Each federal province is administered by a Provincial Government, which is headed by a Provincial Governor (Landeshauptmann) elected by the respective Provincial Assembly.  The Federal Government One of the Federal Government’s tasks is to prepare draft legislation, which is then submitted to Parliament. The Federal Government is headed by the Federal Chancellor (Bundeskanzler) who, along with the Vice Chancellor, federal ministers and state secretaries, conducts government business.  The administration of justice The administration of justice in Austria proceeds from the federal level. Court judgments and decisions are pronounced and published in the name of the Republic. Judges are independent in the exercise of their office. Proceedings in courts of civil and criminal law are verbal and public. The final court of appeal for civil and criminal proceedings is the Supreme Court.  The judiciary is separate from the executive at all levels of jurisdiction. The police, as an executive agency, are subject to the Republic of Austria.  As in other countries, there are four levels of judicial authority in Austria: district courts (Bezirksgericht); regional courts (Landesgericht); Higher Regional Court (Oberlandesgericht); Supreme Court (Oberster Gerichtshof).  The Administrative Court (Verwaltungsgericht) deals with disputes in connection with decisions taken by the administrative authorities. The Constitutional Court (Verfassungsgericht) deals with actions against federal, provincial, regional or municipal authorities.

election_issues.issues: Economy; corruption; migration; human rights; foreign affairs; education; Law on Foreign Influence

voting_methods.instructions:
Citizens must register at the consulate or the election commission abroad no later than October 7, 2024 (19 days before the election day).The voter lists must be submitted by the Central Election Commission of Georgia (CEC) no later than October 8, 2024 (18 days before the election day). Thus, voting for Georgian citizens residing abroad will most likely take place on October 26, 2024, the same day as in Georgia. However, the exact start and end times of voting may vary depending on the country of residence and the time zone.

The main requirements are as follows:

a) Consular registration or registration in the country of residence: Georgian citizens must be registered with the consulate at the diplomatic mission or consular institution of Georgia in the country of residence, or have registration in the country of residence.

b) Additional registration for voting: If a citizen is not on the consular register and does not have registration in the country of residence, they must complete the registration process for voting no later than 19 days before Election Day.

c) Documents: To vote, a Georgian citizen ID card or passport is required.

The voting procedure is as follows:

a) Upon entering, voters are checked for marking. Unmarked voters may vote by presenting a Georgian ID card or passport, with no more than two voters at the registration table.

b) Voters present their ID at the registration table, are marked by the registrar, and sign to acknowledge receipt of the ballot(s), which are signed and stamped by the registrar.

c) Voters fill out the ballot(s) in the secret booth, then fold them to keep their vote confidential.

d) Voters place the folded ballot(s) in a special envelope at a separate table. Only the voter may handle the envelope.

e) Only one voter at a time may approach the ballot box.

f) A commission member monitors the ballot box, ensuring only one envelope is inserted.

g) After voting, the ballot box slot is sealed.

government_functions.details: The executive branch of Georgia is headed by the President, who acts as the chief of state, and the Prime Minister, who is the head of government. The President is elected by an electoral college for a five-year term, while the Prime Minister is nominated by the party that holds the majority in the Parliament and is appointed by the President. The executive branch is responsible for implementing laws, conducting foreign policy, and overseeing government administration. The legislative branch of Georgia is unicameral, consisting of the Parliament (Sakartvelos Parliament), which has 150 members. As of 2024, all 150 members are directly elected by proportional representation vote. Parties must win at least 5% of valid votes to receive a seat. Members of Parliament serve four-year terms, and the legislative branch is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the executive branch​. The judicial branch of Georgia includes the Supreme Court, the Constitutional Court, and lower courts. Judges of the Supreme Court are nominated by the High Council of Justice and appointed by the Parliament, while Constitutional Court judges are appointed by the President, Parliament, and Supreme Court judges. The judicial branch interprets laws, ensures justice, and protects the rights and freedoms of individuals.

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters living abroad must register to vote via an online portal (https://www.rinkejopuslapis.lt/ra-web/), and registration deadlines vary depending on location. Voters can opt to vote in person at one of 52 embassies or consulates or to vote by mail.

Voters must present a passport or national ID (valid or expired) to register and to cast their votes in person.

Voters who will be at least 70 years old on the day of the election, voters with disabilities, voters who care for persons with disabilities at home, or who are temporarily unable to work due to illness, will be permitted to vote from home on October 11 and 12 after filling in  the form P6 by October 9 at the latest. Voters who will be temporarily outside their constituency of residence on the early voting datys may vote from home on October 10, and they must submit form P6 by October 8.

Voters can submit requests to vote at home to precinct election commissions by phone, e-mail, or on the Voter Page portal. Voters who will vote at home will have to provide an identity document to the election organizers.

Also, voters residing in health care, social care institutions, military units, and penal institutions will be able to vote on October 9-11 at special polling places within their institutions.

Voters who will vote at a special point will have to submit an identity document to the election organizers, after voting they will receive an envelope receipt with a special stamp.
Voters who come to vote at the polling station will have to present a document confirming their personal identity to the election organizers.

Every voter who wants to vote at a polling station must first identify themselves, as a rule, by means of an identity card, passport, driver's license or any other public document with a photo, on the basis of which the identity of the voter can be established beyond doubt. If, on election day, a voter goes to vote at a polling station determined by their place of residence, and the polling committee determines that the voter is not listed in the extract from the list of voters for that polling station, the polling committee will not allow them to vote, but will refer them to the nearest administrative body of the county where can obtain a certificate for voting (the so-called blue certificate). After obtaining the voting certificate, the voter can return to their polling station, submit the voting certificate to the polling committee and exercise their right to vote.

government_functions.details: The prime minister is the head of government and the commander in chief of the armed forces. The president is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system for a 5 year-term. The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislature. The Supreme Court is the highest court in appeal. The president of the Supreme Court is nominated by the president of Croatia and elected by Croatian Sabor (parliament) for a 4-year term. Other Supreme Court justices are appointed by national judicial council with a mandatory retirement age of 70. The parliament's (Sabor) powers include enactment and amendment of the constitution and laws, adoption of the government budget, declarations of war and peace, defining national boundaries, and calling referenda and elections. The assembly has 151 members elected through a closed-list proportional representation system.

voting_methods.instructions:
Per Article 92 of the Law on Election:

"Voters residing in a foreign country shall cast their votes using a ballot paper printed by the central election authority. They shall come to the polling station and cast his/her vote in person by secretly marking inside a pooling booth the name of a candidate he/she supports on a ballot paper according to the instructions on the ballot paper. They shall then insert the ballot paper in the vote counting equipment (ballot box) after marking and leave the polling station immediately."

Per Article 64 Law on the State Great Hulan (Parliament) Election of Mongolia: 

"64.1. A voter to vote through a sealed mobile ballot box shall mark his/her vote by secret ballot in a mobile voting booth and put it in an envelope.

64.2. The ballot paper put into an envelope shall be put into the sealed mobile ballot box.

64.3. It is prohibited to open sealed mobile ballot boxes until the election day, until the start of the polling of voters.

64.4. The procedures for casting a vote in a polling station indicated in Article 65 of this law shall be enforced unless otherwise provided in this Law."

Article 66, Law on the State Great Hulan (Parliament) Election of Mongolia states:

"66.1. A voter shall come to the polling station with their citizen identification card and cast his/her vote in person.

66.2. The voter shall make a mark according to the instructions written on the ballot paper to cast his/her vote.

66.3. The voter shall mark his/her vote by secret ballot in a voting booth.

66.4. The voter shall use a folder to keep the secrecy of his/her vote after marking his/her vote and shall put the ballot paper in the vote counting machine /ballot box/.

66.5. A voter shall leave the polling station after putting the ballot paper on which he/she marked his/her vote in the vote counting machine /ballot box."

The judicial system consists of the Supreme Court, provincial and capital city courts, Region, inter-region, and district courts. Supreme Court judges are nominated by a Judicial General Council but then confirmed and appointed by the president.

Otherwise, a second round is held two weeks later featuring the top two candidates from the first round.

If you have not lost your citizenship of the Republic of Lithuania, but do not have a valid identity document, you can register and vote with an expired passport or identity card of the Republic of Lithuania.

Voters who are temporarily staying in the territory of a specific electoral district and are not included in the list of voters of this electoral district will vote at home on May 9. from 8 to 20 hours.
Voters can submit requests to vote at home to precinct election commissions by phone, e-mail, or on the Voter Page portal. Precinct election commissions start accepting applications by delivering election notices to voters and end on May 8. Requests to vote at home from voters who have temporarily stayed in the territory of a specific electoral district and are not included in the list of voters of that district will end on May 7. Voters who will vote at home will have to provide an identity document to the election organizers.
Voters who come to vote at the polling station will have to present a document confirming their personal identity to the election organizers.

government_functions.details: Lithuania is a parliamentary democracy and a decentralised unitary state. The Lithuanian Parliament is called the Seimas. The 141 members of the Seimas are elected by a mixed system: 71 members are elected in single-member constituencies using a two-round system, and the other 70 members are elected in multi-member constituencies using a proportional representation system. All members serve 4-year terms, and there are no term limits. The Prime Minister serves as the head of government and is nominated by the President and confirmed by the Seimas.  The President serves as the head of state and is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.

The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

The President of Liberia is both the head of state and government. The President is elected  to serve a six-year term and can serve up to two terms.  Liberia has a bicameral legislative system, which consists of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate has 30 members, two from each county, who are elected to serve nine-year terms. The House of Representatives has 73 members, who are elected to serve six-year terms.  The judicial branch is headed by the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country. Other courts include circuit courts, magistrate courts, and special courts.

government_functions.details:
The executive branch is vested with the authority to implement and administer the laws of the country. It is headed by the Governor-General, who exercises executive powers on behalf of the Head of State. The executive branch includes the Prime Minister, the Cabinet, and various government departments and officials such as the Attorney-General and the Commissioner of Police. The Cabinet, led by the Prime Minister, is responsible for policy-making and administration of government affairs. (Constitution, Ch. 5, Sec. 30-45)

The legislature, or the National Parliament, is responsible for enacting laws and consists of members elected by the people. The Parliament has the power to make laws, and its composition, qualifications for membership, and electoral processes are specified in the Constitution (Constitution, Ch. 6, Sec. 46-58)​​.

The judiciary is the branch responsible for interpreting the law and administering justice. It comprises the High Court, the Court of Appeal, and subordinate courts. The judiciary has jurisdiction over constitutional questions and ensures that the law is applied fairly and impartially. The Constitution also provides for the appointment and tenure of judges, as well as the establishment of rules of court (Constitution, Chapter 6, Sec. 77-95)

The President of the Maldives serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and serves up to two 5-year terms.   The Maldives has a unicameral legislature: the People's Assembly. All 87 members are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Maldivian judiciary. The Supreme Court is composed of 7 justices who are nominated by the President and confirmed by the People's Assembly. Justices may serve until age 70.

voting_methods.instructions:
An overseas elector is a person who is a citizen of India and who has not acquired citizenship of any other country and is otherwise eligible to be registered as a voter and who is absenting from his place of ordinary residence in India owing to his employment, education or otherwise is eligible to be registered as a voter in the constituency in which his place of residence in India as mentioned in his passport is located. According to the provisions of Section 20A of the Representation of People Act, 1950, an NRI settled in foreign land can become an elector in electoral roll in India.

Non-resident Indians (NRIs), who are citizens of India but reside overseas for employment, education, or other reasons, are eligible to register as voters in Lok Sabha elections. The process for these overseas electors to vote is outlined in Section 20A of the Representation of People Act, 1950 and The Representation of the People (Amendment) Act, 2010. The NRI must be an Indian citizen, must not have acquired citizenship of any other country, and must have an ordinary residence in India as per their passport. The NRI needs to file an application in Form 6A to register as a voter. This form is submitted to the Electoral Registration Officer / Assistant Electoral Registration Officer of the constituency where their residence in India (as per the passport) is located. Once the application is processed and approved, the NRI is registered as a voter in the electoral roll of the constituency linked to their place of residence in India.
This process enables NRIs to vote. They can vote by proxy or postal ballot.

After application for a postal ballot several days in advance, and receipt of the ballot, the voter must record his vote, make his declarations in accordance with the instruction communicated to him and ensure that his ballot reeach the returning officer before the the hour fixed for the commencement of counting of votes.

Voters who wish to vote by post, including special voters, those on election duty, and those under preventive detention, must follow specific procedures to obtain a postal ballot paper. Special voters must send a Form 12 to the returning officer at least ten days before the poll date. Election duty voters should send Form 12 for postal voting at least seven days before, or a shorter period if allowed. Electors under preventive detention need to send an intimation within fifteen days of an election call, including their details and place of detention, for a postal ballot. The returning officer issues postal ballots upon receipt and verification of these intimations.

The law refers to early voters as (a) special voters; (b) service voters; (c) voters on election duty; and (d) electors subjected to preventive detention. If voting in person, special voters must send Form 12A at least four days before the poll, leading to the issuance of an election duty certificate (Form 12B) and a marking of 'EDC' against their name in the electoral roll.

Every voter issued a ballot under these rules must keep their vote secret and follow these steps: After receiving the ballot, the voter should immediately go to a voting compartment, mark the ballot near their chosen candidate's symbol using the provided instrument, fold the ballot to hide their vote, and, if needed, show the presiding officer the unique mark on the ballot. Then, they should place the folded ballot in the ballot box and leave the polling station promptly. Voters must vote without delay and cannot enter a voting compartment if it's already occupied.

voting_methods.instructions:
Any elector can vote by post outside the Slovak Republic.

By-mail voting is for a voter who does not have permanent residence in the Slovak Republic and who was on request entered on a special list of registered voters and a voter who has permanent residence in the Slovak Republic, but at the time of the election is residing outside its territory and who, based on a request, was entered on a special list of voters.

The Ministry of Interior facilitates postal voting that is available to voters permanently or temporarily abroad. Those wishing to vote by post file a request - electronically or in paper form - at least 52 days before election day. Postal voting applications must include proof of identity. The Ministry of Interior maintains a special voter register of postal voters, dispatches the ballots (not later than 40 days before the election day), and distributes returning envelopes with ballots to the respective special electoral precincts (up to 4,000 voters each) formed by the Ministry of Interior to handle returned overseas postal votes. Voters who applied electronically to vote by post are delivered the postal voting package electronically (by e-mail) and those who applied in paper form to vote by post are mailed out the postal voting package to their address abroad. Voters who are registered to postal vote, receive by post the voting envelope, a returnable envelope and instructions on the method of voting to their address abroad. Those voters who applied electronically are to print the ballot paper published on the website of the Ministry of Interior which he/she is to use for voting. Voters who applied in paper form receive a paper ballot with the other voting package materials. On one ballot, a voter marks which one of the candidates he/she prefers by circling the candidate's ordinal number. Any voter who spoils their postal ballot that was sent to him/her in paper form may print a new ballot from the website of the Ministry of Interior. The voter places the marked ballot in the voting envelope and places the sealed voting envelope in the official returnable envelope, which he/she sends to the Ministry of Interior. The return envelope is marked "Vote by Mail" and has the address of the Home Office as the addressee, the voter's address as the sender and a unique identification code. The voter pays the postage. To prevent multiple voting, voters with permanent residence in Slovakia (i.e. temporarily outside of Slovakia) who have voted by post are deleted from the voter lists, upon notification by the Ministry of Interior to the relevant municipality. Postal ballots must be received by 12:00 on the day before the election in order to be counted. The Ministry of Interior dispatches the postal ballots to the special electoral precinct commissions, which determine the results of postal voting on the day of the election starting at 6:00 pm.

An elector may vote at the polling district on whose list of voters he or she is registered. Voters can apply to their municipality before election day for an absentee voting certificate that allows them to be registered and to vote in any polling district in the country if they will be unable to vote in the polling district where they are registered. Upon issuing the absentee certificate the voter is deleted from the voter list of their own polling district. Proxy voting is not allowed. Electors are to vote in the order that they arrived to the polling station. At the polling station, the voter must present his or her identity card. The set of ballot papers with an empty envelope are given to the voter who signs the voter list before voting. The poll worker circles the consecutive number of the voter in the list. If the voter is not on the voter list but is at the polling station of his or her residence, he or she is to be added to the voter list. Voters are obliged to proceed to the polling booth to vote in secret. The voter votes for one candidate by circling the ordinal number of the candidate listed on the ballot paper. Replacement of a spoilt ballot paper is allowed; the voter places the spoiled ballot in the box for the unused ballots. The marked ballot is inserted in the envelope by the voter which is then placed by the voter in the ballot box. Physically disabled voters or voters who cannot read or write can be assisted by another voter (not by commission members) to mark the ballot, put it in the envelope and insert it in the ballot box. Both of these electors are to be instructed on the voting and warned about the offense of electoral corruption. Mobile voting at homes and institutions for health reasons is available, in which case secrecy of the vote is guaranteed.

government_functions.details:
Executive power is exercised by the government led by the Prime Minister. The President is the head of state and the formal head of the executive, though with very limited powers. The president is elected by direct popular vote, under a two-round system, for a five-year term.

The members of the 150-seat parliament (National Council) are elected for a four-year term under a proportional representation system, within a single nationwide constituency, with a 5% threshold for parties, 7% for coalitions of two or three parties, and 10% for coalitions of more than four parties. Following National Council elections, the leader of the majority party or coalition is usually appointed prime minister by the president.

The Supreme Court is the country's highest appellate court, the judges of which are elected by the National Council; below that are regional, district, and military courts. The Constitutional Court rules on constitutional issues; its 13 members are appointed by the president from a slate of candidates nominated by the parliament. The 18-member Judicial Council nominates common court judges and is responsible for appointing a disciplinary committee in cases of judicial misconduct.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The president is directly elected in a single nationwide constituency for a six-year period. If no candidate receives more than 50 per cent of the votes cast, a second round takes place 21 days after the first round, between the two candidates who received the highest number of votes.  The candidate who receives the most votes in the second round is declared the winner.

institution.term_details: Under the 2020 constitutional reforms, the two consecutive term limit was changed to two terms overall.  However, the amendment reset the term-limit clock for the incumbent president, who is now eligible to seek two more six-year terms as president after his current term expires.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1993 Constitution Article 60; 2003 Law on Presidential Elections, Article 3(1); 2002 Law on Basic Guarantees of Electoral Rights, Article 14(1)

voting_methods.instructions:
The election law provides that at polling stations established outside the territory of the Russian Federation, the start and end times of voting and its duration are determined in accordance with federal law. In addition, amendments in November 2023 granted embassies and consulates the power to change the times and dates of the out-of-country voting, for public health reasons. Further, the election law provides that the Central Election Commission can make a decision to hold voting in the out-of-country polling stations ahead of schedule but not earlier than 15 days before the election day. 

Polling stations for out-of-country voters are formed by the heads of diplomatic missions or consular offices in the territories of their country of residence. Taking into account the local conditions, information about the establishment of such polling stations is to be published. Precinct commissions formed at polling stations established outside the territory of the Russian Federation have the right to compile a list of voters before election day - based on written requests of eligible voters, and on election day - based on oral appeals from citizens of the Russian Federation who have come to the precinct commission, permanently residing outside the territory of the Russian Federation or on long-term business trips abroad. Only voters who did not have an opportunity to vote early inside the territory of the Russian Federation are entitled to be included on the list of voters at the respective embassy or consulate and to vote abroad. The manner and procedure of in-person voting at out-of-country polling stations is the same as for in-person voting within the territory of the Russian Federation.

Voters vote at a designated polling station in their locality of residence.  Voters who will be outside their locality of residence on election day can apply in advance to vote at a polling station in their temporary location. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. Proxy voting is prohibited. Ballot papers are issued to voters included in the voter list upon presentation of an internal passport or document that replaces a citizen's passport. Before issuing the ballot paper to a voter, the precinct election commission is obliged to check that the voter has not already voted early (for example, by portable ballot box in remote areas) or by mobile (homebound) voting. A voter who is not on the voter list for any reason can be registered on election day, upon showing a passport or other proof of residence at the polling station. Upon receipt of the ballot, the identification document number of the voter is to be entered into the voter list. The voter checks the accuracy of the entry made and both the voter and the poll worker sign the voter list in the column next to the voter's name. The voter should enter the polling booth (or other specially equipped place for secret voting) to mark the ballot. Voters should vote alone, except a voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot can request assistance of another person who is not a poll worker, partisan representative, or observer. The voter using assistance must notify the precinct election commission and the personal details of the helper are to be entered in the voter list in the column next to the voter's name. Using any mark, the voter marks the ballot with any sign in the box relating to the candidate in whose favor the choice was made, or in the case of only one candidate on the ballot, to the position "For" or "Against". A voter who spoils a ballot can receive a replacement one from the poll worker, who records the issuance of a replacement ballot in the voter list next to the voter's name and signs the entry along with the secretary of the precinct election commission. The voters put the marked ballot into the sealed ballot box. If the Central Election Commission makes a decision to use ballot envelopes, the voter is to place the marked ballot into the envelope given to him/her by the poll worker after leaving the polling booth, and places the envelope in the ballot box. Electronic voting and counting machines may be available at polling stations.   Mobile (homebound) voting is available, upon advance application, for voters who, due to health reasons, disability, caring for a person in need, or other reasons, cannot go to the polling station. The Central Election Commission may decide to carry out voting outside the designated polling stations, including in public areas, for public health reasons and to facilitate voting, in the manner and within an established time frame set by the commission, not earlier than seven days before election day (however, this option does not apply if multiple-day voting is used).

Since May 2020, the election law provides for the possibility of the Central Election Commission establishing the option, with procedures and times, of voting by internet. The Internet voting system was first used for the 2019 Moscow City  Duma election and then nationwide for the 2020 constitutional referendum. 

Voters seeking to vote online must register by 11 March via the "Mobile Voter" (Мобильный избиратель) online registration system. Online voting will be available across 28 regions of the country.

A May 2020 amendment to the election law provides for the possiblity of the Central Election Commission establishing the option, with procedures, of voting by mail. However, it is not known whether postal voting will be used in the 2024 elections.

The election law provides for several possibilities for early voting to be implemented, but if the Central Election Commission decides to hold a multi-day election (up to three days), then some of these types of potential early voting cannot be implemented. Firstly, by decision of the respective election commission, early voting  (but not earlier than 20 days before election day) can be implemented for voters registered at one or several polling stations formed in hard-to-reach or remote areas, on ships that will be at sea on the voting day, and at polar stations. In addition, any voter who for a good reason (vacation, business trip, work, and educational activities, performance of state and public duties, state of health, and other valid reasons) will be absent from his/her place of residence and will not be able to arrive at the polling station where he/she is included on the list of voters must be given the opportunity to vote early but no earlier than 10 days before election day. With respect to the latter category, the voter who wishes to vote early must submit an application and indicate the reason for the need to vote early. However, the legislation does not require the voter to show proof of the reason for the absence on election day.

government_functions.details: The Russian Federation is defined as a federal semi-presidential republic. The President of Russia is the head of state and there is a multi-party system with executive power exercised by the government, headed by the Prime Minister, who is appointed by the President with parliament's approval. The government consists of the Prime Minister, deputy prime ministers, and federal ministers and their ministries and departments. The Prime Minister submits to the President nominations for all subordinate Government positions, including deputy prime ministers, and federal ministers.  The President is directly elected under a two-round system in a single nationwide constituency for a six-year period.  Legislative power is vested in the two houses of the Federal Assembly. The 450 members of the lower house - State Duma - are elected  for a term of five years, with parallel voting. Half of the seats (225) are elected by closed party-list proportional representation within a single nationwide constituency, with a five per cent electoral threshold, with the other half elected in 225 single-member constitutencies by first-past-the-post voting.  Regional assemblies with their respective deputies are formed through this system. The upper chamber - Federation Council - is not directly elected; each of the 85 federal subjects of Russia (oblasts, republics, autonomous territories, and autonomous okrugs) sends two delegates to the Federal Council, for a total of 170 members.  The judiciary of Russia is topped by the Constitutional Court, Supreme Court, and Supreme Court of Arbitration.  The judiciary is governed by the All-Russian Congress of Judges and its Council of Judges.

government_functions.details: Executive power of the federal government is vested in the president, assisted by three vice presidents. The president serves as head of state and government and is directly elected in nationwide elections to serve a five-year term, renewable once. Each vice president serves a five-year term and represents one of the three islands.   The unicameral legislature consists of the Assembly of the Union; members are elected to five-year terms. Slightly more than half the members are directly elected, with the remainder selected by the islands’ local governments.   Changes brought about by the 2001 constitution granted the three main islands partial autonomy, and each elects its own governor and legislative assembly. The government of each island is free to administer its own affairs so long as its actions do not infringe upon the rights of the other islands or otherwise threaten the state of the federal union.

voting_methods.instructions: In the period of early voting, on a daily basis after termination of the voting, the chairperson or deputy chair of the precinct commission glues a sheet of paper on the slot of the ballot box, and signatures of the chair, deputy, and a member of the commission are put on the sheet. At the start of each early voting day the slot is opened in front of observers and media. The ballot box is kept secure by the chair throughout the early voting period. On each day of early voting a protocol is filled out by the precinct commission to account for all ballots; the protocol is put up for general familarization in the premises of the precinct commissions. When receiving the ballot in early voting, voters must sign the voter list and enter the day of the early voting. The voting procedures are the same as for election day. Early voting is not held in the voting precincts formed in health care facilities.

Voters are registered at the polling station of their place of residence. At the polling station, voters must submit their internal passport or other document determined by the Central Election Commission. If the voter is on the voter list they are given a ballot and then sign the relevant line on the voter list; if they are not on the voter list but can provide proof of residence, they can be added to the voter list of the respective polling station. Voters mark their ballot in secret in a polling booth or room, with ballot boxes placed so that the voters approach them only through the booths or premises assigned for secret voting. The voter puts any sign in an empty square placed on the right of the surname of the candidate he or she votes for. Ballots have the option of "against all". Proxy voting is prohibited and voters must personally mark their ballots. Another person can assist voters who are unable to personally mark the ballot, at the voter's discretion (election commission members, candidates or their representatives, political party representatives, elected officials, foreign observers or media representatives cannot assist voters). The voter places the completed ballot in the ballot box. Voters who spoil ballots can receive one new ballot; the voter  must sign the spoilt ballot and the poll worker cancels the spoiled ballot and makes a notation of such next to the name of the voter on the voter list.

government_functions.details: Belarus is a presidential republic with a bicameral parliament. The President of Belarus, elected for a five-year term, is the head of state and Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. The president is directly elected by an absolute majority of the votes cast (if not, a second round is held) and if more than half of the registered voters have taken part in the voting (if not, a new election is held). Executive power is nominally exercised by the government, at its top sits a ceremonial prime minister, appointed directly by the President.  Legislative power is de jure vested in the bicameral parliament, the National Assembly. The 110 members of the lower House of Representatives are directly elected for five-year terms under a majoritarian system in single-member constituencies. The Council of the Republic is the upper chamber of territorial representation, its members elected at meetings of the local councils of deputies and the City of Minsk, plus eight members appointed by the President of the Republic.  The Constitutional Court is the highest court in Belarus which deals with matters involving the Constitution and legality of certain laws passed by the government. The Supreme Court is the highest court of general jurisdiction that deals with matters of civil and criminal law.

voting_methods.instructions:
Accepted reasons for voting by mail are stated by law are: when voters are appointed for the performance of any duty in connection with an election at a polling station other than the one at which they are entitled to cast their votes; Bangladeshi voters who are living abroad.

A qualified voter may apply to the Returning Officer of the constituency in which he or she is an elector specifying his/her name, address, and serial number in the electoral roll. Upon receipt of application, the Returning Officer shall immediately send by post a ballot paper and an envelope bearing on its face a form of certificate of posting, showing the date thereof, which must be filled in by the proper official of the Post Office at the time of posting by the elector. The voter upon receipt of ballot paper must cast his or her vote in the manner prescribed by law and post without delay the ballot containing his/her vote insider the envelope mentioned above to the Returning Officer.

Upon receipt of ballot paper, voter must proceed to the place reserved for voting and put the prescribed mark on the ballot paper at the prescribed space corresponding to the name and symbol of the contesting candidate for whom he wishes to vote. After marking his or her ballot paper, he or she must fold the ballot paper and insert it in the ballot box and leave the polling station without undue delay.

government_functions.details: Bangladesh is a multi-party parliamentary democracy with a non-executive president. The prime minister has executive power and leads a cabinet of ministers, which is collectively responsible to the Parliament. The role of the president is ceremonial, and she or he is elected by members of Parliament.  The national parliament, or Jatiyo Sangshad, consists of 350 members, 300 of which are directly elected through a national election for a five-year term in single-seat constituencies while 50 memberships are reserved for the women who are selected by the ruling party or coalition. The president has the power to dissolve the Parliament.

government_functions.details: Taiwan has a semi-presidential system, with a president as the head of state and a premier as the head of government. The president is elected directly by the people for a four-year term, and the premier is appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan, the unicameral parliament.  The Executive Yuan, also known as the Cabinet, is the executive branch of the government. It is responsible for carrying out the policies and decisions made by the president and premier. The Executive Yuan is headed by the premier, who is assisted by a vice premier and a number of ministers.  The Legislative Yuan is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the activities of the government. It has 113 members, who are elected from single-member districts (73), multimember constituencies by single nontransferable voting, exclusively for people with indigenous status (6) and party-list proportional representation (34).  The Judicial Yuan is the judicial branch of the government. It is responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that it is applied fairly.

voting_methods.instructions:
Every Egyptian residing abroad shall have the right to cast his/her vote in election or referendums as long as his/her name is registered in the Voter Database and he/she hold a National Identity Card or valid passport indicating the National Identity Number.

The voter should go to the nearby embassy or consulate in the country where he/she lives and present the national ID card or valid passport to make sure that he/she is registered in the voter database. The registered voter will get a ballot paper in which he/she will select the preferred candidate before signing in the electoral roll.

The electoral domicile is the place of residence shown on the national ID card. Voting shall be made by marking the ballot paper prepared for this purpose. The polling Stations chairperson shall hand each voter an open ballot paper bearing on its back side the PEC’s seal and the election date. The voter shall then proceed to one of the voting booths inside the polling station to mark her/his choice. The voter shall then fold the ballot paper and deposit it inside the ballot box. The voter shall then sign or stamp her/his thump against her/his name on the voters’ list, and shall immerse her/his finger into the indelible ink that is not removable before no less than 48 hours.

electoral_rights.source: Law on the Regulation of the Exercise of Political Rights 2014. Chapter 5 on the Regulation of Referendum and Election Processes, Art. 44 Casting of Votes. ; Law on the Regulation of the Exercise of Political Rights 2014. Chapter 1. Right to Vote. Article 2.

government_functions.details: Egypt's government is divided into three branches: the executive, the legislative, and the judicial. The executive branch is headed by the president, who is the head of state and the supreme commander of the armed forces. The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term and can be re-elected once. The president appoints the prime minister, who forms the government and chairs the cabinet of ministers. The cabinet is responsible for carrying out the day-to-day business of government.   The legislative branch  is a unicameral body called the House of Representatives. It is composed of is composed of no less than four hundred and fifty members elected by direct secret public ballot. At least one quarter of the seats shall be allocated to women. The President of the Republic may appoint a number of members that does not exceed 5%. The primary functions of the House of Representatives include the drafting and approval of legislation, oversight of the executive branch, and the ratification of international treaties and agreements. The House also has the power to grant a vote of confidence to the Prime Minister and the Cabinet, and it plays a key role in fiscal matters, including the approval of the state budget and economic policies.  The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislative branches. It is headed by the Supreme Constitutional Court, which has exclusive authority to decide on the constitutionality of laws and regulations, interpret legislative texts, and adjudicate in disputes pertaining to the affairs of its members, in disputes between judicial bodies and entities that have judicial mandate, in disputes pertaining to the implementation of two final contradictory rulings, one of which is issued by any judicial body or an agency with judicial mandate and the other issued by another body, and in disputes pertaining to the implementation of its rulings and decisions.  However, each judicial body or organization manages ts own affairs and have to be consulted concerning the draft laws regulating its affairs. Each of them has andependent budget. The President  appoints  the heads of the judicial bodies or organizations.

voting_methods.instructions:
Out of country voting is allowed via proxy voting. The form states that the following are sufficient grounds - Illness, working away, on a course, holiday (give details). The absentee voter has to comply with the requirements and steps for voting via proxy.

A ballot paper marked with the official mark shall be delivered to the proxy voter, who must proceed into one of the compartments in the polling station,  and there secretly mark the ballot paper and fold it up so as to conceal the vote, and shall then show to the presiding officer the back of the paper, so as to disclose the official mark, and put the ballot paper so folded up into the ballot box in the presence of the presiding officer. The proxy shall immediately leave the polling station after he or she has put the ballot paper into the ballot box.

There is no specific start and end date. Voter can  download the postal vote application form to request for ballot. This form has to be sent to the Returning Officer to arrive by noon on Wednesday 4th October 2023. The  voter must make sure that there is enough time to receive and return the ballot so that it arrives back by 10 pm on 12 October 2023.

Voters must fill in the postal vote application form, which can be downloaded from the internet.

A ballot paper marked with the official mark shall be delivered to a voter or to a proxy voter, who must proceed into one of the compartments in the polling station,  and there secretly mark the ballot paper and fold it up so as to conceal the vote, and shall then show to the presiding officer the back of the paper, so as to disclose the official mark, and put the ballot paper so folded up into the ballot box in the presence of the presiding officer. Voter or proxy shall immediately leave the polling station after he or she has put the ballot paper into the ballot box.

government_functions.details: The President of Liberia is both the head of state and government. The President is elected  to serve a six-year term and can serve up to two terms.  Liberia has a bicameral legislative system, which consists of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate has 30 members, two from each county, who are elected to serve nine-year terms. The House of Representatives has 73 members, who are elected to serve six-year terms.  The judicial branch is headed by the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country. Other courts include circuit courts, magistrate courts, and special courts.

The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

voting_methods.instructions: PART XIV  POSTAL VOTING  [Part XIV (sections 71 – 80) substituted by Act 3 of 2012]  71 Interpretation in Part XIV  The reference in section 73(2)(b)(ii) to a “letter” includes a reference to a letter sent by way of elec- tronic mail, under the following conditions—      (a)  thesender(thatis,thepersonreferredtoin73(2)(b)(ii)(A)or(B)andrecipient(thatis,theappli- cant for a postal vote) must both use official electronic mail addresses; and      (b)  theelectronicmailsentbysendermustbeauthenticatedbytheelectronicsignatureofthesender; and      (c)  theelectronicmailmustbeembodiedinahardcopyprintedbytherecipient,whichcopyshallbe the “letter” referred to in 73(2)(b)(ii).     72 Personswhomayvotebypost  Where an election is to be held in a constituency, a person who is registered as a voter on the roll for that constituency shall be entitled to vote by post in terms of this Part if, on all polling days in the election, he or she will be—      (a)  on duty as a member of a disciplined force or as an electoral officer; or      (b)  on duty in the service of the Government outside Zimbabwe; or      (c)  outside Zimbabwe as the spouse of a person referred to in paragraph (b);     and so unable to vote at a polling station in the constituency.  For cut offs, see articles 73-79 Electoral Act

57 Manner of voting  The voting at an election shall be by ballot which shall be conducted in substance and as nearly as pos- sible in the following manner—      (a)  every ballot paper shall be in the form prescribed and there shall be printed on every ballot pa- per—         (i)  in type of equal size, the names of all the duly nominated candidates at the election in alphabetical order of surnames; and         (ii)  the symbols, if any, specified by the duly nominated candidates at the election in terms of paragraph (b) of subsection (1) of section forty-six, each printed to a size that permits the vertical extremities or the horizontal extremities or both such extremities to touch oppo- site sides of the appropriate square on the ballot paper; and         (iii)  in capital letters of equal size, the abbreviation of every political party for which a duly nominated candidate at the election is standing or which is sponsoring such a candidate, where the candidate concerned specified the abbreviation in his or her nomination paper in terms of paragraph (c) of subsection (1) of section forty-six; and         (iv)  a passport-sized photograph of the candidate; and [Subparagraph amended by Act 17 of 2007]         (v)  such other particulars as may be prescribed;           (b)  beforetheballotpaperishandedtotheapplicant,thepresidingofficershallmarktheballotpaper   with the official mark;      (c)  when the person claiming the vote has received the ballot paper he or she shall—         (i)  take the paper to the compartment provided for the purpose; and         (ii)  then signify the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote by secretly placing a cross    in the rectangle opposite the name of that candidate or, if there is more than one such rec-    tangle, in the rectangle nearest to the right-hand side of the ballot paper; and         (iii)  then fold the ballot paper so that the official mark is visible and the names of the candi- dates and the cross made by him or her are not visible and drop the ballot paper in the bal-    lot box placed in front of the presiding officer:   Provided that, if he or she has spoilt the ballot paper, he or she may return it to the    presiding officer in terms of section fifty-eight and shall deal with the second ballot paper given to him or her in accordance with this paragraph.

government_functions.details: The head of state and government is the president, who is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The president can serve no more than two 5-year terms. The president is assisted by two vice presidents.  The parliament consists of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly normally has 210 members, all of whom are directly elected. For the first two parliaments elected after the promulgation of the 2013 constitution, however, the National Assembly has 270 seats, with the 60 additional seats reserved for women—6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status—elected through a system of proportional representation. The Senate comprises 80 members: 60 (6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status) elected by a party-list system of proportional representation, with men and women being listed alternately on every list; 16 traditional chiefs elected by the provincial assemblies of chiefs in the 8 provinces; 2 seats for the president and deputy president of the National Council of Chiefs (the administrative body of traditional chiefs); and 2 representatives of people with disabilities. All parliament members serve five-year terms.  The highest courts of the Zimbabwean judiciary are the Supreme Court (5 judges) and Constitutional Court (7 judges). Supreme Court judges may serve until age 70, while Constitutional Court judges serve a single 15-year term.  Judges from both courts are appointed by the President.

Brussels is, together with Luxembourg City and Strasbourg, one of the three official seats of the European institutions.

government_functions.details: The Parliament is composed of representatives of the Union's citizens who are directly elected every five years. They shall not exceed 750 in number, plus the President (currently there are 705 representatives which has increased to 720 for the 2024 elections). Representation of citizens shall be degressively proportional, with a minimum of six members and a maximum 96 members per State. The members must be elected  by either proportional list representation, with closed or open lists, or by single-transferable vote, which varies among the Member States. The Parliament, (equally) together with the Council of the European Union, which is composed of 27 national ministers (one per Member State) adopts European legislation, following a proposal by the European Commission (the executive).  The European Commission serves as the executive branch of the Union, accountable to Parliament. In particular, Parliament can decide whether or not to approve (by simple majority) the European Council's nominee for President of the Commission, and is further mandated with approving (or rejecting) the appointment of the Commission as a whole (the Commissioners are proposed by the President). The Parliament can subsequently force the current Commission to resign by adopting (by two-thirds majority) a motion of censure.  The Court of Justice of the European Union ensures the uniform application and interpretation of European law and has the power to decide legal disputes between member states, the institutions, businesses and individuals.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting overseas is foreseen in the general section of early voting. Early voting outside Iceland shall take place at the office of an Icelandic embassy, the office of an Icelandic consulate or the office of an Icelandic honorary consul, as further decided by the minister with the portfolio for foreign affairs. The same minister may also decide that voting shall take place at other overseas locations. The minister with the portfolio for foreign affairs shall advertise where and when overseas voting may take place and shall also notify the National Electoral Commission thereof.

In cases of absentee voting before election day, that ballot before election day is empty. If voting by mail before election day, the voter uses a blank ballot that does not have printed candidate names. The voter writes or stamps the name of the presidential candidate he/she votes for on the ballot. The letter accompanying the ballot contains information on the voter and where the ballot shall be sent. It must be signed by the voter and the election officer. The voter is responsible for sending the ballot to the right place. The letter can be posted, or it can be handed to someone who the voter entrusts with the task of bringing it to the right place. Up to election day, the election officer is obligated, if the voter so wishes, to post the letter.

In general, no excuse is required because the Elections Act foresees that voters who are unable to attend a polling session on polling day may cast their votes prior to the poll. With regard to scenarios that apply for early voting, the Elections Act explains that early voting may take place at health care and old-age care home premises, institutions for people with disabilities and prisons for voters residing there. Early voting may also take place at a  district commissioner’s head office, office or branch. Early voting outside Iceland shall take place at the office of an Icelandic embassy, the office of an Icelandic consulate or the office of an Icelandic honorary consul, as further decided by the minister with the portfolio for foreign affairs.

A voter wishing to cast a ballot in early voting shall identify him- or herself to the presiding officer by producing a personal identification document bearing the voter’s name, personal identification number and photograph, such as a passport, driving licence or identity card, or by other means deemed satisfactory by the presiding officer. The presiding officer shall make a mark in the electoral register indicating who is casting a vote at the presiding officer’s station.
Following the recording thereof, the voter shall be given the voting materials. The voter shall then, without assistance and without anyone seeing, write his or her vote on the ballot paper.
The voter shall then place the ballot in the ballot envelope and carefully glue the top flap together. Next, the voter shall address and sign the covering letter in the presence of the presiding officer, who shall witness the casting of the vote by signing the covering letter and, if applicable, stamp it with an official seal.
Voters are entitled to be assisted when casting their ballots. Such assistance shall be provided by the presiding officer or an assistant accompanying the voter to the polling station. Assistance shall only be given if the voter him- or herself can tell the person providing the assistance how the voter wishes to cast the ballot. The voter’s assistant must abide by the instructions of the voter and shall be bound by a duty of confidentiality not to disclose what passes between the assistant and the voter in the polling booth. A candidate or a candidate’s spouse, children, siblings and parents are not permitted to assist with voting. A voter’s assistant is not permitted to become an assistant to more than three voters in the same poll.
Finally, the ballot paper envelope together with the covering letter shall be placed inside the sending envelope, which shall then be carefully closed. The envelope shall then be addressed to the electoral commission in the municipality where the voter believes he or she is registered on the electoral register. The voter’s personal identification number shall be written on the back of the postal envelope. Instead of a personal identification number, a special label containing the voter’s personal identification number may be placed on the envelope.

The Election Board receives the voter and requests their address and identification, such as a driver license or passport, but the voter can also identify him/herself in another adequate manner acceptable to the Election Board. A digital driver´s license can be presented. The Election Board marks the voter on the Election Register and provides a ballot. The voter takes the ballot to the voting booth. In the voting booth the voter marks an X with a writing instrument into a box before the choice he/she wishes to make. Cards with braille are made available to read and mark on the ballot. Once the voter has voted, they fold their ballot, leave the voting booth, and insert the ballot into the ballot box outside the booth.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is elected by direct, secret ballot, by those who have the right to vote in parliamentary elections. The President is the Head of State. The Executive Power is exercised by the Government.  However, the Legislative Power is vested in both the Parliament and the President. The Legislative Power is comprised through 63 representatives through six constituencies elected through proportional representation in elections celebrated every four years.  The Judicial Power lies in the Supreme Court, Court of Appeal and district courts. The Judiciary is indepndent of the Executive and the Legislative. The Supreme Court of Iceland shall be composed of seven judges, commisioned for an indefinite period of time by the President of Iceland as proposed by the Minister of Justice.

voting_methods.instructions:
The requirements to be eligible for voting early/online are:
1. Be over 18 years of age and have a personal identity card, or be a minor with a youth card, who will come of age until May 5, 2024. At the time of registration, the card may have expired or in the process of renovation.
2. In the case of adults, at the time of registration they must be in full enjoyment of civil and political rights.
3. Have a personal email account.
4. Citizens who reside abroad and those who anticipate that they will be abroad on the day of the general elections or popular consultations, and those who are on duty in the Public Force, in the Public Ministry and the Judicial Branch, in the Benemérito Corps of Firefighters of the Republic of Panama, in the National Civil Protection System, the Panamanian Red Cross, medical and nursing personnel, as well as press photographers, television cameramen and journalists, electoral delegates and Court servants Electoral and the General Electoral Prosecutor's Office may vote through early voting, online, only for the presidential level.
5. Citizens with disabilities.

There are two scenarios for out of country voting, both include using electronic methods, one is the List of Voters Residing Abroad (RERE) and the other is the List of Voters Residing in Panama to Vote Early (REVA).
The RERE applies in cases in which voters residing abroad voluntarily register to vote early electronically only for the presidential level. The REVA includes the voters residing in Panama that voluntarily registered to vote early electronically for the presidential level because they will be out of the country on election day or due to other impediments such as work or disability.

The voter enters the polling station after making a line and they say their name out loud and turn in their identification card to the president of the polling station. The president of the polling station will check if the voter appears on the voter list. Once the latter is confirmed, the speaker of the polling station will give the ballots to the voter, which must be signed by the president, secretary, and the speaker of the polling station on the reverse part. The voter enters the box to mark the ballots, showing the signed part of the ballots to the polling station and introducing them to the ballot boxes. Lastly, the voter will sign the voter list, and the secretary, the president, or the speaker of the polling station will sign beside the voter´s signature as a witness. The secretary of the polling station will return the identification card to the voter.

government_functions.details: Executive Power is constituted by the President of the Republic and the Secretaries of State. The president and the vice-president are elected by direct decision of the people with a relative majority of the votes. The president has the faculties to name and remove the Secretaries of State and to coordinate the public administration. The president, with the participation of his cabinet members, sanctions laws, appoints the director and other members of the police and leads the international relations of the State.  The 71 members of the National Assembly are elected through direct popular vote, elected in single-member and multi-member circuits, guaranteeing the principle of proportional representation. The members of the National Assembly are elected for a five-year term. The legislative body is in charge of enacting reform, derogating the National Codes, approving treaties and international conventions before they are ratified, and approving the structure of the national administration body by request of the Executive Power.

voting_methods.instructions:
Overseas polling stations are set up in diplomatic missions in principle. However, additional polling stations may be established outside of diplomatic missions and in barracks of troops dispatched overseas in specific cases. In the polling station, the voting procedure is very similar as that for out of district voting in early voting.

At the end of polling, the ballot boxes are sent by diplomatic pouches to their relevant election commission and stored under CCTV surveillance. They are then counted on election day.

Mail Voting is the Home Voting. Under the Law To use home voting you must qualify under the rules in Article 38 of the Public Official Election Act and register. According to paragraph 4, the following persons qualify for home voting:

1. Those at military bases with no polling station.

2. A person admitted long term in a hospital, sanatorium, asylum, prison or detention centre.

3. A person with a serious physical disability who are unable to move freely.

4. A person who lives on a remote island specified by the election commission that is too far from a polling station.

5. A person living somewhere that is too far from a place were practically a polling station can be installed as specified by the election commission

A home voter shall choose one candidate (referring to one political party in cases of an election of proportional representative National Assembly members or an election of proportional representative local council members), put a mark in the corresponding column of the balloting paper received from the competent Gu/Si/Gun election commission, put the ballot paper into the envelope for return, seal the envelope, and then dispatch the envelope by registered mail.

An elector shall go, in person, to an advance polling station, and shall present his/her resident registration card in the presence of voting witnesses, and shall, after the identification is confirmed, affix his/her signature or seal or thumbmark to the electoral register, and then shall receive a ballot paper. After receiving the ballot paper, shall enter a balloting booth, select one candidate (referring to one political party in the election of the proportional representative National Assembly members and the election of the proportional representative local council members), from among those entered in the ballot paper, make a mark in the corresponding column of the ballot paper, fold the ballot paper on the spot so that other persons can not see the contents, and then put it in the ballot box in the presence of the voting witnesses.

An elector shall go, in person, to a polling station, and shall present his/her resident registration card in the presence of voting witnesses, and shall, after the identification is confirmed, affix his/her signature or seal or thumbmark to the electoral register, and then shall receive a ballot paper. After receiving the ballot paper, shall enter a balloting booth, select one candidate (referring to one political party in the election of the proportional representative National Assembly members and the election of the proportional representative local council members), from among those entered in the ballot paper, make a mark in the corresponding column of the ballot paper, fold the ballot paper on the spot so that other persons can not see the contents, and then put it in the ballot box in the presence of the voting witnesses.

government_functions.details:
Executive Branch: Headed by the President, who is the head of state and commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The President is responsible for implementing laws, directing foreign policy, and overseeing government administration through various ministries. The Prime Minister, appointed by the President with the National Assembly's consent, assists in coordinating government functions and can act as the President’s deputy.
 
Legislative Branch: The National Assembly is a unicameral parliament composed of elected representatives. It makes laws, approves the national budget, ratifies treaties, and oversees the executive branch. It also has the authority to impeach public officials, including the President.
 
Judicial Branch: The judiciary ensures the constitutionality of laws and delivers justice. It includes the Supreme Court, the highest ordinary court, and the Constitutional Court, which rules on constitutional matters like impeachment and political party dissolution.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting abroad shall be conducted at an Official Overseas Representative of Republic of Indonesia on the exact same time or in an adjusted time with the operation of polling stations in Indonesia. Voting will take place on a single day at each polling (ex: 10 February in Berlin). If  unable to cast  vote in the assigned overseas polling station, voters are allowed  to cast their vote via mail to the PPLN headquartered at the Official Overseas Representative of Republic of Indonesia.

Voters who have registered on the Permanent Voter List (DPT) will receive a Notification Letter which can be taken to the TPS. Voters can bring the Notification Letter along with their electronic KTP to the KPPS officer at the TPS and have the right to get a ballot paper for voting at the TPS.

Casting a vote in an election is done by puncturing the presidential election ballot once with a nail inside the square containing the running number, name, photo, or symbol of a presidential candidate ticket or nominating political party.

voting_methods.instructions:
Overseas voters may vote in-person (on election day only) or online throughout an early voting window.

To vote in-person, the voter shall go to an overseas voting center previously established by the Tribunal, where he/she shall present him/herself and identify him/herself to the JRVEX.Once the voting procedure in the system has been completed, the voter shall be sent an acknowledgement of receipt, indicating that the vote was successfully cast, according to the type of election in question and the procedures established by the Tribunal.

To vote online, the voter shall access the system and shall identify himself/herself by means of the validation mechanisms determined by the Tribunal. Once the voter's identity has been verified, the application shall be enabled for casting the vote. Once the voting procedure in the system has been completed, the voter shall be sent an acknowledgement of receipt, indicating that the vote was successfully cast, according to the type of election in question and the procedures established by the Tribunal.
Prior to the delivery of the ballot, the voter shall deliver to the Voting Reception Board his Single Identity Document (DUI) and it shall be returned once the vote has been cast.
