voting_methods.instructions: Persons living or staying abroad for the duration of the entire advance voting period and on election day can vote outside the country in-person or by post. The Finnish diplomatic missions and their offices at which out-of-country voters can vote are determined by a government decree.  The ballot, ballot envelope, covering letter form, and envelope for the covering letter form provided by the Ministry of Justice are used for out-of-country voting. A voter who wishes to vote in at a diplomatic mission shall report to the election official at the location.  The voter is obliged to present a proof of his or her identity to the election official. Thereafter, he or she is given a ballot, a ballot envelope and a covering envelope and, if needed, a covering letter form.  The voter shall be provided with the opportunity to familiarise himself or herself with the master list of candidates for his or her electoral district. A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered.  The voter shall mark the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. The marking shall be made in the voting booth or somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter. The covering letter,which includes the name and identifying number of the voter, shall be addressed to the central electoral committee of that municipality and entered in the voter register next to the voter.  The voter shall sign a declaration on the covering letter stating that he or she himself or herself has, maintaining the election secrecy, filled in the ballot and enclosed it stamped in the ballot envelope. The voter shall give the folded ballot to the election official to be stamped and, immediately after the ballot is stamped, enclose it in the ballot envelope in front of the election authority. The closed ballot envelope and the signed covering letter are to be given to the election official. When a voter register is used in the advance polling station, the election official  shall check in the register that the voter has the right to vote, make an entry in the register indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote, and make a marking on the covering letter indicating that an entry has been made in the voter register. When the voter register is not used at the polling location, a list of voters shall be kept.  The election offiical of a Finnish ship must deliver without delay the covering envelopes to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or to a Finnish diplomatic mission in the country where the ship is or where it first arrives. The election official in a Finnish diplomatic mission, or, if the mission does not serve as an advance polling station, the Head of Mission, shall ensure that the covering envelopoes that have been given there or that have arrived there are delivered to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in a manner determined by it. The Ministry shall ensure that the covering envelopes are delivered without delay to the central electoral commitee of the municipality in question.  An eligible out-of-country voter wishing to vote by post shall order the postal voting documents online from the Ministry of Justice to be sent to an address abroad. The postal voting documents can be ordered three months before the election day at the earliest, which is October 28, 2023 for the 2024 Presidential election. An assistant may be used for placing the order. The voter's name and personal identity code and the postal address abroad to which the documents will be sent must be given with the order. The postal voting package includes a ballot, a postal ballot envelope in which the ballot is inserted, a postal vote covering letter, which the voter must fill in, a postal vote covering envelope, in which the ballot envelope and the covering letter are inserted, and postal voting instructions, drawn up by the Ministry of Justice. The first possible date for postal voting for the 2024 Presidential election is December 21, 2023, when the candidates and their candidate numbers will be confirmed. The eligible voter himself or herself must find out the number of the candidate that he or she wants to vote for (which are published about one month before the election day). The instructions to vote are as follows: First, the voter marks the number of the candidate he or she wants to vote for on the ballot, inserts the ballot in the postal ballot envelope, and seals the envelope. Next, the voter fills in the postal vote covering letter and signs it. Postal voters are obliged to mark the ballot and put it into the ballot envelope personally and in secret and maintaining electoral freedom. The voter must sign an attestation concerning this on the covering letter. Two witnesses must be present when the postal voting takes place. The witnesses must also sign the attestation on the covering letter stating that election secrecy has been preserved and electoral freedom respected while voting. The witnesses must have reached the age of 18. The spouse, child, or parent of the voter or an election candidate or his or her family member cannot be a witness. The witnesses need not be Finnish citizens. At the end of the postal voting, the voter puts the ballot envelope and the covering letter into the covering envelope and seals it. The name and address of the central municipal election board to which the vote will be sent must be visible in the window of the covering envelope. The voter must send the covering envelope, containing the ballot sealed in the ballot envelope and the covering letter, to Finland to the central municipal election board of the municipality in which the voter has the right to vote according to the voter register. The voter is responsible to find out which municipality this is by calling the relevant authorities or if the voter received a polling card, by using the address indicated on it. The voter must put enough postage on the covering envelope (the mailing is not pre-paid). Finally, the voter posts the covering envelope to Finland through the postal service of a foreign country in the same manner as any other postal item.  The voter may also choose to post the envelope as a registered letter or to use an international courier service. For the first round of the 2024 Presidential election, the postal vote must arrive at the central municipal election board of the municipality of the voter's residence by 19:00 on January 26, 2024.

At a general advance polling station in Finland, the voting takes place at the times determined by a decision of the local executive, which may not be before 8:00 or after 20:00 on weekdays or before 10:00 or after 18:00 on Saturdays and Sundays. Every eligible voter may vote in advance at the general advance polling stations in Finland.

There must be at least one general advance polling station located in each municipality in Finland.  In addition, advance voting  is held n hospitals, full-time care facilities, and prisons for one or two days as determined by the electoral commission. Homebound voting also takes place during the advance polling days. The ballot, ballot envelope, covering letter form, and envelope for the covering letter form provided by the Ministry of Justice are used in advance voting.  A voter who wishes to vote in advance shall report to the election official or the electoral commission at the advance polling station. Where necessary, advance voting conducted in an institution is to be organized in different units and patients rooms. The voter is obliged to present a proof of his or her identity to the election official or the electoral commission. Thereafter, he or she is given a ballot, a ballot envelope and a covering envelope and, if needed, a covering letter form.  The voter shall be provided with the opportunity to familiarise himself or herself with the master list of candidates for his or her electoral district. A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered.  The voter shall mark the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. The marking shall be made in the voting booth or somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official or member of an electoral commission, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter. The covering letter,which includes the name and identifying number of the voter, shall be addressed to the central electoral committee of that municipality and is entered in the voting register next to the voter.  The voter shall sign a declaration on the covering letter stating that he or she himself or herself has, maintaining the election secrecy, filled in the ballot and enclosed it stamped in the ballot envelope. The voter shall give the folded ballot to the election official or, in an institution, to the electoral commission to be stamped and, immediately after the ballot is stamped, enclose it in the ballot envelope in front of the election authority. The closed ballot envelope and the signed covering letter are to be given to the election official or the electoral commission. When a voter register is used in the advance polling station, the election official or the chairperson of the electoral commission shall check in the register that the voter has the right to vote, make an entry in the register indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote, and make a marking on the covering letter indicating that an entry has been made in the voter register. When the voter register is not used at the advance polling station, a list of voters shall be kept. The election official and the electoral commission of a general advance polling station in Finland shall ensure that the covering envelopes addressed to the municipality's own central electoral committee are without delay delivered to the central electoral committee in the manner determined by it.

Proxy voting is not allowed. The voter reports to the election board in the polling station of his or voting district where he/she is assigned to vote. The voter is obliged to present proof of his or her identity to the electon board (with an official photo ID such as a passport or drivers license, or a free temporary ID card issued by the police). The election official must determine that the voter has the right to vote by checking the voter register. The voter receives the ballot and proceeds to the polling booth or, if that is not possible without causing undue difficulty to the voter, somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy. The voter marks the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official or member of an electoral commission, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter.The voter then presents the folded ballot paper to the election board in order to be stamped. The stamp is placed in the middle of the reverse side of the folded ballot. The voter then puts the ballot in the ballot box. The electoral board makes a marking in the list of voters, as well as the voter register, indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote. All voters who are still in line at a polling station at 20:00 are allowed to vote.

government_functions.details: In Finland, the President serves as chief of state, and the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 6-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by Parliament and formally appointed by the President.  Finland has a unicameral Parliament (Eduskunta) with 200 seats. 199 members are directly elected in single and multi-seat constituencies via proportional representation vote. The remaining member, who represents the autonomous region of Åland, is directly elected by plurality vote. All members serve 4-year terms.   The Finnish judiciary has two high courts: the Supreme Court (civil and criminal cases) and Supreme Administrative Court (government cases). The Supreme Court consists of 19 judges, while the Supreme Administrative Court has 21 judges. All high court judges are appointed by the President and may serve until age 68.

voting_and_voters.registered_voters_source: CONOREC Facebook post (see Results file in Documents tab)

provisions.provision: Do you approve of the draft Constitution submitted to you, enshrining the unitary form of the State?

government_functions.details: The new constitution submitted to referendum largely reproduces the text of the 1996 Constitution. Unlike the 2018 Constitution, the latter benefits from a better image, being the fruit of numerous consultations that led to a consensus during the Sovereign National Conference organised in 1993.  The text of this new fundamental law - the eleventh since the country's independence in 1960 - marks a return to a semi-presidential system, replacing the presidential system of 2018 by confirming the restoration of the post of Prime Minister as head of government accountable to the National Assembly, distinct from the role of Head of State of the President of the Republic. The President's term of office will be reduced from six to five years, always renewable once consecutively. The minimum age for presidential candidates is lowered from 40 to 35. The draft constitution also ratifies the existence of the Senate, which was theoretically created by the 2018 constitution but has never yet been set up, as well as the division of the country into 23 regions, or provinces.  The text is also notable for its objective of restoring a number of rights, concepts and democratic institutions that had been removed from the 1996 text by a succession of constitutional revisions under the presidency of Idriss Déby. Independence of the judiciary has been consolidated by assigning the chairmanship of the High Council of the Judiciary not to the President of the Republic but to the President of the Supreme Court, who was previously second vice-president. The High Court of Justice, placed under the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in 2018, has also regained its independence as an institution, and the sole power to try for high treason the President of the Republic, those of other institutions, as well as members of the government and their possible accomplices.The same applies to the Constitutional Council, which regains its independence from the Supreme Court and exercises sole control over the constitutionality of laws, organic laws, decrees and international treaties.Its review is carried out automatically before they are promulgated, but also a posteriori on the basis of a dispute referred to the Council by an ordinary court.The Council also judges electoral disputes and administers the oath of office to the newly elected President of the Republic.  In terms of military justice, a Court of Appeal was created, in addition to the military courts and the Supreme Court.

government_functions.details: The Executive Branch is led by the President of ireland (uachtarán na hÉireann), who shall take precedence over all other persons in the state and who shall exercise and perform the powers and functions conferred on the President by this constitution and by law. The Legislative Branch rests in the oireachtas which shall consist of the President and two houses, viz.: a house of representatives to be called dáil Éireann and a senate to be called seanad Éireann. the sole and exclusive power of making laws for the state is hereby vested in the Oireachtas: no other legislative authority has power to make laws for the state. On the other hand, Justice shall be administered in courts established by law by judges appointed in the mannerprovided by the constitution, and, save in such special and limited cases as may be prescribed by law, shall be administered in public. The Courts shall comprise the Court of First Instance, a Court of Appeal, and a Court of Final Appeal.

The President of Guatemala serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds along with the Vice President. The President serves a single 4-year term and is not eligible for reelection.  Guatemala has a unicameral Congress with 160 seats. 128 members are elected from multi-seat departmental constituencies and 32 additional members are elected in a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected by closed list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice is the highest court within the national judicial system. It is composed of 13 judges nominated by an expert legal panel and elected by members of Congress. Judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits. There is also a Constitutional Court that is independent from the judicial system and rules only on constitutionality. The Constitutional Court consists of 5 active judges and 5 reserve judges. Each active judge is appointed by a different institution: the President, Congress, the Supreme Court, the University of San Carlos, or the Assembly of the College of Attorneys and Notaries. Constitutional Court judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits.

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters residing abroad who wish to receive a postal ballot are required to actively register with the municipality of The Hague by post or electronically not later than six weeks prior to the polling day. The overseas voter register is permanent, so that voters do not need to register anew for each election. Registered out-of-country electors may also designate a proxy upon application to the mayor of The Hague at least six weeks before the polling day. Registered postal voter receive a postal vote certificate (not a voting pass) as proof of being allowed to vote by post. The postal voting packages are mailed out to out-of-country voters. Postal voters have the option of downloading their postal ballot electronically but must mark and cast the ballots in hard copy. To allow for voters to print the ballot themselves, in past elections the postal ballot was much smaller than the in-person ballot, with numbers for places on the list but not all the candidates' names. The postal voting package includes the ballot, the ballot envelope, the return envelope with the pre-printed return address, a postal vote certificate containing a declaration to be signed by the person that he or she has personally completed the ballot paper, and voting instructions. In the return envelope, voters send back the ballot in the ballot envelope, as well as signed postal vote certificate, which they received separately. The postal voter colours the white spot in front of the name/number of the candidate of her or his choice, in red, blue or black. The ballot is then folded and put in the ballot envelope. The voter then signs the postal vote certificate declaring that he or she has completed the ballot paper personally. The voter encloses a copy of an approved identity document, which must be valid.  The postal ballot certificate, copy of ID, and envelope containing the ballot paper are then placed in the accompanying return envelope which is closed and returned (with adequate stamps). The postal ballots can be mailed to The Hague municipality or dropped off at a designated Dutch diplomatic or consular mission or other overseas location serving as a collection point for votes abroad, Dutch representations at the Carribean countries of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, or collection points designated by the Ministry of Defence at military missions outside The Netherlands. The votes handed in to these collection points are counted at the collection points and the results transmitted electronically to The Hague district election committee. The oveseas ballots are counted by the The Hague district election committee and count in the results of The Hague municipality.

Everyone eligible to vote will receive an invitation to cast their vote sent to their home address no later than 14 days prior to election day. This invitation includes the voter's poll card (voting pass) which allows the voter to cast their vote in the polling station of their choice within the borders of the municipality in which he or she is registered. The poll card (voting pass) is a personalized document with security features against copying. Voters can request a replacement in case of loss, including on election day. Voters may also request, by written or oral application to the  municipality where he or she is registered, to vote at any other location in the country, in which case they are issued a voter's (absentee) pass. Such requests in writing must be received no later than five days before polling day or in case of oral request, by 12 noon on the day before voting.  Municipal authorities can set up mobile polling stations that move from designated location to designated location on election day during certain times. Any voter unable to cast their vote in person on election day, including voters residing abroad, may appoint a proxy to vote on their behalf. No justification is required to request a proxy vote, but voters cannot request a proxy in a polling station. Appointing a proxy may be done by simply providing the chosen proxy who resides in the same municipality with a signed voting pass or voter's (absentee) pass. A proxy residing outside the voter's municipality may be authorized through an application to the mayor received no later than five days before the polling day, in which case a certificate of authorization is issued to the proxy. A proxy may cast the additional vote in a polling station only together with her or his vote, upon presentation of the signed voting or voter's pass and (copy of) the identification document of the represented person. One person can be the proxy of only up to two persons. Prisoners can only vote by proxy. All voters casting votes must show an authorized identification document to the poll worker. Any such identification may not have expired by more than five years. The voter must also hand in his/her poll card (voting pass) or voter's (absentee) pass to the poll worker before voting. Upon doing so, the poll worker checks that the voting pass has not been invalidated (according to the list of invalid passes) and that it corresponds to the identity document. If the pass is not on the invalid list and the pass and identification correspond then the voter is issued a ballot paper and the poll worker directs the voter  to the polling booth. The poll worker retains and cancels the voting pass. Proxy voters who have a certificate of authorization are to hand it over to the poll worker. Polling stations do not keep voters lists (the retention of voting passes prevents multiple voting.) The polling booths must have instructions on voting, established by ministerial order. Voters are required to mark the ballot in secret in the polling booth with a red pencil.  In each electoral district, votes are cast for the candidates whose names appear on the lists of candidates for that electoral district. Voters can vote for a list or have the option to cast a preferential vote for a candidate of choice.  The voter colours in the white spot opposite the name of the candidate of her or his choice. The voter then folds the ballot paper, leaves the polling booth, and inserts the ballot in the ballot box next to the electoral committee's table. If the voter does not put the ballot in the box, the chairperson shall make a note of it. If a voter makes a mistake when completing the ballot paper, he or she can return it to the chairperson and, on request, will be provided (once) with a new ballot paper. The law provides that if a voter requires help because of her or his physical condition, the electoral committee should allow him or her to avail themself of assistance.  Voters are allowed to remain in the polling station while the electoral committee is in session, provided they do not create a disturbance or hinder the progress of the session.

government_functions.details: The President of Micronesia serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Congress from among four senators-at-large.   The Micronesian legislature is composed of a unicameral Congress with 14 seats. All members of Congress are directly elected. 10 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 2-year terms. An additional “at large” member is elected from each of the four Micronesian states by proportional representation vote, and these members serve 4-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Micronesian judiciary and consists of up to six judges split into two divisions. These judges are nominated by the President and confirmed by a two-thirds vote of Congress. Judges may serve for life.

voting_methods.instructions:
For National Council elections, citizens resident abroad can register to vote in the canton in which they last reside (of their canton of citizenship otherwise) and are able to vote no matter how long since, or whether they ever have, lived in Switzerland. Swiss citizens abroad must join the Register of the Swiss Abroad and be registered on the electoral roll of their last commune of residence (or place of origin if they have never lived in Switzerland) by filling out a form online or at an embassy. Once registered for the first time, the person remains in the register unless the voting materials to the voter were returned undeliverable for three times in a row.

Swiss citizens abroad can vote by post in the same manner as in-country postal voting, and those registered in cantons participating in federal online voting pilot projects may also cast their vote online.

Online voting is only through federally approved pilots in the cantons, which are currently restricted to a maximum of 10 per cent of the country's electorate. This limit does not apply to Swiss citizens living abroad but out-of-country voters can vote online only if their canton of registration is utilizing online voting.

The federal legislation provides minimum standards for internet voting pilots to be introduced and implemented  by cantons. Comprehensive end-to-end testing of internet voting systems  must take place before the Federal Counil can approve their use. The law includes requirements for publishing the source code, providing voter information, and allowing voters to familiarize with and to test internet voting outside of an election. The legislation requires that verification of eligibility to vote and voting secrecy be guaranteed and abuses prevented in the use of online voting system. All internet voting systems are required to provide voters with the possiblity to individually verify that their vote has been cast as intended. Eligible voters will receive codes and their voter identification card that will allow them to check that their ballot is recorded correctly and corresponds to their intention. The federal authorities have also undertaken measures to promote cyber security and data protection in online voting systems.

All voters automatically receive the official voting materials by post ahead of election day; if they choose to vote by post, they can do so as soon as the voting materials are received between three to four weeks before the election day.  All cantons are required to provide a postal voting option, including to citizens residing abroad. 

The delivery by post of the official voting materials to all voters is mandated for between three to four weeks prior to election day, to be sent by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The cantons are mandated to enact provisions regulating postal voting, including to guarantee the verification of eligibility to vote, voting secrecy and the counting of all the votes, and to prevent abuses. Voters who choose to vote by post, follow the postal voting instructions in the voting materials sent to them.  The voter must send their identification card, using a double envelope system, with the ballot to prevent the possibility of voting additionally at a polling station. Once the voter has filled out his/her ballot these are put into an anonymous return envelope provided in the package. This first anonymous envelope and the identification card are placed into the return envelope and then sent back to the municipality.  In some municipalities, the envelope can be returned directly to the municipality mailbox. Otherwise, the envelope is to be returned by post; in some cantons postage does not have to be paid.

Under federal law, cantons are obliged to provide early voting at polling stations for a minimum of two of the four days immediately prior to election day.  Cantonal law specifies the time that all or certain polling stations will be open for advance voting. Instead of opening polling stations on advance polling days, the canton can allow voters to hand over their ballot paper in a sealed envelope at a public office.

The manner of early voting is the same as for voting on election day, whereby the voter brings the ballots that were sent to him/her by post ahead of the election day to cast at the polling station or to hand  over in a sealed envelope at a public office, whichever means is provided by the canton. The cantons are mandated to enact the required provisions relating to the preservation of voting secrecy and the prevention of abuses in early voting processes.

All voters receive the official voting materials by post to their home address between three to four weeks ahead of election day by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The Federal Chancellory is required by law to issue brief instructions on voting procedures prior to each general elecction, which are delivered along with the voting materials to voters in cantons with a system of proportional representation. If the voter wishes to vote in-person (rather than postal vote), he/she takes the ballots that weree previously received by post and drops them off at the polling station where they are registered to vote. At the  polling station, the voter must present his/her identification card. Votes may be cast by proxy at the polling station provided the cantonal law permits this for cantonal elections. Persons who are unable to write may have their ballot paper completed in accordance with their instructions by a person of their chose who is eligible to vote. Voting secrecy must be preserved in the voting process. In cantons where the proportional list system is used for the National Council elections, voters may cross out names on party lists or write names twice, split their vote between parties or draw up their own lists on a blank ballot combining candidates from different lists within the constituency.

electoral_rights.source: 1976 Federal Act on Political Rights, Articles 5(6), 6; Cantonal Laws; 1999 Constitution, Article 136(1); 1997 Federal Act on Political Rights, Article 2.6

government_functions.details: Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term.   Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly.   The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

provisions.provision: A Proposed Law: to alter the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. Do you approve this proposed alteration?

government_functions.details:
Australia is a parliamentary democracy that is a part of the British Commonwealth. As such, the chief of state is the British Monarch. The monarchy is hereditary. The monarch appoints an in-country representative called a governor on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party or majority coalition in government. 

Australian parliament is bicameral, with a 76-seat Senate and a 151-seat House of Representatives. Both houses are directly elected. The Senate is comprised of six senators for each original state (per the Constitution), with a provision that additional seats can be apportioned should new state be recognized. Senators serve six-year terms. The House of Representatives is intende to comprise twice the number of Senators. Seats in the House are apportioned by population.

The highest court in Australia is the High Court of Australia. Additionally, there are a variety of state and territory courts.

institution.term_details: Article 11 (Law n°001/2018 of January 12, 2018) The term of office of the President of the Republic begins on the day of his swearing-in and ends on the expiry of the seventh year following his swearing-in. The election of the President of the Republic takes place at least one (1) month and at most two (2) months before the expiry of the term of office of the incumbent President. The latter may not shorten his term of office in any way whatsoever in order to seek another. If the incumbent President of the Republic becomes a candidate, the National Assembly may not be dissolved. Moreover, from the official announcement of his candidacy until the election, he may not exercise his power to legislate by ordinance. If necessary, Parliament is convened in extraordinary session. If the President of the Republic is re-elected, he may take the oath of office as soon as the results of the election have been announced by the Constitutional Court.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is the Head of State and must be "the guarantor of national independence, territorial integrity, and respect for international agreements and treaties." The President is elected for seven years by direct universal suffrage (absolute majority or majority at runoff) and can be re-elected once. The Legislative is composed of the National Assembly (deputies, directly elected for 5-year terms) and the Senate (senators, indirectly elected for 5-year terms). The Judiciary is composed of the Constitutional Court, judicial courts, administrative courts, financial courts, the High Court of Justice, the Court of Justice of the Republic, and other exceptional courts.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: In two-seat constituencies, the first seat is given to the slate that obtains the highest number of votes; and the second is given to the slate with the second highest vote tally (if the tally is at least 35% of that of the first slate); otherwise both seats are given to the most voted slate. In constituencies with three or more seats, the votes are tallied for each slate and divided by the series of numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11,... The slates are ranked from highest to lowest by these quotients

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

voting_methods.instructions:
Registered voters wishing to exercise their right to vote abroad have to submit an online application through a dedicated government portal.  If accepted, the voter is placed on the foreign voters list for a period of eight years. Overseas voters will have the right to elect only candidates who are on the parties' nationwide candidate lists and not the parliamentarians that represent a particular regional constituency.  Overseas voting will takeplace in person at polling stations which will be set up in embassies, consulates and suitable venues of Greek disaspora organizations. For an out-of-country polling station to be constituted, a minimum of 40 registered voters is required. On the day appointed for voting, voters come to the polling station of the relevant electoral division and present themselves to the electoral commitee, which determines their identity based on their Greeck police ID or Greek passport, and verifies their registration in the foreign voter list. To each voter, the electoral committee delivers an envelope initialed by the representative of the judicial authority and sealed with a stamp of the committee, a complete set of ballot forms and a blank ballot. Then the voter proceeds to the special separate area, in such a way that he/she cannot be seen, and there the voter secretly inserts the ballot paper of his choosing in the envelope given to him/her by the election committee. After securely sealing the envelope, the voter returns to the election committee and shows the envelope to the members and other attendees, to show that he/she is holding only one envelope, and then inserts the envelope into the ballot box. The election committee draws up minutes during the voting for every matter related to its conduct.

The 2023 elections will be the first time that certain out-of-country Greek citizens will be able to vote abroad.  According to legislation adopted in December 2019, after the 2019 parliamentary elections,  registered voters who are temporarily or permanently abroad must fulfil two main requirements in order to vote abroad. They must have had a two-year stay in Greece in the last 35 years and for those over 30 years old they  must have filed  a tax return in Greece in the year of the election or the preceding year.

Voters must vote in person in the electoral constituency where they are registered. Citizens residing outside their constituency can apply to vote at specially designated absentee polling stations in the  municipalities of their temporary residence. Voters go to the polling station and present themselves to the returning board which will examine their identification and verify whether they are registered in the electoral rolls. Voters will enter the polling station one by one or in groups of small numbers in the order they arrive or in the manner laid down by each returning board. In order to be identified when proceeding to exercise their right to vote, voters have to present their ID card or their passport. The returning board provides each voter with a specially marked envelope initialled by the court representative and stamped by the board as well as a full set of ballot papers for all party-lists and independent candidates. The voter is to proceed to the polling booth and must vote in secret, in such a way that he/she cannot be seen. The voter must place the chosen and marked ballot papers within the specially marked envelope and seal it, then proceed to show the sealed and stamped envelope to the chairperson of the returning board and others present, and then the voter places the envelope in the ballot box. Voters physically incapable of performing such tasks can request the court representative or a member of the returning board for obligatory assistance.  For the constituency voting, voters may select the candidate or candidates of their choice by marking the candidate's name on the party ballot.  Upon request, voters will be provided with a certificate signed by the chairperson of the returning board and bearing its stamp that he/she voted. The returning board keeps a protocol in which the electors who vote are written.

government_functions.details: In Greece, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Parliament and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister, customarily the leader of the parliamentary majority party, is appointed by the President.   Greece has a unicameral Hellenic Parliament with 300 seats. 285 members are elected in multi-seat constituencies, while the remaining 15 are elected from a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected via open party-list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  There are three high courts: the Supreme Civil and Criminal Court, the Council of State (for cases involving the national government), and the Court of Audit. The 56 judges of the Supreme Court and the president of the Court of Audit are nominated by an expert panel called the Supreme Judicial Council and appointed by the President. The president of the Council of State is appointed by the executive cabinet. All other Council of State and Court of Audit judges are hired via a competitive process.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

Turkey is a presidential republic. The President serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The president is directly elected for a 5-year term and is eligible to serve two terms.   Turkey has a unicameral Grand National Assembly (Buyuk Millet Meclisi) which has 600 members. Members are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies to serve 5-year terms.   The highest courts are the Constitutional Court (Anayasa Mahkemesi), Court of Cassation, and the Council of State.

voting_methods.instructions: Any poll (including an advance poll) at an overseas polling station must be conducted in the same manner as that in which voting at a polling station within Singapore on polling day is conducted.  The hours of any poll at an overseas polling station for any contested election must be not less than 4 hours and may start in advance of the poll on polling day in Singapore, except that every such poll at an overseas polling station must close not later than the close of the poll on polling day in Singapore.

Voting by post or at an overseas polling station are meant for Singaporeans residing overseas only and does not include local Singaporeans who happen to be overseas on Polling Day, such as those on overseas vacation. An overseas voter may vote by post by registering via Elections Department's online Voter Services using Singpass and must upload his/her wet-ink signature during registration. He/she may download and print a postal ballot paper and return envelope the day after Nomination Day.  Voting by post is done by marking, folding, and inserting the postal ballot paper in the return envelope. Thereafter, the voter must seal and sign on the return envelope and post the same to Returning Officer in Singapore. Note that return envelopes containing the postal ballot papers must be postmarked before Polling Day and reach the custody of the Returning Officer in Singapore within 10 days after Polling Day in Singapore to be accepted for counting.

The voter, on receiving the ballot paper, shall immediately proceed to such place in the station as may be indicated by the presiding officer shall secretly mark the paper; voter’s mark on the ballot paper must be made in the area demarcated on the ballot paper for that purpose, and not elsewhere;  fold the paper so as to conceal his vote, and shall put the paper so folded up into the ballot box.

institution.term_details: Article 45 The President of the Republic is the Head of State. He is elected by universal direct suffrage for a mandate of five years renewable one sole time. Article 46 Any candidate to the functions of President of the Republic must be of Malagasy nationality, enjoy their civil and political rights, be at least thirty-five years old at the date of the closure of the presentation of the candidatures, and reside on the territory of the Republic of Madagascar for at least six months before the day of the deadline established for the presentation of the candidatures. The President of the Republic in office who stands as a candidate to the Presidential elections resigns from his position sixty days before the date of the Presidential ballot. In this case, the President of the Senate exercises the current Presidential attributions until the investiture of the new President. In the case that the President of the Senate stands as a candidate himself, the functions of Head of the State are exercised by the Government, jointly.

government_functions.details: The President and Prime Minister are in charge of executing the day-to-day operations of the government along with the cabinet. The president is elected by majority vote through a two-round system. The prime minister is appointed by the president for 5 years.  The Supreme Court addresses judicial administration issues. The High Constitutional Court interprets the Constitution when the law is questioned. The Supreme Court is elected by the president and judiciary officials. The High Constitutional Court members are appointed - 3 each by the president, by both legislative bodies, and by the Council of Magistrates.  The legislature includes the Senate and National Assembly which are in charge of creating legislature. The Senate has 22 members appointed by regional legislatures and 11 appointed by the president. The National Assembly has 115 members elected by plurality vote in single-member constituencies and 12 by single non-transferable vote.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: If no candidate obtains an absolute majority of valid votes, a second round is held between the two highest vote-getters 15-30 days after election day. At least 33 per cent of voters must participate for the first round to be valid; there is no turnout requirement for the second round.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters staying in densely populated areas of citizens of Uzbekistan abroad can vote in embassies and consular offices. Voter lists at polling stations formed at embassies and consular offices are compiled on the basis of data provided by the heads of those institutions. The precinct election commissions formed at embassies and consular offices inform citizens in foreign countries about the method, place and time of familiarlization with the voter lists. Citizens in foreign countries can apply in writing to precinct election commissions in the embassies and consular offices, or electronically through the official website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, to be included in the voter list for fifteen days before the election. The precinct election commissions submit to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs information on citizens included on the voter lists and the Ministry submits information about such citizens to the State Center for Personalization under the Cabinet of Ministers to make appropriate changes to the Single Electronic Voter Register. The method for out-of-country voting is the same as for voting in-country. Out-of-country voting includes the possibility of early and mobile voting. In polling stations at embassies and consular offices, the precinct election commission may at any time report the voting completed if all citizens included in the list have voted.

A voter who is unable to vote at his/her place of residence on election day has the right to vote early, upon application indicating the reasons for absence (vacation, business trip, travel abroad, etc.). The voter receives the ballot paper from the relevant precinct election commission and signs the voter list in the presence of at least two members of the commission. The ballot is marked by the voter in a specially equipped booth or room for secret voting.  The voter then places the marked ballot in a sealed envelope, two members of the precinct election commission sign on the seal which is then officially sealed with the commission seal. The early ballot envelopes are stored in a safe at the relevant precinct election commission until mixed with all other ballots on election day.

Voters can vote at a specified polling station in the location where they are registered to vote.  Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter presents his/her identity document and signs the voter list. Then he/she is given a ballot. If a voter is not on the voter list, he/she can register to vote on election day at the polling station, provided that the person is on the Single Electronic Voter Register. The voter fills out the ballot paper in the voting booth or room for secret voting.  A voter who is unable to mark the ballot on their own can invite another person to the booth at his/her discretion, with the exception of poll workers, observers and media representatives. The voter puts a valid mark on the empty square situated on the right side, opposite the surname of the candidate for whom he/she is voting. The voter then puts the ballot in to the ballot box. To ensure secrecy of the vote, the polling station must be set up so that the voter must pass through a secret voting booth/room in order to cast the ballot in the ballot box. If a voter spoils a ballot, the ballot may be replaced with a new one by the poll worker. A voter who cannot come to the polling station due to health or other reasons can request the polling commission to come to the voter's house to allow him/her to vote.  The homebound voting must respect the secrecy of the vote. Special polling stations are established in places where voters temporarily reside such as penitentiary institutions, military units, hospitals and other health institutions.

government_functions.details: In Uzbekistan, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister serves as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 7-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the majority party in the Supreme Assembly and appointed by the President.   Uzbekistan has a bicameral Supreme Assembly consisting of a 100-seat Senate and a 150-seat Legislative Chamber. Members of the Senate are indirectly elected by regional councils (84 members) or appointed by the president (16 members). All members serve 5-year terms. All 150 members of the Legislative Chamber are directly elected by absolute majority vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court and Constitutional Court are the highest judicial bodies of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Court has 67 judges, while the Constitutional Court has only 7. Judges for both institutions are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Judges may serve one term of 10 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Electors cast their vote at a specified polling station in the locality of their domicile where they are registered for national elections. Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter should submit a certificate of his/her registration and present his/her nationality certificate which is then stamped with a special seal. The voter must also present a civil identification card that shows the person's address. If the certificate of registration was lost, provided the voter's name is on the voter list, he/she can vote. The head of the polling committee hands each voter a ballot paper and the voters goes to one of the areas designated for voting in secret inside the polling hall. After the voter marks the ballot, he/she returns it to the chairperson who puts it in the ballot box. The polling clerk then enters a mark in the voter list in front of the name of the voter who cast his/her ballot to indicate the voter has voted.  A voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot can state his/her choice orally so that only the members of the polling committee can hear it (or just the chairperson) and the chairperson marks the voter's choice on the ballot paper and puts it in the ballot box.

government_functions.details: Kuwait is a hereditary emirate. The chief of state is the Amir, who is chosen from within the ruling family and confirmed by the National Assembly. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Amir, as is the Crown Prince, who also must be approved by the National Assembly. The Crown Prince is also designated as the Heir Apparent and the National Assembly must swear fealty to the Crown Prince.   Kuwait has a unicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Umma), which has 50 members and 15 ex-officio seats reserved for cabinet ministers. Per the Constitution, there may be more ministers (and thus ex-officio members) so long as the number of ministers does not exceed one-third of the total assembly.   The highest courts in Kuwait are the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. All judges are appointed by the Amir on the recommendation of the Supreme Judicial Council.

government_functions.details:
In Mauritania, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and has no term limit.

Mauritania has a unicameral National Assembly (Al Jam'iya Al Wataniya) with 176 seats. 88 members are elected via absolute majority vote (up to two rounds) in a single, nationwide constituency. The remaining 88 members are elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-member constituencies, including 4 overseas constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. Out of the 88 nationwide constituency seats, 20 seats are reserved for women, and 11 are reserved for youth (aged 25 to 30). 

The Mauritanian judiciary is composed of the Supreme Court (21 judges), the Constitutional Council (9 judges), and the High Court of Justice (9 judges). Judges within these institutions are all appointed by either the President, the Prime Minister, or members of the National Assembly.

government_functions.details: The President of French Polynesia is indirectly elected by the Assembly from among its members. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.  In the Assembly, 38 members are directly elected via absolute majority, closed-list vote in multi-seat constituencies in up to two rounds. Only lists receiving at least 12.5% of the total vote can advance to the second round, but parties may combine their votes and lists to meet this requirement. The remaining 19 seats are allocated to the party that receives the most votes. All members serve 5-year terms.  Within the French legislature, French Polynesia directly elects three deputies of the National Assembly via absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. French Polynesia indirectly elects two members of the Senate via an electoral college, and one senate seat is contested every three years. Deputies serve 5-year terms, and senators serve 6-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
For this voting method, the voter must be French, residing abroad, and registered on a consular electoral list.

The postal voting material will be sent for each round to voters who have activated this option, together with the convocation letter and the candidates' declarations of faith. It will contain: ballot papers; a ballot envelope (colour according to the ballots); an identification envelope (white) to be filled in the voters; a shipping envelope made out to the address of the position that receives their vote. Voters must select the ballot and drag it into the ballot envelope. They must then insert the ballot envelope into the identification envelope (white) on which they indicate their first and last name. Thereafter, paste the identification envelope and sign it. Voters must put the identification envelope and a copy of identification with their signature in the shipping envelope. Note that voters must not insert the copy of the identity document either in the ballot envelope or in the identification envelope (white). They must send the shipping envelope to the consulate – if they would send it by mail, they must not forget to put a stamp. Their vote must reach the consular post before the deadline date and time.

To vote online, the voter must be French, residing abroad, and registered on a consular electoral list.

Voters must log into their voting portal by entering their 12-digit character ID, which they will receive by email, and their 12-character password, which they will receive by SMS.

Upon logging in, voters may cast their votes by entering the 4-digit security code first, then by clicking the "connection" button.

Thereafter, voters may already select the candidates they will vote for, and if they have to change their votes, they may click on the "back" button, select the candidate they wish to vote for, and complete it by clicking the "confirm" button.

Next, voters must enter their 6-digit validation code, which they will receive by email, and click the "vote" button to complete the voting process.

Voters will receive their proof of signing by email in the next hour. To leave the voting portal, voters may click on the "disconnect" button and download the receipt of their vote.

Upon entering the polling room, the voter, after having had his identity ascertained in accordance with established rules and practices or after having proved his right to vote by the production of a decision of the judge of the judicial court ordering his registration or a judgment of the Court of Cassation annulling a judgment which would have pronounced his striking off, takes, himself, an envelope. Without leaving the polling room, he must go in isolation to the part of the room set up to hide it from view while he puts his ballot in the envelope; He then makes the President declare that he is carrying only one envelope; The President notes this without touching the envelope, which the voter himself inserts into the ballot box. In polling stations equipped with a voting machine, the voter shall have his identity ascertained or proof of his right to vote under the conditions provided for in paragraph 1 and have his vote registered by the voting machine.

Note that with the following polling stations will close at a different time: Mahina / Paea / Papeete / Punaauia / Taputapuatea / Uturoa / Rurutu (07:00 pm) Ua Pou / Gambier (07:00 pm; local time is 6:30 pm in Papeete) Faa’a / Taiarapu-Est / Bora Bora (08:00 pm)

government_functions.details: The President of French Polynesia is indirectly elected by the Assembly from among its members. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.  In the Assembly, 38 members are directly elected via absolute majority, closed-list vote in multi-seat constituencies in up to two rounds. Only lists receiving at least 12.5% of the total vote can advance to the second round, but parties may combine their votes and lists to meet this requirement. The remaining 19 seats are allocated to the party that receives the most votes. All members serve 5-year terms.  Within the French legislature, French Polynesia directly elects three deputies of the National Assembly via absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. French Polynesia indirectly elects two members of the Senate via an electoral college, and one senate seat is contested every three years. Deputies serve 5-year terms, and senators serve 6-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
The election law provides for one advance polling day.  Only election-related officials (polling staff and the police), the elderly (those over 70 years old), disabled or illiterate persons who need extra time and assistance in the voting process, those on remand, and voters travelling on election day, can vote on the advance polling day. Persons wanting to vote on the advance polling day must submit an application in writing to be witnessed by a person holding certain positions (e.g., justice of the peace, medical doctor, lawyer, etc., or a person of similar standing as approved by the Supervisor of Elections) and who has known the applicant personally for at least two years. Persons who will be travelling in advance of polling day are to include his/her travel ticket with the application as proof of travel. It is expected, however, that a bill is to be laid before the House of Assembly to include other categories of voters to be allowed to vote on Advance Polling Day which is to be effective for the 2023 election.

On the advance polling day, voters vote in the same manner and according to the same procedures that apply on election day.  At the close of the advance poll, the presiding officer shall, in addition to various reconciliation procedures, ensure that the ballot papers remain in their boxes, seal the ballot boxes with seals provided by the Supervisor of Elections, close the poll on the electronic tabulation system (if utilized) and run the paper tape, remove the media stick placing it with the printed report in a designated pouch, seal the pouch and place it in a second sealed pouch which is placed with other election materials in a designated carrying case. The ballots cast at the advance poll and the carrying case with election materials are then submitted to the Supervisor of Elections for safe keeping until election day when they are delivered to the presiding officers.

Only voters registered in the electoral district and at a particular polling station can vote there. Voters can apply in advance to transfer their voter registration from one electoral district to another. Upon entering the polling station, the voter must present their voter registration card or Government issued ID to the poll clerk, and the poll clerk then ascertains that the voter's name is on the voter list or electronic poll book for that polling station. The poll clerk then enters the voter's name and corresponding number from the voter list into the poll book. The voter is then allowed to immediately vote unless the election official or any candidate agent present desires that the voter first be sworn. The presiding officer issues to the voter a ballot paper that has a detachable counterfoil attached with a number printed on the face of the ballot paper and has the poll clerks initials on the back. The presiding officer instructs the voter to mark the ballot with an "X" or to shade the designated oval sign, by referring the voter to a speciman ballot paper posted in a conspicuous place. The voter then immediately proceeds to vote in secret in a polling booth where the ballot is marked as instructed. The voter marks the ballot for up to five candidates - one vote in the local electoral district and up to four votes in the territorial-at-large district. Voters with a physical disability or blindness, or who are illiterate, may be assisted by the presiding officer to cast the ballot, upon the swearing of the required oath by such persons. After voting, the voter returns the ballot paper to the presiding officer, folded as instructed. In full view of all present, the presiding officer then removes the counterfoil and directs the voter to insert the ballot into the locked ballot box or into the electronic tabulation machine (ballot scanner), if being used at that polling station. If the voter inadvertently spoils the ballot paper, the presiding officer can issue another ballot paper and writes or stamps "spoiled" on the face of the spoiled ballot. The poll clerk then enters next to the voter's name in the (electronic) poll book, the word "voted". If at any point a voter has taken an oath or affirmation or refused to take an oath or affirm or to answer any question that the voter is legally required to do, this is to be noted in the (electronic) poll book. After voting, the voter must immediately leave the polling station.

government_functions.details: The British Virgin Islands are an overseas territory of the United Kingdom with a limited internal governance structure. The internal governance structure is a parliamentary democracy. The Chief of State is the British Monarch (currently King Charles III). The monarchy is represented by a territorial governor. The Premier is the head of the government and is appointed by the governor and is typically the leader of the ruling coalition or party.   The legislative branch is comprised of a unitary House of Assembly with 15 seats. Members serve 4-year terms. 13 seats are directly elected and 2 seats are ex-officio and are chosen from outside of the House.   The highest court is the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court (ECSC) which also represents other Caribbean states.

government_functions.details:
Montenegro is a parliamentary republic. The Prime Minister is nominated by the president and approved by the Assembly. The President is directly elected in a two rounds of voting if necessarily. Voters in Montenegro must have resided in the country for a minimum of 10 of the past 15 years. 

The unicameral Skupstina or Assembly has 81 seats with all members directly elected in a single nationwide constituency. Members serve for four years unless snap elections are called by the President of Montenegro, the government, or a minimum of 25 members of parliament. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (Vrhovni Sud), which has 17 members including a court president and deputy president, as well as the Constitutional Court (Ustavni Sud).

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Article 4 Councillors and members of parliament shall be elected in an electoral district based on a list submitted by a political party (party candidate list), coalition of political parties (coalition candidate list) or group of citizens (citizen group candidate list) (hereinafter referred to as the candidate list). Councillor and member of parliament seats shall be allocated in proportion to the number of votes received.

voting_methods.instructions: Article 67 Voters shall cast their votes at polling stations in which they have been included into the extract from the electoral register. As an exception to the provision of para.1 of this Article, voters may vote by post outside of the polling station in which they have been included into the extract from the electoral register, under the conditions laid down in this Law. The manner of voting outside of the polling station, as well as the number of voters who have thus exercised their voting right shall be entered into a record of polling board work. More detailed rules on postal voting shall be laid down by the State Election Commission.  Article 85 Voters who are unable, due to old age, disability, inpatient or outpatient medical treatment, to vote at the polling station where their names are on the extract from the electoral register and who wish to vote, shall submit an application to vote by post to the polling board, using the prescribed form. Voters who wish to vote by post shall personally sign the form referred to in para.1 of this Article. The application to vote by post shall be submitted to the polling board at the polling station at the latest until 13:00h on polling day. The application to vote by post may be submitted to the polling board at the polling station only by the person authorised by the signature of the postal voting applicant to do so. One person may not submit to the polling board more than one application to vote by post, except where he is doing so for two or more voters voting by post and living in the same household. The authorisation to deliver the application to vote by post to the polling board shall be an integral part of the form referred to in para.1 of this Article. The form referred to in para.1 of this Article shall be prescribed by the State Election Commission. ID card or passport of the voter wishing to vote by post shall be submitted to the polling board together with the application to vote by post and the authorisation to deliver the application to vote by post to the polling board. Article 85a Upon receipt of the application to vote by post, the polling board shall check the identity of the person who brought the application to vote by post, ascertain if the person wishing to vote by post is on the electoral register and evaluate the reasons for postal voting.

Article 80 Voters shall state their name and surname to the polling board and prove their identity via a biometric ID card or passport. Voters may not vote without presenting evidence of their identity. Having ascertained the identity of a voter, polling board presiding officer or member shall circle the ordinal number under which voter has been included into the extract from the candidate list, explain to him how to vote and hand over the ballot paper.

voting_methods.instructions: The law provides for voting in diplomatic posts and consular missions abroad.  Voting procedures are the same as those of in-country, in-person voting.

The following may vote in advance:
a) Military personnel who, on the day of the election, are prevented from going to the polling station due to an urgent need to carry out their duties;
b) Agents of forces and services who carry out functions of internal security under the terms of the law and are in a similar situation to that foreseen in the previous subparagraph.
c) Long-distance maritime and aeronautical workers who, by virtue of their professional activity, are presumably on board or displaced on the day of the election.

Qualified voters imay go to the President of the CRE of the area in which he is registered, 72 hours before election day, expressing his will to exercise his right to vote in advance. After verification, ballot is given to the voter. The voter fills in the ballot secretly, folds it in four, inserting it in the white subscript, which closes properly. Then the white subscript is inserted into the blue subscript together with the  supporting document, the blue subscript being closed, sealed and legibly signed on the back by the President of the CRE and by the voter

The voter presents himself to the polling station, which proceeds with his identification, upon examination of the voter card. The Chairman of the Board gives the voter a ballot paper indicating the polling booth. After voting, voter must dip a finger in indelible ink.

voting_methods.instructions:
Any registered elector may vote as a special voter if, on polling day, he will not be in the constituency of which he is a resident.

If the Chief Electoral Officer is satisfied that the application is made in good faith, the applicant will be issued a ballot paper; and an envelope marked “Vote in Advance of Poll” and addressed to the Returning Officer in charge of the constituency. The applicant shall then alone and secretly on the ballot paper indicate the candidate for whom he desires to vote, place the ballot paper duly folded in the envelope, and deliver the envelope, after sealing it, to the Chief Electoral Officer.

The voter, after  receiving  ballot paper, must immediately retire into one of the inner compartments provided for the purpose, and shall there alone and secretly exercise their vote by marking their ballot paper by striking out the name of every candidate except the one for whom they wish  to vote.Before leaving the inner compartment, voter must fold their ballot paper so that the contents cannot be seen, and shall then deposit it in the ballot box.

government_functions.details: The President of the Maldives serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and serves up to two 5-year terms.   The Maldives has a unicameral legislature: the People's Assembly. All 87 members are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Maldivian judiciary. The Supreme Court is composed of 7 justices who are nominated by the President and confirmed by the People's Assembly. Justices may serve until age 70.

The President of Cyprus is the head of state and government and is directly elected with the requirement that the President must be Greek Cypriot and the Vice President must be Turkish Cypriot. Both Turkish and Greek Cypriots vote for each position. Note that the Vice Presidency has been vacant for decades due to a boycott of Cyprus' government by Turkish Cypriots.   Cyprus has a unicameral House of Representatives (Vouli Antiprosopon) that with 80 seats total. 56 seats are allocated to Greek Cypriots, 24 are allocated to Turkish Cypriots, and 3 are reserved for religious minority groups. Like the vice presidenct, the seats allocated to Turkish Cypriots are vacant.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in Cyprus and has 12 judges and 1 court president. New judges are recommended by the Supreme Court and appointed by the President.
