voting_methods.instructions:
Voters can find ballots for postal elections on the website of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic https://www.minv.sk/?nr23-hl . The voter prints the ballot of the political entity to which he wants to cast his vote. If the data on this ballot is given on two pages, he will print both sides of the ballot, if possible on both sides .  

The voter receives two envelopes - an envelope for voting with an imprint of the official stamp of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic and a returnable envelope marked with the slogan "ELECTION BY MAIL". It contains the address of the seat of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic as the addressee, the address of the voter as the sender and a unique identification code. Each return envelope must contain only one voting envelope. In the event that the return envelope contains multiple ballot envelopes, all of these envelopes will be invalid. Any number of sealed return envelopes from multiple voters may be sent in one package. 

The postage for sending the return envelope is paid by the sender.  

A voter from abroad can send a returnable envelope from abroad in any way - classic mail, registered mail and courier service. The shipment of the courier service (courier envelope) must contain a return envelope in which the reporting envelope will be inserted. He can also send a returnable envelope from Slovakia or personally deliver it to the office of the Ministry of the Interior of the Slovak Republic at Drieňová Street 22 in Bratislava, no later than Friday, September 29 by 12:00 p.m.

Upon arrival at the polling station, the voter is obliged to prove his identity to the district election commission by presenting his identity card. If the voter was issued a voting card at his request, he shall submit the voting card together with the ID card, which will be taken away by the district election commission.  Then the precinct election commission circles the voter's serial number in the voter list and issues ballot papers and an empty envelope bearing the stamp of the municipality's official stamp to the voter. Receipt of ballots and envelopes is confirmed by the voter in the voter list with a handwritten signature.  Before voting , each voter must go to a special area designated for editing ballots. A voter who does not enter this space will not be allowed to vote by the district election commission. In a special space designated for editing ballots, the voter selects one ballot of the candidate subject to which he has decided to cast his vote. This ballot can be placed in an envelope without further modification,   or on the selected ballot, the voter can mark which candidate he prefers by circling the candidate's serial number. A voter can circle the serial number of a maximum of four candidates.

electoral_rights.source: https://www.minv.sk/?nr23-volic

government_functions.details:
Executive power is exercised by the government led by the Prime Minister. The President is the head of state and the formal head of the executive, though with very limited powers. The president is elected by direct popular vote, under a two-round system, for a five-year term.

The members of the 150-seat parliament (National Council) are elected for a four-year term under a proportional representation system, within a single nationwide constituency, with a 5% threshold for parties, 7% for coalitions of two or three parties, and 10% for coalitions of more than four parties. Following National Council elections, the leader of the majority party or coalition is usually appointed prime minister by the president.

The Supreme Court is the country's highest appellate court, the judges of which are elected by the National Council; below that are regional, district, and military courts. The Constitutional Court rules on constitutional issues; its 13 members are appointed by the president from a slate of candidates nominated by the parliament. The 18-member Judicial Council nominates common court judges and is responsible for appointing a disciplinary committee in cases of judicial misconduct.

voting_methods.instructions: The Central Election Commission determines the conditions and procedure for formation of the polling stations abroad, including the conditions, procedure and organization for voting of Bulgarian citizens abroad, not later than 57 days before the election day. Bulgarian citizens who have the right to vote and wish to exercise their right to vote outside the country in the elections for national representatives declare their wish by submitting an application for inclusion in a list for voting outside the country not later than 25 days before the election day by a written application according to a form, signed in person and delivered in person or submitted by post to the diplomatic mission or consular representation in the relevant state, or by electornic application via the website of the Central Election Commission.   Persons who have submitted an application and are included in a list for voting outside the country are automatically deleted from the voter list for these elections at their permanent address in the Republic of Bulgaria, without the need for them to take any action for this. Submitting a written or electronic application for voting outside the country in the elections for national representatives is not mandatory. Citizens who have not submitted an application for voting outside the country by the deadline, may nevertheless vote in a section, in a country and place of their choice. When voting, they submit a declaration that they meet the conditions to vote and that they have not voted and will not vote elsewhere. As inside Bulgaria, polling stations with more than 300 registered voters are to have voting machines available so that voters can choose to vote by machine or paper ballot.

Voters vote in person at their designated polling station. However, polling commission members and security officers are allowed to vote at the polling station of their duty; students are entitled to vote in the  municipality where they study; and persons with disabilitiles may vote in any suitable polling station of their choice without submitting a prior request. Up until 14 days before election day, candidates, higher level election officials, and accredited observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency. Up until 14 days before election day, any voter can request inclusion in the voter lists at the place of their current (temporary) registered residence. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. In polling stations with at least 300 registered voters, the voters have the option to use either paper ballot voting or direct recording electronic voting machines.  If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting screen and in private marks the square of the candidate list of his/her choice and if so wishes, also marks the circle of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, leaves the screen and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list and if he/she chooses, also for a candidate on the list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and the voted ballot is printed and the voter proceeds to cast the printed ballot in the same way as the paper ballots are cast. The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.  The mobile voting is carried out by not less than four poll workers on election day.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister.   Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected.   The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

provisions.provision: The extradition of Ecuadorians is prohibited for all crimes, including those related to transnational organized crime such as drug, arms, human, and migrant trafficking. Do you agree to allow the extradition of Ecuadorians who have committed offenses related to transnational organized crime via processes that respect their rights and guarantees, thus amending the Constitution according to Appendix 1?

Currently, the Judiciary Council selects, evaluates, promotes, trains, and sanctions prosecutors. Do you agree to guarantee the autonomy of the State Prosecutor's office so that it may select, evaluate, promote, train, and sanction its officials via a Prosecution Council, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 2?

Currently, the National Assembly is made up of 137 assembly members, and it is estimated in the 2022 census that this number will increase to approximately 152 assembly members. Do you agree to reduce the number of assembly members and elect them according to the following criteria: 1 assembly member per province and 1 additional assembly member per 500,000 residents; 2 national assembly members per million residents; and 1 assembly member per 500,000 overseas residents, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 3?

There are currently 272 political parties in Ecuador. Do you agree to require political parties to have, at minimum, a number of members equivalent to 1.5% of registered voters within their jurisdiction and require them to maintain a member registry which is periodically reviewed by the National Electoral Council, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 4?

The CPCCS (Council of Civic Participation and Social Control) is a public entity that currently has the power to appoint 77 authorities. Do you agree to eliminate the CPCCS's power to appoint authorities and to implement public processes that guarantee civic participation, meritocracy, and public scrutiny, such that the Nacional Assembly appoints, via the aforementioned processes, the authorities currently chosen by the CPCSS, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 5?

The CPCCS is a public entity that is currently elected by universal voting.  Do you agree to modify the Council of Civic Participation and Social Control member appointment process such that members are elected through a process that guarantees civic participation, meritocracy, and public scrutiny, carried out by the National Assembly, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 6?

The Constitution excludes hydrological protection areas from the National System of Protected Areas.  Do you agree that a hydrological protection subsystem shall be incorporated into the National System of Protected Areas, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 7?

The Constitution does not include compensation for those who support the production of ecosystem services. Do you agree that persons, communities, peoples, and nationalities can become beneficiaries of compensation duly regulated by the State, for their support of the production of ecosystem services, amending the Constitution according to Appendix 8?

government_functions.details: The President of Ecuador serves as both head of government and head of state.  The president is directly elected by plurality of at least 40% and a 10% differential to the runner-up vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.  The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

The members of the 150-seat parliament (National Council) are elected for a four-year term under a proportional representation system, within a single nationwide constituency, with a 5% threshold for parties, 7% for coalitions of two or three parties, and 10% for coalitions of more than four parties. Following National Council elections, the leader of the majority party or coalition is usually appointed prime minister by the president.

The Supreme Court is the country's highest appellate court, the judges of which are elected by the National Council; below that are regional, district, and military courts. Article 42.   Conduct of voting       Ballots shall be filled in by voters in a polling booth. While filling in the ballots, the presence of anybody in the polling booth, except the voter, shall be forbidden. The voter (elector) who cannot independently fill in a ballot shall be eligible to be assisted by a person to whom he/she trusts. After voting, the surname of this person shall be written down in the register next to the voter’s (elector’s) signature upon receipt of a ballot. This person cannot be:   1)  a member of the election commission;  2)  an official of the local representative or executive body;  3)  a proxy of the candidate;  4)  a journalist – a media representative;  5)  an observer registered in the corresponding election commission.    The voter (elector) shall put any mark in an empty space to the right of the surname of the candidate for whom he/she votes.   In the ballot with the names of political parties the voter shall put any mark in an empty space to the right of the name of the political party for which he/she votes.    At election of members of other than maslikhats local self-government bodies the voter shall put a mark in an empty space to the right of the surnames of those candidates for whom he/she votes.   3-1. It shall be inadmissible to mark the ballot with a pencil as well as to make any corrections in it.    The filled ballot shall be put by a voter (elector) in the ballot-box.  The clause is excluded by the Constitutional Act of RK of 14.04.2004 No. 545-II.      Footnote. Article 42 is with the changes, introduced by the Constitutional Acts of RK of 06.11.1998 No. 285-I, of 06.05.1999 No. 375-I, of 14.04.2004 No. 545-II, of 19.06.2007 No. 268-III.

government_functions.details: Kazakhstan is a unitary state with a presidential form of government. The President is the head of the state and is directly elected by simple majority popular vote for a 7 year term. The Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Ministers are approved by the lower house of parliament following nomination by the President.   Kazakh parliament is a bicameral system that consists of the 50-sear Senate and the 98-seat Mazhilis. 40 Senate members are indirectly elected by oblast-level assemblies and 10 members are appointed by decree of the President. Members of the Mazhilis are directly elected.   The highest levels of the judiciary are comprised of the Supreme Council of the Republic (44 members) and the Constitutional Council (7 members, including a chairperson).

voting_methods.instructions: Election Law Article 72 While the polling station is open and the voting is ongoing, all polling board members and their deputies shall be present at the polling station. A special room shall be ensured for all polling stations in which it is possible to ensure the secrecy of the ballot. The maximum number of voters simultaneously present at the polling station shall match the number of polling booths at the polling station. All persons who have no rights and duties regarding election administration as laid down by this Law shall not be allowed to stay at the polling station longer than needed to vote. Police officers may not cast their votes nor enter polling stations wearing a uniform, except when requested to do so by the polling board presiding officer, in order to prevent immediate threat to public order and security at the polling station. An objection may be lodged to the municipal election commission due to a breach of rules contained in paras. 1 to 4 of this Article, which shall decide whether to repeat voting at that polling station.

government_functions.details:
Montenegro is a parliamentary republic. The Prime Minister is nominated by the president and approved by the Assembly. The President is directly elected in a two rounds of voting if necessarily. Voters in Montenegro must have resided in the country for a minimum of 10 of the past 15 years. 

The unicameral Skupstina or Assembly has 81 seats with all members directly elected in a single nationwide constituency. Members serve for four years unless snap elections are called by the President of Montenegro, the government, or a minimum of 25 members of parliament. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (Vrhovni Sud), which has 17 members including a court president and deputy president, as well as the Constitutional Court (Ustavni Sud).

government_functions.details: The President of the DRC serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President.  The DRC has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 109-seat Senate and a 500-seat National Assembly. Within the Senate, 108 members are indirectly elected by provincial assemblies and serve 5-year terms. The final member is former president Joseph Kabila who is allowed to serve for life. Within the National Assembly, 439 members are elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies, and 61 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms.  The DRC has two high courts: the Court of Cassation and the Constitutional Court. The Court of Cassation has 26 judges who are nominated by the Judicial Service Council. The Constitutional Court has 9 judges who are nominated by either the President, the Judicial Service Council, or the Parliament and appointed by the President. Constitutional Court judges serve a 9-year term.

voting_methods.instructions:
Togolese citizens living outside Togo and registered with diplomatic and consular representations may register on the electoral list of the commune or prefecture of their place of birth, or in the commune of Lome for Togolese citizens born outside the national territory. Requests for registration must be sent to CENI, together with supporting consular or diplomatic documents, in order to be processed by the Iistes and Cards Committee.

Upon entering the polling station, the voter, bearing his /her voter's card, after having established his/her identity and his/her registration on the electoral roll, takes the ballot paper himself/herself and go into  the polling booth, marks his choice and folds the ballot paper into the ballot box . The president of the polling station, who does not touch the ballot paper, controles that the voter is carrying only one ballot paper. Then, the voter dips his index finger into a bottle containing indelible ink.

Upon entering the polling station, the voter, bearing his or her his voter's card, after having established his identity and his his identity and registration on the electoral roll, takes the ballot paper himself the polling booth, marks his choice and folds the ballot paper. ballot paper. The president of the polling station, who does not touch the that he is carrying only one ballot paper. ballot paper into the ballot box and dips his index finger into a bottle dips his index finger into a bottle containing indelible ink.

Togolese armed forces, security forces and paramilitary forces called upon to guarantee the security of voters and electoral operations on polling day are authorized to vote seventy-two (72) hours before polling day. The voting date for members of the armed forces, security forces and paramilitary forces is April 10, 2024. Voting takes place in polling stations designated by the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI). At the end of voting, the ballot boxes are sealed and deposited with the Independent Local Electoral Commission (CELI). The various electoral documents are placed in sealed envelopes and forwarded to the CELI.

government_functions.details: The President of Togo serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and may serve an unlimited number of 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President.  Togo has a unicameral National Assembly with 113 seats. All members are directly elected via list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Togo has three high courts with distinct purposes. The Supreme Court is composed of a civil/penal chamber and an administrative chamber. The Constitutional Court is composed of 9 judges. Constitutional Court judges may serve up to two 6-year terms and are appointed by the President (2 judges), the National Assembly (2), the Senate (2), and several national legal organizations or communities (3). The High Court of Justice handles treason and other criminal cases against current and former presidents. It is composed of the president and chamber presidents of the Supreme Court and 4 additional judges selected by the National Assembly.

voting_methods.instructions: Article 75. Exercise of the vote by persons living abroad 1. In elections for Deputies, Senators, members of the Legislative Assemblies of the Autonomous Communities, members of the Assemblies of the Autonomous Cities of Ceuta and Melilla and Deputies to the European Parliament, when in the latter case the election is chosen in Spain, the Provincial Delegations of the Electoral Census Office shall send, ex officio, to the address of registration of each person of Spanish nationality registered in the census of resident-absent voters living abroad, the following documentation:  (a) The voting envelope or, as the case may be, the voting envelopes for each process called, with adequate security systems.  b) Two identical certificates of being registered in the census of absentee resident voters living abroad, except in the case of concurrent elections with scrutiny in different electoral boards, in which case the corresponding ones shall be sent according to said electoral concurrence.  c) The envelope or envelopes in which the address of the competent Electoral Board and the envelope in which the address of the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission in which he/she is registered shall appear,  d) An information sheet on how to exercise the right to vote and the address of the official website where the final candidacies shall be displayed, and where downloadable sets of ballots shall be available, with all the competing candidacies, as well as any other information on the electoral processes in progress, and  e) The list of centers authorized for the deposit of votes in ballot boxes in the area of their consular demarcation.  2. The ballot or ballots of the voters registered in the census of absent residents living abroad for each process called shall correspond to the official ballot, as well as to a downloadable model ballot approved by the Electoral Board. The information sheet that shall accompany the documentation referred to in the previous section shall contain the instructions for obtaining a set of ballots telematically in an accessible manner, with all the competing candidacies, as well as the means by which the voters shall be able to know the proclaimed candidacies.  In order to guarantee the secrecy of the vote, only the complete set of ballots may be downloaded telematically.  The Public Administrations shall guarantee the material and technical means to provide the voters with access to the information on the electoral process and to the downloadable ballots.  3. The electoral documentation referred to in the first paragraph shall be sent by registered mail as from the eighteenth day and before the twenty-fifth day following the call for elections.  The Provincial Delegations of the Electoral Census Office shall also send the official ballots to the address of registration of absentee voters living abroad, as of the twenty-ninth day and no later than the thirty-third day following the call, in those provinces where the proclamation of candidates has not been challenged, and in the remaining provinces, no later than the thirty-ninth day.  The downloadable ballots shall be available after the resolution of the appeals filed against the proclamation of candidacies and no later than the fifth day after the proclamation of candidacies.  The Public Administrations shall provide the necessary means in each case so that the mailings provided for in paragraphs 1, 3 and 8 of this Article are carried out in the quickest, safest and most efficient manner, including the diplomatic pouch and forwarding by internal mail of the corresponding country, to the extent that the Electoral Roll Office and the consular administration deem it necessary and possible.

Only OCV voters can vote by mail. 7. Voters who choose to exercise their right to vote by mail shall include in the envelope addressed to the corresponding Electoral Board, in addition to the voting envelope or envelopes, one of the certificates of being registered in the census, on the back of which shall be the signature and passport or National Identity Card number of the voter, a photocopy of the passport or National Identity Card issued by the Spanish authorities or a certificate of nationality or, failing this, a certificate of registration in the Consular Register issued by the Consular Office or the Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission of Spain in the country of residence. All of the above shall be placed in the envelope addressed to the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission to which each voter is attached, and the other certificate of being registered in the census shall be included in this envelope. The documentation thus ordered shall be sent personally by the voter by postal mail, certified when possible, to the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission to which each voter is attached, no later than the fifth day prior to the day of the election.  Envelopes received by mail at the Consular Post or Consular Section of the Diplomatic Mission before the final proclamation of candidatures shall not be valid. Those arriving after the second day prior to the day of the election shall not be valid either. This deadline shall not be extended in order to ensure that the votes arrive in time to be counted by the Electoral Boards.

Article 32 LOREG 1. Registration in the electoral roll is compulsory. In addition to the name and surname, the only data necessary for the identification of the voter in the act of voting, without prejudice to the provisions of Article 85, the number of the National Identity Card shall be included among the remaining census data.  2. The Municipal Councils shall process the registration of the residents in their municipal district ex officio.  3. The Consular Posts and Consular Sections of the Diplomatic Missions shall ex officio process the registration of Spaniards residing in their demarcation in the manner established by regulation.

Deputies serve 4-year terms and are directly elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies (348 seats) or directly elected by plurality vote (2 seats in Ceuta and Melilla).  The Spanish judiciary is headed by the Supreme Court (president and 79 judges organized into thematic chambers) and the Constitutional Court (12 judges). Supreme Court judges are nominated by the General Council of the Judiciary Power (CGPJ) and appointed by the King. These judges may serve until they are 70 years old. Constitutional Court judges are nominated by the legislature, president, and CGPJ and appointed by the King to serve 9-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions:
This voting method is for registered voters who reside outside of the Republic or will be outside of the Republic on the day of the election. 

If the Chief Electoral Officer is satisfied that prima-facie an applicant for postal ballot paper is entitled to the same, the latter will receive a ballot paper; a ballot envelope, in a form approved by the Chief Electoral Officer; a form of affidavit for completion by the applicant verifying his right to vote in the election and his right to a postal vote, in a form approved by the Chief Electoral Officer; and a covering reply envelope marked “Postal Ballot Paper Enclosed.”

The postal voter shall mark the ballot paper in the usual way, so that no person can see or know how it is marked (except as allowed by Section 174 of this Chapter). The voter shall deposit the ballot paper in the ballot envelope and securely seal it. He or she must also complete the affidavit, and swear it before a person authorized to administer oaths in the place where the applicant is, and enclose the ballot envelope and the affidavit in the covering reply envelope.

The covering reply envelope must be placed in the mail and be postmarked on or before the date of the election; provided, however, that in no event will a covering reply envelope that is received through the mail be accepted on or after fourteen (14) days after the date of the election.

Upon entering the polling place, the voter shall state his or her name in full and his address to the election officials and present his or her RMI national ID or any of the following: valid passport, valid driver's license, or any other identification documents produced to the satisfaction of the election official.  

Another election official will check the voters list to confirm is he or she is a registered voter, and if so, the official will announce the name and address as shown in the list. 

If the person cannot present any of the required forms of identification, that person must provide verification as to the identity by the oral confirmation from one poll watcher representing each of the candidates in the electoral district for which the voter is registered to vote in; two registered voters eligible to vote in the electoral district for which the voter is registered to vote in; and one of the electoral officials. (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 1(a)(b)(c) of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980) 
 
The voter shall mark his ballot paper in accordance with procedures laid down in the electoral instructions, but in such a way that the secrecy of the ballot is not infringed (except as allowed by Section 174 of this Chapter - Assistance to certain voters). (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 5 of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980) 
 
The voter (except those to whom Subsection (2) of this Section applies) must, prior to receiving ballot laterals from the election official, sign his name next to his printed name as it appears on the list of voters as provided in, accordance with Section 128. (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 6(a) of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980) 
 
Note that the voter who signs on the list of voters in accordance with Subsection 6(a) of this Section shall be deemed to be signing an affidavit, under penalty of law, as to the truthfulness of the facts stated in the voters list. (Part VIII, Sec. 173, Subsection 6(c) of the Elections and Referenda Act 1980)

electoral_rights.source: Part VIII, Sec. 173 of the Elections and Referenda Act of 1980 (last amended 2006) ; Article 4, Sec. 3, Subsection 2 of the Constitution of the Republic of Marshall Islands

voting_methods.instructions:
For Council of States elections, citizens abroad registered to vote in a canton are permitted to vote in that canton's Council of States elections only if the canton's law allows it (half  of the cantons allow it). Swiss citizens abroad must join the Register of the Swiss Abroad and be registered on the electoral roll of their last commune of residence (or place of origin if they have never lived in Switzerland) by filling out a form online or at an embassy. Once registered for the first time, the person remains in the register unless the voting materials to the voter were returned undeliverable for three times in a row.

If canton law allows citizens to vote from overseas, they must vote by postal vote in the same manner as in-country postal voting.

Online voting is only through federally approved pilots in the cantons, which are currently restricted to a maximum of 10 per cent of the country's electorate. This limit does not apply to Swiss citizens living abroad but out-of-country voters can vote online only if their canton of registration is utilizing online voting.

The federal legislation provides minimum standards for internet voting pilots to be introduced and implemented  by cantons. Comprehensive end-to-end testing of internet voting systems  must take place before the Federal Counil can approve their use. The law includes requirements for publishing the source code, providing voter information, and allowing voters to familiarize with and to test internet voting outside of an election. The legislation requires that verification of eligibility to vote and voting secrecy be guaranteed and abuses prevented in the use of online voting system. All internet voting systems are required to provide voters with the possiblity to individually verify that their vote has been cast as intended. Eligible voters will receive codes and their voter identification card that will allow them to check that their ballot is recorded correctly and corresponds to their intention. The federal authorities have also undertaken measures to promote cyber security and data protection in online voting systems.

All voters automatically receive the official voting materials by post ahead of election day; if they choose to vote by post, they can do so as soon as the voting materials are received between three to four weeks before the election day.  All cantons are required to provide a postal voting option, including to citizens residing abroad. 

The delivery by post of the official voting materials to all voters is mandated for between three to four weeks prior to election day, to be sent by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The cantons are mandated to enact provisions regulating postal voting, including to guarantee the verification of eligibility to vote, voting secrecy and the counting of all the votes, and to prevent abuses. Voters who choose to vote by post, follow the postal voting instructions in the voting materials sent to them.  The voter must send their identification card, using a double envelope system, with the ballot to prevent the possibility of voting additionally at a polling station. Once the voter has filled out his/her ballot these are put into an anonymous return envelope provided in the package. This first anonymous envelope and the identification card are placed into the return envelope and then sent back to the municipality.  In some municipalities, the envelope can be returned directly to the municipality mailbox. Otherwise, the envelope is to be returned by post; in some cantons postage does not have to be paid.

Under federal law, cantons are obliged to provide early voting at polling stations for a minimum of two of the four days immediately prior to election day.  Cantonal law specifies the time that all or certain polling stations will be open for advance voting. Instead of opening polling stations on advance polling days, the canton can allow voters to hand over their ballot paper in a sealed envelope at a public office.

The manner of early voting is the same as for voting on election day, whereby the voter brings the ballots that were sent to him/her by post ahead of the election day to cast at the polling station or to hand  over in a sealed envelope at a public office, whichever means is provided by the canton. The cantons are mandated to enact the required provisions relating to the preservation of voting secrecy and the prevention of abuses in early voting processes.

All voters receive the official voting materials by post to their home address between three to four weeks ahead of election day by the commune in which the voter is registered to vote. The Federal Chancellory is required by law to issue brief instructions on voting procedures prior to each general elecction, which are delivered along with the voting materials to voters in cantons with a system of proportional representation. If the voter wishes to vote in-person (rather than postal vote), he/she takes the ballots that weree previously received by post and drops them off at the polling station where they are registered to vote. At the  polling station, the voter must present his/her identification card. Votes may be cast by proxy at the polling station provided the cantonal law permits this for cantonal elections. Persons who are unable to write may have their ballot paper completed in accordance with their instructions by a person of their chose who is eligible to vote. Voting secrecy must be preserved in the voting process. In cantons where the proportional list system is used for the National Council elections, voters may cross out names on party lists or write names twice, split their vote between parties or draw up their own lists on a blank ballot combining candidates from different lists within the constituency.

electoral_rights.source: 1976 Federal Act on Political Rights, Articles 5(6), 6; Cantonal Laws; 1999 Constitution, Article 136(1); 1997 Federal Act on Political Rights, Article 2.6

government_functions.details: Switzerland is a federal republic. The President, Vice President, and second Vice President are elected by Parliament from the Federal Council to serve 1-year, non-consecutive terms. The Federal Council is an entity comprised of 7 federal councillors. These councillors are indirectly elected by the Federal Assembly for a 4-year term.   Switzerland has a bicameral parliament that consists of the Council of States (comprised of 46 members that represent Cantons) and the National Council (which has open elections). Both houses have equal standing under the Constitution. Jointly, parliament is called the Federal Assembly.   The Federal Supreme Court is the highest level of the judiciary. Judges serve for six-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions: Any eligible voter residing abroad, temporarily or permanently, can cast a vote from outside Poland. Citizens  who will be out of the country on election day can apply for an absentee voting certificate and vote at any polling station abroad.  There are 402 overseas polling places. Overseas voters can cast votes in-person at polling stations established at embassies/consulates (and possible other locations) or, 15 days before the election day, can apply for postal voting to the respective consul and receive a voting package sent out not later than 10 days before election day.  The number and offices of the overseas polling stations  are determined by the minister of foreign affairs in consultation with the National Election Commission, on the basis of establishing a polling station where there are at least 15 registered voters and establishing at least one polling station within the territorial responsiblity of the consultate to facilitate postal voting. Voters living abroad and holding a valid Polish passport (or valid ID in countries where Polish citizens can enter with only a Polish ID card) can be entered into the voter list compiled by the respective consulate, based on personal application lodged verbally, in writing, or by phone, fax or electronically. The foreign ministry, in consultaton with the National Election Commission, is to issue a regulation that will ensure that an overseas voter is entered on only one voter list.  Voters in possession of an absentee voting certificate issued in Poland can vote abroad at any polling station.  Citizens permanently living abroad can be entered on the voter list of a consultate on election, provided the voter presents proof of permament residence abroad in which case the commission places its seal and date of votong on the free page of the passport dedicated to visas and enters the passport number and validity date in the remarks section of the voter list.  The in-person oveseas voting process is the same as for in-country voting, except for the Polish passport requirement in countries where Polish citizens cannot enter without a passport and proxy voting is not permitted in overseas voting. For overseas postal voting, the voting package includes an addressed return envelope, the ballot paper(s), a ballot paper envelope, a statement of personal and secret casting of the vote, and voting instructions. The postal voter is to mark the ballot, and insert the marked ballot into the ballot paper envelope, seal the envelope and insert it into the return envelope together with the signed declaration (a statement of personal and secret casting of the vote) and return it by mail at his or her own cost to the address of the consul. Voters can also deliver the postal vote in the envelope in person to the respective consul. The consul transfers all returned envelopes that it received by the end of voting time to the appropriate election commission.

In-country postal voting is limited to those who can produce a disability certificate or who are at least 60 years old or who are in mandatory quarantine or isolation on election day.  Eligible in-country postal voters must apply for postal voting at least 12 days before the election day and receive a voting package which includes an addressed return envelope, the ballot paper(s), a ballot paper envelope, a declaration of personal and secret casting of the vote, and voting instructions. The postal voter is to mark the ballot, and insert the marked ballot into the ballot paper envelope, seal the envelope and insert it into the return envelope together with the signed declaration and return it by mail at his or her own cost or drop it off at the office of the designated operator or the respective post office.  Voters can also choose to have their marked ballot picked up at their place of residence provided that they request this service at the time of collecting the voting package.  Voters must provide documentary proof of identity when returning postal ballots.

Citizens are included in the voter list at their permanent place of residence. Until voter lists are finalized, voters can apply to obtain an Absentee Voting Certficate, enabling them to vote at any polling station. These voters are removed from the voter list in their place of residence and added to the supplementary voter list of the precinct where the vote was cast on election day. On the day of voting, the precinct election commission can add omitted persons to the voter list with proof of permanent residence on the territory of the given voting circuit, provided that the office of the municipality has confirmed that it has not received a notice of this person’s forfeiture of the right to vote or notice of the inclusion of that person on the roll of voters of another voting circuit. Proxy voting is prohibited except that voters with a significant or moderate degree of disability within the meaning of the law or who are over 60 can formally give another person their proxy vote (a proxy vote can be taken only from one person or two if immediate family member, and cannot be given to election commission members or partisan agents). Upon arrival at the polling station, a voter must provide proof of identity to the election commission. A stamped ballot paper is issued and the voter confirms receipt with his/her signature on the voter list. The voter must mark the ballot in the polling booth that guarantees secrecy. For Sejm elections, the voter must vote for only one candidate list with an "X" in the box to the left side next to the name of one of the candidates from this list, which indicates this candidates priority in obtaining the mandate; for Senat elections, the voter puts an "X" in the box to the left of the chosen candidate. The voter inserts the ballot in the ballot box located in a visible position, in such a way that the printed side of ballot is not visible. Upon request by a disabled voter, another person who is not a poll worker or partisan observer can assist the voter to vote.

1997 Constitution, Article 62; 2011 Election Code, Article 10(4)

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

government_functions.details:
Oman is a sultanate. The Sultan is also the Prime Minister and is unelected. The Sultan must be a male descendent of Sayyid Turki bin Said bin Sultan and must be the legitimate son of Omani Muslim parents. Heirs to the Sultanate are determined by the Royal Family Council, which is constitutionally enshrined. The cabinet is appointed by the Sultan. 

Oman has a bicameral parliament called the Council of Oman. It is comprised of the Council of State and the Consultative Council. Members of the Council of State are directly appointed by the monarch. Members of the Consultative Council are elected by simple majority vote to serve 4-year terms. Members must be meet several requirements prior to running for office. 

The highest court in Oman is the Supreme Court. The judiciary is supervised by the Supreme Council, which has supervisory powers over the judicial system, as well as auxilliary bodies.

institution.term_details: Although not specified in the law, the term of the members start  on the day after the day of the return of that writ and ends at the close of polling day at the next general election. This means the term is 3 years, approximately, as elections are called and held every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions:
Overseas voters have multiple options for obtaining their voting papers. They can either download the papers from the Electoral Commission's website, apply to have the papers posted to their overseas address, or vote in person at a designated overseas voting place. When it comes to returning the voting papers, overseas voters can choose to upload them to a secure server on the Commission's website, post them directly to the Commission, or post/hand deliver them to the nearest designated overseas voting place. These methods ensure that overseas voters can obtain and return their voting papers conveniently and securely.

Votes returned using the overseas upload service need to be received by the Commission before 7pm on election day. Postal votes need to be postmarked in another country before or on the day before election day and received by the Commission or a Returning Officer before noon on the Tuesday 10 days after the election.

A limited service for advance voters leaving New Zealand before advance voting starts will be available from the Returning Officer from two and a half weeks before election day.

Voters can vote at a voting place from 9am to 7pm on election day. The doors close at 7pm - anyone inside the voting place at 7pm is allowed to complete their vote.

If the voter is not enrolled they can complete an enrolment form at the voting place or enrol online at vote.nz.

Voters do not have to be enrolled in the electorate to vote at a voting place in the electorate. A voter enrolled in any electorate can vote at any voting place anywhere in the country.

Upon receiving a ballot paper, the voter is required to promptly proceed to one of the designated inner compartments provided for privacy. Inside the compartment, the voter must cast their vote alone and in secret. This involves marking their party vote by placing a tick within the circle adjacent to the name of the desired party. Similarly, the electorate vote is indicated by placing a tick within the circle just before the name of the preferred constituency candidate. Following these steps ensures the voter's choices are accurately recorded while maintaining the confidentiality of their ballot.

In-country voters can request mail-in ballots up to 15 days before election day by writing to the government of their current commune of residence or via a secure web form. Completed ballots must be received by 14h on election day.

Loi du 8 mars 2018, Art. 168-170

Overseas voters can request a mail-in ballot up to 30 days before election day by writing to the government of their most recent commune of residence (or the Luxembourg City government if they have never lived in Luxembourg) or via a secure web form.

Completed ballots must be received by 14h on election day.

Voters must present their ID card, passport, residency permit, or residency letter to polling staff.

Loi du 8 mars 2018, Art. 74

government_functions.details: The hereditary Grand Duke is the chief of state of Luxembourg, while the Prime Minister serves as the head of government. The Prime Minister, typically the Chamber of Deputies majority leader. is appointed by the monarch.  The legislature consists of a unicameral Chamber of Deputies with 60 seats. All members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice (27 judges) and the Constitutional Court (9 judges) are the highest judicial institutions of Luxembourg.  Judges in these bodies are appointed by the Grand Duke and may serve for life.

The President is elected for seven years by direct universal suffrage (absolute majority or majority at runoff) and can be re-elected once. The Legislative is composed of the National Assembly (deputies, directly elected for 5-year terms) and the Senate (senators, indirectly elected for 5-year terms). The Judiciary is composed of the Constitutional Court, judicial courts, administrative courts, financial courts, the High Court of Justice, the Court of Justice of the Republic, and other exceptional courts.

voting_methods.instructions: Only permitted for people with disabilities as per the official election schedule (ECB/NOTIF-01/2023/4403)

The Polling Officer 1 shall verify the identity of the voter from the Voters’ List against his/her Voter Photo Identity Card (VPIC). A voter whose identity is established shall then proceed to Polling Officer 2 who will obtain his/her signature or thumb impression in the Register of Voters and issue a White Voter’s Slip for male voters and Yellow Voter’s Slip for female voters. The voter will proceed to Polling Officer 3 and hand over the Voter’s Slip, proceed to the Voting Compartment to vote secretly unless he/she requires assistance as permitted under the Election Act. The casting of the vote by a voter shall be confirmed by a single beep that will be heard after a vote is cast.

government_functions.details: Executive Power is vested in the Lhengye Zhungtshog which shall consist of the Ministers headed by the Prime Minister and shall protect and strengthen the sovereignty of the Kingdom, provide good governance, and ensure peace, security, well-being, and happiness of the people. The number of Ministers shall be determined by the number of Ministries required to provide efficient and good governance. The creation of an additional ministry or reduction of any ministry shall be approved by Parliament.   The Legislative Branch consists of the Druk Gyalpo (monarch), the National Council, and the National Assembly which shall ensure that the Government safeguards the interests of the nation and fulfills the aspirations of the people through public review of policies and issues, bills and other legislations and scrutiny of State functions.  The judicial authority of Bhutan is vested in the Royal Courts of Justice comprising the Supreme Court, the High Court, the Dzongkhag Court, the Dungkhag Court, and such other Courts and Tribunals as may be established from time to time by the Druk Gyalpo on the recommendation of the National Judicial Commission.  Source: Bhutan 2008 Constitution - Article 10, Sections 1 and 2, Article 20, Sections 1 and 2, Article 21, Sections 1 and 2

The presiding officers shall not accept any challenge based on the voter's inability to appear on the electoral roll. government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The two (2) incumbents corresponding to the list of the party or electoral alliance that obtained the majority of the votes cast and the first of the next list in number of votes shall be elected. The second incumbent of the latter list shall be the first alternate of the Senator elected by it.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

If they have been reelected or succeeded each other, they may not be elected to either office, except after the interval of a term.

The presiding officers shall not accept any challenge based on the voter's inability to appear on the electoral roll. Anyone who is found crossed out in red ink on the electoral roll of the polling place shall be excluded from the same, and in such case shall not be able to cast a vote even if an error is alleged.

government_functions.details: The President of Liberia is both the head of state and government. The President is elected  to serve a six-year term and can serve up to two terms.  Liberia has a bicameral legislative system, which consists of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Senate has 30 members, two from each county, who are elected to serve nine-year terms. The House of Representatives has 73 members, who are elected to serve six-year terms.  The judicial branch is headed by the Supreme Court, which is the highest court in the country. Other courts include circuit courts, magistrate courts, and special courts.

government_functions.details: Tuvalu is a constitutional monarchy with a parliamentary democracy. The British sovereign is head of state and is represented by a governor-general, who must be a citizen of Tuvalu and is appointed by the head of state on the recommendation of the prime minister. The prime minister is elected by parliament and is head of government. The cabinet consists of the prime minister, plus up to four other ministers, appointed by the governor-general from among the members of parliament, on the advice of the prime minister. The cabinet advises the governor-general who must accept its advice.     Parliament is composed of 15 members: two elected every four years by universal adult suffrage from seven electoral districts and one from the remainder. The speaker, elected by the members, presides over parliament.     The constitution provides for the operation of a judiciary and for an independent public service. It guarantees protection of all fundamental rights and freedoms, and provides for the determination of citizenship.     Source: Constitution of Tuvalu; Commonwealth Governance profile

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Proportional representation for some seats, two-round system for others plus separate lists for women and youths/people with disabilities

voting_methods.instructions: Voters living abroad can vote in-person at Mauritanian embassies and consulates.
Members of the Armed and security forces vote the day preceding the polling day.

Voters vote in person at the polling station where they are registered to vote. The voter is admitted to vote upon presentation of his/her Voter's Card and National ID Card. Indelible ink on the voter's finger is checked and applied, as a safeguard against multiple voting. Once the voter's identity and presence on the voter list is determined, and after he/she is determined not to have an inked finger, the polling official gives the voter the (four) ballot(s).  Upon receiving the ballot(s), voters proceed to the polling booth to manually mark the ballot(s) in secret. Voters with certain affirmities can be assisted by a person or voter of their choice. After marking the ballot(s), the voterproceeds to insert each ballot into the respective  ballot box.

electoral_rights.source: 1991 Organic Law on the election of deputies to the National Assembly, Article 26

government_functions.details:
In Mauritania, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and has no term limit.

Mauritania has a unicameral National Assembly (Al Jam'iya Al Wataniya) with 176 seats. 88 members are elected via absolute majority vote (up to two rounds) in a single, nationwide constituency. The remaining 88 members are elected via closed-list proportional representation vote in multi-member constituencies, including 4 overseas constituencies. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. Out of the 88 nationwide constituency seats, 20 seats are reserved for women, and 11 are reserved for youth (aged 25 to 30). 

The Mauritanian judiciary is composed of the Supreme Court (21 judges), the Constitutional Council (9 judges), and the High Court of Justice (9 judges). Judges within these institutions are all appointed by either the President, the Prime Minister, or members of the National Assembly.

election_issues.issues: Monarchy; democracy; electoral process

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country registered voters may cast a ballot in person at a diplomatic mission in their country of residence. These include the office of each Ambassador, High Commissioner, and Trade Representative, as the case may be. The election legislation does not provide specific locations, times or instructions for out-of-country voting. These will likely be specified in regulations adopted by the election commission.

Electors vote at specified polling stations in the chiefdom where they are registered  as a voter unless a special polling arrangement has been prescribed. Electors vote first in the primary elections among their chiefdom's candidates and then on another day in the secondary elections among the winning chiefdom candidates within that constituency. Voting is only in person. On arrival at the polling station, a voter presents his/her voter ID card to an election official. The official then checks for the voter's name in the voter register. If the voter is registered but does not have a voter card, he/she must prove to the presiding officer that he/she is the one whose name appears on the voter register. The election official is also required to determine that the voter has not already voted in the election by checking that the voter's name is not marked off the voter register (in past elections, indelible ink on the index finger has also been used). Next, the election official issues the voter an ordinary ballot. A  tendered ballot is issued if the voter's name on the register is already marked as voted and the voter properly answers a set of specified questions and makes and signs a declaration that he/she has not already voted (the voter's registration number is put on the back of the tendered ballot and entered on the tendered ballots register).  The presiding officer can refuse to issue a ballot paper to the voter if an objection by declarationn on oath is made by a candidate, agent or voter on grounds that the person is impersonating a dead or incapacitated voter and the election officer is not satisfied of the person's claimed identity; the refusal can be appealed to the returning officer. Next, the election official calls out the number of the voter on the voter register, enters the number in the space provided on the counterfoil of the issued ballot, tears out the ballot paper and marks it with the official mark on the back of the ballot, folds the ballot paper in four so that the face of the ballot is on the inside and the official mark on the outside, then unfolds it and hands it to the voter, and draws a line in red ink through the number and name or photograph of the voter in the voter register as evidence that the ballot has been issued. Voting is by secret ballot in both primary and secondary elections. The voter goes immediately with the ballot paper to an unoccupied polling booth and in secret puts a marks on the picture of one candidate of his/her choice. The voter then folds the ballot so that the face of it is on the inside and places it in the respective ballot box. If the election officer has any doubt that the ballot was not the one issued at the polling station, he/she may require the voter to show the presiding officer the number and official mark on the back of the ballot paper before it is inserted in the ballot box.  Tendered ballots are placed the presiding officer in a separate envelope. Any voter who is illiterate or has a physical disability can request the presiding officer to assist or to allow a person accompanying that voter to assist him/her cast a ballot. The assisting person is bound to keep the secrecy of the vote. The presiding officer is to record in the voter register that the voter has been assisted by him/her or an accompanying person and the reason for doing so. A voter who inadvertently spoils his/his ballot paper may return it to the presiding officer for a new ballot paper. After voting, a voter must immediately leave the polling station.

government_functions.details: Eswatini is an absolute monarchy. The Monarch is the chief of state and the monarchy is hereditary. The successor to the monarchy is determined by Swazi law and custom and is called the Crown Prince or Umntfwana. The Prime Minister is appointed by the monarch from among the members of the House of Assembly.   The legislative branch is bicameral. The Senate has 30 total seats. 10 seats are indirectly elected by the House of Assembly. The other 20 seats are appointed by the monarchy. In the House of Assembly, the majority of members are directly elected, although 10 members are directly appointed by the monarch. Per the Constitution, there is a maximum of 76 seats in the Assembly, however, there is a provision wherein 4 of these seats can be allocated to ensure representation of women. These seats are elected by members of the Assembly.  The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (which has a chief justice and at least 4 justices) and the High Court. The Supreme Court has jurisdiction over all constitutional matters. Justices of both courts are appointed by the monarch with the advice of the Judicial Service Commission.

Subject to this Constitution, every Zimbabwean citizen who is of or over eighteen years of age has the right-- a. to vote in all elections and referendums to which this Constitution or any other law applies, and to do so in secret; and b. to stand for election for public office and, if elected, to hold such office

voting_methods.instructions: PART XIV  POSTAL VOTING  [Part XIV (sections 71 – 80) substituted by Act 3 of 2012]  71 Interpretation in Part XIV  The reference in section 73(2)(b)(ii) to a “letter” includes a reference to a letter sent by way of elec- tronic mail, under the following conditions—      (a)  thesender(thatis,thepersonreferredtoin73(2)(b)(ii)(A)or(B)andrecipient(thatis,theappli- cant for a postal vote) must both use official electronic mail addresses; and      (b)  theelectronicmailsentbysendermustbeauthenticatedbytheelectronicsignatureofthesender; and      (c)  theelectronicmailmustbeembodiedinahardcopyprintedbytherecipient,whichcopyshallbe the “letter” referred to in 73(2)(b)(ii).     72 Personswhomayvotebypost  Where an election is to be held in a constituency, a person who is registered as a voter on the roll for that constituency shall be entitled to vote by post in terms of this Part if, on all polling days in the election, he or she will be—      (a)  on duty as a member of a disciplined force or as an electoral officer; or      (b)  on duty in the service of the Government outside Zimbabwe; or      (c)  outside Zimbabwe as the spouse of a person referred to in paragraph (b);     and so unable to vote at a polling station in the constituency.  For cut offs, see articles 73-79 Electoral Act

57 Mannerofvoting  The voting at an election shall be by ballot which shall be conducted in substance and as nearly as pos- sible in the following manner—      (a)  every ballot paper shall be in the form prescribed and there shall be printed on every ballot pa- per—         (i)  in type of equal size, the names of all the duly nominated candidates at the election in alphabetical order of surnames; and         (ii)  the symbols, if any, specified by the duly nominated candidates at the election in terms of paragraph (b) of subsection (1) of section forty-six, each printed to a size that permits the vertical extremities or the horizontal extremities or both such extremities to touch oppo- site sides of the appropriate square on the ballot paper; and         (iii)  in capital letters of equal size, the abbreviation of every political party for which a duly nominated candidate at the election is standing or which is sponsoring such a candidate, where the candidate concerned specified the abbreviation in his or her nomination paper in terms of paragraph (c) of subsection (1) of section forty-six; and         (iv)  a passport-sized photograph of the candidate; and [Subparagraph amended by Act 17 of 2007]         (v)  such other particulars as may be prescribed;           (b)  beforetheballotpaperishandedtotheapplicant,thepresidingofficershallmarktheballotpaper   with the official mark;      (c)  when the person claiming the vote has received the ballot paper he or she shall—         (i)  take the paper to the compartment provided for the purpose; and         (ii)  then signify the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote by secretly placing a cross    in the rectangle opposite the name of that candidate or, if there is more than one such rec-    tangle, in the rectangle nearest to the right-hand side of the ballot paper; and         (iii)  then fold the ballot paper so that the official mark is visible and the names of the candi- dates and the cross made by him or her are not visible and drop the ballot paper in the bal-    lot box placed in front of the presiding officer:   Provided that, if he or she has spoilt the ballot paper, he or she may return it to the    presiding officer in terms of section fifty-eight and shall deal with the second ballot paper given to him or her in accordance with this paragraph.

electoral_rights.source: Electoral Act

government_functions.details: The head of state and government is the president, who is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The president can serve no more than two 5-year terms. The president is assisted by two vice presidents.  The parliament consists of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly normally has 210 members, all of whom are directly elected. For the first two parliaments elected after the promulgation of the 2013 constitution, however, the National Assembly has 270 seats, with the 60 additional seats reserved for women—6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status—elected through a system of proportional representation. The Senate comprises 80 members: 60 (6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status) elected by a party-list system of proportional representation, with men and women being listed alternately on every list; 16 traditional chiefs elected by the provincial assemblies of chiefs in the 8 provinces; 2 seats for the president and deputy president of the National Council of Chiefs (the administrative body of traditional chiefs); and 2 representatives of people with disabilities. All parliament members serve five-year terms.  The highest courts of the Zimbabwean judiciary are the Supreme Court (5 judges) and Constitutional Court (7 judges). Supreme Court judges may serve until age 70, while Constitutional Court judges serve a single 15-year term.  Judges from both courts are appointed by the President.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: SINGLE MEMBER MAJORITY The Single Member Majority system is applied for the Presidential election. In this system the winner must obtain an absolute majority of votes the minimum being 50% plus one vote. If a candidate fails to secure an outright majority, a run-off election is conducted between the two candidates with the highest number of votes.

A person is disqualified for election as President or Vice-President if he or she has already held office as President under this Constitution for two terms, whether continuous or not, and for the purpose of this subsection three or more years' service is deemed to be a full term.

government_functions.details: The head of state and government is the president, who is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The president can serve no more than two 5-year terms. The president is assisted by two vice presidents.  The parliament consists of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly normally has 210 members, all of whom are directly elected. For the first two parliaments elected after the promulgation of the 2013 constitution, however, the National Assembly has 270 seats, with the 60 additional seats reserved for women—6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status—elected through a system of proportional representation. The Senate comprises 80 members: 60 (6 from each of the 8 provinces and the 2 cities with provincial status) elected by a party-list system of proportional representation, with men and women being listed alternately on every list; 16 traditional chiefs elected by the provincial assemblies of chiefs in the 8 provinces; 2 seats for the president and deputy president of the National Council of Chiefs (the administrative body of traditional chiefs); and 2 representatives of people with disabilities. basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 336 members of the National Assembly consist of 266 general seats elected by first-past-the-past voting in single-member constitutencies, 60 seats reserved for women elected by indirect closed list proportional representation based on the number of general seats won by each party in each province, and ten seats reserved for non-Muslims elected through indirect closed list proprotional representation based on the number of overall general seats won by each party.
