voting_methods.instructions:
The following persons may cast their votes by advance postal ballot: Persons in the government or military service who temporarily reside in an electoral area due to being in the service, as well as their spouse and children; a person appointed by a Returning Officer, including police personnel, for the performance of any duty in connection with an election at a polling station other than the one at which he/she is entitled to cast a vote; a person with any physical disability who is unable to travel and has a national ID card with a logo for physical disability; a person detained in a prison or held in custody.

A voter who is entitled to cast a postal ballot and wishes to do so must submit an applicaton to the relevant Returning Office within such time as is specified by the Election Commission (22 January 2024 as per the ECP press release on postal voting) or in the case of poll workers, to apply within three days of being appointed. Upon receipt of the application, the Returning Officer sends the postal ballots by post to the voters, including an envelope bearing on its face a form of certificate of posting, showing the date, to be filled in by the proper official of the Post Office at the time of posting by the voter. Upon receiving the postal ballot paper, the voter is to record his/her vote in the prescribed manner and then to post the ballot paper to the Returning Officer in the envelope sent to him/her, so as to reach the Returning Officer before the consolidation of results by him/her.

When a voter presents himself/herself at the polling station to vote, the presiding officer is to issue a ballot paper after the voter produces his/her national ID card and is shown not to have the indelible ink on his/her finger. A bio-metric verification system or other technologies to verify identity in addition to the ID card may be used, but failure to provide identify through the new technology cannot disentitle the voter to cast a vote if otherwise entitled to do so. Before the ballot paper is issued to a voter, the number and name of the voter on the electoral roll is to be called out and struck off. Indelible ink is to be put on the finger or thumb of either hand of the voter. The ballot paper is to be stamped on its back with the official mark and signed by the presiding officer. The presiding officer will also record, on the counterfoil of the ballot paper, the number of the voter on the electoral roll and the number of the voter's ID card, stamp and sign the counter foil, and obtain the thumb impression of the voter on the counterfoil. The voter must also put their thumb impression on the space provided on the electoral roll next to their photo. On receiving the ballot paper, the voter should proceed to the place reserved for marking the ballot paper; in secret, put the prescribed mark on the ballot paper at any place within the space containing the name/symbol of the candidate for whom he/she wishes to vote; and fold the ballot paper and insert it in the ballot box. The voter must immediately leave the polling station after voting. If a voter inadvertently spoils the ballot paper, he/she can obtain a replacement ballot from the presiding officer. Tendered ballot papers are used when a voter who presents himself/herself to vote but another voter is recorded to have voted in his/her place. A candidate or polling agent can challenge the identity of a voter who presents himself/herself or declare reasonable cause to believe that the voter has already voted at the same or another polling station. If the candidate/agent undertakes to prove the charge in court and makes a monetary deposit to the presiding officer, the officer is to issue the voter a 'challenged ballot paper'. When the voter marks the challenged ballot paper, the presiding officer places it in a separate packet instead of the ballot box.

government_functions.details:
The Islamic Republic of Pakistan is a federal parliamentary republic and comprises four provinces. The president is the head of state, representing the unity of the republic, elected indirectly by an electoral college consisting of members of both houses and provincial assemblies. Presidential powers are largely ceremonial.

 

Parliament is bicameral and comprises the National Assembly and the Senate. The Senate consists of 104 members indirectly elected for a six-year term, with one half of the membership renewed every three years by the members of the four provincinal assemblies, by proportional representation. The National Assembly comprises 342 members, with 272 members directly elected to general seats, 60 members elected to seats reserved for women and 10 members to seats reserved for non-Muslims. All members serve a five-year terms. The executive is headed by the prime minister, appointed by the members of the National Assembly through a vote. The prime minister is assisted by a council of ministers whose members are appointed by the president on the advice of the prime minister.

 

The judiciary consists of the Supreme Court of Pakistan, provincial High Courts, District Courts, anti-terrorism Courts, and Sharia Courts.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Law on Elections of Members of the National Assembly ( as amended 2013)  Art. 5. The Members of the National Assembly shall be elected by a general, universal, free, fair, just, equal, direct, and secret election by means of secret balloting. The electoral system shall be proportional representation with provincial/municipal constituencies.

institution.term_details: Article 78 Constitution The term of the National Assembly is five years and ends on the day when the new National Assembly takes office.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Article 34 Constitution Khmer citizens of either sex shall enjoy the rights to vote and to stand as candidates for an election.  Khmer citizens of either sex who are at least eighteen years old shall have the rights to vote.

voting_methods.instructions: Art. 85- (new)  The Polling shall be conducted in one (1) day only.  The polling shall start at 7 a.m. and end at 3 p.m., unless otherwise decided by the National Election Committee.  If all voters who have their names in the voter list of a polling station have cast their ballots, the Polling Station Commission may declare to end the polling before 3 p.m.  The chairperson of the polling station shall announce the closure of the polling at 3 p.m.  Every person who wishes to cast his/her vote shall not be permitted to enter into the inner perimeter after 3 p.m.  Voters who have the rights to vote after 3 p.m. are the persons being inside the polling station or the inner perimeter at 3 p.m.

government_functions.details: In Cambodia, the monarch serves as chief of state while the prime minister acts as head of government. The King is appointed by the Royal Council of the Throne out of all eligible men in the royal family. The Prime Minister is nominated by the Chairman of the National Assembly from among the majority party and confirmed by the King.   Cambodia has a bicameral Parliament including a 62-seat Senate and a 125-seat National Assembly. In the Senate, 58 members are indirectly elected by commune councils. An additional 2 members are indirectly elected by the National Assembly, and 2 members are appointed by the King. All members serve 6-year terms. In the National Assembly, all 125 members are directly elected by proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. All members serve 5-year terms.    The highest judicial bodies in Cambodia are the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges serve for life, while Constitutional Court judges serve 9-year terms.  Judges from both courts are nominated by the Supreme Council of Magistracy and confirmed by the monarch.

government_functions.details: The President of Guatemala serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds along with the Vice President. The President serves a single 4-year term and is not eligible for reelection.  Guatemala has a unicameral Congress with 160 seats. 128 members are elected from multi-seat departmental constituencies and 32 additional members are elected in a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected by closed list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  The Supreme Court of Justice is the highest court within the national judicial system. It is composed of 13 judges nominated by an expert legal panel and elected by members of Congress. Judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits. There is also a Constitutional Court that is independent from the judicial system and rules only on constitutionality. The Constitutional Court consists of 5 active judges and 5 reserve judges. Each active judge is appointed by a different institution: the President, Congress, the Supreme Court, the University of San Carlos, or the Assembly of the College of Attorneys and Notaries. Constitutional Court judges serve 5-year terms, and there are no term limits.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The President and [the] Vice-President of the Republic will be elected by the people through universal and secret suffrage and for a single term of four years. If none of the candidates should secure an absolute majority it will be proceeded to a second election within a period no longer than sixty[,] or less than forty-five days, counting from the first Sunday, between the candidates who have won the two highest relative number of votes.

institution.term_details: Consecutive terms are not allowed (Article 186 Constitution)

government_functions.details: Sierra Leone is a presidential republic. The President is the chief of state, head of government, and the minister of defense. The President is directly elected by an absolute majority popular vote in two rounds if necessary. Presidents must, per the Constitution, be nominated by a political party.   Sierra Leone has a unicameral parliament with 146 seats total. 132 members are directly elected. 14 seats are filled in seperate elections by non-partisan members called "paramount chiefs". Paramount chiefs are regional leaders.   The highest court is the Superior Court of Judicature, which consists of the Supreme Court, the Court of Appeal, and the High Court of Justice. The Supreme Court is the highest-ranking court out of these three. There are also a variety of subordinate courts, including District Appeals Court, magistrates' courts, and local courts.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Closed party lists; To be eligible for seat distribution, coalitions and parties running separately must pass a national seven percent threshold. The threshold does not apply to independents. Seats are allocated using the D'Hondt Method.

voting_methods.instructions:
Only voters registered on the Overseas Electoral Register can vote overseas. The Overseas Electoral Register includes the records of Turkish citizens residing abroad taken from the address registration system of the General Directorate of Population and Citizenship Affairs by the General Directorate of Electoral Register.

Overseas voting is implemented by several methods: in-person at foreign representations (or other designated locations), at customs gates, and by-mail. Electronic voting for overseas voters can also be implemented by decision of the Supreme Board of Elections, in which case voters are to be provided with passwords and similar safety measures are to be taken to prevent multiple voting. If electronic voting is used, it is to begin 30 days before election day and end 17:00 on election day. The Supreme Board of Elections, based on the opinion of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, determines separately or individually, the voting methods either using electronic or paper ballots, considering the type of elections and conditions of the country. The foreign representations (and other designated places) where voting will take place in-person are determined by the Supreme Board of Elections, based on the opinion Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  Overseas voters may vote in the presidential election and the proportional part of the parliamentary election (not majoritarian elections.) For by-mail overseas voting, specially manufactured ballot papers and coloured voting envelopes are used, which are sent to the addresses of the overseas voters five days before the election.  One small envelope carries the seal of the foreign district election board in which the ballot is included. This envelope is to be put in another medium envelope in which the words "foreign district election board Ankara/Turkiye" is written and this envelope is put in a third larger envelope on which the the voters' foreign address is written. After marking the ballot paper with an 'X' beside the column of the preferred political party or presidential candidate, the voter puts the ballot paper in the small envelope and closes it. This envelope is put in the  medium envelope which is then sealed and the voter sends it in a way to arrive at the foreign district election board at the latest at 17:00 on election day. For in-person voting at polling stations located at  foreign representations (and other designated places), secrecy of the vote must be respected.  The ballots and envelopes for overseas voting in-person are specially  manufactured in special colours. When the voters comes to vote, the president of the ballot box committee checks the voters identification document and whether the voter has already voted, over a computer supported central electoral roll system. If the voter has not yet voted, he/she is given a stamped ballot paper and the 'yes' or 'preference' stamp. After voting, the voter signs on the electoral roll next to his/her name.  The sealed envelopes with the ballots are put in a bag along with the other voting materials, and sent to the overseas district election board for counting. For voting at customs gates, the period of voting begins 45 days before election day and ends 17:00 on election day; voting hours are 8:00 to 17:00. Specially manufactured ballot papers and envelopes in special colours are used for customs gate voting. The designated customs gates are determined by the Supreme Board of Elections. Secrecy of the vote must be guaranteed.  When a voter comes to a customs gate to vote, the president of the ballot box committee checks his/her identity document and that he/she has not already voted, as indicated on the computer supported central electoral roll. The voter is given a stamped ballot paper and a 'yes' or 'preference' stamp, and enters the secret voting area and completes the voting process. The voter then signs the electoral roll.  Ballots are counted at the customs gates.

Voters must vote at the polling station at which they are appear on the voter list (absentee voting is not permitted), unless the voter has a decision of the district election board to be presented to the ballot box committee. Poll workers and law enforcement officers are provided documentation from the distriction election board to vote at the polling station to which they are assigned (MPs and candidates can vote at any polling station by presenting their voter document). The names of the above-noted persons are added at the end of the voter list by the ballot box committee. Voters who are pregnant, ill or diabled did not have to wait in line at the polling station.  One by one, the voters registered in the voter list are to prove their identity by official documents shown to the president of the ballot box committee; the list of acceptable identfication documents is  determined by the Supreme Board of Elections prior to the election day. Proxy voting is not permitted. The president finds the name fo the voter in the voter list and gives him/her one ballot paper and envelope, as well as 'yes' stamp, guides him/her to the place for secret voting if there is more than one cabin and tells the voters to go out of the cabin after folding the ballot and inserting it in the envelope. The voter must then go directly to the place for secret voting with the ballot/envelope. Nobody is allowed inside the secret voting area unless the previous voter leaves; voters who remain inside the cabin for more than a reasonable time are to be warned by the president. Voters who do not leave the area despite warning are removed from the cabin. Voters are not allowed inside the secret voting area with phones, cameras, audio or video recorders or any other communication tools. These kind of devices are to be turned off and presented to the president before voting; the devices are returned to voters after voting. The voter casts his/her vote by affixing the stamp inside the circle belonging to the political party or candidate of preference. After folding the ballot paper and placing it in the envelope and sealing it, the voter leaves the voting cabin and personally inserts the envelope inside the ballot box. The voter returns the stamp back tothe president. Voters with disabilties can be assisted by a relative registered at the polling station or by another voter. The president returns the voter's ID card to the voter and has the voter put his/her signature on the voter list. If the voter cannot sign, the fingerprint of the left thumb is taken or other finger if necessary. After voting, voters must immediately leave the polling station. Voters in line at the time of closing are to be allowed to vote.

government_functions.details: Turkey is a presidential republic. The President serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The president is directly elected for a 5-year term and is eligible to serve two terms.   Turkey has a unicameral Grand National Assembly (Buyuk Millet Meclisi) which has 600 members. Members are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies to serve 5-year terms.   The highest courts are the Constitutional Court (Anayasa Mahkemesi), Court of Cassation, and the Council of State.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The president is directly elected under a two-round system; if no candidate receives an absolute majority of valid votes in the first round, a second round between the top two candidates is held two weeks later.  Candidates can be party-nominated or independent.

election_issues.issues: Economy; inflation; demand for democracy; separation of powers; bribery and corruption; refugee crisis; freedom of expression; oppression of minorities (Kurds and Alevis)

concurrent_events.events: There is a long-term, ongoing conflict between the Turkish government and armed Kurdish groups in the east of the country.

institution.term_details: The president may serve for up to two terms, with the possibility of a third term if an early presidential election is called while the second term is being served.

government_functions.details: Turkey is a presidential republic. The President serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The president is directly elected for a 5-year term and is eligible to serve two terms.   Turkey has a unicameral Grand National Assembly (Buyuk Millet Meclisi) which has 600 members. Members are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies to serve 5-year terms.   The highest courts are the Constitutional Court (Anayasa Mahkemesi), Court of Cassation, and the Council of State.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Each voter selects a party/coalition list consisting of 25-65 candidates, 1/3 of whom must be women. Seats are allocated according to the highest average system, using the d'Hondt method. Parties and coalitions obtaining less than 4 per cent of the total votes are not entitled to a seat.

voting_methods.instructions:
Timorese citizens who reside abroad may exercise their right to vote as long as they are registered in the voter register and display their voter’s card. Out of country voting will be available at Timor-Leste diplomatic missions or consular offices in Lisbon and Porto, Portugal;  Dungannon, Oxford and Peterborough, United Kingdom ; Seoul, South Korea; and Darwin, Sydney and Melbourne, Australia. Voters must be on the voter register compiled for the areas covered by these missions or offices and vote in person on Election Day. However, Timorese voters in Indonesia will not be able to vote.

Presentation of an updated voter’s card shall constitute a necessary condition for the exercise of the right to vote. If a voter does not have his/her voter’s card on election day, he or she may exercise his/her right to vote by presenting his/her Timorese ID card or passport, as long as his/her data appear on the voters list for that geographic unit.

The voter shall indicate his or her choice by placing a mark or by punching in the blank square in the corresponding line for the list for which he or she wishes to vote. The voter then folds the ballot paper with the printed part on the inside, and places it in the ballot box.

government_functions.details: Timor-Leste is a semi-presidential system in which the president and the parliament (which chooses the prime minister) are elected by direct, universal suffrage for five-year terms. The President is the Head of State while the  Prime Minister acts as the Head of government. The prime minister oversees the day-to-day functioning of government and chairs the Council of Ministers. The prime minister is designated by the political party or alliance of political parties with a majority in the national legislature and is formally appointed by the president.  The Legislature is a unicameral Parliament, composed of the National Assembly. Parliamentarians are elected on national party slates with proportional representation. Ministers are also appointed by the president, following the recommendations of the prime minister.   The judiciary is notionally headed by the Supreme Court: as it has not yet been appointed, the Court of Appeal acts in its place.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The President of the Republic and the Vice President will be elected jointly and directly by the People, by simple majority of votes, in general elections realized between ninety and one hundred and twenty days before the expiration of the constitutional period in force.

institution.term_details:
Constitution Article 229. Of the Duration of the Mandate
The President of the Republic and the Vice President will remain five non- extendable
years in the exercise of their functions, counting from the fifteenth of August following
the elections. They may not be reelected in any case. The Vice President may only be
elected President for the next period if he had ceased in his office six months before the
general elections. Whoever had exercised the presidency for more than twelve months
may not be elected Vice President of the Republic.

The Paraguayans residing abroad are electors. The citizens are electors and eligible, with no other restrictions than that established in this Constitution and in the law. The foreigners with definitive residence [radicación] will have the same rights in the municipal elections.

government_functions.details: The President of Paraguay serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and serves a single 5-year term. The president and vice president are elected as a slate.  Paraguay has a bicameral consisting of a 45-seat Chamber of Senators and an 80-seat Chamber of Deputies. All 45 senators are directly elected by closed-list proportional representation vote from a single, nationwide constituency. Senators serve 5-year terms. All 80 deputies are directly elected by closed-list proportional vote in 18 multi-seat constituencies (departments). Deputies serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court of Justice is Paraguay's highest court. It is made up of 9 justices who are nominated by the Council of Magistrates and confirmed by the Chamber of Senators and the President. Justices may serve until age 75.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Proportional: Closed party list proportional representation system. - Each political party or movement presents a list of candidates with as many names as the number of seats to be filled. - The votes received by each list are divided by one, two, three, four and so on up to the number of seats to be filled. The quotients are ranked from the largest to the smallest. Seats are then allocated to the lists with the highest averages.

institution.term_details: Article 187. Of the Election and of the Duration The titular and substitute Senators and Deputies will be elected in elections simultaneously with the presidential [elections]. The legislators will remain five years in their mandate, from the first of July and they may be reelected. The definitive or temporary vacancies of the Chamber of Deputies will be filled by the substitutes elected for the same department, and those of the Chamber of Senators will be filled by the substitutes of the list proclaimed by the Electoral Justice.

The foreigners with definitive residence [radicación] will have the same rights in the municipal elections.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Single national district closed lists

institution.term_details: Article 187. Of the Election and of the Duration The titular and substitute Senators and Deputies will be elected in elections simultaneously with the presidential [elections]. The legislators will remain five years in their mandate, from the first of July and they may be reelected. The definitive or temporary vacancies of the Chamber of Deputies will be filled by the substitutes elected for the same department, and those of the Chamber of Senators will be filled by the substitutes of the list proclaimed by the Electoral Justice. Article 189. Of Life Senators [Senadurías] The former Presidents of the Republic, democratically elected, will be Senators for life of the Nation, unless they were submitted to political trial and found guilty. They will not integrate the quorum. They will have voice but not vote.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Article 120. Of the Electors Paraguayan citizens, without distinction, that have turned eighteen years old are electors. The Paraguayans residing abroad are electors. The citizens are electors and eligible, with no other restrictions than that established in this Constitution and in the law. The foreigners with definitive residence [radicación] will have the same rights in the municipal elections.

The Paraguayans residing abroad are electors. The citizens are electors and eligible, with no other restrictions than that established in this Constitution and in the law.  The foreigners with definitive residence [radicación] will have the same rights in the municipal elections.

government_functions.details: The President of Paraguay serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and serves a single 5-year term. The president and vice president are elected as a slate.  Paraguay has a bicameral consisting of a 45-seat Chamber of Senators and an 80-seat Chamber of Deputies. All 45 senators are directly elected by closed-list proportional representation vote from a single, nationwide constituency. Senators serve 5-year terms. All 80 deputies are directly elected by closed-list proportional vote in 18 multi-seat constituencies (departments). Deputies serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court of Justice is Paraguay's highest court. It is made up of 9 justices who are nominated by the Council of Magistrates and confirmed by the Chamber of Senators and the President. Justices may serve until age 75.

voting_methods.instructions:
A Postal Voter shall, before marking the Postal Ballot Paper, show the unmarked ballot paper, the IDC, and the Envelope B before a competent witness. He/she shall first fill the IDC in the presence of the competent witness who shall, if satisfied, counter-sign it. The Postal Voter shall mark the Postal Ballot Paper to cast his/her vote. He/she shall, immediately upon marking the Postal Ballot Paper in total secrecy, place the same in Envelope B and ensure that the envelope is properly sealed. The sealed Envelope B together with the IDC shall be placed in Envelope A. The Postal Voter shall then dispatch Envelope A by post without delay, or hand it over to the Returning Officer who must issue a receipt for it. He/she must also use the provided seal or pen on the Ballot Paper to cast his/her vote in the designated Facilitation Booth.

Votes may be casted by post by any of the following: (a) Diplomats and persons working in the Embassies of Bhutan abroad; (b) Any person on special government duty who is for the time being residing outside Bhutan for the performance of the duty; (c) Members of the Armed Forces of Bhutan; (d) Any person on election duty; (e) Civil servants; (f) Students and trainees; (g) The spouse or dependent of a person referred to in sub-section (a) to (e), if the spouse or dependent is ordinarily residing with him/her; and (h) Any other group of voters as specified by the Election Commission in consultation with the Government.

The Polling Officer 1 shall verify the identity of the voter from the Voters’ List using his/her Voter Photo Identity Card (VPIC). A voter whose identity is established shall proceed to Polling Officer 2 who will obtain his/her signature or thumb impression in the Registry of Voters and issue a White Voter’s Slip for male voters and Yellow Voter’s Slip for female voters. The voter will then proceed to Polling Officer 3 and hand over the Voter’s Slip, proceed to the Voting Compartment to vote secretly unless he/she requires assistance as permitted under the Election Act. The casting of the vote by a voter shall be confirmed by a single beep that will be heard after a vote is casted.

electoral_rights.source: Election Act of the Kingdom of Bhutan 2008 - Chapter 17, Section 358 & Chapter 6, Section 102(a)(b)(c)

government_functions.details: Executive Power is vested in the Lhengye Zhungtshog which shall consist of the Ministers headed by the Prime Minister and shall protect and strengthen the sovereignty of the Kingdom, provide good governance, and ensure peace, security, well-being, and happiness of the people. The number of Ministers shall be determined by the number of Ministries required to provide efficient and good governance. The creation of an additional ministry or reduction of any ministry shall be approved by Parliament.   The Legislative Branch consists of the Druk Gyalpo (monarch), the National Council, and the National Assembly which shall ensure that the Government safeguards the interests of the nation and fulfills the aspirations of the people through public review of policies and issues, bills and other legislations and scrutiny of State functions.  The judicial authority of Bhutan is vested in the Royal Courts of Justice comprising the Supreme Court, the High Court, the Dzongkhag Court, the Dungkhag Court, and such other Courts and Tribunals as may be established from time to time by the Druk Gyalpo on the recommendation of the National Judicial Commission.  Source: Bhutan 2008 Constitution - Article 10, Sections 1 and 2, Article 20, Sections 1 and 2, Article 21, Sections 1 and 2

government_functions.details: The President of Benin serves as chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms.  Benin has a unicameral National Assembly with 109 members. All members are directly elected by list proportional representation vote within multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Benin has several high courts with different legal domains. The Supreme Court has 17 judges who are appointed by the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The Constitutional Court has 7 judges who are appointed by either the National Assembly or the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The High Court of Justice forms only to try high treason cases involving national government officials. It is formed from 6 judges of the Constitutional Court who are selected by the National Assembly and Supreme Court president.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1993 Constitution, Articles 24, 51(3); 1993 Law on the Electoral System and the Referendum, Article 2

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters who are permanently or temporarily residing abroad may apply  to vote by postal voting. Voters must either be living abroad and appear as such on the final voter list or, despite not being registered in the voter list as residing abroad, can vote from abroad if they prove by documentation that they are studying abroad or doing temporary or professional activity abroad.

Out-of-country postal voting, like in-country in-person early voting is administered by judges. Overseas postal voters must apply by post or online by the established deadline to receive their postal ballots.  The law provides that the government will regulate the form, terms and means to be used to deliver the documents to the postal voters. The government sends to the voters voting packs by registered mail, comprising ballot papers, envelopes, and electoral information, and a pre-addressed return envelope. The postal voter inserts each of the two chosen ballots into each of the two ballot envelopes and closes the envelopes.  These envelopes are then put into the pre-addressed return envelope, sent to the court of first instance in Andorra. The postal voters is to include in the main envelope their certificate of registration on the final voter list and a photocopy of their passport. The envelope is to be closed and the voter is to put their name, address and signature on the back of the envelope. The voter is to return the package in the manner set out in the instructions. The receiving court records the receipt of postal voting packages. At the start of the election day, the judges are responsible to take the voted ballots to the respective polling stations and place them in the ballot boxes. The postal voters are then marked off the voters list at the polling station to prevent multiple voting.

Early voting is adminstered by judges, also called "judicial voting".  Early voters can collect the ballots and envelopes at the respective common house during office hours and deposit the chosen ballots in-person at the courts of first instance. These voters can alter their vote before the election day, with all previous ballots invalidated. At the start of the election day, the judges are responsible to take the marked ballots to the respective polling stations and place them in the ballot boxes. At that time, those who voted in advance are marked as such in the voter lists at the polling stations to prevent multiple voting.

In addition, during the period for early voting, homebound, detained and hospitalized voters may also request to vote at their place of stay. A judge of the court of first instance, accompanied by a court secretary, travels to the requested locations with the necessary materials. A medical certificate is needed for homebound voting.  The above-noted process is not included in the legislation itself but is described in the OSCE/ODIHR Needs Assessment Mission Report, 7 April 2019 Parliamentary Elections, Principality of Andorra.

All voters are entitled to have a paid absence from their workplace for two hours in order to vote. At the parish polling station, which may be divided into more than polling station, the voter must present his/her identification.  The poll worker verifies that the person is registered to vote in that electoral district. Voters can be registered to vote in their parish of residence or parish or origin. Once the identity and registration is verified, the voter receives two envelopes: one for the parish seats and the other for the proportional contest. The voter is to go into one of the ballot booths alone to vote in secret (except persons with disabilities can be accompanied by a person of their choice or the presiding officer to assist in casting the ballot). The voting booth includes an illuminated table or desk on which there will be ballots for each candidate list for both the parish and national elections. In the booth, the voter puts inside each of the two envelopes one chosen ballot paper.  The voter then proceeds to insert the two envelopes inside each of the two ballot boxes. A poll worker counts the number of voters who exercise the right to vote. All voters waiting to vote at the time of closing are allowed to vote.

electoral_rights.source: 1993 Law on the Electoral System and Referendum; 2017 Law on Urgent Measures for Implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities; 1993 Law on the Electoral System and Referendum, Article 1(3)

government_functions.details: In Andorra, a parliamentary leader (Cap de Govern) serves as head of government, while two foreign co-princes traditionally share the role of chief of state. The president of France and Bishop of Seu d’Urgell, Spain automatically become co-princes of Andorra upon assuming their primary offices. Each co-prince appoints a local representative. There are no defined terms of office; co-princes reign as long as they maintain their primary offices. The Cap de Govern is indirectly elected by the General Council and confirmed by the co-princes. The Cap de Govern serves 4-year terms.  Andorra's legislature, the unicameral General Council, has 28 members. Half of those members are elected by proportional representation vote in a single, nationwide constituency while the other half are elected by plurality vote in multi-seat constituencies (2 seats for each of 7 parishes). All members serve 4-year terms.  The Andorran judiciary is headed by the Supreme Court of Justice (9 judges) and the Constitutional Court (4 judges). Supreme Court judges are selected by a panel called the Supreme Council of Justice and serve 6-year terms. Constitutional judges are selected by the General Council and the co-princes, and they may serve up to two 8-year terms.

election_issues.issues: Russia-Ukraine war; Finland-EU relations; economy; migration; climate change

voting_methods.instructions: The Finnish diplomatic missions and their offices at which out-of-country voters can vote are determined by a government decree.  The ballot, ballot envelope, covering letter form, and envelope for the covering letter form provided by the Ministry of Justice are used for out-of-country voting. A voter who wishes to vote in at a diplomatic mission shall report to the election official at the location.  The voter is obliged to present a proof of his or her identity to the election official. Thereafter, he or she is given a ballot, a ballot envelope and a covering envelope and, if needed, a covering letter form.  The voter shall be provided with the opportunity to familiarise himself or herself with the master list of candidates for his or her electoral district. A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered.  The voter shall mark the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. The marking shall be made in the voting booth or somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter. The covering letter,which includes the name and identifying number of the voter, shall be addressed to the central electoral committee of that municipality and entered in the voter register next to the voter.  The voter shall sign a declaration on the covering letter stating that he or she himself or herself has, maintaining the election secrecy, filled in the ballot and enclosed it stamped in the ballot envelope. The voter shall give the folded ballot to the election official to be stamped and, immediately after the ballot is stamped, enclose it in the ballot envelope in front of the election authority. The closed ballot envelope and the signed covering letter are to be given to the election official. When a voter register is used in the advance polling station, the election official  shall check in the register that the voter has the right to vote, make an entry in the register indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote, and make a marking on the covering letter indicating that an entry has been made in the voter register. When the voter register is not used at the polling location, a list of voters shall be kept.  The election offiical of a Finnish ship must deliver without delay the covering envelopes to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs or to a Finnish diplomatic mission in the country where the ship is or where it first arrives. The election official in a Finnish diplomatic mission, or, if the mission does not serve as an advance polling station, the Head of Mission, shall ensure that the covering envelopoes that have been given there or that have arrived there are delivered to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in a manner determined by it. The Ministry shall ensure that the covering envelopes are delivered without delay to the central electoral commitee of the municipality in question.

For the 2023 parliamentary elections, postal voting documents can be ordered starting 2 January 2023.  The first possible date for postal voting is 2 March 2023, when the candidates and their candidate numbers will be confirmed. 

Postal voting can be used only by persons living or staying abroad for the duration of the entire advance voting period and on election day. An eligible voter wishing to vote by post shall order the postal voting documents online from the Ministry of Justice to be sent to an address abroad. The postal voting documents can be ordered three months before the election day at the earliest. An assistant may be used for placing the order. The voter's name and personal identity code and the postal address abroad to which the documents will be sent must be given with the order. The postal voting package includes a ballot, a postal ballot envelope in which the ballot is inserted, a postal vote covering letter, which the voter must fill in, a postal vote covering envelope, in which the ballot envelope and the covering letter are inserted, and postal voting instructions, drawn up by the Ministry of Justice. The eligible voter himself or herself must find out the number of the candidate that he or she wants to vote for (which are published about one month before the election day). The instructions to vote are as follows: First, the voter marks the number of the candidate he or she wants to vote for on the ballot, inserts the ballot in the postal ballot envelope, and seals the envelope. Next, the voter fills in the postal vote covering letter and signs it. Postal voters are obliged to mark the ballot and put it into the ballot envelope personally and in secret and maintaining electoral freedom. The voter must sign an attestation concerning this on the covering letter. Two witnesses must be present when the postal voting takes place. The witnesses must also sign the attestation on the covering letter stating that election secrecy has been preserved and electoral freedom respected while voting. The witnesses must have reached the age of 18. The spouse, child, or parent of the voter or an election candidate or his or her family member cannot be a witness. The witnesses need not be Finnish citizens. At the end of the postal voting, the voter puts the ballot envelope and the covering letter into the covering envelope and seals it. The name and address of the central municipal election board to which the vote will be sent must be visible in the window of the covering envelope. The voter must send the covering envelope, containing the ballot sealed in the ballot envelope and the covering letter, to Finland to the central municipal election board of the municipality in which the voter has the right to vote according to the voter register. The voter is responsible to find out which municipality this is by calling the relevant authorities or if the voter received a polling card, by using the address indicated on it. The voter must put enough postage on the covering envelope (the mailing is not pre-paid). Finally, the voter posts the covering envelope to Finland through the postal service of a foreign country in the same manner as any other postal item.  The voter may also choose to post the envelope as a registered letter or to use an international courier service.

General advance voting in Finland takes place starting the 11th day before the election day and ends on the 5th day before the election day. At a general advance polling station in Finland, the voting takes place at the times determined by a decision of the local executive, which may not be before 8:00 or after 20:00 on weekdays or before 10:00 or after 18:00 on Saturdays and Sundays. A voter who arrives at the advance polling station within the time frame specified but has not been able to cast a vote during that time may vote after the said time.

Every eligible voter may vote in advance at the general advance polling stations in Finland.

There must be at least one general advance polling station located in each municipality in Finland.  In addition, advance voting  is held n hospitals, full-time care facilities, and prisons for one or two days as determined by the electoral commission. Homebound voting also takes place during the advance polling days. The ballot, ballot envelope, covering letter form, and envelope for the covering letter form provided by the Ministry of Justice are used in advance voting.  A voter who wishes to vote in advance shall report to the election official or the electoral commission at the advance polling station. Where necessary, advance voting conducted in an institution is to be organized in different units and patients rooms. The voter is obliged to present a proof of his or her identity to the election official or the electoral commission. Thereafter, he or she is given a ballot, a ballot envelope and a covering envelope and, if needed, a covering letter form.  The voter shall be provided with the opportunity to familiarise himself or herself with the master list of candidates for his or her electoral district. A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered.  The voter shall mark the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. The marking shall be made in the voting booth or somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an election official or member of an electoral commission, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter. The covering letter,which includes the name and identifying number of the voter, shall be addressed to the central electoral committee of that municipality and is entered in the voting register next to the voter.  The voter shall sign a declaration on the covering letter stating that he or she himself or herself has, maintaining the election secrecy, filled in the ballot and enclosed it stamped in the ballot envelope. The voter shall give the folded ballot to the election official or, in an institution, to the electoral commission to be stamped and, immediately after the ballot is stamped, enclose it in the ballot envelope in front of the election authority. The closed ballot envelope and the signed covering letter are to be given to the election official or the electoral commission. When a voter register is used in the advance polling station, the election official or the chairperson of the electoral commission shall check in the register that the voter has the right to vote, make an entry in the register indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote, and make a marking on the covering letter indicating that an entry has been made in the voter register. When the voter register is not used at the advance polling station, a list of voters shall be kept. The election official and the electoral commission of a general advance polling station in Finland shall ensure that the covering envelopes addressed to the municipality's own central electoral committee are without delay delivered to the central electoral committee in the manner determined by it.

Proxy voting is not allowed. The voter reports to the election board in the polling station of his or voting district. The voter is obliged to present proof of his or her identity to the electon board, which then must determine that the voter has the right to vote by checking the voter register. The voter receives the ballot and proceeds to the polling booth or, if that is not possible without causing undue difficulty to the voter, somewhere else in a manner that maintains the election secrecy.  A voter in parliamentary elections has the right to vote for a candidate in the master list of candidates for the electoral district in which the voter is registered. The voter marks the number of the candidate he or she is voting for in the ballot in such a manner that there can be no uncertainty as to whom he or she has voted for. A person whose ability to mark the ballot is essentially weakened may request assistance from an eletion official or member of an electoral commission, or can use the help of an assistant he or she has chosen. A candidate or his or her family member cannot assist voters. The assistant must strictly comply with the directions of the voter and keep secret the choice of the voter.The voter then presents the folded ballot paper to the election board in order to be stamped. The stamp is placed in the middle of the reverse side of the folded ballot. The voter then puts the ballot in the ballot box. The electoral board makes a marking in the list of voters, as well as the voter register, indicating that the voter has used his or her right to vote.

electoral_rights.source: 1999 Constitution, Section 6; 1998 Election Act, Sections 9, 46, 48, 54-55, 58-59, 73, 76, 190; 1999 Constitution, Section 27

government_functions.details: In Finland, the President serves as chief of state, and the Prime Minister is head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 6-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by Parliament and formally appointed by the President.  Finland has a unicameral Parliament (Eduskunta) with 200 seats. 199 members are directly elected in single and multi-seat constituencies via proportional representation vote. The remaining member, who represents the autonomous region of Åland, is directly elected by plurality vote. All members serve 4-year terms.   The Finnish judiciary has two high courts: the Supreme Court (civil and criminal cases) and Supreme Administrative Court (government cases). The Supreme Court consists of 19 judges, while the Supreme Administrative Court has 21 judges. All high court judges are appointed by the President and may serve until age 68.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 125 members of the Assembly (Mejlis) are elected for a five-year term in single seat constituencies. To be elected, a candidate must receive above 50 per cent of the votes cast. If no candidate gains more than half of the votes in the first round, a second round is held within two weeks between the two frontrunners from the first round.
basic_data.election_commission_name: Central Commission for Holding Elections and Referendums in Turkmenistan

voting_methods.instructions: Voters abroad who are on the voter list of a polling station established at an embassy/consultate can vote there in person.  The law, however, does not determine any procedures for out-of-country voting, and provides that the Central Election Commission is to determine the procedure. The law provides that voting at embassies/consulates may be declared finished at any time if all voters on the voter list have voted.

Early voters vote at the regular polling stations.  At least two members of the polling station commission must be present in order for early voting to take place. The law provides that early voting is to be conducted under the same voting procedures provided in the law for election day voting. The early voted ballots are to be dropped into a ballot box that has been previously sealed.

Each voter must vote in person; no proxy voting is permitted. Upon verification of the voter's identity by presentation of a passport or or other identification document, and based on the voters inclusion on the voter list at the polling station, the ballot paper is issued to the voter by the poll worker. The voter signs the voter list to confirm he/she has received the ballot paper. The voter proceeds alone to the polling booth and marks the ballot paper in the booth. A voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot paper may invite into the booth another person of his/her choice, but excluding members of the election commission, observers, candidate representatives, or members of initiative groups.  The voter puts the surname of the candidate for whom he/she is voting in a designated spot on the ballot paper. The voter then proceeds to drop the completed and folded ballot paper in the ballot box.  A voter may request a new ballot paper in exchange for a spoiled ballot paper. Homebound voting is available for voters who cannot come to the polling station due to ill health or disability.

electoral_rights.source: 2013 Electoral Code, Articles 72(2), 74; 2016 Constitution, Article 119; 2013 Electoral Code, Article 3(3)

disinformation.source: 1997 Criminal Code, Articles 132, 334.3; 2013 Electoral Code, Articles 68(5), 92(3)

government_functions.details: The President of Turkmenistan serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The presidential term is 7 years, and there are no term limits.  The Mejlis is the unicameral legislature of Turkmenistan, and it has 125 seats. All 125 members are elected by absolute majority vote (via up to two rounds of voting) in single-seat constituencies. Members serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest judicial body in Turkmenistan, and it consists of a president and 21 judges split into three chambers. Judges are appointed by the President and serve 5-year terms.

institution.term_details: There is no term limit for members of the House of Representatives in general, but there is an 8-year limit for the role of Prime Minister.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters can register to exercise the right to vote in another country. The Commission or the person entrusted by the Commission in that country, however, shall arrange for vote casting.

Voter wanting to vote early must submit to the election committee of the constituency a request for registration within a period of time prescribed by the Commission or the Commission may require registration to be made by an electronic means in accordance with the rules and procedures prescribed by the Commission.

If ordered to perform duties out of the constituency where he is entitled to vote, or a person entitled to vote, staying out of the constituency in respect of which his name is listed in the household register, who intends to exercise his right to vote prior to the election date in the constituency or out of the constituency.

In casting a vote, a cross shall be affixed in the box provided for a candidate’s personal number on  a ballot card and, in the case where a person entitled to vote decides not to vote for any candidate, a cross shall be affixed in to Vote for Anyone”.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Cuba is a one party system that has a special way of selecting candidates and electing the members of its parliament. Fifty percent of the candidates for the national assembly is chosen by municipal councilors (12,400). The other half is nominated by a commission of representatives of the country's main social organizations. The Communist party verifies the nominations while the voters vote to ratify the nominations.
basic_data.election_commission_name: National Electoral Council (Consejo Nacional Electoral / CNE)

(Art. 202, Law No. 127)

government_functions.details: The president is the head of government, has the executive power, and is also commander in chief of the armed forces. He is indirectly elected by the national assembly for a term of 5 years. The legislative branch has the ability to amend the constitution; to pass, amend, and repeal laws; to debate and approve national plans for economic development, the state budget, credit and financial programs; among other powers. It has 470 members elected by absolute majority vote from slated candidates approved by the government. It has a term of 5 years. The Supreme Court rules on constitutional matters, and reviews final appeals from lower courts, including all criminal, civil, administrative, labor law, and economic cases.

voting_methods.instructions: In order to vote, a voter must be registered in the register of electors in that constituency. Employers must provide four hours paid leave for voters to go to their polling station to vote. At their designated polling station, voters are required to present a voter identification card (issued by the Electoral Commission) to a polling official who checks off the name of the voter against the voter register and issues the voter with a ballot paper. Before handing the ballot to the voter, the voter is checked that he or she does not have the black electoral ink on the right index finger. If the voter is refused a ballot due to having such ink on his or her finger, the presiding officer must make an entry in the poll book setting out the facts of the refusal.  The polling official then puts the official stamp on the ballot paper, calls out the number, name and description of the voter as stated in the voter register, and instructs the voter how to fold the ballot. A presiding officer may, and if required by a candidate or polling agent must, put to a voter at the time of applying for a ballot paper specific questions regarding the identity of the voter and whether he or she has already voted. Only if the voter satisfactorily answers the questions, if asked, can he or she be  given a ballot paper. The voter then proceeds to the polling booth to vote in secret. Electors vote by putting a cross on the ballot paper against the name of the candidate they want to represent them (any other mark or comment on the paper renders it invalid), folds the ballot so as to conceal the vote, shows the back of the folded ballot paper to the presiding officer, so as to disclose the official stamp, and then inserts the ballot paper in a sealed box in the presence of the presiding officer. Prior to inserting the ballot in the box, the presiding officer must cause the voter to immerse his or her right index finger in the black electoral ink. If the voter refuses to do so, the presiding officer takes possession of and destroys the ballot paper. A voter who spoils his or her ballot paper can return it to the presiding officer who will issue a new ballot paper if satisified that it was mistakenly spoiled.   Blind voters and those with physical disabilities may be assisted to cast their vote through a regulated procedure. A voter must vote without undue delay and leave the polling station as soon as he or she has inserted the ballot in the box. The law allows proxy voting for those unable or likely to be unable to vote in person at the polling station for reason of providing law enforcement or defence service on election day or working as an election official or polling agent on election day.  Such person wishing to vote by proxy must submit an application not later than three days before election day to be treated as an "absent voter" and provide the name and address of a person within the country whom he or she wishes to act as proxy to him or her. A letter 'p' will be marked beside the voter's name in the voter register and a list of proxies is made for each polling station. At the polling station, a proxy must appear on the list of proxies and show that his or her left index finger does not have red electoral ink on it (different than the black in on the right index finger for regular voters). Upon a proxy receiving the ballot paper, a mark is to be placed by his or her name in the list of proxies. Prior to placing the ballot in the ballot box, a proxy is to immerse his or her left index finger in the indelible red ink. Election officials and polling agents may, in the alternative, apply in advance to be "transferred" to vote at the polling station to which they are assigned, in which case they are issued a transfer certificate. If a person who appears on the voter register or on a proxy list applies for a ballot paper after another person has voted in person either as the elector or proxy, the applicant is entitled to vote a "tendered ballot" provided he or she satisfactorily answers questions regarding his or her identity and whether he or she has already voted. Any marked tendered ballot is separately packaged and the name and electoral number of the voter recorded.

government_functions.details: Antigua and Barbuda is a member of the British Commonwealth and thus the monarch is hereditary. The monarch appoints a Governor-General. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Governor-General. Per the Constitution, the Prime Minister must be a member of the House of Representatives who has the support of the majority of members of the House and is typically the leader of the ruling coalition or party.   There is a bicameral parliament with a 17-seat Senate that is appointed by the Governor-General and a 17-seat House of Representatives that is directly elected in single-seat constituencies by simple majority vote to serve 5-year terms. There are two ex-officio seats reserved for the attorney general and the speaker of the House, respectively.   The highest court is the Eastern Caribbean Supreme Court (ECSC), which rules over Anguilla, Dominica, Grenada, Saint Vincent, Saint Kitts & Nevis, and Saint Lucia as well. The chief justice of the ECSC is appointed by the British monarchy.

government_functions.details: Sierra Leone is a presidential republic. The President is the chief of state, head of government, and the minister of defense. The President is directly elected by an absolute majority popular vote in two rounds if necessary. Presidents must, per the Constitution, be nominated by a political party.   Sierra Leone has a unicameral parliament with 146 seats total. 132 members are directly elected. 14 seats are filled in seperate elections by non-partisan members called "paramount chiefs". Paramount chiefs are regional leaders.   The highest court is the Superior Court of Judicature, which consists of the Supreme Court, the Court of Appeal, and the High Court of Justice. The Supreme Court is the highest-ranking court out of these three. There are also a variety of subordinate courts, including District Appeals Court, magistrates' courts, and local courts.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 14-member Congress has 10 members elected every two years by first-past-the-post voting in single-member constituencies and 4 senators (1 for each of the 4 states) who are elected every four years.  A state may set aside one seat for a traditional leader chosen by statute for a two-year term, in lieu of one representative elected by popular vote. In that case, the number of constituencies shall be reduced and reapportioned accordingly. There are no political parties in Micronesia.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1978 Constitution, Article VI, Section 1, 2005 Revised National Election Act, Section 103

voting_methods.instructions: The election law provides for the establishment of two special polling places in other territories: one in Guam and one in Honolulu. The law expressly prohibits the establishment of any other special polling places abroad.   Voters who will be in those territories on election day can apply in writing to the national election commissioner of the state of registration not later than 30 days prior to the election day to vote at one of those special polling places on election day. The notice requirement can be waived if the person had applied in an earlier election for such absentee voting at that special polling place on a default basis. At the out-of-country polling place, the voter must present himself or herself as they would at a polling place inside Micronesia and the ballots are to be issued in the same manner. The election legislation does not elaborate procedures on the manner of voting, which may be included in regulations issued by the national election board.

Postal voting is available for voters who will be outside their state of registration on the election day, either inside Micronesia or out-of-country. A request to vote by mail should be sent to the national commissioner of the state in which the voter is registered. Alternatively, if the voter resides in a foreign country where Micronesia maintains an embassy or consulate, he or she can send the request to the embassy or consultate which shall then forward the request to the national election director or his or her designee, for verification and processing.  A postal voters shall indicate on the request form whether he or she intends to pick up the postal ballot at the embassy/consulate.  Within two days of receipt, the national election commissioner shall mail back to the requester the postal ballot provided the printed ballots are available, or otherwise to send them no later than five days after the postal ballots are printed. Ten days before the election day, the embassies/consulates are to be provided with sufficient postal ballots for voters to pick up if requested. Voters who request postal ballots are to be struck off the signature list for that voter's regular polling place. Postal ballot packages include an official ballot, a ballot envelope, an affidavit, and a covering reply envelope. The postal voter marks the ballot in the usual manner provided by law and in secret. The voter then inserts the ballot in the envelope and securely seals the envelope. Then the voter completes and executes the affidavit. The ballot envelope and the affidavit are to be enclosed and sealed in the covering reply envelope . The envelope is to be posted to the national election commissioner of the state that issued the postal ballot or the voter can deliver the envelope to the embassy/consulate where he or she had requested the postal ballot, if he or she had done so. All postal ballots must be received by the national election commissioner or the embassy/consulate, as applicable, by the established closing hour of the polls on election day. Postal ballots received at a post office in Micronesia must be stamped with the time and date of receipt.

Registered voters who will be travelling outside their state of registration (to another state or out of the country) on election day may cast a ballot at a designated 'traveller polling place' prior to their departure from the state.  Not more than 30 days and not less than one day prior to the election day, the voter must submit in person to the national election commissioner of the state of registration a written request to cast a ballot prior to travelling outside his or her state of registration. The voter must submit proof, in the form of an airline or passenger ship ticket, of his or her travel plans. Upon approval, the voter is issued the same voting materials that are issued to postal voters. The law provides that the same procedures for marking, returning, and disposition of the postal ballots shall apply to the marking, returning and disposition of the traveller's advance ballots. However, at the same time, the law provides that the traveller's ballot is to be 'cast' at a designated traveller polling place, where he or she must present himself or herself as they would in a regular polling place. As such, it is unclear whether the voter posts the ballot or must deliver it to the traveller polling place. The national election director or his or her designee shall strike out or delete the entry of the  early voter on the signature list for that voter's regular polling place.

In general, voters must vote at the polling place where they appear on the so-called signature list (essentially a voter list). However, voters who will be absent from their electoral district on election day but will be within their state can apply in writing not later than seven days before the election day to vote at any polling place within their state (their name will be deleted from the signature list of their regular polling place). Also, a voter who has a voter identification card may vote in any polling place within their state without having to submit a written request.  In addition, voters who will be outside of their state on election day but within the country can apply in writing not later than 30 days prior to the election day to vote at a special designated polling place in the state where they will be located on election day.  In certain circumstances, the 7-day and 30-day notice requirements can be waived, including if the person had applied in an earlier election for absentee voting in that same polling place on a default basis.  A person appearing at any regular or special polling place to vote shall report his or her full name to the election board members. If the person has been issued a voter identification card, he or she must present it to the election board members in order to vote. If the person has not been issued a voter identification card, then he or she shall present other proof of identity. An election board member checks the signature list  to determine whether or not the person appearing is a registered voter for that election district and if so, shall announce the name appearing on the list. Once the person's identity is established and entry has been found on the list, the voter shall sign his or her full name next to his or her entry on the list. An election board member issues the person an official ballot, and, if the person has presented a voter identification card, marks the card so as to indicate that the person has already voted. If a person's name does not appear on the signature list they cannot vote except in the following circumstances where they will be added to a supplemental signature list. The circumstances are: the voter presenting a valid voter identification card for that polling place and which does not indicate that the person has already voted; the voter's name appears on the national voter register but is not on the signature list at that polling place in the election district where he or she resides and has voted in at least one prior election and is not listed in any other polling place; the voter's name appears on the national voter register and on a signature list of a polling place in an election district where he or she does not reside and the voter did not apply for absentee voting. Any election board member, poll watcher or registered voter may challenge the identity or eligibility to vote of any person that appears at the polling place to vote on election day, by fileing an oral or written complaint. The board member is to give the challenged voter time to present witnesses and an explanation, if any, provided the decision is made prior to the close of polls. The decision may be appealed to the national election commissioner of the respective state, whose decision can be further appealed to the national election director. An election board member must record in the official log book for the polling place, the identifying informaton of any person who is not allowed to cast a ballot, and the reason for the disallowance. The person not allowed to vote shall then sign the log book next to the entry. The election legislation does not elaborate the procedures for the manner of voting, other than stating that all national elections shall be by secret ballot, which may be included in regulations issued by the national election board. The election law does provide that write-in votes may be used in national elections, whereby any name written upon a ballot shall be counted as a vote for that person. The law further provides that any voter who spoils a ballot may return it to a member of the election board and receive another one in its place, provided that the number of ballots given to him or her does not exceed three in all. Mobile voting also takes place on election day (or the day before the election day), whereby voters who are confined to their homes, hospitals or places of incarceration can submit a written request not more than 120 days before election day to vote at their place of confinement. If the voter is unable to personally complete or deliver the request form then the voter can request the assistance of a family  member. Mobile voters must vote in their place of confinement in secrecy, but any mobile voter who, by reason of physical disability, is unable to mark their ballot, is authorized to receive assistance to mark it.  Mobile voters and the election officials who assist these voters to vote may be required to submit an affidavit or other written statements to the national election director.

electoral_rights.source: 1978 Constitution, Article VI, Section 1; 2005 Revised National Election Act, Sections 103, 201, 603

government_functions.details: The President of Micronesia serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Congress from among four senators-at-large.   The Micronesian legislature is composed of a unicameral Congress with 14 seats. All members of Congress are directly elected. 10 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 2-year terms. An additional “at large” member is elected from each of the four Micronesian states by proportional representation vote, and these members serve 4-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Micronesian judiciary and consists of up to six judges split into two divisions. These judges are nominated by the President and confirmed by a two-thirds vote of Congress. Judges may serve for life.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Open list proportional representation in 12 constituencies

institution.term_details: Article 60 of the Constitution Regular elections of the Riigikogu are held on the first Sunday of March of the fourth year counting from the year of the preceding election of the Riigikogu.   Extraordinary elections of the Riigikogu are held in the cases prescribed in §§ 89, 97, 105 and 119 of the Constitution, not earlier than twenty and not later than forty days after the election was called.
