voting_methods.instructions: (1) If a voter does not submit an application to vote by post within the term provided for in subsection 50 (5) of this Act or does not send a ballot paper to the foreign mission by the due date provided for in subsection 52 (2), he or she may vote at the foreign mission at a time determined by the foreign mission.   (2) A foreign mission shall allow voting at the mission on at least two days in the period between fifteen days and ten days before the election day.   (3) At a foreign mission, a voter shall complete a ballot paper pursuant to the provisions of this Act. Thereafter the voter shall place the completed ballot paper in an envelope. The voter shall place the envelope in another envelope. The voter or the person organising the voting shall write the name and personal identification code and the number of the electoral district of the voter on the outer envelope. A voter temporarily staying in a foreign state shall also write his or her residential address in Estonia on the outer envelope.   (4) A voter voting at a foreign mission shall sign the list of voters voting at the foreign mission against the receipt of a ballot paper.  Overseas voters can vote in person, by mail, or online

Chapter 71ELECTRONIC VOTING   [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 482.  General principles of electronic voting   (1) Electronic voting shall be held by the Electronic Voting Committee.   (2) The electronic voting system administered by the Electronic Voting Committee shall be used in electronic voting. The technical requirements for the electronic voting system, which are necessary for ensuring the compliance with the requirements provided for in subsections 1 (2)–(3) of this Act, shall be established by the National Electoral Committee in the regulation provided for in clause 15 (4) 2) of this Act.   (3) A voter shall vote himself or herself. Under the conditions prescribed in this Act, a voter may change his or her vote cast by electronic means.   (4) The Electronic Voting Committee shall organise the testing of the electronic voting system. The National Electoral Committee shall organise the auditing of the electronic voting system and the acts of the Electronic Voting Committee. The procedure for the testing and auditing, and the inspection of the acts of the electronic voting committee shall be established by the National Electoral Committee in the regulation provided for in clause 15 (4) 2) of this Act. [RT I, 11.07.2014, 1 - entry into force 21.07.2014]  § 483.  Preparation of electronic voting   (1) The Electronic Voting Committee shall bring the electronic voting system to readiness and enter the list of voters and the consolidated lists of candidates in the electoral districts in the system not later than by the thirteenth day before election day.   (2) Any amendments to the lists of voters provided for in §§ 24 and 25 of this Act shall be entered on the days of electronic voting in the electronic list of voters at least once a day.   (3) Prior to the start of electronic voting, the Electronic Voting Committee shall create the encryption key for electronic votes and the vote-opening key. The vote-opening key shall be distributed among the members of the National Electoral Committee. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 484.  Electronic voting procedure   (1) A voter may vote using electronic means on the days prescribed in clause 38 (2) 3) of this Act using the system provided for in subsection 482 (2) of this Act.   (2) A voter shall identify himself or herself by a certificate which enables digital identification, issued on the basis of the Identity Documents Act.   (3) Following the identification of the voter pursuant to the procedure provided for in subsection (2) of this section, the consolidated list of candidates in the electoral district of the residence of the voter shall be displayed to the voter.   (4) The voter shall indicate the candidate in the electoral district of his or her residence for whom he or she wishes to vote. The application used for electronic voting shall encrypt the voter's vote using the votes encryption key. The voter shall confirm the vote by a digital signature in conformity with the Digital Signatures Act.   (5) A notice that the vote has been taken into account shall be displayed to the voter after the voting is confirmed. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 485.  Change of electronic votes    A voter has the right to change his or her vote cast by electronic means:  1) by voting again using electronic means at the time prescribed in clause 38 (2) 3) of this Act;  2) by voting with a ballot paper from the tenth to the fourth day before election day pursuant to the procedure provided for in §§ 40–43, 45 or 47 of this Act. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 486.  Verification of electronic votes   (1) A voter has an opportunity to verify whether the application used for electronic voting has transferred the vote cast by the voter to the electronic voting system according to the voter's wish.   (2) The procedure for verification of electronic votes shall be established by the National Electoral Committee in the regulation provided for in clause 15 (4) 2) of this Act. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012, not implemented before 2015]  § 487.  Taking into account of electronic votes   (1) In case of several votes cast using electronic means (subsection 485 (1)), the last vote cast by the voter shall be taken into account.   (2) After the close of electronic voting, the Electronic Voting Committee shall prepare a list of persons who voted using electronic means by voting districts and shall forward the list to the county electoral committees not later than on the second day before election day. A county electoral committee shall forward the list to voting district committees not later than on the day preceding the election day.   (3) If a voter has voted using electronic means, a member of the voting district committee shall make a notation in the list of voters concerning voting using electronic means.   (4) If a voter has voted using electronic means as well as with a ballot paper, the ballot paper of the voter shall be taken into account. The voting district committee shall send to the Electronic Voting Committee an appropriate notice, based on which the Electronic Voting Committee shall not take into account the voter's vote cast using electronic means.   (5) If a voter has voted several times outside the voting district of his or her residence, and using electronic means, all envelopes with ballot papers of the voter as well as the vote cast using electronic means shall not be taken into account. The voting district committee shall send to the Electronic Voting Committee an appropriate notice, based on which the Electronic Voting Committee shall not take into account the voter's vote cast using electronic means. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 488.  Suspension, termination and not starting electronic voting   (1) In case of suspension of electronic voting, the National Electoral Committee shall promptly notify the voters of the suspension and restarting of electronic voting.   (2) In case of not starting or termination of electronic voting, the National Electoral Committee shall promptly notify the voters thereof and provide the information which types of voting can be used instead of electronic voting.   (3) In case the suspension or termination of electronic voting is accompanied by the annulment of the votes cast using electronic means, the National Electoral Committee shall promptly notify the voters of the necessity to vote again and the types of voting that can be used for this purpose. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]

§ 40.  Advance voting   (1) Advance voting shall be held pursuant to the procedure prescribed in § 39 of this Act.   (2) A voter entered in the list of voters who has attained 18 years of age by the day of the advance voting has the right to vote in the advance voting.   (3) At least three members of a voting district committee shall hold the advance voting.   (4) A member of the voting district committee shall mark the date of voting in the list of voters concerning voters who have voted.   (5) The voting district committee shall keep the ballot box and voting documents on advance voting days and the following days such that only members of the voting district committee have access to these.  § 41.  Specifications for advance voting held outside voting district of residence   (1) On advance voting days (subsection 38 (2)), voters may vote outside the voting district of their residence in a voting district designated by the county electoral committee or rural municipality or city government.   (2) A voting district committee designated by the rural municipality or city government shall organise voting outside the voting district of residence on the days prescribed in clause 38 (2) 2) of this Act. The rural municipality or city government may designate a voting district committee which, in addition to advance voting, organises voting only at the location of a voter (§ 43) or in custodial institutions, hospitals and twenty-four hour social welfare institutions (§ 45). [RT I, 11.07.2014, 1 - entry into force 21.07.2014]   (3) A county electoral committee, except the Harju County Electoral Committee and the Tartu County Electoral Committee, shall designate, not later than on the forty-fifth day before election day, at least one voting district located in a county town, where voters can vote outside the voting district of their residence on the days prescribed in clause 38 (2) 1) of this Act. In Tallinn and the city of Tartu, the city electoral committee shall designate this voting district. Each county electoral committee shall publish its resolution not later than in the week preceding the beginning of advance voting. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 42.  Advance voting held outside voting district of residence in polling place   (1) A voter who wishes to vote in a polling place outside the voting district of his or her residence shall present an identity document to a member of the voting district committee and he or she shall be entered in the list of voters voting outside the voting district of their residence.   (2) The member of the voting district committee shall issue to the voter a ballot paper, two envelopes and the consolidated list of candidates in the electoral district of the residence of the voter. The voter shall sign the list of voters voting outside the voting district of their residence against the receipt of a ballot paper.   (3) The voter shall complete the ballot paper pursuant to the provisions of subsections 39 (3)-(6) of this Act.   (4) The voter shall place the ballot paper in one of the envelopes given by the member of the voting district committee. The voter shall place the envelope in the other envelope given to him or her by the member of the voting district committee. The voter or the member of the voting district committee shall write the name, personal identification code and residential address of the voter on the outer envelope. The voter shall deposit the envelope in the ballot box prescribed for the ballot papers of voters who vote outside the voting district of their residence.  § 43.  Advance voting held outside voting district of residence at location of voter   (1) If a voter who wishes to vote outside the voting district of his or her residence is unable to vote at a polling place located in a voting district due to his or her state of health or for another good reason, he or she may, until 2 p.m. on the last day of advance voting, submit a written application to vote at his or her location to the rural municipality or city government of his or her location or to a voting district committee prescribed in subsection 41 (2) of this Act. The voting district committee shall register the application. The rural municipality or city government shall register the application and forward the application to the appropriate voting district committee. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]   (2) Voting shall be organised by at least two members of the voting district committee pursuant to the provisions of subsections 39 (4)-(6) and subsections 42 (1), (2) and (4) of this Act.

Chapter 7VOTING PROCEDURE    § 34.  Polling place   (1) Voting in a voting district shall be held at a polling place designated by the rural municipality or city government. Different polling places may be designated for voting on election day and on advance voting days.   (2) A polling place shall have places for the distribution of ballot papers, voting booths and a ballot box. In a voting district where voting outside the voting districts of voters’ residences is held, the polling place shall have, during advance voting, a separate voting booth and ballot box for the voters who vote outside the voting district of their residence. The consolidated list of candidates in the electoral district and the national lists of candidates shall be posted in the polling place.   (3) Order in a polling place shall be maintained by the voting district committee. Lawful oral orders given by members of the voting district committee are mandatory for all persons in the polling place.  § 35.  Voting booth   (1) A voting booth shall enable secret ballot.   (2) A voting booth shall have a table and a writing instrument. The consolidated list of candidates in the electoral district shall be placed on the wall of the voting booth, except the booth designated for voters voting outside the voting district of their residence. [RT I 2006, 30, 231 - entry into force 14.07.2006]  § 36.  Ballot box   (1) Voting district committees shall inspect and seal ballot boxes before voting opens. Ballot boxes sealed before the start of advance voting shall be used for advance voting only.   (2) The opening of a ballot box shall be covered. It shall be opened only to deposit a ballot paper in the box.   (3) On advance voting days, voting district committees shall seal the openings of the ballot boxes used for advance voting after the close of voting.  § 37.  Ballot paper   (1) The National Electoral Committee shall establish the standard format of the ballot paper.   (2) The National Electoral Committee shall organise the preparation and delivery of ballot papers to the voting district committees.   (3) After the receipt of ballot papers, a voting district committee shall put an impression of the seal of the voting district committee on the ballot papers. The National Electoral Committee shall put an impression of the seal on ballot papers used for voting in foreign states and on board ships.  § 38.  Time of voting   (1) Voting on election day shall open at 9 a.m. and close at 8 p.m.   (2) Advance voting shall be held:  1) from the tenth day to the seventh day before election day in a voting district designated by a county electoral committee. Voting shall open at 12 a.m. and close at 8 p.m.;  2) from the sixth day to the fourth day before election day, in all voting districts. Voting shall open at 12 a.m. and close at 8 p.m. Voting at the location of a voter, in custodial institutions, hospitals and twenty-four hour social welfare institutions shall be organised between 9 a.m. and 8 p.m.; [RT I, 11.07.2014, 1 - entry into force 21.07.2014]  3) from the tenth day to the fourth day before election day by electronic means. Voting shall open at 9 a.m. on the tenth day before election day and shall last twenty-four hours a day until the close of voting at 6 p.m. on the fourth day before election day.   (3) Home voting shall be held on election day in the cases prescribed by this Act. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]  § 39.  Voting   (1) A voter shall vote in the voting district where he or she is entered in the list of voters, except in the cases prescribed in §§ 41-45 and 47 and in Chapter 71 and 8 of this Act. [RT I, 01.11.2012, 1 - entry into force 11.11.2012]   (2) In order to receive a ballot paper, a voter shall present an identity document to the voting district committee. The voter shall sign the list of voters against receipt of the ballot paper.   (3) The voter shall complete the ballot paper in a voting booth.   (4) The voter shall write the registration number of the candidate in the electoral district of his or her residence for whom he or she wishes to vote in the designated space on the ballot paper.   (5) The voter shall complete the ballot paper himself or herself. If he or she is unable to complete the ballot paper himself or herself due to a physical disability, another voter, but not a candidate in the election district of his or her residence, may do so at his or her request and in his or her presence.   (6) The voter shall not take the ballot paper out of the polling place. If the voter spoils the ballot paper, he or she has the right to receive another ballot paper from the voting district committee. The voter shall return the spoilt or unused ballot paper to the voting district committee. [RT I 2006, 30, 231 - entry into force 14.07.2006]   (7) After completing the ballot paper, the voter shall fold the ballot paper and hand it to a member of the voting district committee who shall put an impression of the seal of the voting district committee on the outside of the folded ballot paper.   (8) The voter shall deposit the ballot paper in the ballot box himself or herself. If a voter, due to physical disability, is unable to deposit the ballot paper in the ballot box himself or herself, another voter may do so at his or her request in the presence of the voter.

electoral_rights.source: Constitution Article 57, 58

government_functions.details: Estonia's President serves as the chief of state and the Prime Minister serves as the head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Parliament for a five-year term. In cases where the President does not secure a majority of vote after three rounds of voting, the Constitution of Estonia provisions for an electoral college to determine the winner. The Prime Minister is nominated by the President and approved by Parliament.   The Parliament (Riigikogu) is comprised of 101 seats that are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies. Terms are four years long.   The judiciary in Estonia consists of 1) county, city, and administrative courts 2) circuit courts and 3) the Supreme Court. Supreme Court Justices are appointed for life by parliament on the advice of the Chief Justice. The Chief Justice is proposed by the President and appointed by parliament.

voting_methods.instructions: In order to cast a ballot, a voter must present a valid identification document and a personal voting card, which is mailed to all registered voters at least two weeks before election day. All voters are required, upon entering the polling room, to establish their identity by presenting their voter card and an identity card or a valid passport. He receives the envelope intended to contain the ballot paper; he is required, to place his ballot paper in the envelope, to go to the part of the voting room arranged to isolate him from view.  On his return, he affirms his vote on the copy of the electoral list and in the margin of his name by his signature. A distinctive sign is affixed to the voter's card by one of the members of the office.

government_functions.details: Executive power is exercised by the supreme authority of the prince, who is the head of state. The government, led by the Minister of State who is assisted by the government council, is directly appointed by the prince and is not accountable to the National Council. A network of advisory bodies mitigates the extensive powers of the prince as compared to the limited powers of the National Council. Legislation can only be initiated by the prince and while the parliament has the responsibility to deliberate and vote on bills, the prince retains a power of veto.  Monaco has a unicameral legislature, the National Council, with 24 seats. All members are directly elected and serve 5-year terms. However, 16 members are elected by plurality vote, and 8 members are elected by proportional representation vote.  Judicial power vests in the Prince who delegates its full exercise to the courts and tribunals. Supreme Court is composed of five full time members and two substitute members.

voting_methods.instructions: Upon entering the polling room, the voter after proving his identity, has his registration recorded on the electoral list. In addition, the voter's vote is recorded by the affixing of the imprint of his left thumb in indelible ink in front of his name in the presence of the members of the office.  Civil servants, military and magistrates on a mission, and all other persons traveling for reasons of service may vote outside of their place of registration.  1992 Electoral Law Chapter V Section 2 Article 47 and 49

The Parliament is made up of a single Assembly, called the National Assembly, whose 65 members hold the title of Deputy.  The National Assembly exercises the legislative power. It alone has the power to pass laws by simple majority. The judicial power is independent of the legislative power and the executive power. It is exercised by the Supreme Court, the Court of Accounts and the other Courts and Tribunals.

voting_methods.instructions: This is designed to help you understand the Voting Procedures during an election. Remember that you are qualified to vote if you are a registered voter and your name appears on the register of voters at your polling.  Opening of the Polling Units: On each Election Day, polling stations will open for Accreditation and Voting from 8:00 am to 2.00 pm. However, voters on the queue before the close of poll at 2:00pm will be accredited and allowed to vote.  Voting Procedure: Voting at the polling unit will be as follows:  Step 1:  At the polling unit, join the queue. An INEC official will check if you are at the correct polling unit and confirm that the PVC presented belongs to you.  Step 2:  An INEC official will confirm if your PVC is genuine using the card reader. You will be asked to place your finger on the card reader.  Step 3:  An INEC official will ask for your PVC and confirm you are listed in the Voters Register. Your name will be ticked and your finger will be inked to confirm you have voted. If your name is not found you cannot vote.  Step 4:  The Presiding officer will stamp, sign and endorse your ballot paper. You will be given the ballot paper rolled with the printed side inwards and directed to the voting cubicle.  Step 5:  Stain your finger with the ink given and mark the box for your preferred candidate/party. Roll the ballot paper in the manner you were given and flatten it.  Step 6:  Leave the voting cubicle and drop the ballot paper in the ballot box in full view of people at the Polling Unit.  Step 7:  Leave the Polling Unit or wait if you so choose, in an orderly and peaceful manner, to watch the process up to declaration of result.  N.B: The result of each Polling Unit shall be pasted at the unit for everyone to see.  Your right as a voter:  On each Election Day, you have the right to:  Access the polling station Receive information on the voting procedures from the poll officials Vote in secret. Responsibility of the Voter:  Obey all lawful instructions from the INEC and Security Officials on election duty. Leave the polling unit or wait if you so choose in an orderly and peaceful manner. Encourage other voters to do likewise.

government_functions.details: The President of Cyprus is the head of state and government and is directly elected with the requirement that the President must be Greek Cypriot and the Vice President must be Turkish Cypriot. Both Turkish and Greek Cypriots vote for each position. Note that the Vice Presidency has been vacant for decades due to a boycott of Cyprus' government by Turkish Cypriots.   Cyprus has a unicameral House of Representatives (Vouli Antiprosopon) that with 80 seats total. 56 seats are allocated to Greek Cypriots, 24 are allocated to Turkish Cypriots, and 3 are reserved for religious minority groups. Like the vice presidenct, the seats allocated to Turkish Cypriots are vacant.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in Cyprus and has 12 judges and 1 court president. New judges are recommended by the Supreme Court and appointed by the President.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The president is elected directly by citizens under a two-round system. If no candidate receives more than 50 per cent of valid votes cast in the first round, a second round is held two weeks later between the two leading candidates. The candidate who receives the greatest number of votes in the second round is considered elected.

election_issues.issues: Russia/Ukraine war; energy crisis; cost-of-living crisis; EU/migration; main opposition leader facing fraud charges

voting_methods.instructions:
Ballots for the presidential election are printed separately for each candidate; voters will receive the ballots no later than 3 days before the day of the first round of elections amd for any second round, voters will only receive their ballots at the polling station. Voters are required to vote at the electoral district in which they are registered in the voter lists. However, a voter can apply for an absentee voting certificate which allows them to vote in a polling station outside the electoral district in which they are registered, either on the terriroty of the Czech Republic or at a diplomatic mission abroad (the certificate must be handed in at the polling station where they choose to vote). At a polling station, the voter must prove his/her identity and citizenship of the Czech Republic with the necessary document. Each voter must vote in person; No proxy voting is allowed. The voter receives an empty official envelope, stamped with the official stamp of the district election commission. Upon request, the commission will also issue the voter a set of ballots.  With the official envelope and the ballots, the voter must go to the area designated for inserting the ballot into the official envelope. Otherwise, the voter will not be allowed to vote. The voter places one ballot for the candidate for whom she/he has decided to vote in the official envelope. The ballot cannot be modified in any way. The voter votes by inserting the official envelope with the selected ballot into the ballot box in front of the precinct election commission. Assisted voting is allowed for voters who are disabled or illiterate, but only another voter (not a poll worker) can assist.  Mobile voting is also available for home-bound voters upon request. Voting also takes place in medical and similar facilities, according to special voter lists.

The stamp on the official envelope is the stamp of a munucipal authority or an embassy. The commissions do not have its own stamp. The voter has to be in the designated area alone, except for the people with disabilites.

A voter can vote abroad in a special electoral district at the embassies and consular offices of the Czech Republic. Out-of-country voting is possible in two ways. Firstly, on the basis of registration in a special list of voters maintained by the embassy/consulate (in case of a long-term stay), with a registration deadline of no later than 40 days before the election day.  An absentee voting certificate can be issued for a voter who is registered at an embassy/consulate which allows them to vote at another embassy/consulate or polling station on the territory of the Czech Republic. Voters with a permanent residence in the Czech Republic but who register at an embassy will be removed from the permanent list of voters kept by the respective municipal office (when removed from the special voters list at an embassy/consullate, the voter will be put back on the permanent voter list in the Czech Republic.) Secondly, a voter with permanent residence in the Czech Republic can vote at any embassy abroad using a standard absentee voting certificate which they apply for ahead of the election. The Ministry of Interior sends the ballot papers electronically to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which forwards them to the diplomatic missions no later than 3 days before the election day. The diplomatic missions are to secure the printing or copying of the ballot papers. Voters who vote at diplomatic missions are to receive the ballots papers in the polling station. The method of voting at diplomatic missions is the same as for voting inside the territory of the Czech Republic. 

2012 Presidential Elections Act, Article 28(5), 31, 33

disinformation.source: Article 35(2) of the presidential election law

government_functions.details: The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister.   Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected.   The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

Kuwait is a hereditary emirate. The chief of state is the Amir, who is chosen from within the ruling family and confirmed by the National Assembly. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Amir, as is the Crown Prince, who also must be approved by the National Assembly. The Crown Prince is also designated as the Heir Apparent and the National Assembly must swear fealty to the Crown Prince.   Kuwait has a unicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Umma), which has 50 members and 15 ex-officio seats reserved for cabinet ministers. Per the Constitution, there may be more ministers (and thus ex-officio members) so long as the number of ministers does not exceed one-third of the total assembly.   The highest courts in Kuwait are the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. All judges are appointed by the Amir on the recommendation of the Supreme Judicial Council.

The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters wishing to vote by mail must attend in person at an Electoral Commission office in their district, establish their identity and eligibility (authenticated by a document from their superior or employer).  They are issued with ballot paper and envelopes which they complete there and then.  The Electoral Commission then posts the ballot, voter card and supporting document to the voter's polling station.  The voter marks with a cross the square corresponding to the candidacy for which the voter votes, or does not indicate any, and then folds the paper in four and hands to the president of the polling place who puts it in the ballot box.  Postal voting is limited to military personnel or security force officers who are unable to attend because of duties or health workers, seafarers, airport staff who are presumed unable to attend at a polling place because of professional responsibiities.  See Art 124 & 125 of the Electoral Law

To vote they must be registered in the census book and have their identity recognised by polling place officials (Art 107).  The voter marks with a cross the square corresponding to the candidacy for which the voter votes, or does not indicate any, and then folds the paper in four and hands to the president of the polling place who puts it in the ballot box.   See Art 105, 107 & 122 of the Electoral Law

government_functions.details: The Tunisian government has three branches the executive, legislature, and the judiciary.  The president, prime minister, and the cabinet make up the Tunisian executive. The president appoints both the prime minister and cabinet members. The president is the head of state while the prime minister is the head of government. The president is elected through a two-round system and must attain more than 50% of the total votes cast to win in the first round. The elected president serves for up to two five-year terms.  The legislative branch consists of a 161-member Assembly of the Representatives of the People.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 24 members of parliament are elected from single-member constituencies by FPTP voting. The legal framework, however, does not explicitly state that the candidate that receives the highest number of votes wins the seat.

voting_methods.instructions: The Chief Electoral Officer sends eligible postal voters a postal voting package to their address indicated on the electoral roll or to the address the voter indicated in their applicaton for postal voting. The package includes a postal voting paper, an envelope marked "Postal Vote", and an envelope addressed to the Chief Electoral Officer. The outer envelope includes on its face the number of the elector's name on the roll.  Before sending out the postal voting paper, the Chief Electoral Officer must effectively conceal the consecutive number of the voting paper, write his or her initials and the elector's roll number on the counterfoil of the voting paper, place his or her official mark on both the counterfoil and the voting paper, and indicate on a copy of the roll beside the relevant electors' names, the fact that a postal voting paper has been forwarded to the elector, together with the date that it was forwarded.  Upon receipt of the postal voting paper, the elector shall alone and secretly, exercise his or her vote in accordance with the instructions on the voting paper and any additional instructions that the Chief Electoral Officer considers advisable to give to the elector. The elector then encloses the voting paper in the envelope marked "Postal Vote" and then encloses the envelope in the envelope addressed to the Chief Electoral Officer.  Provided the postal vote is received before the close of polls, the Chief Electoral Officer must record on the envelope received, the date of receipt and the name of the person from whom it was received if delivered by hand, draw a line in ink through the number of the elector on a copy of the roll to be called the "Postal Votes Received" and the date of receipt of that postal vote, open the envelope addressed to him or her and take out the envelope marked "Postal Vote" containing the voting paper and place the unopened envelope in the sealed or locked ballot box in his or her office designated for all postal votes. The ballot box shall not be opened until after the close of the poll.  Source: 2004 Electoral Act Articles 65 (1-5), 66 (1-2), 67 (1-2), 68, 69, 70 (1-2)

An elector of any constituency who satisfies a Returning Officer that he or she is unlikely to be in the constituency for which he or she is registered as an elector may vote in advance of polling day, in any polling booth (station) established by the Chief Electoral Office for that purpose. Every applicant must sign and deliver to the Returning Officer a declaration in Form 12. The Returning Officer is to issue the applicant a voting paper and an envelope addressed to the Returning Officer and marked "Vote in advance of poll". Before giving the voting paper to the elector, the Returning Officer must follow the same procedures as for the issuing a voting paper on the ordinary polling day, e.g. concealing the consecutive number of the voting paper, writing his or her initials and the elector's roll number on the counterfoil, place his/her official mark on the counterfoil and voting paper, strike out the elector's name/number on the roll, etc.  The Returning Officer must also enter the date of the advance voting on the counterfoil and at the top right-hand corner of the voting paper, and also beside the name of the applicant on the roll. The applicant then proceeds alone to vote in secret, folds the voting paper, places it in the envelope provided, and delivers the envelope after sealing it to the Returning Officer. The Returning Officer must keep the safe custody of the sealed envelopes with the declarations attached and on polling day is to open all the advance voting envelopes and place the folded voting papers in the ballot box in the respective constituency.   Source: 2004 Electoral Act Articles 62(1-5), 61 (1-2), 64(1-2)

Electors who are ordinarily voting in-person on election day can vote at any place in their constituency that is designated for the taking of the poll. An elector informs the Presiding Officer of his or her name and the constituency in which he or she proposes to vote, and the Presiding Officer, being satisfied that the person is entitled to vote and has not already voted, issues the elector one voting paper.  If so required by any scrutineer, the Presiding Officer may, before issuing any voting paper, put certain questions to the person proposing to vote, for example, whether the person is at least 18 years of age or whether he or she has already voted in the election.  In issuing a voting paper, the Presiding Officer must firmly fix a piece of gummed paper over the consecutive number on the paper in order to conceal it or to otherwise conceal the number, write his or her initials and the elector's roll number on the counter foil of the voting paper, place his or her official mark on both the counterfoil and the voting paper, and draw a line in ink through the number and name of the elector on the roll as evidence that the elector has received a voting paper. The elector is to immediately go into one of the inner compartments of the polling booth/station and while there alone (except for the case of electors in need of assisted voting), secretly vote by marking a cross (or other clear mark) in the square opposite the name of the candidate for whom he or she desires to vote.  If an elector inadvertently spoils a voting paper, he or she can return it to the Presiding Officer who will then supply the elector with a new voting paper. Before leaving the inner comparement, the elector is to fold the voting paper so that the contents cannot be seen and must then deposit it so folded in the ballot box (which is sealed or locked).   At the time of the close of the poll, electors who are present in a polling booth for the purpose of voting can cast their vote. Electors may not remain in the polling booth/station after casting a vote.  Any elector who has registered as an elector of a constitutency but whose name is not found on the roll for that constituency, or has since closing of the rolls become qualified as an elector in a constituency, or is on polling day present in a constituency other than that for which the person is registered as an elector (but has not cast an advance or postal vote) may, upon completing a declaration form, receive an ordinary voting paper and an envelope addressed to the Returning Officer marked "Vote by Declaration". Upon marking the voting paper in secret in an inner compartment, the elector shall place the paper, duly folded, into the envelope, and return the envelope to the Presiding Officer. After the preliminary count of the ordinary votes, the Presiding Officer is to forward the unopened envelopes with declarations to the Returning Officer who shall forward them to the Registrar of the relevant constitutency. The Registrar determines the elector's qualification or non-qualification and returns the envelopes to the Returning Officer who shall allow all qualified voting papers.  Source: 2004 Electoral Act Part 5, Articles 44-59

Timor-Leste is a semi-presidential system in which the president and the parliament (which chooses the prime minister) are elected by direct, universal suffrage for five-year terms. The President is the Head of State while the  Prime Minister acts as the Head of government. The prime minister oversees the day-to-day functioning of government and chairs the Council of Ministers. The prime minister is designated by the political party or alliance of political parties with a majority in the national legislature and is formally appointed by the president.  The Legislature is a unicameral Parliament, composed of the National Assembly. Parliamentarians are elected on national party slates with proportional representation. Ministers are also appointed by the president, following the recommendations of the prime minister.   The judiciary is notionally headed by the Supreme Court: as it has not yet been appointed, the Court of Appeal acts in its place.

The Executive Power shall be exercised by the President of the Republic acting with the respective Minister or Ministers, or with the Council of Ministers, in accordance with the provisions of this Section and other concordant provisions.

(Art. 13 of Electoral (Early Voting) Regulations 2019)  Early voting will be available for a week before Polling day from 12:00 PM on a Thursday (1 week before polling) to 17:00 PM the day before polling. Saturdays from 09:00 AM to 13:00 PM and closed on Sundays. (Nauru Electoral Commission)

After voting, voters must fold their ballot paper and place it at the ballot box in the presence of the presiding officer or an electoral official. government_functions.details: The President of Turkmenistan serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The presidential term is 7 years, and there are no term limits.  The Mejlis is the unicameral legislature of Turkmenistan, and it has 125 seats. All 125 members are elected by absolute majority vote (via up to two rounds of voting) in single-seat constituencies. Members serve 5-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest judicial body in Turkmenistan, and it consists of a president and 21 judges split into three chambers. Judges are appointed by the President and serve 5-year terms.

The president is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two consecutive 4-year terms.    The National Congress is composed of a Senate with 81 seats and a Chamber of Deputies with 513 seats.  Senators are directly elected in multi-seat constituencies by plurality vote and serve 8-year terms.  Deputies are directly elected via an open-list proportional representation system and serve 4-year terms.    The Brazilian judiciary is headed by the Federal Supreme Court (STF), a body of 11 justices.  Justices are nominated by the President and confirmed in the Senate by absolute majority vote.

government_functions.details: France has a semi-presidential system of government. The President serves as the head of state and is elected by an absolute majority. He/she serves for 5 years and cannot hold office for more than 2 consecutive terms. He appoints the Prime Minister, can dissolve the National Assembly, leads foreign policy, serves as commander-in-chief of the armed forces, and can call for referendums on certain issues. The Prime Minister serves as the head of government and is responsible for domestic policy and day-to-day administration. The Parliament is composed of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly has 557 members who are directly voted and serve for 5 years. The Senate ensures the representation of the territorial communities. There are 348 Senators. They are elected every 6 years. The High Council of the Judiciary consists of a section with jurisdiction over judges and a section with jurisdiction over public prosecutors. The former is presided over by the Chief President of the Cour de Cassation and the latter by the Chief Public Prosecutor at the Cour de Cassation.

government_functions.details: Belarus is a presidential republic with a bicameral parliament. The President of Belarus, elected for a five-year term, is the head of state and Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. The president is directly elected by an absolute majority of the votes cast (if not, a second round is held) and if more than half of the registered voters have taken part in the voting (if not, a new election is held). Executive power is nominally exercised by the government, at its top sits a ceremonial prime minister, appointed directly by the President.  Legislative power is de jure vested in the bicameral parliament, the National Assembly. The 110 members of the lower House of Representatives are directly elected for five-year terms under a majoritarian system in single-member constituencies. The Council of the Republic is the upper chamber of territorial representation, its members elected at meetings of the local councils of deputies and the City of Minsk, plus eight members appointed by the President of the Republic.  The Constitutional Court is the highest court in Belarus which deals with matters involving the Constitution and legality of certain laws passed by the government. The Supreme Court is the highest court of general jurisdiction that deals with matters of civil and criminal law.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters first select the list of a single party (or coalition of parties or isolated independent candidate) and then, within the list, mark one preference for every four seats to be filled in their constituency.  Seats are distributed among lists within each constituency by dividing the total number of votes cast for each list by the electoral quota. The remaining seats are distributed among parties or coalitions of parties that have gained at least one seat in any constituency pursuant to the first distribution or, for single parties, at least 1.8% of all valid votes cast throughout the island (for coalitions of 2 or more parties, the applicable figures are 10% and 20%, respectively). Notwithstanding the above, 3.6% of the total number of votes cast is required for lists of single parties which participate in the second distribution in order to be entitled to a second seat.  Vacancies arising between general elections are filled by the unsuccessful candidates of the same party in the constituency concerned who received the highest number of preferential votes after the last successful candidate.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 30 members of the House of Assembly are elected by first-past-the-post voting in single-member constituencies.

voting_methods.instructions: The Supervisor of Elections provides each Special Presiding Officer (assigned for the early voting) with a list of the election officers, their national ID numbers, and the constitutencies in which they are registered to vote. Each Special Presiding Officer is to be provided with a sufficient number of ballot papers and envelopes for the number of election officers on the list. The early voting by election officers is to be carried out according to the same procedures that apply to voting on polling day, with the exception that early voters are to place their marked ballot in the ballot paper envelope provided by the Special Presiding Officer (which indicates on the outside the number of the polling district) and seal the envelope, then place that envelope in the covering envelope provided (that is addressed to the relevant returning officer) and seal the envelope, and then insert the envelope in the sealed ballot box. Each ballot box is to be marked "special ballot box" and have the number of the constituency written on it. The Supervisor of Elections is to ensure the safe keeping of all the special ballot boxes.  Source: 1991 Representation of the People Act 34(1-9)

Voters must vote in-person at the specified polling station where they are regisered. At the polling station, eligible voters must present their national ID card and are given a single paper ballot by the presiding officer if their name appears on the voter register. If the person is on the register but does not have an ID, they must still be given a ballot provided that he or she satisfies the presiding officer that they have not been issued an ID card or that it has been lost or destroyed. At the time any person applies for a ballot paper, the presiding officer may, and if required by a candidate or his or her agent, must put to that person certain questions, such as relating to identity and whether the person has already voted in that election.   Immediately before giving a person a ballot paper, the presiding officer must mark the ballot with the offiical mark, call out the name, description and roll number of the elector, mark the elector's roll number on the counterfoil, and place a mark next to the elector's roll number in the register to indicate that a ballot paper has been received. Upon receiving a ballot, the elector must proceed into one of the compartments (polling booth) and, in secret, mark the ballot by placing a cross next to their chosen candidate. The voter then folds the ballot to conceal his or her vote and must then shows the presiding officer the back of the paper so as to disclose the official mark. In the presence of the presiding officer, the voter then puts the folded ballot into a sealed ballot box.   If a voters spoils their ballot, he or she can notify the presiding officer who will issue a new ballot paper upon return of the spoiled ballot.  Upon voting, the elector must immediately leave the polling station. Where another person has voted as the elector and after satisfactorily answering the questions permitted by the law to be asked at the poll, the presiding officer is to issue the elector a "tendered" ballot paper. The voter does not put it in the ballot box, but gives it to the presiding officer who keeps all tendered ballots in a separate package, along with a list of electors who voted by tendered ballot.   Source: 1991 Representation of the People Act 39; Second Schedule 27(1-4), 28 (1-2), 29(1-3), 32(1-3), 33

basic_data.electoral_system_other: There are 22 multi-member constituencies (18 continental consitutencies, 2 Autonomous Region constituencies, 1 constituency for Portuguese living abroad in Europe, and 1 constituency for Portuguese living abroad in the rest of the world). Political parties/coalitions submit closed party lists. There is no threshold for parties to enter parliament. Seats are allocated using D'Hondt formula.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1976 Constitution, Article 49(1) 1979 Law governing Elections to the Assembly of the Republic Article 1(1)

voting_methods.instructions:
Residents abroad can vote by-mail or in person, and citizens who happen to be in a foreign country can vote in advance of election day in-person.

Vote by mail is free for all citizens residing abroad. The State is obliged to pay the costs. The Ministry of Internal Affairs sends the paper ballots to the citizens registered in the census elaborated by the census comissions abroad, that opted for voting by mail. The shipping is made in the fastest way possible, under registration, in the shortest term possible, after the draw which is referred to in paragraph 1 of article 31, to the addresses indicated in the census registration. Each paper ballot is accompanied by two envelopes: a) One green envelope, which is meant to receive the paper ballot and does not contain any instructions; b) The other envelope, a white and larger one, which is meant to contain the envelope for the paper ballot. The voter cross marks, in the respective square, the candidacy in which they want to vote and folds the paper ballot in four, introducing it in the green envelope, which is then closed. The green envelope, sealed, is introduced in the white envelope, with a copy of th identification card, that the voter sends, sealed, before the election. 

Source: 1979 Electoral Law of the Assembly of the Republic Articles 79-F(1-3), 79-G(1-6)

Voters can register ahead of time for early voting at the municipality in which they want to vote, at the election administration of the General Secretariat of the Ministry of Internal Affairs. Inpatients and prisoners can register to vote in advance at the hospital or prison where they are. Seven days before the election, the voter goes to the polling station where they chose to vote (there is at least one per constituency), shows a civil identification document and indicates the parish where they are registered. The voter is given a ballot paper and a white envelope. The voter marks their choice on the ballot in secret, folds it in four, puts it in the white envelope and seals it. This envelope is placed in another blue envelope where the voter's name and civil identification number, county, and the parish and registration office, if any, in which they are registered will be written. This envelope is closed and protected with a sticker whose duplicate will be delivered and serves as a receipt.    Source: 1979  Law governing Elections to the Assembly of the Republic Articles 40b(1-3), 79b(1-2), 79c(1-3)

The vote is exercised directly and in person by the voter at the polling station corresponding to the place where the voter is registered. The voters vote by order of arrival at the polling station. Voters are to show a civil identification document or any other official document that contains an updated photograph. If the voter does not have such an ID, he/she can vote as long as their identity is unanimously recognized by the board or by two duly identified voters. Proxy voting is not allowed.  The voter's name and ID number is read aloud and if the voter appears in the register they are given one ballot. The voter must mark the ballot in secrecy in the voting booth. The voter must make a cross within a box on the ballot paper corresponding to the candidate they wish to vote for. The voter folds the ballot in four and returns it to the polling president who puts it in the ballot box. The polling staff initial beside the name of the voter on the register. If a voter inadvertently spoils the ballot they can ask the chairman for another ballot and return the spoiled one.  Source: 1979 Law governing Elections to the Assembly of the Republic Articles 79(1-3), 82(1-2), 84, 88(1-8)

government_functions.details:
Portugal has a semi-presidential system.
 
Executive Branch: Headed by the Prime Minister, who is responsible for implementing laws and running the day-to-day affairs of the country. The government includes the Prime Minister, ministers, and secretaries of state.
 
Legislative Branch: the Assembly of the Republic, responsible for making laws. It consists of 230 deputies elected for four-year terms through a closed-list proportional system.
 
Judiciary Branch: Composed of the Constitutional Court, the Supreme Court, Courts of Appeal, First-Instance Courts, Administrative and Fiscal Courts, and Auditors Courts. The branch interprets and applies the law, ensuring justice is administered fairly.
 
President of the Republic: elected by direct popular vote, the President acts as a mediator and has some significant powers, including appointing the Prime Minister and other key officials.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The president and the vice-president are elected jointly through a nationwide majoritarian system. For the election to be valid, at least 50 per cent of the registered voters have to participate. A candidate is considered elected if s/he receives an absolute majority of the valid votes cast. If no candidate obtains the required number of votes, a second round is held one week later between the two candidates who obtained the most votes. government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 39  members of the House of Assembly are elected in single-member constituencies by a FPTP system to serve five- year terms.

voting_methods.instructions: Citizens seeking to (advance) vote abroad must submit an application for enrolment as an overseas (or special) voter in person at any embassy, high commission or foreign mission or apply in writing to the Parliamentary Commissioner. Applications can be submitted in person, by fax, or electronically, to reach the Parliamentary Commission within 7 days of the issue of the writ of election. A person who meets the criteria and is enrolled as an overseas voter cannot vote in the the Bahamas on polling day. Overseas voting is held in-person at certain designated polling locations (High Commissions, Consulates, and other foreign missions of the Bahamas) on the appointed advance polling date. Persons who wish to vote in the Bahamas as a special voter on the advance polling day must apply in writing to the Parliamentary Commissioner for a special voter certificate within 14 days of the issue of the writ of election.  The Parliamentary Commissioner designates the places for advance polling for special voters in the Bahamas, paying due regard to the facilities of such institutions as he or she may designate. Institutions that house certain categories of special voters, such as hospitals and nursing homes, can apply to be designated as an advance polling place for special voters.  Advance polling for eligible members of the police and defence forces is to be held at places designated by the Parliamentary Commission.  Not less than 14 days prior to the designated advance polling day, the police commissioner and defence force commodore must submit to the Parliamentary Commissioner a list of the members of the police and defence forces, respectively, which lists shall be made available for inspection by the Parliamentary Commissioner not later than 7 days before the advance polling day.  The election law provides that advance polling for all of the categories of advance voters is to be conducted in the same manner as the polling on the regular polling day in accordance with the law. At any advanced poll, a separate ballot box is provided, and at the close of such advanced poll the ballot papers in each box shall, without examination, be placed in separate packets and sealed by the presiding officer, each packet designating the number of ballot papers it contains and the relevant constituency. The sealed packets are to be immediately returned to the Parliamentary Commissioner (from both inside and outside the Bahamas) to be kept in his or her office or other safe place until delivery on the day appointed for the regular polling day to one of the presiding officers for the same constitutency to which such packet relates. Immediately before the commencement of the regular polling day, the presiding officer is to open such advance polling packets and without examining the ballot papers shall place them in the ballot box at his or her poll before he or she locks the box up and places the seal on it.

A voter must vote in person at the polling division to which he or she is designated in the voter register (except for those persons scheduled to vote in the advance polls.) The voter is to show his or her voter's card or other sufficient means of identification. Then, if the presiding officer is satisfied that the person has not already voted and that his or her name is on the voter register for that polling division, the voter is allowed to vote.  If a voter uses an identification other than a voter's card, the presiding officer must record the voter's name and type of ID on a list. If the presiding officer is not satified with the identification of the voter or his or her right to vote because of a defective voter's card, incorrect entry in the voter register, or missing entry on the voter register for the relevant constituency or polling division, the voter is allowed to cast a "protest vote" using a coloured ballot paper (regular ballot papers are white).  The presiding officer gives a voter one ballot paper after the officer signs his or her own name on the back of the ballot paper, calls out the number, full name and description of the peron as stated in the register and marks the said number on the counterfoil, puts a mark against the name of that person in the register to indicate that the person has voted in that polling division,  marks the thumb of the person by dipping the thumb of his or her right hand in indelible ink or by such other officially designated mark (or otherwise left thumb, other finger, or other way to indicate the person has been issued a ballot paper), and stamps that person's voter card to indicate that the person voted in that election in that polling division. After inspecting the person's thumb or fingers with the proper equipment, the presiding officer should refuse to give a ballot paper unless satisifed that there does not appear any such mark of indelible ink. If the proper equipment is not working properly or not available, each voter must take an oath that he or she has not previously voted in that election.  A refusal to give a voter a ballot paper must be recorded with a reason by the presiding officer. Before issuing a ballot paper, the presiding officer may, and, if required so to do by a candidate or election agent, must, require any person to to take and subscribe to an oath  to confirm his or her identify and residence qualification, and that he or she has not already voted in that election. If the voter refuses to do so, the ballot cannot be issued.  Before giving the voter the ballot paper, the presiding officer must immerse the voter's thumb (finger) in the indelible ink. Upon receiving a ballot paper, the voter is to immediately go into one of the compartments to secretly vote, using the indelible pencil provided, marking one cross opposite the name of the candidate for whom he or she votes. The voter is to fold the ballot paper to conceal the vote, show the back of the paper to the presiding officer to show the officer's signature, and then drop the folded ballot paper into the ballot box. The voter must then immediately leave the polling station. A voter who inadvertently spoils a ballot paper can return it to the presiding officer and be issued a new one.  Source: 1992 Parliamentary Elections Act 56, 57(1-3), 58(1-2), 59(1-9), 60(1-5), 61, 62(1-3), 63(1-4), 64(1-3)

government_functions.details: The President serves as both head of state and head of government. The President is elected indirectly through the Electoral College, a body made up of electors with each state receiving the number of electors equal to the size of their delegation in both house  of Congress. Generally, the electors give their votes to the candidate who won the state. The President is elected to four-year terms with an absolute two-term limit.  The legislature is a bicameral Congress consisting of the Senate and the House of Representatives. In the Senate, 100 members are elected by plurality vote (2 members per state) to serve 6-year terms. One-third of Senate seats are up for election every 2 years. In the House of Representatives, 435 members are elected by plurality vote in single-member constituencies to serve 2-year terms.  The Supreme Court is the highest court in the US judiciary. The court consists of nine justices, each nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Justices serve lifetime appointments. The federal court system also includes 13 regional courts of appeal and 94 district courts.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters wanting to vote by mail must apply for a postal ballot with the Fiji Electoral Office and the application must be received no later than 21 days before polling; once approved, during the polling, the voter must use the Voter Instruction Booklet to identify the number of the candidate voters would like to vote for, and circle or tick or cross the number of the candidate on the ballot paper. After voting, voters must fold the ballot paper and place it inside the Secret Envelope, seal it, and put it inside the Transmission Envelope. Voters must complete and sign the Declaration Form at the back of the Transmission Envelope, place it in the Return Envelope then send it by the courier to the address printed in front of the Return Envelope. (Fijian Elections Office: Election Information Booklet)

The voter shall vote by use of a secret envelope, as prescribed for postal voting. After having voted, the voter must fold the pre-poll ballot paper and insert it in the secret envelope and seal the secret envelope; the voter must put the completed and sealed envelope into a ballot box and must not mark the secret envelope in any manner.

After the identification process, and upon the receipt of the ballot paper, the voters must: -retire to a voting screen -secretly mark their vote on the ballot paper in the way prescribed in section 54 (by placing a circle around, or a tick or a cross on the number of their preferred candidate on the ballot paper) -fold the ballot paper to conceal their vote -after voters have marked their vote and before they placed the ballot paper in the ballot box, have one finger marked with an indelible substance -deposit the ballot paper in a ballot box in the presence of the Presiding Officer or a designated election official

The Riksdag is appointed by means of free, secret and direct elections. Voting in such elections is by party, with an option for the voter to express a personal preference vote.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: The Constitution of Sweden "Chapter 3, Art. 4. Every Swedish citizen who is currently domiciled within the Realm or who has ever been domiciled within the Realm, and who has reached the age of eighteen,..."

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters abroad can vote either in person at diplomatic representations 24 days before election day or by mail 45 days before election day.

If you are outside Sweden, you can vote by post or in advance at many Swedish embassies and consulates. To vote by post, you must use special materials that you can order from the Swedish Election Authority, your municipality, or a Swedish embassy or consulate. You can send a postal ballot from abroad from 28 July for the 2022 elections. You can vote in advance at a Swedish embassy or consulate from 18 August.

Voters can vote in advance in designated polling stations during 18 days before the election day.  Vote in advance in either your own or another municipality You can vote in advance at any voting location in Sweden. Advance voting in Sweden will take place from 24 August 2022 up to election day. You must bring your voting card with you when voting in advance. You can find out where to vote in advance from your municipality or on val.se.

Who can vote? To be eligible to vote, an individual must be at least 18 years old on election day. The details listed in the Swedish Population Register 30 days before election day determine whether you are eligible to vote, and which electoral district you belong to.  You are eligible to vote in Riksdag elections if you are: a Swedish citizen, and you are or have been listed in the Swedish Population Register. You are entitled to vote in local council elections for your municipality and region if you are: a Swedish citizen, and you are listed in the Swedish Population Register a citizen of an EU country, Iceland or Norway, and you are listed in the Swedish Population Register a citizen of any other country, and you have been listed in the Swedish Population Register for three consecutive years before election day Those who are eligible to vote receive a voting card Those who are eligible to vote are sent a voting card by post about three weeks before election day. Your voting card will state the elections in which you are entitled to vote, as well as the name, address and opening hours of your polling station. If your voting card is missing, you can order a new one from your municipality or the Swedish Election Authority.  Ballot papers Ballot papers are yellow for Riksdag elections, white for municipal council elections and blue for regional council elections. There are ballot papers at every voting location.  Voting for a party You vote primarily for a party. The name of the party is on the ballot paper. If you cannot find a ballot paper for your party of choice, you can write the name of the party on a blank ballot paper.  Specifying a candidate If you want a particular candidate to be elected, you can put a cross in the check box before that candidate’s name on your named ballot paper. You can only put a cross in one check box for one candidate. You can also specify a candidate by stating both the name of a party and your preferred candidate on a blank ballot paper.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The members of parliament are elected for a five-year term from 13 five-seat constituencies by single transferable vote. Candidates who pass the Hagenbach-Bischoff quota in the first round are elected and any surplus votes transferred to the remaining candidates, who will be elected if this enables them to pass the quotient. The lowest ranked candidates are then eliminated on-by-one with their preferences transferred to other candidates, who are elected as they pass the quotient...

voting_methods.instructions: Voters who reside abroad or will not be in Malta on polling day or who will be hospitalized on polling day and want to vote in advance are required to submit a declaration/oath to the election commission at least one week prior to the election. Early voting for such voters, as well as for election offiicals, takes place at designated locations, as well as in designated retirement homes and hospitals, and at the main correctional facility. Such advance polling stations are considered by law to be, in effect, ordinary polling stations and for the conduct of advance voting the same rules apply as for voting on election day.  Advance (early) voting is to take place on three non-consecutive days during the 7-day period prior to election day. The first advance voting day is the Saturday before polling day for voters who reside or will be abroad or who will be in hospital on polling day, for voters in homes for the elderly, for election commissioners, and for residents of the main correctional facility. The second advance voting day is the Tuesday before polling day when voting takes place for the assistant election commissioners. The third advance voting day is the Thursday before polling day when voting takes place for voters inside hospitals. The hours for all advance voting are 7:00 am - 10:00 pm.  Source: 1991 General Elections Act Articles 2(1), 77(1-4)

Persons may only vote in the electoral division in which they are registered to vote. At the polling station, voters are required to present a voting document produced by the election commission which are distributed ahead of the election and that specifies the polling station where the voter must vote. Proxy voting is not allowed.  Once the election commisisioner is satisfied of the person's identity and that he or she is on the voter list, a ballot will be issued to the voter (after the commissioner puts the official mark on the ballot). The voter's name is to struck out on the list. Provided the voter's name is on the list, no inquiry is permitted at the time of voting as to the right of such person to vote. However, the commissioner can ask the person questions to confirm their identity and require the person to take an oath regarding their identity.  When the voter is issued a ballot, he or she  must proceed to the voting compartment to vote in secret. Each voter shall have one transferable vote. A voter, in recording his or her vote must place the figure 1 against the name of their chosen candidate and may in addition, indicate the order of his or her choice or preference for as many other candidates as he or she pleases by placing against their respective names the figure 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 and so on in consecutive numerical order.  If a voter spoils the ballot paper, he or she can turn it into the assistant election commissioner and receive a new one. After marking the ballot paper, the voter shall fold the ballot so as to show the official mark while concealing his/her vote, show the official mark to the chairperson of the assistant commissioners, and shall then put the ballot in the sealed ballot box in the presence of the assistant commissioners.  Voters in need of assistance to mark their ballot (due to blindness, other physical cause or illiteracy) are required to read out loud their enumerated voting preferences in front of the assistant election commissioners, with one assistant commissioner marking their ballot accordingly. The polling station doors remain closed during this process, and no other voters are permitted inside. Braille templates are required to be made available for visually impaired voters.    Source: 1964 Constitution Article 56(9-10); 1991 General Elections Act Article 16(1-3), Part XI "Voting"

government_functions.details: France has a semi-presidential system of government. The President serves as the head of state and is elected by an absolute majority. He/she serves for 5 years and cannot hold office for more than 2 consecutive terms. He appoints the Prime Minister, can dissolve the National Assembly, leads foreign policy, serves as commander-in-chief of the armed forces, and can call for referendums on certain issues. The Prime Minister serves as the head of government and is responsible for domestic policy and day-to-day administration. The Parliament is composed of the National Assembly and the Senate. The National Assembly has 557 members who are directly voted and serve for 5 years. The Senate ensures the representation of the territorial communities. There are 348 Senators. They are elected every 6 years. The High Council of the Judiciary consists of a section with jurisdiction over judges and a section with jurisdiction over public prosecutors. The former is presided over by the Chief President of the Cour de Cassation and the latter by the Chief Public Prosecutor at the Cour de Cassation.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The president of Serbia is elected using a two-round system and has a term of five years. The candidate who receives the absolute majority of all votes wins. If no candidate receives an absolute majority in the first round, a second round is held within 15 days between the two candidates who received the most votes. The candidate who receives the majority of votes in the second round wins.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters generally vote at the polling station in accordance with their registered place of domocile. Voters can change their address to their temporary location to allow them to vote outside their area of domocile on election day.  Internally displaced persons may vote in their area of temporary relocation. Proxy voting is not permitted.  Upon entering the polling station, the voter is checked with the UV lamp to determine that he or she has not voted at another polling station (except a member of the polling board can vote even if found with UV ink on fingers), the voter's identity is established by inspecting his/her ID card or other appropriate public document with a photograph (a list to be determined by the national election authority), and the voter list is checked to ensure that the voter is entered in the list. If satisfied of the voter's identity and that he or she is in the voter list and has not voted, the polling board member then marks the ordinal number of the voter in the voter list and the voter signs the  list next to his or her number.  As a sign that the voter has voted, his or her right index finger (or other appropriate hand) is then marked with an UV ink spray.  The poll worker then hands out a ballot paper to the voter and is obliged to explain all aspects of the manner of voting. The poll mark must also warn the voter that voting is free and that no one has a right to prevent and force him or her to vote or to make the voter account for the fact that he or she did or did not vote or to ask why (how?) and when the voter voted. The voter then proceeds alone to the polling booth to mark the ballot in secret, by circling the ordinal number in front of the name of the (one) chosen candidate. The voter then folds the ballot so that the mark is not visible and inserts it folded in the sealed ballot box.  A voter who is for any reason unable to cast their ballot independently, can request a person of their choice to assist them to cast their ballot. Mobile voting, whereby polling committee members take a ballot box to voter's homes who have applied (by 11 am on polling day) for mobile voting due to being unable to come to the polling station. Voting takes place inside detention centres and prisons for registered voters in those locations.  Source: 2006 Constitution Article 52; 2022 Law on the Election of the President of the Republic Article 2; 2022 Law on the Election of Members of Parliament Articles 51, 85, 92-97; 2009 Law on Unified Electoral Register
