government_functions.details: Serbia is a parliamentary democracy in which the President serves as head of state. The President is directly elected and serves 5-year terms.   The legislature is the unicameral Serbian National Assembly. It has 250 seats, and members serve 4-year terms. The Prime Minister serves as head of government.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The 250 members of the National Assembly are elected for a four-year term by closed-list proportional representation from a single nationwide constituency. Seats are allocated using the D'Hondt Method with an electoral threshold of 3% of all votes cast, although the threshold is waived for ethnic minority parties. The status as an ethnic minority party is, on request, approved by the national election authority according to established criteria.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters generally vote at the polling station in accordance with their registered place of domocile. There are exceptional circumstances where a voter can vote outside their place of domicile, e.g. internally displaced persons. Proxy voting is not permitted.  Upon entering the polling station, the voter is checked with the UV lamp to determine that he or she has not voted at another polling station (except a member of the polling board can vote even if found with UV ink on fingers), the voter's identity is established by inspecting his/her ID card or other appropriate public document with a photograph (a list to be determined by the national election authority), and the voter list is checked to ensure that the voter is entered in the list. If satisfied of the voter's identity and that he or she is in the voter list and has not voted, the polling board member then marks the ordinal number of the voter in the voter list and the voter signs the  list next to his or her number.  As a sign that the voter has voted, his or her right index finger (or other appropriate hand) is then marked with an UV ink spray.  The poll worker then hands out a ballot paper to the voter and is obliged to explain all aspects of the manner of voting. The poll mark must also warn the voter that voting is free and that no one has a right to prevent and force him or her to vote or to make the voter account for the fact that he or she did or did not vote or to ask why (how?) and when the voter voted. The voter then proceeds alone to the polling booth to mark the ballot in secret, by circling the ordinal number in front of the name of the (one) chosen electoral list. The voter then folds the ballot so that the mark is not visible and inserts it folded in the sealed ballot box.  A voter who is for any reason unable to cast their ballot independently, can request a person of their choice to assist them to cast their ballot. Mobile voting, whereby polling committee members take a ballot box to voter's homes who have applied (by 11 am on polling day) for mobile voting due to being unable to come to the polling station. Voting takes place inside detention centres and prisons for registered voters in those locations.  Source: 2006 Constitution Article 52; 2022 Law on the Election of Members of Parliament Articles 2, 85, 93-97; 2009 Law on Unified Electoral Register

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Lebanese Constitution   Article 24  The Chamber of Deputies consists of elected representatives whose number and the manner of the election are determined by the electoral laws in effect. Until the Chamber of Deputies issues an Electoral Law, outside the sectarian record, representative seats are distributed according to the following rules: a. Equally between Christians and Moslems. b. Proportional between the sects of both sides. c. Proportional among districts.  Lebanese Electoral Law 44/2017

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Lebanese Constitution 2004 Article 21  Every Lebanese citizen, twenty-one years old, has a right to be an elector, pending meeting the requirements prescribed by the Electoral Law.

voting_methods.instructions: Lebanese Electoral Law 44/2017 Article 88: Early voting The Ministry shall organize early voting for polling officers in all constituencies, on the Thursday preceding Election Day. Once the number of ballots contained in every ballot box has been counted, all ballot boxes used in the polling officers’ polling stations shall be sealed and immediately sent- while sealedwith security forces escort, to the Banque du Liban or any of its branches. At the end of the voting process on Sunday, these ballot boxes shall be sent to the competent registration committee who shall sort them and combine their results with those of the other ballot boxes. This process shall be subject to the regulations provided for in Chapter Eleven of the present Law.

The voting process 1.When the voter enters the polling station, the head officer shall verify their identity by checking their identity card or valid ordinary Lebanese passport. If a material difference is noticed between the identity card or passport data and the checklist data, the identity card number of passport number shall be the basis for verification. 2.After the polling station officers have verified that the name of the voter is included in the polling station checklist, the head officer shall hand to the voter a ballot paper signed on its back side by the head officer and clerk, and an envelope officially signed and stamped by the head officer, and request the voter to mandatorily go behind the booth and freely exercise their right to vote, under penalty of being prevented from voting. 3.The voter shall mark the list or candidate name of his choice in accordance with Article 98 of the present law. The voter shall return toward the polling station officers and show the head officer that they hold one sealed and folded ballot paper only. The head officer of the polling station shall verify that without touching the paper before allowing the voter to personally cast the ballot in the ballot box. 4.The head officer of the polling station shall make sure that the voters use the voting booth under penalty of preventing them from voting. The voters may not disclose their ballot after exiting the voting booth. 5.A voter’s vote is validated by the voter’s signature on the checklist and by having their thumb marked with a 24-hour indelible ink supplied by the Ministry to all polling stations. Voters who already have their thumb marked shall thus be prevented from voting again. 6.The head officer of the polling station shall be responsible for preventing any voter from casting their vote should they act in breach of the provisions of paragraph (4) of this Article. 7.The voter may not delegate any other person to vote on their behalf.

electoral_rights.source: Lebanese Electoral Law 44/2017   Article 96: Voters with special needs 1.In accordance with the provisions of the law on the Rights of People with Disabilities, voters with special needs or suffering from disability preventing them from marking their choice and placing the ballot paper inside the envelope and casting it in the ballot box may be assisted by another voter of their choice, under the supervision of the polling station officers. Such occurrence shall be noted in the “comments” column

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1991 Constitution Article 43; 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Article 7

voting_methods.instructions:
Out-of-country voting is available in-person at embassies/consulates or by postal voting for eligible voters permanently or temporarily abroad. According to the website of the election management body, in-person voting abroad is held on election day from 9:00 am - 5:00 pm (local time).  Voting procedures are the same as at a polling station in Slovenia.

Persons enrolled in the voter register of citizens who do not have permanent residence in Slovenia (i.e. those with permanent residence abroad) will be sent the postal ballot paper in due time. Persons who are (or will be) temporarily abroad on election day and wish to vote by post must notify the national authorities no later than thirty days prior to the election day.

Persons enrolled in the voter register of citizens who do not have permanent residence in Slovenia (i.e. those with permanent residence abroad) will be sent the postal ballot paper in due time. Persons who are (or will be) temporarily abroad on election day and wish to vote by post must notify the national authorities no later than thirty days prior to the election day.  Voters who are in detention, prison, in a hospital, or in a social protection institution for institutional care and wish to vote by post must submit their intention to the local electoral commission or the constituency electoral commission at least ten days prior to polling day (or within five days for those entering detention facilities, social care institutions, or hospitals, or declared to have a disability after the deadline). The postal voting materials will be sent to the address indicated in the voter register or in the application and will include instructions on the method of voting by post.   A postal vote is cast on an official empty ballot paper containing the mark of the constituency and of the electoral district, and voters express their will by entering, personally or otherwise, in the appropriate space on the ballot paper the name and surname of the candidate for whom they are voting, or the name of the list of candidates for which they are voting.  Postal voters must send the completed ballot paper and personally signed voting card to the address of the competent local electoral commission (the address will already by printed on the return envelope enclosed). According to the website of the election management body, postal voters abroad can choose to deliver the postal ballot to the Slovenian embassy/consulate where the polling station is located (deliver before that polling station closes on election day.)  Source: 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Articles 81 and 82

Voters who will be absent on polling day may vote early at a special polling station at the headquarters of the local electoral commission where they are listed in the voter register (at the administrative unit where they are registered as a permanent resident). Voting procedures are the same as those applicable to election day voting. After each closure of early voting, ballot boxes and other voting material shall be sealed; they shall be opened for each resumption of early voting and prior to the establishment of the results of the voting.  Source: 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Article 69

Voters usually vote at the polling station at which they are registered to vote, that is where they have permanent residence (or if they do not have permanent residence, in the place of their, or one of their parent's, last permanent residence). However, a voter can apply with the local electoral commission up to three days before election day for absentee voting if they will not be at their district of registered permanent residence on election day, including voters who permanently reside abroad and are to be in Slovenia on election day. Absentee voting allows a voter to vote outside the regular polling station where he or she has permanent residence, at a designated polling station without territorial jurisdiction.  Hungarian and Italian national community voters residing outside of their bilingual municipalities have the opportunity to vote for their respective deputy in their place of residence anywhere in Slovenia and abroad.  At the polling station, voters give their name and surname (and if necessary their address) and the election committee official will determine the voter's identity using any personal identification document that shows the voter's personal data, or in some other manner. Proxy voting is not allowed. The electoral official then circles the serial number before the name on the voter register and the voter signs next to his or her name. The ballot paper(s) is then handed to the voter. Voters are entitled to one ballot, except members of the Italian and Hungarian national communities (which each have one deputy in the parliament) are entitled to a regular ballot and a ballot to vote for their respective ethnic miniority deputy, provided that the person is registered as a minority voter.  If requested by the voter, the election official must explain the technical aspects of the voting. If by mistake, a voter is not entered on the voter register, he or she may vote on the basis of a certificate issued by the competent body stating that he or she is enrolled as a voter in the area of that polling station. If the name of a person who wishes to vote has already been circled on the voter register and there is a signature next to the name, or if there is a note that the person is registered to vote by another method, this fact should be entered in the records, but the voter will not be allowed to vote.  Once issued the ballot(s), voters proceed to vote in secret in the polling booth as follows: (1) for the general ballot, the voter shall vote by circling the serial number before the name of the (one) candidate for whom he or she wishes to vote and (2) for the Hungarian and Italian national community ballot, the minority voter shall vote by circling the serial number before the name of the (one) candidate for whom he or she wishes to vote. The voter then proceeds to insert the ballot(s) in the ballot box.  Persons with disabilities can be assisted in voting by a person of their choice. Voters who are disabled or illiterate and not able to vote independently, can be assisted by a person of their choice to complete and cast the ballot paper(s).  Mobile voting is available for ill (and disabled?) voters who cannot vote in person at the polling station where they are registered to vote, whereby the election committee visits their home to facilitate their voting. Applications for mobile voting must be made no later than three days before polling day.  Source: 1992 National Assembly Elections Act Articles 7-9, 71-75, 79a

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 2011 Hungarian Fundamental Law Article XXIII (1); 2013 Act on Electoral Procedure Section 102 (2)

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country voters without residence in Hungary can apply with the national election authority to be able to vote by-mail.  The application must be submitted no later than 25 days before the election day, and must include the necessary identification information and the voter's postal address to send the voting package or an indication of which embassy/consultate or election office they will pick up the package. The postal voting package is sent to the voter at the indicated address or delivered to the respective embassy/consulate/office. The postal voting package contains a postal ballot paper, a voter identification declaration form, the ballot envelope, a prepaid and pre-addressed reply envelope for mailing, and information on the voting method.  After filling in the postal ballot paper(s), the voter places the ballot(s) in the inner envelope and seals it, completes and signs the voter identification declaration, and inserts the sealed ballot envelope and the declaration form in the outer envelope or in any other envelope. The by-mail ballot can be returned by post to the national election office or embassy/consulate or delivered in-person (or by proxy) to the embassy/consultate or a constitutency election commission.

Voters generally vote at the polling stations at which they are registered to vote, that is in the place of their domocile. Absentee voting is allowed, whereby a voter can vote in a polling station in their area of temporary residence (including outside their election constituency, where they can vote for a candidate from their place of domocile), usually in a dedicated absentee polling station, based on an application submitted to the election authorites at least nine days prior to election day. Also, voters with disability can request to be transferred to an accessible polling station in their same settlement and constituency, if their regular polling station is not accessible. At a polling station, voters show an official identification card, which allows them to vote for a party list (or minority list) and show documentary proof of their address or their personal identification number, which allows them to vote for a constituency candidate.  Upon producing their identification documents and determination that the voter is on the voter list at that polling station and has not voted, the voter receives a ballot paper(s) (normally two ballots - a party/minority list ballot and a constituency ballot), to be stamped in front of the voter, and a ballot envelope, and the voter must sign the voter register (or if unable, two polling officials can sign). Voters registered as a minority voter can vote for a minority list (not a party list), and for constituency candidate. Absentee voters, even if voting outside their constituency, will be provided a ballot from the constituency of their domicile. When necessary, the polling official explains the voting process to the voter. The polling commission must advise voters to use the polling booth but cannot oblige them to do so. The voter then proceeds (to the polling booth) to mark their ballot(s).  Votes can only be cast by drawing two intersecting lines in the circle beside the name of the candidate, or above the name of the list, using a pen. The voter inserts the marked ballot(s) into the ballot envelope and inserts the envelope into the sealed ballot box. If the voter spoils the ballot paper, he or she can receive a new ballot from a polling official provided the spoiled ballot is returned before inserting it in the ballot box. Only one replacement per type of ballot can be provided. Voters with disability or who are illiterate can request a person of their choice (or two polling commission members) to assist them to fill in the ballot paper. Mobile voting can be requested by persons with limited mobility due to the health condition or disability or who are in detention, which is carried out by two members of the polling station commission. The same voting procedures apply for mobile voing; except instead of a polling booth, the voter must be provided circumstances to vote in secret.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: In the presidential election, each of the three main national communities will elect a (rotating) Presidency member. In Republika Srpska, voters elect the Serb representative, whilst the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina voters elect the Bosniak and Croat members. The three members of the Presidency are each elected by plurality (simple majority) on separate candidate lists in the two entities.

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country voters wishing to vote by mail must submit an application to be registered as a by-mail voter for each election to the central election commission for each election. Proof of identity of the applicant by way of a legally acceptable identification document and details of the address abroad must be provided. Those who register for out-of-country voting are removed from the main voter list in their regular polling station.  The manner and procedure of by-mail out-of-country voting is to be regulated by the central election commission. In order for a timely delivered by mail ballot to be counted, it must be returned by a voter who has been determined to be properly registered to vote by mail, sealed in the ballot envelope to ensure secrecy of the person’s vote, and accompanied by a copy of one of the legally acceptable identification documents.  Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 5.21(1) and 5.28(3)

Voters normally vote at the polling station at which they are recorded on the voter register, which is their place of permanent residence (internally displaced persons may vote in their area of displacement if they so choose).                                            Internally displaced persons have the right to either vote in the polling station of their temporary residence, provided such residence has been kept for at least six months, or in special "absentee" polling stations for the electoral unit where they were registered before being displaced.   The polling official determines the identity of the voter on the basis of one of three types of valid identification documents. Proxy voting is not allowed. Once the voter is identified, the polling official marks the voter's name in the voter register, the voter signs the voter register next to his or her name (must correspond to signature on ID), and a ballot is issued to the voter. Voters who are not found on the voter list on election day and  can present a valid identification card and proof of residence are allowed to vote.   To cast their vote, the voter proceeds to the polling booth to vote in secret. The voter marks their one preferred candidate on the ballot. If the voter spoils his or her ballot, a new ballot can be obtained upon returning the spoiled ballot to the polling station committee. Upon marking the ballot, the voter proceeds to insert it into the sealed ballot box.  A person registered as an out-of-country voter who has returned from abroad and wants to vote in-person in the country is entitled to vote by 'tendered' ballot. Tendered ballots are put by the voter into a sealed envelope bearing the voters identification information (which is then inserted into the ballox box) and later counted only after the envelope is forwarded to the central election body and the voter's information is checked against the central voter register.  A blind, illiterate or bodily incapacitated person can request from the president of the polling station committee to allow another person selected by the voter to assist him or her to sign the voter register and cast his or her ballot. The helper cannot be a polling official or election observer, and can help only one voter; the helper must sign the voter register next to the name of the voter he or she assisted.  Homebound voters and those voters confined in places of detention can vote via mobile ballot boxes.  Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 1.4 (2), 3.9 (1-4), 3.16 (6), 3.17 (1-3), 5.1 (1), 5.8 (1), 5.10, 5.11 (1-2), 5.12 (1-5), 5.13 (1-2), 5.14 (1-3), 5.18 (1-2), 5.19 (1-4), 5.20, 5.21 (2)

government_functions.details: The governance structure of Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) was established by the 1995 Dayton Accords that ended the Bosnian War. BiH is a parliamentary republic. It is comprised of three administrative divisons: Republika Srpska (primarily Serb), the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (primarily Bosniak and Croat), and the Brcko District (primarily ethnically mixed). Each of the primary ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Serbs, Bosnians, and Croats) elect a president for a 4-year term. Each of these presidents serves on a rotating basis as the Chairman of the Presidency, with rotations every 8 months.   BiH has a bicameral national parliament (called the Assembly) that consists of the House of Peoples and the House of Representatives. The House of Peoples has 15 seats, with each of the three main ethnic groups alotted 5 seats each. Members of the House of Peoples are designated by regional parliaments in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Republika Srpska respectively. The House of Representatives is comprised of 42 total seats, which are split between members from Republika Srpska and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina.   Notably, both major entities in BiH have their own regional parliamentary systems. In Republika Srpska, there is a unicameral National Assembly with 83 seats. In the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a bicameral parliament with a total of approximately 180 seats split between the two houses. The Brcko District also has its own governance structure, but does not directly feed into the National Assembly in the same way.   The judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina is comprised of the Constitutional Court and the Court of BiH, as well as a variety of cantonal and municipal courts. Members of the Constitutional Court are selected by the President of the European Court of Human Rights in consultation with the tripartite presidency. Note that Republika Srpska has begun the process of splitting away from the jurisdiction of the broader judiciary in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

voting_methods.instructions:
Voters normally vote at the polling station at which they are recorded on the voter register, which is their place of permanent residence (internally displaced persons may vote in their area of displacement if they so choose).                                     

Internally displaced persons have the right to either vote in the polling station of their temporary residence, provided such residence has been kept for at least six months, or in special "absentee" polling stations for the electoral unit where they were registered before being displaced. 

The polling official determines the identify of the voter on the basis of one of three types of valid identification documents. Proxy voting is not allowed. Once the voter is identified, the polling official marks the voter's name in the voter register, the voter signs the voter register next to his or her name (must correspond to signature on ID), and a ballot is issued to the voter. Voters who are not found on the voter list on election day and can present a valid identification card and proof of residence are allowed to vote. 

To cast their vote, the voter proceeds to the polling booth to vote in secret. The voter can choose one of the following options on the ballot: (1) an independent candidate, if any; (2) a political party, coalition or list of independent candidates; or (3) within one list of candidates, mark one or more candidates on the one list chosen by the voter. If the voter spoils his or her ballot, a new ballot can be obtained upon returning the spoiled ballot to the polling station committee. Upon marking the ballot, the voter proceeds to insert it into the sealed ballot box.

A blind, illiterate or bodily incapacitated person can request from the president of the polling station committee to allow another person selected by the voter to assist him or her to sign the voter register and cast his or her ballot. The helper cannot be a polling official or election observer, and can help only one voter; the helper must sign the voter register next to the name of the voter he or she assisted. Homebound voters and those voters confined in places of detention can vote via mobile ballot boxes.

Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 1.4 (2), 3.9 (1-4), 3.16 (6), 3.17 (1-3), 5.1 (1), 5.8 (1), 5.8, 5.10, 5.11 (1-2), 5.12 (1-5), 5.13(1-2), 5.14 (1-3), 5.18 (1-2), 5.19 (1-4), 5.20, 5.21 (2)

Out-of-country voters can choose to vote either in-person at one of the designated embassies or consulates or by mail. They must submit an submit an application to the Central Election Commission of BiH for every elections. Proof of identity of the applicant as prescribed by this law and accurate details of the address abroad, as well as a declaration concerning the voting option: in a diplomatic and consular representation office (DCRO) or by mail, shall be attached to the application, signed by the applicant.

Out-of-country voters wishing to vote by-mail must submit an application to be registered as a by-mail voter for each election to the central election commission for each election. Proof of identity of the applicant by way of a legally acceptable identification document and details of the address abroad must be provided. Those who register for out-of-country voting are removed from the main voter list in their regular polling station.  The manner and procedure of by-mail out-of-country voting is to be regulated by the central election commission. In order for a timely delivered by mail ballot to be counted, it must be returned by a voter who has been determined to be properly registered to vote by mail, sealed in the ballot envelope to ensure secrecy of the person’s vote, and accompanied by a copy of one of the legally acceptable identification documents.

A person registered as an out-of-country voter who has returned from abroad and wants to vote in-person in the country is entitled to vote by 'tendered' ballot. Tendered ballots are put by the voter into a sealed envelope bearing the voters identification information (which is then inserted into the ballox box) and later counted only after the envelope is forwarded to the central election body and the voter's information is checked against the central voter register.

Source: 2001 Election Law Articles 5.21 (1), 5.28 (3)

government_functions.details:
The monarchy is hereditary. The Governor General is appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister for a 5-year term. The Governor General designates the Prime Minister, who is generally the leader of the majority party or coalition.  
All 338 members of the House of Commons are directly elected by plurality/majority vote. Seats are redistristributed after each decennial census on the basis of population between the 10 states and 3 provinces, which may also change the overall number of seats. Members serve 5-year terms.  
All 105 members of the Senate are appointed by the Governor General on behalf of the Monarch. Seats are equally allocated between the following four divisions: Ontario, Quebec, the Maritime Provinces/Nova Scotia and New Brunswick/Prince Edward Island, and the Western Provinces of Manitoba/British Columbia/Saskatchewan/Alberta. Members of the Senate serve for life, with a mandatory retirement age of 75.

government_functions.details: Taiwan has a semi-presidential system, with a president as the head of state and a premier as the head of government. The president is elected directly by the people for a four-year term, and the premier is appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan, the unicameral parliament.  The Executive Yuan, also known as the Cabinet, is the executive branch of the government. It is responsible for carrying out the policies and decisions made by the president and premier. The Executive Yuan is headed by the premier, who is assisted by a vice premier and a number of ministers.  The Legislative Yuan is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the activities of the government. It has 113 members, who are elected from single-member districts (73), multimember constituencies by single nontransferable voting, exclusively for people with indigenous status (6) and party-list proportional representation (34).  The Judicial Yuan is the judicial branch of the government. It is responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that it is applied fairly.

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting is personal and confidential. When entering the hall, the voter proves his identity to the members of the voting office. The voter takes an envelope and a copy of the ballot paper or ballot papers and goes directly to the polling station where he puts his paper in the envelope without leaving the hall. After that, the head of the voting office certifies that he carries only one envelope, and then the president authorizes him to insert the envelope into the box. Each voter with a disability that prevents him from inserting his paper in the envelope and putting it in the box is authorized to seek the assistance of a person of his choice. The voter's vote shall be proven by placing the thumbprint of the left index finger, in indelible ink, on the signature list, opposite their name and surname, in front of the members of the voting office. The voter's card shall be stamped with a wet seal bearing the phrase “Vote (T)” and the date of the election is affixed to it.        Note: When it is impossible to present a voter card, any voter can exercise his right to vote if he is registered on the list.  He must present his national identification card or any other official document proving his identity

hate_speech.source: Electoral Law 1/2021 Article 293: Every person who participates in the campaign shall be punished election and uses hate speech or any form of Discrimination according to the provisions of Articles 30 to 42 of Law No. 05 of Ramadan 5 1441 Corresponding to April 28-20 The year 2020 related to the prevention of discrimination and hate speech and combat them.

government_functions.details: The President is the head of the state. He is elected by an absolute majority vote and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The legislative power is exercised by a Parliament, consisting of two Chambers, the People’s National Assembly and the Council of the Nation. The members of the People’s National Assembly are elected by universal, direct, and secret suffrage. Two-thirds (2/3) of the Members of the Council of the Nation are elected by indirect and secret suffrage, with two seats per Wilaya, among members of the People’s Communal Assemblies and members of the People’s Wilaya Assemblies. One-third (1/3) of the members of the Council of the Nation are appointed by the President among national personalities and qualified experts from scientific, professional, economic, and social fields. The People’s National Assembly is elected for a period of 5 years. The mandate of the Council of the Nation is limited to 6 years. Half the members of the Council of the Nation are renewed every 3 years. No one can serve more than 2 terms in Parliament. The Algerian judicial system is composed of the following: (1) the Supreme Court, (2) the State Council - a regulating organ of the jurisdiction activity under the judicial power, (3) the Superior Council of Magistrature - headed by the President, it sees to it that the public office statutes are respected and controls discipline among magistrates.

government_functions.details:
The President of the Republic of Moldova is the head of state. The executive branch of the Republic of Moldova is headed by the President, who is elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote. The government, led by the Prime Minister, is nominated by the President after consulting parliamentary factions, and it requires a vote of confidence from the Parliament.
The legislative branch consists of the Parliament, and it is composed of 101 deputies elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote for a four-year term.
The judicial branch of Moldova is composed of the Supreme Court of Justice, courts of appeal, and other courts as established by law. Judges are appointed by the President of the Republic, based on the proposal of the Superior Council of Magistracy, until they reach the age limit

government_functions.details: Part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, Aruba has full autonomy on all internal affairs with the exception of defense, foreign affairs, and some judicial functions. The constitution was enacted in January 1986. Executive power rests with a governor, while a prime minister heads an eight-member Cabinet. The governor is appointed for a 6-year term by the monarch and the prime minister and deputy prime minister are elected by the legislature, or Staten, for 4-year terms. The Staten is made up of 21 members elected by direct, popular vote to serve 4-year terms. Aruba's judicial system, mainly derived from the Dutch system, operates independently of the legislature and the executive. Jurisdiction, including appeal, lies with the Common Court of Justice of Aruba and the Supreme Court of Justice in the Netherlands.

government_functions.details: The president is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system and the prime minister is elected by parliament. The prime minister appoints the governors of the 21 aimags of Mongolia and the governor of the capital. The National Parliament is the highest organ of state power, and the supreme legislative power is vested only in the National Parliament. It has only one chamber and is composed of 126 members.  The judicial system consists of the Supreme Court, provincial and capital city courts, Region, inter-region, and district courts. Supreme Court judges are nominated by a Judicial General Council but then confirmed and appointed by the president.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The system used for Scottish Parliament general elections is a mixed member system comprising a first-past-the-post component, under which seats are allocated in single member constituencies, and a proportional representation (PR) component based on regional party lists. These two elements are then linked through a formula known as the d’Hondt method or system. This electoral system is known as the Additional Member System (AMS). voting_methods.instructions: The deadline for submitting an application for a postal vote is currently 5pm on 20 April 2021.  But note that the Electoral Commission advises that because of legislative changes the deadline will move to 6 April.  The Commission advises that this will be confirmed at the end of January 2021. Rule 7, schedule 4 of the Scottish Parliament (Elections etc) Order 2010 provides that postal votes must not be issued before 5pm on the 11th day before the poll.  From Electoral Commission website: http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/postalvote  You need to download, print and fill in the postal vote application form.     Once you have completed the form and made sure you have signed it, you need to send it to the Electoral Registration Office for your area.    After the deadline to become a candidate has passed (approximately three weeks before polling day), ballot papers are produced and printed. Yours will then be sent to you, in your postal voting pack.     Complete the ballot paper in line with the instructions. Make sure you do it alone and in secret.   Once you've completed your ballot paper, put it in the smaller envelope and seal it up. Next, complete and sign the postal voting statement, and put everything inside the big envelope and seal it all up.  When you're ready to return your postal vote, take it to the postbox yourself.  If you can't post it yourself, you can either ask someone you know and trust to post it for you, or you can contact your local authority to ask if they can collect it from you.  Avoid asking a candidate or party worker to post it for you.  Your postal vote needs to be with your local authority by 10pm on polling day to be counted.  If you can't post your postal vote pack in time, you can take it your polling station or to your local authority on polling day.

Voters are given two ballot papers.  The voting procedure and form of the ballot papers are provided for in the Scottish Parliament (Elections etc) Order 2010.  The form of the ballot paper for constituency candidates is prescribed by rule 27, schedule 2 and Form J and contains the instruction: Vote once only in the box opposite the candidate of your choice using an X.    The form of the ballot paper for regional candidates is prescribed by rule 28, schedule 2 and Form K and contains the instruction: Vote once only in the box opposite the party or candidate of your choice using an X.    The voting procedure is set out in rule 46, schedule 2.

government_functions.details: The Governor of Guam, together with the Lieutenant Governor, shall be elected by a majority of the votes cast by the people who are qualified to vote for the members of the Legislature of Guam in each general election. The Governor shall have general supervision and control of all the departments, bureaus, agencies, and other instrumentalities of the executive branch of the government of Guam.  Legislative power in Guam is vested in a single house, composed of 15 members, directly elected for a two-year term. In addition, Guam appoints at the polls a delegate to the U.S. Congress, who will be responsible for defending Guam's interests before the federal government. This delegate has a voice but no vote in the U.S. House. The legislative power of Guam shall extend to all rightful subjects of legislation not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act and the laws of the United States applicable to Guam.  The judicial authority of Guam shall be vested in a court established by Congress designated as the “District Court of Guam”, and a judicial branch of Guam which branch shall constitute a unified judicial system and include an appellate court designated as the “Supreme Court of Guam”, a trial court designated as the “Superior Court of Guam”, and such other lower local courts as may have been or shall hereafter be established by the laws of Guam.

voting_methods.instructions: Voters eligible to vote at their place of residence (mobile voting) submit an advance written application to the precinct election commission, not later than 3 days before election day. Each polling station will have up to three mobile ballot boxes. Mobile voting is conducted by at least two members of the precinct election commission (drawn by lots) together with the operator who received the required number of ballot papers, and together with the sealed mobile ballot boxes. Parties, candidates, observers and media can observe the mobile voting process. A special list of mobile voters is posted outside the polling station two days earlier. The home-bound voter must identify him/herself to the poll workers on the basis of biometric and personal data. Upon identification, the ballot is issued to the voter (no check issued) and the poll worker registers the voter in the paper voter list by putting the series and number of the voter's ID and signs it. The voter signs the voter list upon verification of the entries.  The voter marks the ballot in a special place that allows secrecy of the vote, as well as observation by poll workers and observers. A voter who is unable to fill out the ballot on his/her own due to disability or health condition can request assistance of another voter (but not poll worker, partisan representatives or observers.) In the voter list is noted that the voter voted outside the voting premises.

Only citizens on the voter list have a right to vote on election day. Proxy voting is not permitted.  A voter's identity is checked at the polling station based on his/her biometric and personal data using identification equipment at the polling station. Voter consent is not required. The voter's information is shown on a monitor, visible to partisan representatives and observers. After identification, a check is printed out which the voter hands to the poll worker in exchange for a ballot. If the equipment fails to identify the voter, the voter is not allowed to vote. An official act is to be drawn up with a copy to the voter and another copy to be provided to the relevant state bodies after the official announcement of the election results for taking measures. A ballot is issued to the voter upon presentation of an identity document. When a ballot is issued to a voter, the poll worker registers the voter in the paper voter list, by entering the series and number of the voter's ID and signing the voter list. The voter signs the voter list upon checking the accuracy of the entries. The voter marks the ballot in secret in the voting booth or other specially equipped place. The voter marks the ballot in the square or in the position "Against all" in favour of the candidate or party of choice. If a voter spoils the ballot, a new ballot can be issued; next to the voter's name on the voter list, the poll worker notes that a replacement ballot was provided. Upon verbal notification to the polling commission, voters not able to independently vote can request assistance from another voter who is not a poll worker, candidate, partisan representative, or observer. The voter puts the marked ballot in the automated ballot box. If the automated ballot box breaks down on election day, a spare automated box is to be used and an official act drawn up. If the spare automated ballot box is damaged, voting is to be carried out using a stationary ballot box, and an official act drawn up. If the automated ballot box is repaired it cannot, in any case, be used.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Party-nominated and independent candidates can run. A presidential candiate who receives more than one half of the votes cast in the first round is declared elected. If no candidate receives the required majority, a second round takes place beween the two front runners, within 20 days from the announcement of the first-round results (after election day, the Central Election Commission has 20 days to establish the official election results.)

voting_methods.instructions: Opens at 12.00am on Monday and ends at 4pm on Thursday  Can apply for early vote between October 10 2020 (after the closing of the rolls) and 5pm on 26 March 2021 [s61(2) Electoral Act 2019].  Eligibility for applying for early vote is set out in s61 of Electoral Act 2019         (1)  A person qualifies to pre-poll if the person:         (a)  travels outside Samoa during the    designated period under section 60(2);         (b)  is 65 years old or above;         (c)  is a person living with disabilities;         (d)  is nominated (in a method approved by    the Commissioner) by a person qualified under paragraphs (b) or (c) to be his or her carer;         (e)  is confirmed (in a method approved by the Commissioner) to be employed in an Office providing a service listed under section 5 of the Public Holidays Act 2008;

Polls open at 8am and close at 3pm [s66 of Electoral Act 2019]  Method of voting set out in s71 of Electoral Act 2019         (1)  The voter, having received a ballot paper, must immediately go into one of the inner compartments provided for marking his or her vote, and must there alone and secretly indicate on the ballot paper the candidate he or she desires to vote for by marking a tick (√) in a square set opposite to the name that candidate.      (2)  A ballot paper is not void on the ground that the marking in the square set opposite the name of the candidate is not marked as a tick but is marked in a manner that clearly indicates the candidate that the voter voted for.      (3)  A voter must before leaving the inner compartment, fold the ballot paper so that the contents cannot be seen, and must deposit the ballot paper so folded, in the ballot box made available.

voting_methods.instructions: A May 2020 amendment to the election laws provides for the possiblity of the Central Election Commission establishing the option, with procedures, of voting by mail or internet voting. However, it is not known whether postal or internet voting will be used in the 2021 elections.

A May 2020 amendment to the election laws provides for the possiblity of the Central Election Commission establishing the option, with procedures, of voting by mail or internet voting. However, it is not known whether postal or internet voting will be used in the 2021 elections.

The election laws provide for the possibility for constituency election commissions to allow early voting (not earlier than 20 days before election day) for voters registered at one or several polling stations formed in hard-to-reach or remote areas, on ships that will be at sea on the voting day, and at polar stations, or for voters in settlements or areas without polling stations to vote, up to 15 days early. The dates of early voting are established by a decision of the relevant precinct election commission. However, it is not known whether, and to which extent, early voting will be available in the 2021 elections.       If early voting is conducted in the remote areas and settlements, it is done by sealed portable ballot boxes, accompanied by at least two members of the precinct election commission.  The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On the front side of each ballot paper issued to an early voter, in the upper right corner, the signatures of two voting members of the precinct election commission shall be put, certified by the seal of the precinct election commission.  The voter list with those eligible to vote early accompanies the portable ballot box. The voting is done according to the same procedure for voting on election day at polling stations. Upon receiving the ballot, the voter signs the voter list and the poll worker marks in the list that the voter voted early.  If an extract of the voter list is used, after the early voting is completed, the notations on early voting are transfered to the regular voter list at the polling station.

Voters vote at a designated polling station in their locality of residence. Permission for absentee voting (to allow a voter to vote at a polling station outside their area of residence) can be obtained by advance application by voters who will be away from their residential polling precinct on election day. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. Proxy voting is prohibited. Ballot papers are issued to voters included in the voter list upon presentation of a passport or document that replaces a citizens passport. Before issuing the ballot paper(s) to a voter, the precinct election commission is obliged to check that the voter has not already voted early (e.g. by portable ballot box in remote areas) or by mobile (homebound) voting. Each voter has a right to receive two ballot papers, one for voting in the federal electoral district and one for voting in the corresponding single-mandate electoral district (except absentee voters voting outside the territory of their single-mandate electoral district receive only the ballot for the federal electoral district.) A voter who is not on the voter list for any reason can be registered on election day, upon showing a passport or other proof of residence at the polling station. Upon receipt of the ballot, the identification document number of the voter is to be entered in the voter list. The voter checks the accuracy of the entry made and both the voter and the poll worker sign the voter list in the column next to the voter's name. The voter should enter the polling booth (or other specially equipped place for secret voting) to mark the ballot. Voters should vote alone, except a voter who is unable to independently mark the ballot can request assistance of another person who is not a poll worker, partisan representative, or observer. The voter using assistance must notify the precinct election commission and the personal details of the helper are to be entered in the voter list in the column next to the voter's name. Using any mark, the voter marks the ballot for voting in the federal electoral district - in the square referring to the chosen list of candidates, and on the ballot for voting in the single mandate electoral district - in the square referring to the chosen candidate.  A voter who spoils a ballot can receive a replacement one from the poll worker, who records the issuance of a replacement ballot in the voter list next to the voter's name and signs the entry along with the secretary of the precinct election commission. The voters puts the marked ballots into the sealed ballot box. If the Central Election Commission makes a decision to use ballot envelopes, the voter is to place the marked ballots into the envelope given to him/her by the poll worker after leaving the polling booth, and places the envelope in the ballot box. Electronic voting and counting machines may be used at polling stations.   Mobile (homebound) voting is available, upon advance application, for voters who, due to health reasons, disability, caring for a person in need, or other reasons, cannot go to the polling station.

government_functions.details: The Russian Federation is defined as a federal semi-presidential republic. The President of Russia is the head of state and there is a multi-party system with executive power exercised by the government, headed by the Prime Minister, who is appointed by the President with parliament's approval. The government consists of the Prime Minister, deputy prime ministers, and federal ministers and their ministries and departments. The Prime Minister submits to the President nominations for all subordinate Government positions, including deputy prime ministers, and federal ministers.  The President is directly elected under a two-round system in a single nationwide constituency for a six-year period.  Legislative power is vested in the two houses of the Federal Assembly. The 450 members of the lower house - State Duma - are elected  for a term of five years, with parallel voting. Half of the seats (225) are elected by closed party-list proportional representation within a single nationwide constituency, with a five per cent electoral threshold, with the other half elected in 225 single-member constitutencies by first-past-the-post voting.  Regional assemblies with their respective deputies are formed through this system. The upper chamber - Federation Council - is not directly elected; each of the 85 federal subjects of Russia (oblasts, republics, autonomous territories, and autonomous okrugs) sends two delegates to the Federal Council, for a total of 170 members.  The judiciary of Russia is topped by the Constitutional Court, Supreme Court, and Supreme Court of Arbitration.  The judiciary is governed by the All-Russian Congress of Judges and its Council of Judges.

voting_methods.instructions: Artículo 169. Desarrollo de la votación. A las siete horas (7:00 a.m.), el o la Presidente (a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora, anunciará “empieza la votación”. Seguidamente, se procederá de acuerdo a la secuencia siguiente:1) El o la Presidente(a) requerirá a cada elector la presentación de su Tarjeta de Identidad;2) El o la Presidente (a) mostrará dicha tarjeta a los demás miembros de la mesa para su cotejo con la fotografía que aparece en el cuaderno electoral y la verificación de autenticidad. Seguidamente, la entregará a1 Secretario(a);3) El o la Secretario(a) comprobará que el ciudadano aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral de dicha mesa;4) Una vez comprobado por el Secretario(a) que aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral, los demás miembros de la Mesa Electoral Receptora observarán la mano del elector para comprobar que en sus dedos no existen manchas de tinta indeleble que indique que pudo haber votado en otra Mesa; si las hubiere el Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora retendrá su Tarjeta de Identidad y le ordenará salir del local registrándolo en la hoja de incidencias;5) Si el elector no tuviere impedimento, el o la Presidente(a) firmará junto con el o la Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora en el reverso de las papeletas y las entregará al elector; 6) El o la Secretario(a) retendrá la Tarjeta de Identidad y cualquier aparato digital fotográfico por el tiempo que utilice el elector para votar;7) Seguidamente el elector pasará al lugar privado para marcar las papeletas;8) Enseguida el elector, las doblará de manera que quede oculto el contenido y así las mostrará a los miembros de la Mesa para que éstos verifiquen que contienen las firmas del Presidente(a) y Secretario(a); de tenerlas, se estampará el sello de “ratificado”;9) Efectuado esto el elector depositará cada papeleta en la urna respectiva;10) Seguidamente, uno de los miembros de las Mesa Electoral Receptora examinará el dedo meñique de la mano derecha del votante, o el que corresponda, para ver si tiene residuos grasos o impermeables, procurando eliminarlos si los tuviere y le pondrá tinta indeleble en el mismo;11) El o la Secretario(a) de la mesa hará la anotación respectiva de que el elector votó, consignándolo en el correspondiente Padrón Electoral; y12) Finalmente el Secretario(a) hará entrega al elector de su Tarjeta de Identidad y aparato digital en su caso que le haya retenido quien se retirará de inmediato del local  Artículo 172. Cierre de la Votación. La votación se desarrollará sin interrupción hasta las dieciséis horas (4:00 p.m.);

voting_methods.instructions: Artículo 169. Desarrollo de la votación. A las siete horas (7:00 a.m.), el o la Presidente (a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora, anunciará “empieza la votación”. Seguidamente, se procederá de acuerdo a la secuencia siguiente:1) El o la Presidente(a) requerirá a cada elector la presentación de su Tarjeta de Identidad;2) El o la Presidente (a) mostrará dicha tarjeta a los demás miembros de la mesa para su cotejo con la fotografía que aparece en el cuaderno electoral y la verificación de autenticidad. Seguidamente, la entregará a1 Secretario(a);3) El o la Secretario(a) comprobará que el ciudadano aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral de dicha mesa;4) Una vez comprobado por el Secretario(a) que aparece inscrito en el padrón electoral, los demás miembros de la Mesa Electoral Receptora observarán la mano del elector para comprobar que en sus dedos no existen manchas de tinta indeleble que indique que pudo haber votado en otra Mesa; si las hubiere el Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora retendrá su Tarjeta de Identidad y le ordenará salir del local registrándolo en la hoja de incidencias;5) Si el elector no tuviere impedimento, el o la Presidente(a) firmará junto con el o la Secretario(a) de la Mesa Electoral Receptora en el reverso de las papeletas y las entregará al elector; 6) El o la Secretario(a) retendrá la Tarjeta de Identidad y cualquier aparato digital fotográfico por el tiempo que utilice el elector para votar;7) Seguidamente el elector pasará al lugar privado para marcar las papeletas;8) Enseguida el elector, las doblará de manera que quede oculto el contenido y así las mostrará a los miembros de la Mesa para que éstos verifiquen que contienen las firmas del Presidente(a) y Secretario(a); de tenerlas, se estampará el sello de “ratificado”;9) Efectuado esto el elector depositará cada papeleta en la urna respectiva;10) Seguidamente, uno de los miembros de las Mesa Electoral Receptora examinará el dedo meñique de la mano derecha del votante, o el que corresponda, para ver si tiene residuos grasos o impermeables, procurando eliminarlos si los tuviere y le pondrá tinta indeleble en el mismo;11) El o la Secretario(a) de la mesa hará la anotación respectiva de que el elector votó, consignándolo en el correspondiente Padrón Electoral; y12) Finalmente el Secretario(a) hará entrega al elector de su Tarjeta de Identidad y aparato digital en su caso que le haya retenido quien se retirará de inmediato del local  Artículo 172. Cierre de la Votación. La votación se desarrollará sin interrupción hasta las dieciséis horas (4:00 p.m.);

In accordance with what is established in the electoral law, twenty national members are elected and seventy members in the departmental and autonomous regions.  An obligation is

voting_methods.instructions: Art. 116 Para el acto de votación se procederá así:   1)Cada elector acudirá personalmente ante la Junta Receptora de Votos presentando su Cédula de Identidad Ciudadana o su Documento Supletorio de Votación;   2)La Junta Receptora de Votos verificará la validez de la Cédula de Identidad o del Documento Supletorio de votación y si esta corresponde a su portador, se comprobará si el elector se encuentra registrado en la lista del Padrón Electoral para entregarle las boletas electorales correspondientes;   3)El Presidente de la Junta Receptora de Votos le explicará al elector la forma de emitir el voto;   4)El votante marcará en cada boleta electoral con una “X” o cualquier otro signo en el circulo de su preferencia y la introducirá debidamente doblada en la urna electoral correspondiente;   5)Si la “X” o cualquier otro signo hubiese sido marcada en la boleta fuera del circulo, pero se pueda entender la intención del votante, el voto se consignará válido; y   6)Previo al ejercicio del derecho al voto, en el caso que el elector portare el Documento Supletorio de Votación, este quedará retenido en la Junta Receptora de Votos, salvo en la elección presidencial en cuyo caso será devuelto debidamente marcado a fin de ejercer el derecho al voto en la segunda convocatoria si la hubiere.   Art.117 Los miembros de las Juntas Receptoras de Votos, los fiscales acreditados ante ellas y su personal auxiliar, ubicados en las Juntas Receptoras de Votos diferentes de aquellas en la cual se encuentran registrados, podrán votar en ellas previa presentación de su Cédula de Identidad Ciudadana o Documento Supletorio de Votación y credencial. Esto se hará constar en acta.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Of the 598 members of parliament, 299 are elected from constituency candidates and the remainder from closed political party lists. Each voter has two votes. The first vote elects the constituency candidate directly; the candidate with the plurality vote is elected for that electoral district (party-nominated and independents candidates can run). The second vote goes to the party list.  The seats are distributed according to the Sainte-Lague/Schepers calcluation procedure (also called divisor me

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1949 Basic Law, Article 38(2); 1993 Federal Elections Act, Section 12(1)

voting_methods.instructions: Every voter is entitled to vote by mail upon application for a polling card (postal ballot package) submitted in writing or personally to the relevant local authority. The deadline for application is 18:00 on the second day before election day.   Upon receiving the postal voting package, the voter votes by postal ballot by sending a sealed official return envelope containing his or her signed polling card and in a separate sealed ballot paper envelope, his or her ballot paper. The voter is required to mark the ballot and put it in the ballot paper envelope without being observed and must affirm on the polling card that he or she personally marked the ballot. A postal voter with a disability or who is illiterate can be assisted by a person of choice of at least 16 years old who does not have a conflict of interest. The helper must affirm on the polling card that he/she marked the ballot according to the intent of the voter. Helpers are bound to keep the vote secret.  The voted postal ballot packaged can be mailed free of charge or directly handed in at the relevant authority.  A voter in possession of a polling card can (instead of postal voting) choose to vote in person at any polling station of the constituency in which the polling card was issued.

At the polling station, only voters in the voter register (or who have a polling card) can vote.  A voter casts a ballot in the polling station in the  constituency where he/she is on the voter register (or at any polling station in the constituency where the polling card was issued). Proxy voting is not permitted. Measures must be taken to ensure that the voter can cast the vote and fold the ballot paper without being observed, either a voting booth or room adjoining the main room.  Upon entering the polling station, the voter is given an official ballot paper and may be requested to show his/her voter notice.  In the voting booth, the voter casts the two votes by twice marking the ballot with a cross or other sign to clearly indicate the candidate and party list of choice. The two votes are cast on one ballot that has two parts - one part for the constituency candidate and one part for the party list. The voter then folds the ballot paper to ensure the secrecy of the vote, and approaches the table of the electoral board and hands over his/her voter's notice and identification document ( identification document is not strictly required, unless the voter does not have a voter's notice or if the poll worker otherwise requests). If the voter's notice or identification document is not presented the voter is not allowed to cast the ballot. The poll worker checks the voter's information against the voter register and if present and not marked as voted, marks in the voter register that the voter has voted and allows the voter to proceed to put the ballot in the locked ballot box. If the voter is not in the voter register (or does not produce a polling card if present in the polling register as having received a postal voting package), he/she is not allowed to vote. Other grounds for refusing the voter to cast the ballot is if the voter marked or folded the ballot outside the booth or otherwise jeoparidized the secrecy of the vote. If a voters spoils her/his ballot, another ballot can be requested provided that the voter  destroys the spoiiled ballot in the presence of a poll worker. Voting machines can be used instead of ballot papers and ballot boxes to facilitate the casting and counting of votes.  A voter who is illiterate or has a disability can request a person to assist provided the person does not have a conflict of interest. The person assisting is bound to mark the ballot according to the intent of the voter and must keep the ballot choice secret.   Only voters who arrive before the end of polling hours and are inside the polling station or in front of it due to lack of space shall be permitted to cast their votes.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The law provides that no person shall be elected as President on a first ballot unless the votes cast in his or her favour at the election are more than fifty per cent of the total number of votes validly cast at that election. On a second ballot, the candidate, who receives the highest number of votes shall be declared to have been duly elected President.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Seats are alllocated at two stages: At the first stage, they are allocated at the district level on the basis of proportional representation. The second stage of the allocation of seats is made at the national level. Political parties need to obtain at least 3.6 per cent of valid votes nationwide in order to be considered for the allocation of seats at this stage.

government_functions.details: The President of Cyprus is the head of state and government and is directly elected with the requirement that the President must be Greek Cypriot and the Vice President must be Turkish Cypriot. Both Turkish and Greek Cypriots vote for each position. Note that the Vice Presidency has been vacant for decades due to a boycott of Cyprus' government by Turkish Cypriots.   Cyprus has a unicameral House of Representatives (Vouli Antiprosopon) that with 80 seats total. 56 seats are allocated to Greek Cypriots, 24 are allocated to Turkish Cypriots, and 3 are reserved for religious minority groups. Like the vice presidenct, the seats allocated to Turkish Cypriots are vacant.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in Cyprus and has 12 judges and 1 court president. New judges are recommended by the Supreme Court and appointed by the President.

To gain parliamentary representation, each party needs to receive at least the 5 per cent of the votes nationwide. The threshold will be raised to 10 per cent for two-party coalitions, 15 per cent for three-party coalitions and 20 per cent for coalitions of four or more parties.

voting_methods.instructions: There are two polling days. On the first election day, polling stations shall open at 14:00 hours and close at 22:00 hours. On the second election day, polling stations shall open at 07:00 hours and close at 14:00 hours. A voter shall cast his/her vote in person. No voting by proxy shall be admissible. Upon entering, voters shall approach the ward election board. Qualified Czech citizens living abroad may vote in the Chamber of Deputies election only at voting stations at Czech missions and offices abroad. NOTE: Voters may register in their municipality to cast an absentee ballot elsewhere on election day.

government_functions.details: The Czech Republic or Czechia is a parliamentary republic. The President is directly elected and serves a five-year term. The President appoints the Prime Minister.   Czech parliament consists of the 81-seat Senate and the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies. Both houses are directly elected.   The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court, the Supreme Administrative Court, and the Constitutional Court. Supreme Court judges are proposed by the lower house of parliament and are appointed for life.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Art. 140 : Les modes de scrutin pour les élections législatives sont : - le scrutin majoritaire uninominal à un tour, pour les circonscriptions spéciales ; - le scrutin proportionnel à la plus forte moyenne, pour les circonscriptions ordinaires. Pour les circonscriptions spéciales est déclaré élu le candidat ayant obtenu la majorité relative des voix. En cas d’égalité des voix, il est procédé à un second tour dans les dix (10) jours qui suivent la proclamation des résultats par

voting_methods.instructions: Art. 63 : Le scrutin est ouvert à huit (8) heures et clos le même jour à dix-neuf (19) heures.      Toutefois, la CENI peut, pour faciliter aux électeurs l’exercice de leur droit de vote, avancer l’heure d’ouverture ou retarder l’heure de la clôture dans certaines circonscriptions électorales.   Dans tous les cas, les opérations du vote doivent se dérouler dans un intervalle de temps de onze (11) heures précises.   Les électeurs présents devant le bureau de vote doivent voter. A cet effet, à l’heure officielle de clôture, le Président du bureau de vote fait ramasser les cartes des électeurs en commençant par le dernier de la file en attente, et seuls ceux-ci sont autorisés à voter, mention en est faite au procès-verbal.   Un arrêté du Président de la CENI précise les modalités d’application de ces dispositions.   Art. 64 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Nul ne peut être admis à voter s’il ne justifie de son identité.   La carte d’électeur biométrique est l’unique document de vérification de l’identité de l’électeur.   Le vote par témoignage est interdit.   Art. 65 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Les électeurs inscrits sur la liste d’une même circonscription électorale, lorsqu’ils changent de résidence à l’intérieur de cette dernière, sont autorisés à voter dans le bureau de vote de leur nouvelle résidence, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.         Leurs noms sont ajoutés sur la liste des électeurs votants.   Dans le cas d’espèce, l’électeur doit justifier par un récépissé de changement de résidence délivré et authentifié par la CENI locale ou la Commission administrative de son ressort.   Art. 66 : Pour les élections législatives, les candidats déclarés éligibles par la Cour constitutionnelle sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote du ressort de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils se portent candidats sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Art. 67 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur une liste électorale peuvent voter dans le bureau de vote où ils ont été nommés quelle que soit l’élection.   Les délégués détenteurs d’un mandat votent dans le bureau où ils ont été désignés pour leur mission.   Les personnes chargées d’assurer la sécurité des bureaux de votes sont autorisées à voter dans lesdits bureaux sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Les agents des forces de défense et de sécurité, les membres et le personnel de la CENI et de ses démembrements, les membres et les délégués de la Cour constitutionnelle, les observateurs nationaux et les délégués des partis politiques sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils sont en mission, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique, de leur mandat ou de leur Ordre de mission.      Le président du bureau de vote est tenu de leur faciliter le vote.   Dans tous les cas, mention du vote doit être faite au procès-verbal avec l’ensemble des caractéristiques de la carte d’électeur.   Art. 68 : Le vote est personnel et secret.   Le choix de l’électeur est libre.   Nul ne doit être influencé dans son choix par la contrainte, la menace ou la violence.   Le vote a lieu dans les bureaux désignés par la CENI.   Art. 69 : Le vote se fait au moyen d’un bulletin unique, à mettre dans l’urne par l’électeur.   Tout électeur atteint d’infirmité ou de handicap physique le mettant dans l’impossibilité d’introduire son bulletin dans l’urne est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix ou par un membre du bureau de vote.      Art. 75 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : A son entrée dans le bureau de vote, l’électeur porteur de sa carte d’électeur biométrique ou de la preuve de son droit de voter par la production d’une décision du Président du Tribunal d’Instance, après avoir fait constater qu’aucune de ses mains ne porte d’empreinte et de trace d’encre indélébile, prend lui- même un bulletin unique mis à sa disposition. Le président ou un membre du bureau de vote lit à haute et intelligible voix les noms et prénoms de l’électeur qui s’apprête à voter. Celui-ci, sans quitter le bureau de vote exprime son choix. Cette opération doit se faire dans l’isoloir.   Il fait ensuite constater au président qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul bulletin unique qu’il introduit lui-même dans l’urne.   Art. 76 : Le vote par procuration est exceptionnel ; il n’est admis qu’en cas d’incapacité physique ou d’empêchement majeur.   Sont déclarées valables les seules procurations établies par les présidents des commissions électorales locales conformément au modèle défini par la CENI.   Tout électeur mandaté pour voter par procuration doit être muni de la carte d’électeur et de la pièce d’identification de la personne qui l’a mandaté.         Le mandataire doit être inscrit dans le même bureau de vote que le mandant. Il ne peut être détenteur que d’une seule procuration.   La procuration doit être établie en deux (2) exemplaires dont l’un sera remis au mandant et l’autre classé dans les archives de la Commission locale des élections.   Elle doit être numérotée et enregistrée dans un registre spécial.   Toute procuration ne respectant pas les prescriptions du présent article est nulle.   A l’issue du dépouillement, les procurations sont jointes aux bulletins nuls, tels que prévus à l’article 88 ci-dessous et transmis à la juridiction compétente.   Art. 77 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par son identification tel que prévue par l’article 75 ci-dessus, puis par sa signature ou son empreinte digitale apposée sur la liste d’émargement en face de son nom.   De plus, le vote de l’électeur est constaté par l’imprégnation de son pouce gauche à l’encre indélébile.   Tout électeur détenteur d’une procuration dûment mandatée doit procéder aux deux (2) opérations avant de passer son pouce à l’encre indélébile.       L’électeur atteint d’une infirmité le privant de son index ou de son pouce peut apposer l’empreinte de tout autre doigt sur la liste d’émargement. S’il ne dispose d’aucun doigt, la personne qui l’assiste est autorisée par le président de bureau de vote à apposer l’empreinte de son index.      Art. 78 : Dès la clôture du scrutin, la liste d’émargement est signée par tous les membres du bureau de vote.   Cette liste d’émargement est tenue à la disposition de tout électeur qui désire la consulter à la Circonscription électorale, pendant un délai de huit (8) jours à partir de la proclamation des résultats provisoires.
