voting_methods.instructions: Sous-section 2 : Des modalités de vote   Art. 63 : Le scrutin est ouvert à huit (8) heures et clos le même jour à dix-neuf (19) heures.         Toutefois, la CENI peut, pour faciliter aux électeurs l’exercice de leur droit de vote, avancer l’heure d’ouverture ou retarder l’heure de la clôture dans certaines circonscriptions électorales.   Dans tous les cas, les opérations du vote doivent se dérouler dans un intervalle de temps de onze (11) heures précises.   Les électeurs présents devant le bureau de vote doivent voter. A cet effet, à l’heure officielle de clôture, le Président du bureau de vote fait ramasser les cartes des électeurs en commençant par le dernier de la file en attente, et seuls ceux-ci sont autorisés à voter, mention en est faite au procès-verbal.   Un arrêté du Président de la CENI précise les modalités d’application de ces dispositions.   Art. 64 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Nul ne peut être admis à voter s’il ne justifie de son identité.   La carte d’électeur biométrique est l’unique document de vérification de l’identité de l’électeur.   Le vote par témoignage est interdit.   Art. 65 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : Les électeurs inscrits sur la liste d’une même circonscription électorale, lorsqu’ils changent de résidence à l’intérieur de cette dernière, sont autorisés à voter dans le bureau de vote de leur nouvelle résidence, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.         Leurs noms sont ajoutés sur la liste des électeurs votants.   Dans le cas d’espèce, l’électeur doit justifier par un récépissé de changement de résidence délivré et authentifié par la CENI locale ou la Commission administrative de son ressort.   Art. 66 : Pour les élections législatives, les candidats déclarés éligibles par la Cour constitutionnelle sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote du ressort de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils se portent candidats sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Art. 67 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur une liste électorale peuvent voter dans le bureau de vote où ils ont été nommés quelle que soit l’élection.   Les délégués détenteurs d’un mandat votent dans le bureau où ils ont été désignés pour leur mission.   Les personnes chargées d’assurer la sécurité des bureaux de votes sont autorisées à voter dans lesdits bureaux sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique.   Les agents des forces de défense et de sécurité, les membres et le personnel de la CENI et de ses démembrements, les membres et les délégués de la Cour constitutionnelle, les observateurs nationaux et les délégués des partis politiques sont autorisés à voter dans l’un des bureaux de vote de la circonscription électorale dans laquelle ils sont en mission, sur présentation de leur carte d’électeur biométrique, de leur mandat ou de leur Ordre de mission.         Le président du bureau de vote est tenu de leur faciliter le vote.   Dans tous les cas, mention du vote doit être faite au procès-verbal avec l’ensemble des caractéristiques de la carte d’électeur.   Art. 68 : Le vote est personnel et secret.   Le choix de l’électeur est libre.   Nul ne doit être influencé dans son choix par la contrainte, la menace ou la violence.   Le vote a lieu dans les bureaux désignés par la CENI.   Art. 69 : Le vote se fait au moyen d’un bulletin unique, à mettre dans l’urne par l’électeur.   Tout électeur atteint d’infirmité ou de handicap physique le mettant dans l’impossibilité d’introduire son bulletin dans l’urne est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix ou par un membre du bureau de vote.      Art. 75 (Loi n° 2019-38 du 18 juillet 2019) : A son entrée dans le bureau de vote, l’électeur porteur de sa carte d’électeur biométrique ou de la preuve de son droit de voter par la production d’une décision du Président du Tribunal d’Instance, après avoir fait constater qu’aucune de ses mains ne porte d’empreinte et de trace d’encre indélébile, prend lui- même un bulletin unique mis à sa disposition. Le président ou un membre du bureau de vote lit à haute et intelligible voix les noms et prénoms de l’électeur qui s’apprête à voter. Celui-ci, sans quitter le bureau de vote exprime son choix. Cette opération doit se faire dans l’isoloir.   Il fait ensuite constater au président qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul bulletin unique qu’il introduit lui-même dans l’urne.   Art. 76 : Le vote par procuration est exceptionnel ; il n’est admis qu’en cas d’incapacité physique ou d’empêchement majeur.   Sont déclarées valables les seules procurations établies par les présidents des commissions électorales locales conformément au modèle défini par la CENI.   Tout électeur mandaté pour voter par procuration doit être muni de la carte d’électeur et de la pièce d’identification de la personne qui l’a mandaté.         Le mandataire doit être inscrit dans le même bureau de vote que le mandant. Il ne peut être détenteur que d’une seule procuration.   La procuration doit être établie en deux (2) exemplaires dont l’un sera remis au mandant et l’autre classé dans les archives de la Commission locale des élections.   Elle doit être numérotée et enregistrée dans un registre spécial.   Toute procuration ne respectant pas les prescriptions du présent article est nulle.   A l’issue du dépouillement, les procurations sont jointes aux bulletins nuls, tels que prévus à l’article 88 ci-dessous et transmis à la juridiction compétente.   Art. 77 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par son identification tel que prévue par l’article 75 ci-dessus, puis par sa signature ou son empreinte digitale apposée sur la liste d’émargement en face de son nom.   De plus, le vote de l’électeur est constaté par l’imprégnation de son pouce gauche à l’encre indélébile.   Tout électeur détenteur d’une procuration dûment mandatée doit procéder aux deux (2) opérations avant de passer son pouce à l’encre indélébile.       L’électeur atteint d’une infirmité le privant de son index ou de son pouce peut apposer l’empreinte de tout autre doigt sur la liste d’émargement. S’il ne dispose d’aucun doigt, la personne qui l’assiste est autorisée par le président de bureau de vote à apposer l’empreinte de son index.         Art. 78 : Dès la clôture du scrutin, la liste d’émargement est signée par tous les membres du bureau de vote.   Cette liste d’émargement est tenue à la disposition de tout électeur qui désire la consulter à la Circonscription électorale, pendant un délai de huit (8) jours à partir de la proclamation des résultats provisoires.   A l’issue du scrutin, les listes d’émargement sont conservées au chef-lieu de la commune sous la responsabilité du Maire, de l’Ambassadeur ou du Consul dans les représentations diplomatiques ou consulaires du Niger à l’étranger.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Representation of the People Act (Act No. 57 of 28 June 2002 relating to parliamentary and local government elections)                                                    2-1. Right to vote at parliamentary elections (1) Entitled to vote at parliamentary elections is any Norwegian citizen who satisfies the following conditions: a) the person in question will have attained the age of 18 by the end of the year in which the election is held b) the person in question has not been disenfranchised purs

voting_methods.instructions: (1) The returning officer shall show the voter to the place where the ballot papers have been placed before the further procedure pursuant to Section 8-4 of the Election Act is decided. (2) Voters with voting rights in another constituency shall receive a cross-off ballot paper containing the names of the registered political parties. (3) If a ballot paper envelope is used in Norway, the returning officer shall sign the polling card and write down the time and place voting took place. The returning officer shall place the ballot paper envelope and polling card in a cover envelope which is then sealed. The voter shall place the cover envelope in a ballot box. (4) Voters who are not included in the relevant section of the electoral register or who have already been crossed off in the electoral register shall not place their ballot papers in the ballot box. When the ballot paper has been stamped, the voter in person places them in a ballot paper envelope and seals the envelope. The returning officer shall place the ballot paper envelope and polling card in a cover envelope which is then sealed. The voter shall place the cover envelope in a ballot box. (5) In the case of ambulatory voting, voting in patient rooms and in social security and care housing, the voter will receive a ballot paper for each group that has put up a list at the election. The ballot papers that were handed out shall be placed back in an envelope which is then sealed. The voter can retain the envelope with the remaining ballot papers or give it to the returning officer. The returning officer shall ensure that the returned ballot papers are properly destroyed. (6) If a vote is cast abroad, on Svalbard or Jan Mayen, the returning officer shall place the ballot paper envelope in a cover envelope and seal this in front of the elector. The returning officer shall then write the following information on the cover envelope: a) the name and address of the Electoral Committee, b) the elector’s name, date of birth and Norwegian identity number, c) the elector’s home address as of 30 June in the year of the election, or the elector’s last address in Norway if he or she has notified the authorities of a move abroad, and d) the time and place when voting took place. The returning officer and the voter must then sign the cover envelope. (7) The same ballot paper envelope is used for both municipal council elections and county council elections.

(1) When the election proceedings open, electors who appear in the register of electors in the municipal authority area are admitted to cast their vote in the order in which they arrive. (2) The polling committee place a cross in the register of electors by the elector’s name. An elector who is unknown to the returning officer shall provide proof of identity. (3) The elector shall in a secluded room and unobserved fold the ballot paper together in such manner that it is not possible to see for which electoral list the elector is voting. The elector hands the ballot paper to the polling committee, who stamp it with an official stamp. The elector in person drops the ballot paper into a ballot box. (4) Electors who do not appear in the relevant section of the register of electors shall not place their ballot paper in the ballot box. After the ballot paper has been stamped, the elector shall in person place it in a ballot paper envelope and give it to the polling committee. The polling committee place the ballot paper envelope in a cover envelope, seal it and write on it the elector’s name, residential address and date of birth. (5) Any electors who have such a need may themselves ask the polling committee to provide any necessary assistance in the process of voting. Electors with a serious mental or physical disability may themselves choose a helper among the persons who are present in the polling station. The polling committee shall draw the helper’s attention to the fact that he or she is under a duty of secrecy. (6) Ballot boxes used for voting on Election Day shall be sealed.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Organic Law No. 27-11 on the House of Representatives, art. 3 / Organic Law No. 70-03 on the Family law, art. 209 "The legal age of majority is 18 full solar years"

voting_methods.instructions: The voting process is as follows: Upon entering the polling station, the voter hands over his/her National ID to the polling station officer; - the officer announces aloud the full name and the voter's ordinal number; - The president of the polling station orders to verify the presence and identity of the voter on the voter list; - The voter takes one ballot paper himself from a table prepared for this purpose, The President shall make sure that this requirement is respected. The voter enters the voting both with his ballot paper in hand and places a mark, according to his choice, in the place designated for the list or for the candidate at the district level, and his vote mark in the place designated for the list or for the candidate At the national constituency level, then fold the voting paper before leaving the both. - The voter personally deposits his folded ballot paper into the ballot box; - The president places on the voter's hand a sign with an ink that cannot be quickly erased. The polling officer shall cross the name of the voter from the Voters' List before returning the National ID to the Voter. - The voter shall leave the Polling station at once.

government_functions.details: None

The President of Micronesia serves as both the chief of state and head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Congress from among four senators-at-large.   The Micronesian legislature is composed of a unicameral Congress with 14 seats. All members of Congress are directly elected. 10 members are elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 2-year terms. An additional “at large” member is elected from each of the four Micronesian states by proportional representation vote, and these members serve 4-year terms.   The Supreme Court is the highest court of the Micronesian judiciary and consists of up to six judges split into two divisions. These judges are nominated by the President and confirmed by a two-thirds vote of Congress. Judges may serve for life.

voting_methods.instructions: While mail voting is allowed for President, Senators, Governors and Chief of Government, it is not allowed for electing members of Chamber of Deputes.

Once qualification is verified, the president of the directive board of the polling station shall give him the ballot of the elections so that he can freely and in secret mark on the ballot the only square corresponding to the political party he votes for, or write down the name of the unregistered candidate he wishes to vote for.  Thereafter, the voter will fold the ballot and proceed to deposit it in the corresponding ballot box. Voting by mail is made available to citizens residing abroad. However, mail voting is only for the election of the President and Senators, as well as of the Governors of the states and of the Chief of Government of the Federal District, whenever this is established in the Constitutions of the States or the Government Statute of the Federal District. voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: 1921 Constitution, Article 29(2); 1973 Citizen's Rights Act, Article 1(1)

voting_methods.instructions: Voters abroad can receive postal voting materials upon written request no later than three weeks before election day. Postal ballots can be cast from abroad (no postage required in Liechtenstein or Switzerland). The marked ballot is placed in the secrecy voting envelope and together with the signed voting card must be sealed by the voter in the officially preprinted delivery envelope. Upon receipt of a postal ballot, the voting is noted in the voter register. Postal ballots received after the deadline are to be destroyed without opening.

Ballot papers and voting materials are automatically mailed out to all voters in the country along with their personal voting cards. Voters abroad can receive postal voting materials upon written request no later than three weeks before election day. Postal ballots can be cast from anywhere in the country or from abroad (no postage required in Liechtenstein or Switzerland) or can be handed over to the municipality personally or by a representative. The marked ballot is placed in the secrecy voting envelope and together with the signed voting card must be sealed by the voter in the officially preprinted delivery envelope. Upon receipt of a postal ballot, the voting is noted in the voter register. Postal ballots received after the deadline are to be destroyed without opening.

At the polling station, a voter must present a personal voting card, which is delivered to all voters at least two weeks before the election day and contain the voter's address, place of registration, identification number and a barcode. At the polling station, the barcode is scanned and the "voter check-in" system in place at every polling station helps identify the voter and indicates if the voter has voted already. Voters can be included on the voter list on election day by the polling commission only if "his or her ommission from the list is an obvious mistake". The members of the election committee vote first and then the voters vote in the order they arrive. After check-in, the voter places the official ballot in the secret voting envelope and enters it in the ballot box. Voting booths are set up on the polling station that allow the voter to fill out the ballot in secret. Voters with disabilites can be assisted by a person of trust. At the polling station, the voter can vote the ballot that was mailed out to them, but official ballot papers are also available in the voting booth; secrecy envelopes can be obtained from the election committee. Only those candidates on the valid candidate lists can be voted for. A voter is allowed to make deletions and amendments to his/her official ballot paper, subject to provisions on invalid ballots. The vote is to be noted in the voter register.

electoral_rights.source: 1973 Citizen's Rights Act Article 27(1)

government_functions.details: According to the Constitution, the Prince Regnant is the Head of the State and shall exercise his sovereign authority in accordance to the constitution. The Prince Regnant shall represent the State in all its relations with foreign countries, without prejudice to the necessary participation of the responsible Government. Parliament is the legal organ representing all the citizens of the Principality and as such has the duty of safeguarding and vindicating the rights and interest of the People in relation to the Government in conformity with the provisions of the  Constitution and also of promoting as far as possible the welfare of the Princely House and of the country while faithfully adhering to the principles laid down in the Constitution. Parliament shall consist of 25 Representatives who shall be elected by the People by universal, equal, secret and direct suffrage according to the system of proportional representation. The Upper Country (Oberland) and the Lower Country (Unterland) shall each form a constituency. Of the 25 Representatives, 15 shall be elected by the Upper Country and 10 by the Lower Country.In terms of the Government, the whole of the national administration shall be conducted by the Collegial Government responsible to the Prince Regnant and Parliament. The Constitution foresees that the Collegial Government shall consist of the Head of the Government and four Government Councillors. The Head of the Government and the Government Councillors shall be appointed by the Prince Regnant with the concurrence of Parliament and on the proposal of the latter. A substitute shall be appointed in like manner for the Head of theGovernment and for each Government Councillor to represent the member of the Government in question who may be prevented from attending the meetings of the Collegial Government. Lastly, the administration of justice is carried by judges appointed by the Prince Regnant.

voting_methods.instructions: Art. 195.- A las siete horas, la Presidencia de la Junta Receptora de Votos, deberá llamar a sus miembros y vigilantes para que emitan su voto, y retendrá su respectivo Documento Único de Identidad, el cual les devolverá al cierre de la votación; posteriormente anunciará en voz alta que dará comienzo la votación, permitiéndose el acceso de los ciudadanos, de uno en uno, y guardando la debida compostura, al lugar destinado al efecto.Las jefaturas de Centro de Votación y supervisores o supervisoras de los partidos políticos o coaliciones a que se refiere el artículo 125 de este Código, votarán en la misma forma indicada en el inciso anterior, pero lo harán en la primera Junta Receptora de Votos del Centro de Votación donde estuvieren acreditados cuando el Centro de Votación tenga menos de veinte Juntas Receptoras de Votos.Cuando tenga más de veinte Juntas Receptoras de Votos, los supervisores o supervisoras votarán en la segunda Junta Receptora de Votos; en todo caso, también se les retendrá su Documento Único de Identidad, devolviéndoseles al cierre de la votación.El delegado o delegada del Fiscal electoral acreditado ante la Junta Electoral Municipal respectiva, los ciudadanos miembros de la Policía Nacional Civil, los alumnos de la Academia Nacional de Seguridad Pública y miembros de la Fuerza Armada, podrán ejercer su derecho al sufragio en los Centros de Votación donde se encuentren destacados, y lo harán en la última Junta Receptora de Votos mostrando su carné policial, de la Academia Nacional de Seguridad Pública o de la Fuerza Armada, y además, su respectivo Documento Único de Identidad vigente, siendo este último retenido hasta el cierre de la votación. En el padrón de votantes de la última Junta Receptora de Votos de cada Centro de Votación, se consignará el nombre y número de Documento Único de Identidad del delegado o delegada Fiscal, de los ciudadanos miembros de la Policía Nacional Civil, de la Academia Nacional de Seguridad Pública y de la Fuerza Armada que voten de la manera que este artículo establece.Los ciudadanos a que se refieren los incisos anteriores podrán votar en elecciones Presidenciales y de Diputaciones al Parlamento Centroamericano, independientemente del domicilio que aparezca en su Documento Único de Identidad; para elecciones Legislativas si su domicilio corresponde a la circunscripción Departamental y, para      CÓDIGO ELECTORAL183Concejos Municipales si su domicilio corresponde a la circunscripción Municipal en que desempeña sus funciones, todo lo anterior de conformidad a los principios Constitucionales de soberanía popular, democracia y representación política.Quienes hagan uso de la prerrogativa establecida en el presente artículo, solo podrán votar en la forma indicada, cuando lo hagan inmediatamente después de instalada la Junta Receptora de Votos y antes de que comience la votación de ciudadanos; una vez iniciada esta, deberán votar en la urna que les corresponda de acuerdo a los padrones electorales (10) Procedimiento de la votación Art. 196.- La Junta Receptora de Votos deberá exigir a todo ciudadano y ciudadana que se presente a votar, se identifique ante dicha Junta y ante los representantes de los partidos políticos o coaliciones contendientes que lo exijan, mediante su respectivo Documento Único de Identidad vigente. El Presidente o Presidenta de la Junta deberá constatar que el ciudadano o ciudadana aparezca en el padrón electoral de búsqueda y que no posea marcas que evidencien que haya votado; verificado esto, se sellará el nombre del votante en dicho padrón, sin que tal sello abarque otro u otros números y nombres. Cumplidos los anteriores requisitos, el secretario o secretaria deberá firmar y sellar la papeleta de votación. Efectuado esto, mostrará el reverso a los demás miembros de la Junta, a los vigilantes de los partidos políticos o coaliciones y al ciudadano o ciudadana a quien le será entregada, con el fin de verificar que ha sido debidamente firmada y sellada; luego procederá a retirar la esquina desprendible y entregar la papeleta al ciudadano o ciudadana, de todo lo cual deberán cerciorarse los demás miembros y vigilantes que asistan. Mientras no se cumplan con las formalidades establecidas en este inciso, no será procedente el ejercicio del voto. La Junta velará que el ciudadano y ciudadana emita el voto de forma secreta en el lugar designado para tal efecto.

The National Assembly shall be comprised of Fifteen (15) Assembly persons elected as representatives of the nation as a whole (national district). Two (2) Assembly persons elected for each province, plus one (1) additional Assembly person for every two hundred thousand (200,000) inhabitants or fraction thereof over one hundred fifty thousand (150,000), on the basis of the last national population census.  The jurisdictional bodies, without detriment to the other bodies with equal powers recognized in the Constitution, are those in charge of administering justice and they shall be as follows: The National Court of Justice. The provincial courts of justice. The courts and tribunals provided for by law. The justices of the peace.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: To be elected, a presidential candidate must receive the votes of an absolute majority of those who take part in the elections, within a single nationwide constituency. If no candidate receives that majority, a rerun is carried out within two weeks between the two candidates who receive the largest number of votes. The candidate who receives the most votes in the rerun is elected. Presidential canddiates must have the support of at least 35 members of parliament.

voting_methods.instructions: The voter exercises his/her right to vote in presidential elections at any polling station in the country.  Citizens can vote upon presentation of an identification card. In practice, there is no voter list at the polling station against which to authenticate the voter. The head of the polling station committee hands the voter an envelope signed by him/her and stamped with the committe's seal. The voter proceeds to a polling booth that ensures secrecy to mark the ballot. The voter puts the completed ballot paper in the sealed envelope - a ballot paper can be printed or written, prepared in advance or written in the polling booth, indicating the candidate of choice. Blind voters and voters with other disabilities can request a trusted person to write a ballot paper for them or can verbally tell a poll worker how they wish to vote and to have the poll worker complete the ballot paper. In both cases, the fact of the assistance must be recorded by the head of the polling committee. In front of the members of the polling station committee, agents and observers, the voter puts the sealed envelope in the ballot box. The voter's name is then recorded in the electoral record of the polling station.

government_functions.details: Iran has a unique system of government known as an Islamic Republic, a combination of democratic and theocratic elements, as outlined in its Constitution established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. The political structure is characterized by a dual sovereignty: the Supreme Leader, who holds the highest state authority, and the elected President, along with the Parliament. It blends aspects of a parliamentary democracy with Islamic theocracy, guided by the principles of Shia Islam.  The executive branch is headed by the President, who is elected for a four-year term and can serve a maximum of two consecutive terms. The President is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the country, including the implementation of laws, overseeing the economy, and conducting foreign policy. However, the President's powers are subject to the oversight and approval of the Supreme Leader, who is the highest-ranking religious and political authority in Iran. The Supreme Leader, appointed for life by the Assembly of Experts, holds significant influence over all branches of government, including the military and judiciary, and has the final say in matters of state and religion.  The legislative branch consists of the Islamic Consultative Assembly, or Majlis, a unicameral body whose members are elected by the public. The Majlis drafts legislation, ratifies international treaties, and approves the national budget. However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

voting_methods.instructions: An elector must not vote at more than one polling station. An elector may vote for 1 candidate only. If the elector votes for more than 1 candidate the ballot paper is void and none of the votes will be counted. If an elector attempts to give an answer more than 1 vote, only 1 vote will be awarded. An elector votes for a candidate by placing an X to the right of the candidate’s name, thus If an elector marks the ballot paper in any way that will identify the elector the ballot paper will be rejected. After voting, an elector must fold the ballot paper along the line shown on the ballot paper and hand the folded ballot paper to the Presiding Officer. The Presiding Officer will, in the full view of those present including the elector, remove the counterfoil from the ballot paper and return the ballot paper to the elector who will deposit the ballot paper in the ballot box; except where the elector is unable from physical or other disability to deposit the ballot paper in the ballot box, the presiding officer will, on the elector’s behalf, deposit the ballot paper in the ballot box. If an elector inadvertently spoils a ballot paper that person can obtain another one by returning the spoilt one to the Presiding Officer. A person given a ballot paper must not take it from the polling station. After voting an elector must leave the polling station.

government_functions.details: In Uzbekistan, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister serves as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 7-year terms. The Prime Minister is nominated by the majority party in the Supreme Assembly and appointed by the President.   Uzbekistan has a bicameral Supreme Assembly consisting of a 100-seat Senate and a 150-seat Legislative Chamber. Members of the Senate are indirectly elected by regional councils (84 members) or appointed by the president (16 members). All members serve 5-year terms. All 150 members of the Legislative Chamber are directly elected by absolute majority vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  The Supreme Court and Constitutional Court are the highest judicial bodies of Uzbekistan. The Supreme Court has 67 judges, while the Constitutional Court has only 7. Judges for both institutions are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Judges may serve one term of 10 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Voting is compulsory but there is no sanction for not voting.  Voters vote in person at their designated polling station (though candidates, higher level election officials, and observers can apply for a certificate to vote at any polling station within the respective constitutency). Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. On arrival at the polling station, voters show their identity card, or in certain cases, their internal passport. The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. Any discrepancy in the name shown in the identification document and the voter register, if the permanent address matches, is recorded in the voter register.  If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. The law provides for the use of both paper ballot voting and direct recording electronic voting machines, at the voter's option. In past elections, such machines were used on  a limited basis as it was not mandatory and due to limited resources and technical expertise, but a 2020 amendment to the election law now mandates that voters have the option of either paper or machine-based voting. If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting booth and in private marks the square of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter folds the ballot to keep the vote secret, exits the booth and hands the folded ballot to the poll worker who checks whether the number on the ballot matches the number on the book of ballots and if so, restamps the ballot with the seal of the commission and detaches the counterfoil and deposits it in a separate box. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site.  If the voter has spoiled the ballot, he/she can return it folded to the poll worker and a replacement ballot will be issued (only once.) In machine voting, the voter is given access to the voting device and votes by means of a magnetic card, with the device displaying a ballot identical to the paper ballot, as well as an option to vote 'against all'. After voting for the candidate list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and a control receipt is printed which is to be deposited in a special machine voting box.The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The fact that the voter voted by machine is noted in the voter register. If the machine voting becomes inoperable, voting proceeds by paper ballots. Mobile (homebound) voting is available for voters with permanent disabililities, based on an advance request before polling day.  The mobile voting is carried out by not less than four poll workers on election day.

electoral_rights.source: 2014 Election Code Article 10; 1991 Constitution, Article 42; 2014 Election Code Article 243

government_functions.details: The President of Bulgaria serves as the chief of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

The poll worker checks the voter's particulars against the voter register and enters the identity number and type of document shown into the voter register and admits the voter to voting. If the voter is not found on the voter register he/she can be added to a supplemental list, with proof of residence in the district, and is allowed to vote upon submitting a declaration (to be attached to the voter register) that he/she has not voted and will not vote elsewhere. The law provides for the use of both paper ballot voting and direct recording electronic voting machines, at the voter's option. In past elections, such machines were used on  a limited basis as it was not mandatory and due to limited resources and technical expertise, but a 2020 amendment to the election law now mandates that voters have the option of either paper or machine-based voting. If paper voting, the voter is given a  ballot that is stamped by the poll worker with the commission's seal. The voter proceeds to the voting booth and in private marks the square of the candidate list of his/her choice and if so wishes, also marks the circle of the candidate of his/her choice. The voter then deposits the ballot in the ballot box, signs the voter register, and his/her identification document is given back and he/she leaves the polling site. After voting for the candidate list and if he/she chooses, also for a candidate on the list, he/she can change the choice once before confirming to vote. The voter receives a message that the voting is completed and a control receipt is printed which is to be deposited in a special machine voting box.The voter then returns the magnetic card, signs the voter register, and is given back his/her identification document and leaves the polling site. The President is directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is indirectly elected by the National Assembly.  Bulgaria has a unicameral National Assembly (Народно събрание / Narodno Sabranie) with 240 seats. Members of the National Assembly are directly elected by proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties and coalitions must earn at least 4% of the overall vote to receive a seat.   The high courts of Bulgaria consist of the Supreme Court of Cassation (penal, civil, and commercial legal matters), the Supreme Administrative Court (national government matters), and the Constitutional Court. Cassation and administrative judges are elected by the Supreme Judicial Council (SJC) and confirmed by the President. These judges can serve until age 65. The Constitutional Court is independent of the judiciary branch, and its 12 justices are elected by the National Assembly and confirmed by the President and SJC. Constitutional Court justices serve 9-year terms, and one-third of justices are replaced every 3 years.

voting_methods.instructions: Article 80: Tout électeur dont le nom figure sur la liste électorale d’un centre de vote, a l'obligation de prendre part au vote dans le poste auquel il a été rattaché.Toutefois, sous réserve du contrôle de leur carte d'électeur et de leur titre de mission, sont admis à voter en dehors de leur lieu d'inscription, les agents des forces de sécurité et de défense, les journalistes et toutes autres personnes en déplacement pour raison de service.Sont également admis à voter en dehors de leur lieu d'inscription, les candidats à l'élection concernée, les membres de la Commission électorale nationale autonome (CENA), lescoordonnateurs d'arrondissementainsi que les délégués des candidats ou de liste de candidats dûment mandatés.Les béninois rapatriés pour cas de force majeure sont admis à voter par dérogation dans les mêmes conditions que les personnes suscitées.Les nom, prénoms, date et lieu de naissance ainsi que le numéro d’inscription sur la liste électorale, l’indication du lieu et du poste de vote où sont régulièrement inscrites ces personnes doivent être mentionnés sur la liste électorale et au procès-verbal du poste où elles ont voté afin que, lors du décompte des électeurs, ils soient retranchés de la liste électorale de leur circonscription.Article 81: Nul ne peut être admis à voter dans un poste de vote si son nom ne figure sur la liste électorale de ce poste de vote.  Article 84: A son entrée dans la salle du scrutin, l'électeur présente sa carte d’électeur et fait constater son inscription sur la liste électorale. Puis il prend lui-même un bulletin, se rend dans l'isoloir, marque son choix et plie le bulletin de manière à cacher son vote. Il fait ensuite constater qu'il n'est porteur que d'un seul pli; le président le constate sans toucher le pli que l'électeur introduit lui-même dans l'urne.En cas de couplage d’élections, l’électeur après unpremier vote, prend le bulletin prévu pour le second vote, se dirige vers l’isoloir prévu pour la seconde élection, marque son choix et plie le bulletin de manière à cacher son vote. Il fait ensuite constater qu’il n’est porteur que d’un seul pli; le président le constate sans toucher le pli que l’électeur introduit lui-même dans l’urne.Article 85: Chaque poste de vote est doté d'un ou de plusieurs isoloirs. Les isoloirs doivent assurer le secret du vote de chaque électeur. Ils doivent être placés de telle manière que le citoyen puisse cacher son vote.Article 86: L'urne est transparente et présente en outre, des garanties de sécurité et d'inviolabilité.Elle est pourvue d'une seule ouverture destinée à laisser passer le bulletin de vote plié. Elle doit, avant le commencement du scrutin, avoir été vidée, fermée et scellée au vu et au su des membres du poste de vote et des électeurs présents.Une deuxième urne est prévue en cas de couplage d’élections.Article 87: Tout électeur atteint d'infirmité ou d'incapacité physique certaine, le mettant dans l'impossibilité de plier et de glisser son bulletin dans l'urne, est autorisé à se faire assister d'une personne de son choix.Article 88: Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par l'apposition de l'empreintede son pouce gauche à l'encre indélébile en face de son nom en présence des membres du poste de vote.  http://coslepi.info/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/MIEUX-COMPRENDRE-LE-CODE-ELECTORAL-DU-BENIN-2018.pdf

government_functions.details: The President of Benin serves as chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve up to two 5-year terms.  Benin has a unicameral National Assembly with 109 members. All members are directly elected by list proportional representation vote within multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Benin has several high courts with different legal domains. The Supreme Court has 17 judges who are appointed by the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The Constitutional Court has 7 judges who are appointed by either the National Assembly or the President and serve up to two 5-year terms. The High Court of Justice forms only to try high treason cases involving national government officials. It is formed from 6 judges of the Constitutional Court who are selected by the National Assembly and Supreme Court president.

government_functions.details: The President of Argentina serves as both chief of state and head of government. The President is directly elected by qualified plurality vote in up to two rounds. To be elected, a candidate must receive either 45% of the overall vote or 40% of the vote and a 10-point lead over the closest opponent. The President may serve up to two 4-year terms.  Argentina has a bicameral National Congress with a 72-seat Senate and a 257-seat Chamber of Deputies. In the Senate, all 72 members are directly elected from multi-seat constituencies. Each constituency (province) awards 2 seats to the party highest-polling party and 1 seat to the second-place party. All members serve 6-year terms, and one-third of seats are up for election every 2 years. In the Chamber of Deputies, all 257 members are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote from multi-seat constituencies. Members serve 4-year terms, and half the seats are up for election every 2 years.   The Supreme Court is the highest court in the Argentinian judiciary. It is composed of four judges who are nominated by the President and approved by a two-thirds vote of the Senate. Judges may serve until age 75.

The President of the Republic of Moldova is the head of state. The executive branch of the Republic of Moldova is headed by the President, who is elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote. The government, led by the Prime Minister, is nominated by the President after consulting parliamentary factions, and it requires a vote of confidence from the Parliament.
The legislative branch consists of the Parliament, and it is composed of 101 deputies elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote for a four-year term.
The judicial branch of Moldova is composed of the Supreme Court of Justice, courts of appeal, and other courts as established by law. Judges are appointed by the President of the Republic, based on the proposal of the Superior Council of Magistracy, until they reach the age limit

basic_data.electoral_system_other: One-third of the seats will be elected via a single member constituency system, another third will be elected through a closed party list system, and the last third will be directly appointed by the president.

government_functions.details: Egypt's government is divided into three branches: the executive, the legislative, and the judicial. The executive branch is headed by the president, who is the head of state and the supreme commander of the armed forces. The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term and can be re-elected once. The president appoints the prime minister, who forms the government and chairs the cabinet of ministers. The cabinet is responsible for carrying out the day-to-day business of government.   The legislative branch  is a unicameral body called the House of Representatives. It is composed of is composed of no less than four hundred and fifty members elected by direct secret public ballot. At least one quarter of the seats shall be allocated to women. The President of the Republic may appoint a number of members that does not exceed 5%. The primary functions of the House of Representatives include the drafting and approval of legislation, oversight of the executive branch, and the ratification of international treaties and agreements. The House also has the power to grant a vote of confidence to the Prime Minister and the Cabinet, and it plays a key role in fiscal matters, including the approval of the state budget and economic policies.  The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislative branches. It is headed by the Supreme Constitutional Court, which has exclusive authority to decide on the constitutionality of laws and regulations, interpret legislative texts, and adjudicate in disputes pertaining to the affairs of its members, in disputes between judicial bodies and entities that have judicial mandate, in disputes pertaining to the implementation of two final contradictory rulings, one of which is issued by any judicial body or an agency with judicial mandate and the other issued by another body, and in disputes pertaining to the implementation of its rulings and decisions.  However, each judicial body or organization manages ts own affairs and have to be consulted concerning the draft laws regulating its affairs. Each of them has andependent budget. The President  appoints  the heads of the judicial bodies or organizations.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

Le fichier biométrique des électeurs du Tchad date de 2015 et a servi lors de l’élection présidentielle d’avril 2016. Il comptait 6.298.801 électeurs dont 3.284.569 (52,15%) femmes et 3.014.232 (47,85%) hommes. La mise à jour du fichier, effectuée du 1er au 30 octobre 2020, a produit 1.283.405 nouveaux enregistrements en données centralisées brutes. Une recherche biométrique de doublons via le système ABIS a identifié environs 20% de ces nouveaux enregistrements comme étant potentiellement doubles ou multiples. Ceci se doit  principalement au fait que les électeurs pouvaient demander à s'inscrire sans que les agents puissent identifier ceux qui étaient déjà dans la base de données de 2015. La déduplication manuelle, comportant l’analyse des cas possibles de doublon et l’adjudication par la CENI, a permis de supprimer 193.858 doublons. Sous réserve de publication de statistiques officielles, les nouveaux enregistrements représentent finalement 1.089.547, soit 54,47% de la cible de 2.000.000 d’électeurs. Le fichier révisé des électeurs du Tchad comporte 7.388.348 électeurs. Il est prévu que tous les anciens et nouveaux électeurs reçoivent une nouvelle carte.

voting_methods.instructions: Code électoral de 2019:   Article 43  Le vote des nomades a lieu sur deux (2) jours. Le premier jour est celui qui précède le jour du scrutin national dans les conditions fixées à l'alinéa 1 du présent article.   Les tchadiens de l'Étranger votent sur deux (2) jours selon les conditions déterminées par la CENI, qui doivent tenir compte du contexte, de l'environnement et des réalités objectives des représentations diplomatiques et consulaires du Tchad.      Les membres des Forces de défense et de sécurité sont consignés dans leurs casernes le jour du scrutin. Ils votent un jour avant les autres citoyens et en dehors des casernes dans des bureaux définis à l'article 38, et supervisés par la CENI.

Code électoral de 2019:   Article 43 : Le scrutin ne dure qu’un seul jour sur l’étendue du territoire national. Il est ouvert à six (06) heures et clos le même jour à dix-sept (17) heures.      Article 48 : L'électeur, après avoir fait constater et confirmer son identité par la présentation de sa carte biométrique, prend le bulletin unique de vote, se rend à l'isoloir, coche le candidat ou la liste de son choix ou appose son empreinte digitale devant le candidat ou la liste de son choix, plie le bulletin, sort de l'isoloir et introduit le bulletin dans l'urne placée devant le Président du bureau de vote.   En cas d’élections couplées, l’électeur fait les mêmes gestes prévus à l’alinéa précédent mais en ramassant à la fois autant de bulletins qu’il y a d’élections.   Article 49 : Le vote de chaque électeur est constaté par l'apposition de sa signature sur la liste d'émargement. S'il ne peut signer, il y appose son empreinte digitale.   Tout électeur doit, après avoir introduit le bulletin dans l'urne, tremper son doigt dans l'encre indélébile avant de quitter le bureau de vote.   Article 50 : Tout électeur, atteint d'infirmité le mettant dans l'incapacité de voter, est autorisé à se faire assister par un électeur de son choix inscrit sur la même liste électorale que lui.   Article 51 : Les membres du bureau de vote régulièrement inscrits sur la liste électorale sont autorisés à voter dans les bureaux où ils siègent sur simple présentation de leur carte d'électeur.

government_functions.details: The new constitution submitted to referendum largely reproduces the text of the 1996 Constitution. Unlike the 2018 Constitution, the latter benefits from a better image, being the fruit of numerous consultations that led to a consensus during the Sovereign National Conference organised in 1993.  The text of this new fundamental law - the eleventh since the country's independence in 1960 - marks a return to a semi-presidential system, replacing the presidential system of 2018 by confirming the restoration of the post of Prime Minister as head of government accountable to the National Assembly, distinct from the role of Head of State of the President of the Republic. The President's term of office will be reduced from six to five years, always renewable once consecutively. The minimum age for presidential candidates is lowered from 40 to 35. The draft constitution also ratifies the existence of the Senate, which was theoretically created by the 2018 constitution but has never yet been set up, as well as the division of the country into 23 regions, or provinces.  The text is also notable for its objective of restoring a number of rights, concepts and democratic institutions that had been removed from the 1996 text by a succession of constitutional revisions under the presidency of Idriss Déby. Independence of the judiciary has been consolidated by assigning the chairmanship of the High Council of the Judiciary not to the President of the Republic but to the President of the Supreme Court, who was previously second vice-president. The High Court of Justice, placed under the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in 2018, has also regained its independence as an institution, and the sole power to try for high treason the President of the Republic, those of other institutions, as well as members of the government and their possible accomplices.The same applies to the Constitutional Council, which regains its independence from the Supreme Court and exercises sole control over the constitutionality of laws, organic laws, decrees and international treaties.Its review is carried out automatically before they are promulgated, but also a posteriori on the basis of a dispute referred to the Council by an ordinary court.The Council also judges electoral disputes and administers the oath of office to the newly elected President of the Republic.  In terms of military justice, a Court of Appeal was created, in addition to the military courts and the Supreme Court.

The voter goes to the polling station identified in their personal electoral card along with a suitable identification card and hands the card and identification to the polling officials.  The polling officials verify their identity and location on the electoral rolls.  The officials provide the voter with a pencil and two ballot papers, one for the Senate and one for the Chamber of Deputies, and direct the voter to a booth to vote in secret.  The voter marks their paper.  They must use a pencil to mark their papers.  In either contest, they can vote by marking either a candidate contesting the single constituency or the closed list linked to it or both.  A single mark on the candidate will also operate as a vote for the linked closed list and vice versa.  Voters cannot split their vote between a candidate linked to one list or coalition and a different list or coalition.   After voting they hand their ballots and the pencil to the polling officials who, while protecting the secrecy of the vote, undertake a check to confirm the ballots were those that the voter was issued.  The officials return the voter their election card and identification.

voting_methods.instructions: In general, the voter must show the unsigned postal vote certificate (declaration)  and unmarked ballot paper to an authorized witness, must complete and sign the certificate in the presence of the witness, the witness must c, sign and date the certificate and note on it their capacity to act.  Then the voter must mark their paper in the presence of the witness but so as the witness cannot see the vote, fold the paper, seal it in the envelope.  The voter and the witness must both declare on the certificate (which forms part of the envelope) that these steps were completed before the close of the poll.  the person must then post or deliver the envelope to the Divisional Returning Officer for which they are enrolled.  There are some exceptions to some of these requirements for persons registered as a general postal voter or for persons voting from outside Australia.

You can vote at an early voting center, or if you're overseas, at an overseas voting center.  Where a voter is voting at an early voting center within their district and is on the certified roll they may vote in the same way they do on polling day (that is, they are marked off the roll, they are issued with ballot papers which they mark in a booth and place in the appropriate ballot box.  If not, they must first complete a declaration in front of the issuing officer, mark their voting paper in the presence of the issuing officer without letting the officer see the vote, fold the ballot paper and give it to the issuing officer who puts it into the envelope containing the declaration.  The issuing officer fastens the envelope and secures it in a ballot box.  You can vote early either in person or by post if on election day you: •    are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote •    are more than 8km from a polling place •    are travelling •    are unable to leave your workplace to vote •    are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or caring for someone who is) •    are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital •    have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place •    are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained •    are a silent elector •    have a reasonable fear for your safety.  While this is technically true, it in practice is not enforced.

The Senate ballot paper is divided into two parts.  'Above the line' the party or groups contesting the election are listed.  'Below the line' all the candidates contesting the election are listed  (including those who have been nominated by the parties and groups listed above the line).  A voter may choose to vote above or below the line.  If voting above the line, the voter is accepting the order of candidates as determined by the parties or groups.  The voter indicates their preferences by writing the number 1 against the first preference and must mark at least 6 preferences (or if there are fewer than six parties or groups, all of them). If the voter chooses to vote below the line, they must mark their preferences by writing the numbers 1 up to, at least, 12 (unless there are fewer than 12 candidates).  For Senate, Above The Line papers with a single '1'  and Below The Line papers with a sequence of at least 1 through 6 (or in either case any number of additional preferences above those minimums) are considered formal for the purposes of counting.

government_functions.details:
Australia is a parliamentary democracy that is a part of the British Commonwealth. As such, the chief of state is the British Monarch. The monarchy is hereditary. The monarch appoints an in-country representative called a governor on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party or majority coalition in government. 

Australian parliament is bicameral, with a 76-seat Senate and a 151-seat House of Representatives. Both houses are directly elected. The Senate is comprised of six senators for each original state (per the Constitution), with a provision that additional seats can be apportioned should new state be recognized. Senators serve six-year terms. The House of Representatives is intende to comprise twice the number of Senators. Seats in the House are apportioned by population.

The highest court in Australia is the High Court of Australia. Additionally, there are a variety of state and territory courts.

voting_methods.instructions:
Registered voters wishing to exercise their right to vote abroad have to submit an online application through a dedicated government portal.  If accepted, the voter is placed on the foreign voters list for a period of eight years. Overseas voters will have the right to elect only candidates who are on the parties' nationwide candidate lists and not the parliamentarians that represent a particular regional constituency.  Overseas voting will takeplace in person at polling stations which will be set up in embassies, consulates and suitable venues of Greek disaspora organizations. For an out-of-country polling station to be constituted, a minimum of 40 registered voters is required. On the day appointed for voting, voters come to the polling station of the relevant electoral division and present themselves to the electoral commitee, which determines their identity based on their Greeck police ID or Greek passport, and verifies their registration in the foreign voter list. To each voter, the electoral committee delivers an envelope initialed by the representative of the judicial authority and sealed with a stamp of the committee, a complete set of ballot forms and a blank ballot. Then the voter proceeds to the special separate area, in such a way that he/she cannot be seen, and there the voter secretly inserts the ballot paper of his choosing in the envelope given to him/her by the election committee. After securely sealing the envelope, the voter returns to the election committee and shows the envelope to the members and other attendees, to show that he/she is holding only one envelope, and then inserts the envelope into the ballot box. The election committee draws up minutes during the voting for every matter related to its conduct.

The 2023 elections will be the first time that certain out-of-country Greek citizens will be able to vote abroad.  According to legislation adopted in December 2019, after the 2019 parliamentary elections,  registered voters who are temporarily or permanently abroad must fulfil two main requirements in order to vote abroad. They must have had a two-year stay in Greece in the last 35 years and for those over 30 years old they  must have filed  a tax return in Greece in the year of the election or the preceding year.

Voters must vote in person in the electoral constituency where they are registered. Citizens residing outside their constituency can apply to vote at specially designated absentee polling stations in the  municipalities of their temporary residence. Voters go to the polling station and present themselves to the returning board which will examine their identification and verify whether they are registered in the electoral rolls. Voters will enter the polling station one by one or in groups of small numbers in the order they arrive or in the manner laid down by each returning board. In order to be identified when proceeding to exercise their right to vote, voters have to present their ID card or their passport. The returning board provides each voter with a specially marked envelope initialled by the court representative and stamped by the board as well as a full set of ballot papers for all party-lists and independent candidates. The voter is to proceed to the polling booth and must vote in secret, in such a way that he/she cannot be seen. The voter must place the chosen and marked ballot papers within the specially marked envelope and seal it, then proceed to show the sealed and stamped envelope to the chairperson of the returning board and others present, and then the voter places the envelope in the ballot box. Voters physically incapable of performing such tasks can request the court representative or a member of the returning board for obligatory assistance.  For the constituency voting, voters may select the candidate or candidates of their choice by marking the candidate's name on the party ballot.  Upon request, voters will be provided with a certificate signed by the chairperson of the returning board and bearing its stamp that he/she voted. The returning board keeps a protocol in which the electors who vote are written.

government_functions.details: In Greece, the President serves as chief of state, while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is indirectly elected by Parliament and may serve up to two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister, customarily the leader of the parliamentary majority party, is appointed by the President.   Greece has a unicameral Hellenic Parliament with 300 seats. 285 members are elected in multi-seat constituencies, while the remaining 15 are elected from a single, nationwide constituency. All members are directly elected via open party-list proportional representation vote and serve 4-year terms.  There are three high courts: the Supreme Civil and Criminal Court, the Council of State (for cases involving the national government), and the Court of Audit. The 56 judges of the Supreme Court and the president of the Court of Audit are nominated by an expert panel called the Supreme Judicial Council and appointed by the President. The president of the Council of State is appointed by the executive cabinet. All other Council of State and Court of Audit judges are hired via a competitive process.

voting_methods.instructions: In general, the voter must show the unsigned postal vote certificate (declaration)  and unmarked ballot paper to an authorized witness, must complete and sign the certificate in the presence of the witness, the witness must c, sign and date the certificate and note on it their capacity to act.  Then the voter must mark their paper in the presence of the witness but so as the witness cannot see the vote, fold the paper, seal it in the envelope.  The voter and the witness must both declare on the certificate (which forms part of the envelope) that these steps were completed before the close of the poll.  the person must then post or deliver the envelope to the Divisional Returning Officer for which they are enrolled.  There are some exceptions to some of these requirements for persons registered as a general postal voter or for persons voting from outside Australia.  You can vote early either in person or by post if on election day you: •    are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote •    are more than 8km from a polling place •    are travelling •    are unable to leave your workplace to vote •    are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or caring for someone who is) •    are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital •    have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place •    are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained •    are a silent elector •    have a reasonable fear for your safety.  While this is technically true, it in practice is not enforced.

You can vote at an early voting center, or if you're overseas, at an overseas voting center.  Where a voter is voting at an early voting center within their district and is on the certified roll they may vote in the same way they do on polling day (that is, they are marked off the roll, they are issued with ballot papers which they mark in a booth and place in the appropriate ballot box.  If not, they must first complete a declaration in front of the issuing officer, mark their voting paper in the presence of the issuing officer without letting the officer see the vote, fold the ballot paper and give it to the issuing officer who puts it into the envelope containing the declaration.  The issuing officer fastens the envelope and secures it in a ballot box.  You can vote early either in person or by post if on election day you: •    are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote •    are more than 8km from a polling place •    are travelling •    are unable to leave your workplace to vote •    are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or caring for someone who is) •    are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital •    have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place •    are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained •    are a silent elector •    have a reasonable fear for your safety.  While this is technically true, it in practice is not enforced.

For the House, the voter must write the number 1 in the square next to their first preference candidate and thereafter must write the numbers 2.3.4 and so on in the squares next to all remaining candidates without the repetition of any number.    If the final preference is left blank (e.g. with six candidates, five preferences are given AND the final box is left blank) the blank box is taken to be a valid last preference.

government_functions.details:
Australia is a parliamentary democracy that is a part of the British Commonwealth. As such, the chief of state is the British Monarch. The monarchy is hereditary. The monarch appoints an in-country representative called a governor on the recommendation of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is the leader of the majority party or majority coalition in government. 

Australian parliament is bicameral, with a 76-seat Senate and a 151-seat House of Representatives. Both houses are directly elected. The Senate is comprised of six senators for each original state (per the Constitution), with a provision that additional seats can be apportioned should new state be recognized. Senators serve six-year terms. The House of Representatives is intende to comprise twice the number of Senators. Seats in the House are apportioned by population.

The highest court in Australia is the High Court of Australia. Additionally, there are a variety of state and territory courts.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The presidential candidate who receives an absolute majority of votes is elected in the first round if at least one-third of all registered voters cast their votes; if no candidate receives a majority, a second round is held between the top two candidates within two weeks; the candidate with the most votes is elected regardless of the voter turnout in the second round.

voting_methods.instructions: The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is prohibited. Voters who are on the voter list and who are resident and domiciled in the polling station district are given ballot papers upon presentation of any of the listed identification documents.  Voters domiciled in the polling station district who are not on the list can register on election day, as can persons who do not have a registered domicile or residence. Voters who come with an (absentee) voting certificate can vote in any polling station.  Voters confirm receipt of the ballot by signing the voters lists next to their name. A stamp is affixed on their ID slip or on the document based on which they vote to confirm they have voted. The voter must mark the ballot in a secret voting booth/room only. Voters who are unable to fill in the ballot him/herself can be assisted by someone they invite in the booth (except poll members, partisan agents, and election observers.) The ballots are marked with a "voted" stamp in the chosen circle. Voters can get one replacement ballot if they have spoilt their ballot. The voter is to insert the ballot in the ballot box. On written request, home (mobile) voting is available for voters who cannot come to the polling station due to health or other grounded reason.

electoral_rights.source: 2012 Law on Equality Article 1, 1997 Electoral Code Articles 11 and 13.

government_functions.details:
The President of the Republic of Moldova is the head of state. The executive branch of the Republic of Moldova is headed by the President, who is elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote. The government, led by the Prime Minister, is nominated by the President after consulting parliamentary factions, and it requires a vote of confidence from the Parliament.
The legislative branch consists of the Parliament, and it is composed of 101 deputies elected by universal, equal, direct, secret, and freely expressed vote for a four-year term.
The judicial branch of Moldova is composed of the Supreme Court of Justice, courts of appeal, and other courts as established by law. Judges are appointed by the President of the Republic, based on the proposal of the Superior Council of Magistracy, until they reach the age limit

voting_methods.instructions: The law provides that voters who wish to early vote are to apply to the returning officer (on his or her own capacity or as a proxy on behalf of an elector) and if the returning officer is satisfied the applicant is entitled to vote at the election and has no reason to doubt the applicant's identity then the advance ballot is issued to an address provided in the British Isles (the returning officer can take such steps as he or she deems necessary to ensure an application is from the person purporting to be that elector). Persons on the island are to advance vote in-person and that off-island are to advance vote-by-mail.  Deadlines for filing the application for an advance ballot and for issuance of advance ballots are provided in the regulations, as noted above.  Prior to voting an advanced ballot, a certifying officer is to certify the declaration of identity of the advanced voter on the specified form (both on and off the Island) by viewing satisfactory evidence of identity (list provided) and the voter must sign the declaration (if unable to sign, certifying officer must note this on the declaration). On-island voters must vote in-person at a location specified by the returning officer or can vote where they reside if an acceptable reason for doing so is provided (returning officer must then make the necessary arrangements for a voter to vote at home). The advance voter must vote secretly by marking the advance ballot (which is stamped with an official mark different than the office mark used on polling day) in the presence but not in the sight of the certifying officer and insert voted ballot in a ballot paper envelope (included in the package), and insert the ballot envelope into a larger covering envelope together with the declaration of identity.  The certifying officer must mark the ballot as directed of any voter who cannot personally do so and who requests such assistance.  The number of elector in the register must be marked on the counterfoil attached to the ballot paper and a mark must be placed on the list of advance voters against the number of the elector, and the number of an advance voter ballot paper must be marked on the declaration of identity issued with that paper. The certifying officer must forward all advance votes on-Island to the returning officer and presiding officers who receive advance votes on polling day are to forward those to returning officer at end of polls or returning officers can collect them.  Advance voters off-Island must use the pre-addressed covering envelope to mail in their ballot.  The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed.  A voter can receive a replacement for a spoilt ballot paper or spoilt declaration of identity by returning the spoilt document and all other documents in the package to the returning officer (by 5:00 pm on the 39th day after the election writ is issued, if the spoilt document is returned received by mail.) Spoilt documents are to be endorsed as such and separately packaged and sealed. Advance voters are also entitled, by request, to a replacement package if the original package is not received by the 35th day after the election write is issued, but only if returning officer is satisfied with voter's identity, has no doubt as to the non-receipt of original advanced ballot sent, and is satisfied that the advance ballot can be returned by 8:00 pm on polling day.

Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is allowed. Presiding officer must regulate the number of voters admitted to polling station at same time; presiding officer may (and if required by a polling agent, must) put to any person applying for ballot paper (as voter or proxy) certain questions concerning identity and registration (as elector or proxy), whether voted already (as elector or proxy), and eligibilty as proxy; polling agents can allege reasonable cause to believe applicant is impersonating voter and undertake to substantiate charge in court; presiding officer can order police arrest of applicant (but not prevent him/her to vote);  voter given ballot paper with official mark; before given ballot, number and name of elector in register is called out, number of elector is marked on counterfoil of ballot, and a mark placed on the voter register against the number of the voter to indicate ballot delivered; voter must immediately go alone into voting booth and mark ballot in secet and fold paper to conceal vote; voter must return immediately to presiding officer's table and show official mark on back of folded ballot paper and put the ballot in the ballot box in presence of presiding officer; voter must then immediately leave polling station; voter must not show anyone the marked ballot; if voter inadvertently spoils ballot, a new ballot can be received; if another person has voted as the elector or his/her proxy (impersonation), the applicant can vote a tendered ballot (different colour) upon satisfactorily answering the questions permitted by law; tendered ballots are endorsed by presiding officer with the name and number of elector and packed separately and elector's name and nubmer entered on list of tendered votes; a proxy voter can vote on presenting the presiding officer with the appointment document issued by the Electoral Registration Officer, and provide satisfactory evidence of identity, as per regulations, if requested by presiding officer; once a proxy receives the ballot, presiding officer must delete him/her from the list of proxies; if voter declares he/she is unable to vote according to the regulations due to blindness or other physical incapacity, or unable to read, the presiding officer in presence of polling agents,  must mark the ballot as directed by the voter and place it in ballot box and this action and reason must be entered on a list of votes marked by presiding officer.
