voting_methods.instructions: Voting shall be conducted without interruptions from seven to nineteen hundred hours. At the seats of diplomatic missions and consular posts, voting shall be conducted over a period of two days, where it shall end on the same day as the closing of voting in the Republic of Croatia. With Article 39 of the Act on Amendments to the Act on the Elections of Representatives to the Croatian Parliament (Official Gazette 19/15), which entered into force on 25 February 2015, paragraph 2 was amended. Polling stations shall be closed at nineteen hundred hours, but voters found at polling stations at the moment of closing shall be allowed to vote.

government_functions.details: The prime minister is the head of government and the commander in chief of the armed forces. The president is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system for a 5 year-term. The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislature. The Supreme Court is the highest court in appeal. The president of the Supreme Court is nominated by the president of Croatia and elected by Croatian Sabor (parliament) for a 4-year term. Other Supreme Court justices are appointed by national judicial council with a mandatory retirement age of 70. The parliament's (Sabor) powers include enactment and amendment of the constitution and laws, adoption of the government budget, declarations of war and peace, defining national boundaries, and calling referenda and elections. The assembly has 151 members elected through a closed-list proportional representation system.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: This is provided for in the Constitution, which states that Althingi shall be composed of 63 members elected by the people by secret ballot on the basis of proportional representation for a term of four years. It is a two-tier proportional representation (PR) system. Of the 63, 54 seats are filled in six multi-member constituencies. In order to participate in the distribution of seats at the national level, a party must obtain at least five percent of all valid votes cast.

voting_and_voters.voting_age_source: Chapter I (Right to Vote and Eligibility), Article 1 of Act No. 24

voting_methods.instructions: Early voting or pre-election voting is held at District commissioners' offices, in main offices and branch offices although District commissioners may decide that pre-election voting at the official address of the commission shall take place at a special location outside the main office, and also that voting shall take place at other locations in their administrative areas. Voters who are members of the crew or passengers on board an Icelandic vessel on sailing routes abroad or on remote fishing grounds may cast their votes on board the vessel. Early voters abroad cast their votes in the offices of Icelandic embassies or permanent missions to international organisations, in consular offices or in the offices of honorary consulates, or any locations abroad, as determined in further detail by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs. Voters have to prove his identity, receive the prescribed electoral materials and vote using it by stamping or writing the letter of the alphabet of the list he or she wishes to vote for on the ballot paper. The voter has the right to indicate a preference regarding the order of the candidates on the list. Vote must be without assistance or without anyone seeing his vote; thereafter, he/she writes the address on the covering letter and signs it in the presence of the election official, who witnesses the casting of the vote. Voters who are unable to attend polling sessions on election day can cast their vote early (Article 56 of Act No. 24/2000). It is the voter himself who decides this. Since this is in fact interpreted broadly voters do not need an excuse to vote early. Note that the start of the early voting is eight weeks before election day and will end before the election day.

Voters cast their votes by marking a cross in the check box with a pencil on the ballot paper in front of the letter of the alphabet of the list for which they wish to vote. If a voter wishes to change the ranking of candidates in the list for which he or she votes, he or she may do so by putting the number 1 in front of the name he or she wishes to place at the top, the number 2 in front of the name he or she wishes to have in second place, the number 3 in front of the name he or she wishes to have in third place, etc., as far as he or she wishes to change anything.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is elected by direct, secret ballot, by those who have the right to vote in parliamentary elections. The President is the Head of State. The Executive Power is exercised by the Government.  However, the Legislative Power is vested in both the Parliament and the President. The Legislative Power is comprised through 63 representatives through six constituencies elected through proportional representation in elections celebrated every four years.  The Judicial Power lies in the Supreme Court, Court of Appeal and district courts. The Judiciary is indepndent of the Executive and the Legislative. The Supreme Court of Iceland shall be composed of seven judges, commisioned for an indefinite period of time by the President of Iceland as proposed by the Minister of Justice.

voting_methods.instructions: After voter registration, the ballot will be stamped with the elections stamp and the Supervisory Board stamp by the official responsible for registration and the Supervisory Board monitor, respectively. After separating [the ballot from the registration paper], the ballot will be returned to the voter. After obtaining the ballot, the voter will write on the ballot the first and last name and other specifics of his or her preferred candidate or candidates. In case the first and last names of the candidates have already been printed on the ballot, the voter will place a mark in front of the names of his/her preferred candidates, and after dropping the ballot in the ballot box, will leave through the exit door of the voting station. Needless to say, the election registration papers and the special supervisory section [of the ballot] will be kept after being stamped under the joint observation of the voting station staff and supervisors of the Guardian Council.

government_functions.details: Iran has a unique system of government known as an Islamic Republic, a combination of democratic and theocratic elements, as outlined in its Constitution established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. The political structure is characterized by a dual sovereignty: the Supreme Leader, who holds the highest state authority, and the elected President, along with the Parliament. It blends aspects of a parliamentary democracy with Islamic theocracy, guided by the principles of Shia Islam.  The executive branch is headed by the President, who is elected for a four-year term and can serve a maximum of two consecutive terms. The President is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the country, including the implementation of laws, overseeing the economy, and conducting foreign policy. However, the President's powers are subject to the oversight and approval of the Supreme Leader, who is the highest-ranking religious and political authority in Iran. The Supreme Leader, appointed for life by the Assembly of Experts, holds significant influence over all branches of government, including the military and judiciary, and has the final say in matters of state and religion.  The legislative branch consists of the Islamic Consultative Assembly, or Majlis, a unicameral body whose members are elected by the public. The Majlis drafts legislation, ratifies international treaties, and approves the national budget. However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

government_functions.details: The Government of Sri Lanka is a semi-presidential democratic republic with a unitary state structure. The executive branch is led by the President, who is the head of state, commander-in-chief, and head of government. The President appoints a cabinet of ministers from elected members of parliament and can serve up to two five-year terms. The Prime Minister, as the President's deputy, leads the ruling party in parliament and shares domestic responsibilities. The legislative branch is a unicameral 225-member parliament, with 196 members elected from multi-seat constituencies and 29 through proportional representation. All members serve five-year terms through universal suffrage. The parliament holds the power to make laws, while the President can summon, suspend, or dissolve sessions. The judicial branch consists of the Supreme Court as the highest court, a Court of Appeal, High Courts, and subordinate courts. The legal system blends British criminal law, Roman civil law, and customary laws. Judges are appointed by the President, with a judicial service commission managing lower court judges.

If vacancies remain after the first round, a second round is held involving unsuccessful candidates on the following basis: if one vacancy is to be filled, the 3 unsuccessful candidates for whom the greatest number of votes were cast in the 1st round; if two vacancies are to be filled, the 4 candidate

government_functions.details:
Kiribati has a unicameral House of Parliament (Maneaba) of 46 members who serve 4-year terms. 44 members are elected through a two-round runoff system from 26 constituencies, 1 member is appointed by the Rabi Council, and 1 member (the attorney general) serves ex officio. The Speaker is elected by the Maneaba and is not counted as a member of the Parliament.

The executive branch consists of a president (te Beretitenti), a vice president, and a cabinet. The President is both the Chief of State and Head of Government.

The judicial system consists of the Court of Appeal, the High Court and Magistrates' Courts. The president makes all judicial appointments.

The Executive Branch is led by the President of ireland (uachtarán na hÉireann), who shall take precedence over all other persons in the state and who shall exercise and perform the powers and functions conferred on the President by this constitution and by law. The Legislative Branch rests in the oireachtas which shall consist of the President and two houses, viz.: a house of representatives to be called dáil Éireann and a senate to be called seanad Éireann. the sole and exclusive power of making laws for the state is hereby vested in the Oireachtas: no other legislative authority has power to make laws for the state. On the other hand, Justice shall be administered in courts established by law by judges appointed in the mannerprovided by the constitution, and, save in such special and limited cases as may be prescribed by law, shall be administered in public. The Courts shall comprise the Court of First Instance, a Court of Appeal, and a Court of Final Appeal.

voting_methods.instructions: Voter can invalidate cancel his/her early vote by casting a ballot on election day. The law provides that pre-election voting can start as soon as possible after the election date has been advertised, but not earlier than eight weeks before election day.

An elector shall vote at the polling station at the location of domicile unless otherwise prescribed. To take a vote, an elector shall receive a ballot by his/her ID card unless otherwise prescribed. After having received the ballot, the electors shall vote by themselves. The electors shall arrive at the polling stations within the specified time limit to vote, and may not enter the polling stations out of time.

government_functions.details: Taiwan has a semi-presidential system, with a president as the head of state and a premier as the head of government. The president is elected directly by the people for a four-year term, and the premier is appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan, the unicameral parliament.  The Executive Yuan, also known as the Cabinet, is the executive branch of the government. It is responsible for carrying out the policies and decisions made by the president and premier. The Executive Yuan is headed by the premier, who is assisted by a vice premier and a number of ministers.  The Legislative Yuan is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the activities of the government. It has 113 members, who are elected from single-member districts (73), multimember constituencies by single nontransferable voting, exclusively for people with indigenous status (6) and party-list proportional representation (34).  The Judicial Yuan is the judicial branch of the government. It is responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that it is applied fairly.

government_functions.details: The prime minister is the head of government and the commander in chief of the armed forces. The president is elected by absolute majority vote through a two-round system for a 5 year-term. The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislature. The Supreme Court is the highest court in appeal. The president of the Supreme Court is nominated by the president of Croatia and elected by Croatian Sabor (parliament) for a 4-year term. Other Supreme Court justices are appointed by national judicial council with a mandatory retirement age of 70. The parliament's (Sabor) powers include enactment and amendment of the constitution and laws, adoption of the government budget, declarations of war and peace, defining national boundaries, and calling referenda and elections. The assembly has 151 members elected through a closed-list proportional representation system.

voting_methods.instructions: Voter can invalidate cancel his/her early vote by casting a ballot on election day. The law provides that pre-election voting can start as soon as possible after the election date has been advertised, but not earlier than eight weeks before election day.

An elector shall vote at the polling station at the location of domicile unless otherwise prescribed. To take a vote, an elector shall receive a ballot by his/her ID card unless otherwise prescribed. After having received the ballot, the electors shall vote by themselves. The electors shall arrive at the polling stations within the specified time limit to vote, and may not enter the polling stations out of time.

government_functions.details: Taiwan has a semi-presidential system, with a president as the head of state and a premier as the head of government. The president is elected directly by the people for a four-year term, and the premier is appointed by the president with the consent of the Legislative Yuan, the unicameral parliament.  The Executive Yuan, also known as the Cabinet, is the executive branch of the government. It is responsible for carrying out the policies and decisions made by the president and premier. The Executive Yuan is headed by the premier, who is assisted by a vice premier and a number of ministers.  The Legislative Yuan is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the activities of the government. It has 113 members, who are elected from single-member districts (73), multimember constituencies by single nontransferable voting, exclusively for people with indigenous status (6) and party-list proportional representation (34).  The Judicial Yuan is the judicial branch of the government. It is responsible for interpreting the law and ensuring that it is applied fairly.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: The law divides Egypt into individual elections constituencies (420 seats) and 4 large constituencies for closed list elections (120 seats). In the last parliamentary election, we had two tracks: a two round system

voting_methods.instructions: The casting of votes by the voter in election or referendums shall be by marking the ballot intended for that purpose. Presiding Officer must ascertain the identity of the voters himself/herself, after which he/she shall hand them the ballot or ballots specified by NEA subject to the electoral system or the subject of the referendum. The ballot must be stamped with the Seal of the Polling Station or the signature or seal of its Presiding Officer and must indicate the date of the election or referendum. The voter must step behind the curtain set up for that purpose in the elections hall, his/her opinion shall be recorded on the ballot, and then the ballot shall be deposited in the ballot box pursuant to the procedures determined by NEA. ... The voter shall sign against his/her name in writing or by thumbprint in the Roll List of Voters of the Polling Station where the names of all voters registered therein are indicated. The Secretary of the Polling Station shall sign next to the name of the voter who has expressed his/her opinion.

electoral_rights.source: Law on the Regulation of the Exercise of Political Rights

government_functions.details: Egypt's government is divided into three branches: the executive, the legislative, and the judicial. The executive branch is headed by the president, who is the head of state and the supreme commander of the armed forces. The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term and can be re-elected once. The president appoints the prime minister, who forms the government and chairs the cabinet of ministers. The cabinet is responsible for carrying out the day-to-day business of government.   The legislative branch  is a unicameral body called the House of Representatives. It is composed of is composed of no less than four hundred and fifty members elected by direct secret public ballot. At least one quarter of the seats shall be allocated to women. The President of the Republic may appoint a number of members that does not exceed 5%. The primary functions of the House of Representatives include the drafting and approval of legislation, oversight of the executive branch, and the ratification of international treaties and agreements. The House also has the power to grant a vote of confidence to the Prime Minister and the Cabinet, and it plays a key role in fiscal matters, including the approval of the state budget and economic policies.  The judicial branch is independent of the executive and legislative branches. It is headed by the Supreme Constitutional Court, which has exclusive authority to decide on the constitutionality of laws and regulations, interpret legislative texts, and adjudicate in disputes pertaining to the affairs of its members, in disputes between judicial bodies and entities that have judicial mandate, in disputes pertaining to the implementation of two final contradictory rulings, one of which is issued by any judicial body or an agency with judicial mandate and the other issued by another body, and in disputes pertaining to the implementation of its rulings and decisions.  However, each judicial body or organization manages ts own affairs and have to be consulted concerning the draft laws regulating its affairs. Each of them has andependent budget. The President  appoints  the heads of the judicial bodies or organizations.

government_functions.details: The President of Togo serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by plurality vote and may serve an unlimited number of 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President.  Togo has a unicameral National Assembly with 113 seats. All members are directly elected via list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 5-year terms.  Togo has three high courts with distinct purposes. The Supreme Court is composed of a civil/penal chamber and an administrative chamber. The Constitutional Court is composed of 9 judges. Constitutional Court judges may serve up to two 6-year terms and are appointed by the President (2 judges), the National Assembly (2), the Senate (2), and several national legal organizations or communities (3). The High Court of Justice handles treason and other criminal cases against current and former presidents. It is composed of the president and chamber presidents of the Supreme Court and 4 additional judges selected by the National Assembly.

voting_methods.instructions: Voter has to come to the building fo the relevant constituency commission by filling in a ballot paper. The ballot paper filled up by the voter beforehand has to be put into the envelope, glued up and signed in glued place by two members of the relevant election commission and then it is confirmed by the seal of the election commission and the signature of the voter. The glued envelope is preserved by the secretary of the relevant election commission in the building of the constituency commission prior to the moment of passing of ballots to the PEC. In the day of voting, before the beginning of voting, the chairman of the PEC in the presence of the member of PEC, observers and other persons gives the information about the number of voters, who have Early Voting and then show the envelopes with the ballots and the list of voters, who have Early Voting. After that he opens the envelopes keeping the secrecy of the voters’ will and cast the ballots into the ballot boxes.

Vote receives ballot-papers on the basis of voter list upon presentation of a passport or other identity documents; fills in a ballot-paper in a polling room or booth in secret and presence of other persons when filling in a ballot-paper except for voter is prohibited; A voter should vote only for one candidate and for one political party. A voter marks an empty box with “+” sign next to the name of a candidate or a party he or she is voting for and then casts the filled ballot-paper into the ballot box.

voting_methods.instructions: Proxy voting is prohibited except that voters with a significant or moderate degree of disability within the meaning of the law or who are over 75 can formally give another person their proxy vote (a proxy vote can be taken only from one person or two if immediate family member, and not commission member or partisan agent); voter must provide proof of identity to the election commission (overseas voters must present a valid Polish paassport); a stamped ballot paper is issued and voter confirms receipt with his/her signature on the voter list; voter must mark ballot in the polling booth that guarantees secrecy; for presidential elections the voter must vote for only one candidate by putting an "X" next to the name in the box on the left; voter inserts the ballot in the ballot box located in a visible position, in such a way that the printed side of ballot is not visible;  voters with absentee voting certificates are allowed to vote after being entered in the voter register; upon request by a disabled voter, another person who is not a poll worker or partisan observer can assist the voter to vote.

Overseas voters apply for postal voting at least 15 days before the election day and receive a voting package.  They are to mark the ballot and insert the marked ballot in the ballot paper envelope, seal the envelope and insert it into the return envelope together with the signed declaration (a statement of personal and secret casting of the vote) and return it by mail at his or her own cost to the address of the consul. Voters can also deliver the postal vote in person to the consul. The consul transfers all returned envelopes that it received by the end of voting to the appropriate election commission.

government_functions.details: The President of Poland serves as chief of state while the Prime Minister acts as head of government. The President is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds and may serve two 5-year terms. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President and confirmed by the Sejm.  Poland has a bicameral Parliament composed of a 100-seat Senate and a 460-seat Sejm. Senators are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Members of the Sejm are directly elected by party-list proportional representation vote in multi-seat constituencies and serve 4-year terms. Parties must earn at least 5% of the national vote to gain a seat in the Sejm, and coalitions must earn 8% of the vote with minority parties excepted from this standard.  Poland has two high courts: the Supreme Court and the Constitutional Tribunal. The Supreme Court is composed of 121 judges separated into thematic chambers. Supreme Court judges are nominated by the National Judicial Council and confirmed by the President, and they may serve until age 65. The Constitutional Tribunal is composed of 15 judges appointed by the Sejm to serve a 9-year term.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Seats are allocated using D'Hondt Method with a 3% threshold. However, minority groups that account for at least 15% of the population in a district are given an exemption that lowers the electoral threshold to 0.7% (for up to three seats). A separate exemption is given to ethnic Croats whereby if no list representing the population passes the 0.7% threshold, the list wth the most votes will win one seat if it receives more than 0.35% of the vote (maximum one seat).

voting_methods.instructions: Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is not allowed. Voters must prove their identity with a biometric ID card or passport. Electronic voter identification devices are to be used at polling stations and each voter is to be identified electronically. Upon receiving a stamped ballot voters are to sign the printed extract of the voter register and poll worker is to circle the ordinal number. Voters are to be explained how to vote; they must circle the ordinal number or name of the chosen competitor. Voters must mark the ballot only in a private polling booth. If a voter votes outside the booth or shows anyone his/her ballot, the polling board is to invalidate the ballot.  Voters must fold the ballot personally, and leave the counterfoil unobstructed, and while holding the ballot folded ballot in their hands, they are to go to the ballot box and allow the designated poll worker to detach the counterfoil from the ballot. The poll worker is to personally sign the overleaf of the counterfoil and store the counterfoils in serial number order. The voter is to put the ballot in the ballot box. A disabled or illiterate voter can be assisted by a person of their choice in marking the ballot  (not by a poll worker or partisan representative).

government_functions.details:
Montenegro is a parliamentary republic. The Prime Minister is nominated by the president and approved by the Assembly. The President is directly elected in a two rounds of voting if necessarily. Voters in Montenegro must have resided in the country for a minimum of 10 of the past 15 years. 

The unicameral Skupstina or Assembly has 81 seats with all members directly elected in a single nationwide constituency. Members serve for four years unless snap elections are called by the President of Montenegro, the government, or a minimum of 25 members of parliament. 

The judiciary is comprised of the Supreme Court (Vrhovni Sud), which has 17 members including a court president and deputy president, as well as the Constitutional Court (Ustavni Sud).

government_functions.details:
The President is the chief executive of the national government (Sect 1). He enforces the law, conducts foreign affairs, makes treaties with the advice and consent of the Olbiil Era Kelulau, appoints ambassadors and other national officers with the advice and consent of the Senate, appoints judges from a list submitted by the Judicial Nominating Commission, grants pardons and reprieves, spends money pursuant to appropriations, collects taxes, represents the national government in legal actions, and proposes an annual budget (Sec 7).

The Olbiil Era Kelulau or the legislative branch consists of two houses: the House of Delegates and the Senate (Sec 1). It has the power to enact legislation, levy taxes, borrow money, regulate commerce, establish a monetary and banking system, ratify treaties, and provide for the national defense, among other powers (Sec 5). To overturn a presidential veto, a bill must be approved by not less than two-thirds of the members of each house (Sec 15).

The judicial power is vested in a unified judiciary, consisting of a Supreme Court, a National Court, and other courts established by law (Sec 1). The Supreme Court has a trial division and an appellate division (Sec 2). It has original and exclusive jurisdiction over matters affecting ambassadors, public ministers, consuls, admiralty and maritime cases, and cases in which the national government or a state government is a party (Sec 5).

The appellate division of the Supreme Court has jurisdiction to review all decisions of the trial division and lower courts (Sec 6).

government_functions.details: Kuwait is a hereditary emirate. The chief of state is the Amir, who is chosen from within the ruling family and confirmed by the National Assembly. The Prime Minister is appointed by the Amir, as is the Crown Prince, who also must be approved by the National Assembly. The Crown Prince is also designated as the Heir Apparent and the National Assembly must swear fealty to the Crown Prince.   Kuwait has a unicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Umma), which has 50 members and 15 ex-officio seats reserved for cabinet ministers. Per the Constitution, there may be more ministers (and thus ex-officio members) so long as the number of ministers does not exceed one-third of the total assembly.   The highest courts in Kuwait are the Constitutional Court and the Supreme Court. All judges are appointed by the Amir on the recommendation of the Supreme Judicial Council.

voting_methods.instructions: Early voting as such is not available for voters. Ill and incapacitated voters who have been approved for home/mobile voting (and voters in prisons and detention facilities and non-family based care institutions) are visited by the Election Board which brings a special ballot box. The voter must be alone when they cast the vote. After they vote, they put the ballot in an envelope, they seal the envelope and put it in the ballot box.

Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed and proxy voting is prohibited.  Only one voter at a time can approach to vote; when a voter approaches, he/she proves his/her identity with a valid identity card or passport and the poll worker inserts the submitted identity document in the technical equipment; the equipment will indicate if the voter is registered at the polling station and if she/he has already voted; if the voter is registered at the polling station and has a proper identity document and has not voted, his/her photo and voter list ordinal number will appear on the screen (if the voter is regsitered but at a different polling station, the equipment will display the number of the correct polling station); with an ultraviolet lamp, the poll worker checks whether there is an indelible mark on the voters' nail and thumb of the right hand; if the voter has not voted and is in the correct polling station with a valid identity document, he/she deposits a fingerprint from the right index finger onto the equipment; the ordinal number of the voter on the voter list is circled by the poll worker and the voter signs the list and he/she is given a ballot; after receiving the ballot, an indelible spray is put on the thumbnail of the right hand; after marking the ballot by circling the number of the preferred contestant, the voter puts the ballot in the ballot box. If a voter is not allowed to vote for any reason, the Electoral Board must provide the voter with written reasons using the template. Due to physical disability or illiteracy, a voter can ask another person to assist him/her with voting (if voter does not have someone to assist the polling committee appoints another person from among the voters, but not a poll worker, partisan representative or observer, and the same person cannot assist more than two voters).  Home (mobile voting) is also available for incapacitated or ill voters who are unable to vote at the polling station, whereby the day before election day a special ballot box is brought to the house of the voter who applied for home voting.  Voters' identities during mobile voting can be confirmed without the use of technical equipment.

voting_methods.instructions: Election Law 1982, 15. Ballot papers: (1) The ballot of every voter shall consist of a ballot paper and the names of the persons shown in the statement of persons validly nominated as candidates, and no other person shall be entitled to have his name inserted in the ballot paper. (2) A ballot paper shall be in Form 7 in the Appendix and shall be printed in accordance with the directions therein and shall - (a)contain the names alphabetically arranged according to surnames and numbered accordingly and other particulars of the candidates as shown in the statement ofthe persons nominated. Opposite to the name of each candidate there shall be printed one of the symbols as are specified in Form 8 in the Appendix which shall be allotted by the Supervisor of Elections; (b) be capable of being folded; (c)have a space provided on the face of the ballot for the initials of the presiding officer; (d)have attached a counterfoil and a stub, and a line or perforations between the ballot and the counterfoil and between the counterfoil and the stub, the whole as in Form 7 in the Appendix. 16. Official mark: (1) Every ballot paper shall be marked with an official mark, which shall be either stamped or perforated. (2) The official mark shall be kept secret and an interval of not less than seven years shall intervene between the use of the same official mark at elections in the same polling division. 17. Prohibition of disclosure of vote: No person who has voted at the election shall, in any legal proceedings to question the election or return, be required to state for whom he voted.

government_functions.details: The President serves as both head of state and head of government. The President is elected indirectly through the Electoral College, a body made up of electors with each state receiving the number of electors equal to the size of their delegation in both house  of Congress. Generally, the electors give their votes to the candidate who won the state. The President is elected to four-year terms with an absolute two-term limit.  The legislature is a bicameral Congress consisting of the Senate and the House of Representatives. In the Senate, 100 members are elected by plurality vote (2 members per state) to serve 6-year terms. One-third of Senate seats are up for election every 2 years. In the House of Representatives, 435 members are elected by plurality vote in single-member constituencies to serve 2-year terms.  The Supreme Court is the highest court in the US judiciary. The court consists of nine justices, each nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Justices serve lifetime appointments. The federal court system also includes 13 regional courts of appeal and 94 district courts.

voting_methods.instructions: Proxy voting is prohibited;  poll worker first checks, with a special device, if any indelible ink is on voter's right thumbnail or forefinger thumbnail (inking procedure does not apply to mobile voters); if no ink, voter is allowed to enter polling station if a national ID card or passport is presented; voter is allowed into polling station only if not more than two voters are at registration desk; at registration desk, voter presents ID and poll worker checks ID against voter list; if voter is on list, poll worker inks voter's finger according to procedure, and poll worker signs voter list against voter's name; poll worker signs back of ballot(s) and certifies ballot(s) with special seal; voter is given ballot(s) [for 2020 parliamentary elections, two ballots will be used - one for proportional and one for majoritarian election, and only one ballot will be issued for subsequent elections under fully proportional system]; voter signs voter list against his/her name to confirm receipt of ballot(s); voter marks ballot(s) in secret voting booth and folds ballot(s) so that mark is not visible; voter must vote alone in booth except if he/she is unable to fill out the ballot paper independently, he/she may ask any person to assist (poll workers, candidates, partisan agents, observers, and media representatives cannot assist); voter takes folded ballot(s) to table with special envelopes and personally puts ballot(s) into an envelope and personally puts envelope into the ballot box; poll worker must keep ballot box slot closed except when voter is inserting envelope;  if voter spoils ballot or special envelope a replacement  is issued on request; home/mobile voting is available for voters who have requested due to health problems (in addition to mobile voting for persons residing in institutions such as military units, hospitals, detention centres, and prisons.) Voters who vote in institutions such as hospitals and prisons, and poll workers, can only vote for the proportional part of the parliamentary elections if they are voting in an election precinct different than the one where they are registered to vote.

government_functions.details: The executive branch of Georgia is headed by the President, who acts as the chief of state, and the Prime Minister, who is the head of government. The President is elected by an electoral college for a five-year term, while the Prime Minister is nominated by the party that holds the majority in the Parliament and is appointed by the President. The executive branch is responsible for implementing laws, conducting foreign policy, and overseeing government administration. The legislative branch of Georgia is unicameral, consisting of the Parliament (Sakartvelos Parliament), which has 150 members. As of 2024, all 150 members are directly elected by proportional representation vote. Parties must win at least 5% of valid votes to receive a seat. Members of Parliament serve four-year terms, and the legislative branch is responsible for making laws, approving the budget, and overseeing the executive branch​. The judicial branch of Georgia includes the Supreme Court, the Constitutional Court, and lower courts. Judges of the Supreme Court are nominated by the High Council of Justice and appointed by the Parliament, while Constitutional Court judges are appointed by the President, Parliament, and Supreme Court judges. The judicial branch interprets laws, ensures justice, and protects the rights and freedoms of individuals.

voting_methods.instructions: Out-of-country voting at diplomatic missions and consular posts is available to citizens who do not reside in Lithuania but are entitled to vote in the elections; they are entered in electoral rolls for the constituency in the territory where the parliament is situated and can vote for a designated period not less than 10 days, and ending on polling day Lithuania time. Voters who are aboard a ship and will not be able to return to Lithuania to vote, are entered on the electoral roll of the polling district on whose electoral roll the ship's crew is entered, and can vote on the ship.

There is no general postal voting; the term postal voting is used to describe special mobile "post offices" which are available to voters who are in healthcare institutions, social care or guardianship institutions because of their health condition or age, voters who perform mandatory military service or who perform active military service, civil service or work under contract in international military operatons abroad, or voters who are in detention facilities. Postal voting is possible at these mobile post offices on the last Wednesday, Thursday or Friday before an election day.  Posting voting envelopes are also used for advance voters (those unable to be go to vote on election day) and home voters; the election committee is to hand the sealed envelopes from advance and home voting to the postal worker. who seals it with a special lable and gives the voter a receipt.

The head of an appropriate post office is responsible for organizing voting by post. The chairman of the electoral committee of the polling district on the territory where a post office is situated is responsible for organizing the supervision over the post office work related to postal voting. The responsible chairpersons are to organize the members of the polling district electoral committees to work during voting in special post officers. The head of the post office with the consent of the constituency electoral committee appoints postal workers for the issue and collection during postal voting of ballot papers and postal voting envelopes. Commanders of military units deployed abroad are responsible for organizing postal voting in those military units. Postal voting for voters in military units deployed abroad is to be conducted in accordance with the procedure laid down by the central election commission, on the recommendation of the Minister of National Defence. Expenses related to postal voting are covered by the state budget. The institutions where postal voting takes place must have a place where voters can, without interference and in secret, mark the ballots and place them into a voting envelope. The postal worker issues the election documents to a voter in accordance with a procedure established by the central election commission. A covering envelope for voting by post is to be addressed by the postal worker to the polling district electoral committee which is indicated on the person's poll card.  An entry on the poll card concerning the issuance of the ballot paper should be made and the card returns to the voter.  After marking the ballot in secret, the voter is to insert the ballot paper into a sealed envelope and then insert the sealed envelope and the polling card into the covering envelope for voting by post which is then sealed and handed to the postal worker who should seal the envelope with a special label and give the voter a receipt.

Generally voters are to vote in the polling district where their name is on the voter list; must show a passport or other identification document or otherwise two citizens on the voter list of the polling district must bear witness in writing to the voter's identity;  proxy voting is prohibited; if entered on voter list voter is given an arrival card; if an electronic voter register is used the arrival of the voter will be entered on it; upon giving arrival card to ballot issuer, voter and ballot issuer sign voter roll; voter is handed two ballot papers; voter must vote in polling booth and personally put ballots in ballot box; a spoilt ballot paper can be replaced on request by voter; assisted voting for disabled voters is allowed by another voter (not poll workers, observers, or partisan representatives) and home (mobile) voting is available on request for persons with disabilities. Secrecy of the vote is guaranteed.

For early voting, a constituency electoral committee organizes the voting on the designated advance voting days in the premises arranged beforehand and suitable for voting in the building housing the workplace of the mayor of the municipality in the territory of which the constituency is located. If a constituency comprises the territories of several municipalities, early voting is to be organized in all those municipalities. For handing out and accepting ballot papers and envelopes in advance voting, the chairman of the constituency electoral committee appoints not less than two members of a constituency electoral committee or district electoral committee who may not be proposed by the same political party. Advance voting is supervised by the chairman of a constituency electoral committee, or upon his instruction, a member of the committee. When voting in advance, an entry is to be made on the poll card concerning the issue of the ballot papers and the poll card shall be returned to the voter; a voter shall vote in person and in secret, mark the ballot papers; put the marked ballot papers into the ballot paper envelope; seal the ballot paper envelope; place the ballot paper envelope together with the poll card into the covering envelope for voting by post, and seal the covering envelope for voting by post.  The sealed envelope should be given to the election committee/postal worker which should seal the envelope with a special label and give the voter a receipt.

government_functions.details: Lithuania is a parliamentary democracy and a decentralised unitary state. The Lithuanian Parliament is called the Seimas. The 141 members of the Seimas are elected by a mixed system: 71 members are elected in single-member constituencies using a two-round system, and the other 70 members are elected in multi-member constituencies using a proportional representation system. All members serve 4-year terms, and there are no term limits. The Prime Minister serves as the head of government and is nominated by the President and confirmed by the Seimas.  The President serves as the head of state and is directly elected by absolute majority vote in up to two rounds. The President may serve up to two 5-year terms.

voting_methods.instructions: On Polling, Counting and Results Summation- Article 7 Head of the polling & counting committee shall at 7:00 am invite the voters to start flowing into the polling and counting room. Every voter shall exercise his/her right to vote as follows: A . When the voter appears before the polling and counting committee, the committee shall verify his/her identity and make sure that his/her name is registered in the final voter list for that district by checking the computer and the hard-copies of the list. The list shall be marked electronically and by hand to indicate that the voter has exercised his/her right to vote. B . The chair of the polling and counting committee or one of its two members shall give the actual voter a ballot paper. C . The actual voter shall: ( i ) mark in the designated place the name, number or emblem of one of the lists standing for election in that electoral district; ( ii ) mark in the designated place of one or more of the candidate names in that specific list. E . The actual voter shall put the ballot paper in the designated ballot box, which must be visible to the committee and to all persons present. F . The actual voter shall put his/her finger in the designated ink. G . Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e) of this Article, the Board may decide to conduct the polling and/or counting process electronically, for which the terms and conditions shall be set out in special executive instructions issued for that purpose.ـ

government_functions.details: Jordan is a constitutional, hereditary monarchy with a parliamentary government. The king remains the country’s ultimate authority and wields power over the executive, legislative, and judicial branches. The king appoints the prime minister who then chooses a cabinet.  Both the prime minister and cabinet appointments must be approved by the parliament.  Jordan has a bicameral National Assembly (Majlis al-Ummah), with a Senate (Majlis al-Aʿyan) as its upper chamber, and a House of Representatives (Majlis al-Nuwwāb) as its lower chamber. Members of the Senate are appointed by the king for four-year terms, while members of the House of Representatives are elected every four years. A small number of seats in the House of Representatives are reserved for Christians and Circassians.  Judges are appointed and dismissed by royal decree following a decision made by the Justices Council. There are three categories of courts. The regular courts, including those of magistrates, courts of first instance, and courts of appeals and cassation in Amman, hear appeals passed on from lower courts. The constitution also provides for a Special Council, which interprets the laws and determines their constitutionality. There are also religious courts and special courts which deal with particular matters such as land, taxes, and customs.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Elections of the President are held in a single nationwide district. The candidate who receives the absolute majority of the cast votes is elected; if no candidate receives an absolute majority a second round is held within two weeks between the top

voting_methods.instructions: In the period of early voting, on a daily basis after termination of the voting, the chairperson or deputy chair of the precinct commission glues a sheet of paper on the slot of the ballot box, and signatures of the chair, deputy, and a member of the commission are put on the sheet. At the start of each early voting day the slot is opened in front of observers and media. The ballot box is kept secure by the chair throughout the early voting period. On each day of early voting a protocol is filled out by the precinct commission to account for all ballots; the protocol is put up for general familarization in the premises of the precinct commissions. When receiving the ballot in early voting, voters must sign the voter list and enter the day of the early voting. The voting procedures are the same as for election day. Early voting is not held in the voting precincts formed in health care facilities.

Voters must submit their internal passport or other document determined by the central election commission; if voter is on voter list they are given a ballot and sign the relevant line on the voter list; votes mark their ballot in a polling booth or room, with ballot boxes placed so that the voters approach them only through the booths or premises assigned for secret voting; proxy voting is prohibited and voters must personally mark their ballots; another person can assist voters who are unable to personally mark the ballot, at the voter's discretion (poll workers, candidates or their representatives, election observers or media representatives cannot assist voters); ballots have the option of "against all"; voters who spoil ballots can receive a new ballot.

government_functions.details: Belarus is a presidential republic with a bicameral parliament. The President of Belarus, elected for a five-year term, is the head of state and Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. The president is directly elected by an absolute majority of the votes cast (if not, a second round is held) and if more than half of the registered voters have taken part in the voting (if not, a new election is held). Executive power is nominally exercised by the government, at its top sits a ceremonial prime minister, appointed directly by the President.  Legislative power is de jure vested in the bicameral parliament, the National Assembly. The 110 members of the lower House of Representatives are directly elected for five-year terms under a majoritarian system in single-member constituencies. The Council of the Republic is the upper chamber of territorial representation, its members elected at meetings of the local councils of deputies and the City of Minsk, plus eight members appointed by the President of the Republic.  The Constitutional Court is the highest court in Belarus which deals with matters involving the Constitution and legality of certain laws passed by the government. The Supreme Court is the highest court of general jurisdiction that deals with matters of civil and criminal law.

government_functions.details: The President of the Republic is elected by direct, secret ballot, by those who have the right to vote in parliamentary elections. The President is the Head of State. The Executive Power is exercised by the Government.  However, the Legislative Power is vested in both the Parliament and the President. The Legislative Power is comprised through 63 representatives through six constituencies elected through proportional representation in elections celebrated every four years.  The Judicial Power lies in the Supreme Court, Court of Appeal and district courts. The Judiciary is indepndent of the Executive and the Legislative. The Supreme Court of Iceland shall be composed of seven judges, commisioned for an indefinite period of time by the President of Iceland as proposed by the Minister of Justice.

Supreme Court judges are nominated by a Judicial General Council but then confirmed and appointed by the president.

The president and vice president run for office on the same ticket and are elected by direct vote for 4-year terms.  Legislative power is exercised by a bicameral congress--the Senate (32 members), and the Chamber of Deputies (150 members). Members of both houses of congress serve 4-year terms. voting_methods.instructions: The voter applies to the Chief Electoral Officer to vote in advance, is issued with a ballot paper and envelope marked "Vote in Advance of Poll".  The applicant then alone and secretly votes by striking out the names of all candidates but the one for whom they wish to vote, places the ballot paper in the envelope, seals it, and then delivers it to the Chief Electoral Officer.  The Chief Electoral Officer shall hold the envelope and the voter's declaration securely until polling day when the envelope will be delivered to the presiding officer of the relevant polling place.  The presiding officer will open the envelopes and, without unfolding the ballot papers, place them in the ballot box,

The voter, having received their ballot papers, shall immediately retire into one of the inner compartments provided for the purpose in the polling place, and shall there alone and secretly vote by marking their ballot papers by striking out, in the case of the village constituency paper,  the name of every candidate except the one for whom they wish to vote, or in the case of the common roll, for those for whom they wish to vote.  They must then fold the papers before leaving the compartment so the contents cannot be seen, and then deposit them so folded in the ballot box.

voting_methods.instructions: Each voter must vote personally; proxy voting is prohibited. When a voter changes his/her residence before the election day, the precinct election commission can issue an absentee voting certificate, on request by 6:00 pm of the day before the vote, to the voter to allow him/her to be included on the voter list, and to vote, at the polling station where he/she resides. Ballot papers are issued to voters on the voter register who submit an identification document. Voters sign the voter register to confirm receipt of the ballot, and the ballot issuer also signs the voter register against the name of the voter who is given the ballot.  Voters must mark the ballot(with the chosen political party) using a pen in a polling booth.  Voters who cannot independently fill in a ballot can be assisted by a person whom he/she trusts (but not a poll worker, public official, candidate proxy, journalist, or election observer). Mobile voting can be requested in writing, not later than 12:00 am on election day, by voters who cannot come to the polling station due to state of health or having to care for an ill family member, as well as voters living in remote areas where no polling station exists.  The secrecy of the vote is guaranteed. Ballots shall be filled in by voters in a polling booth. While filling in the ballots, the presence of anybody in the polling booth, except the voter, shall be forbidden. Note that Kazakhstan has two time zones: Kazakhstan Eastern Standard Time, which is 6 hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time (GMT6).  Kazakhstan Western Standard Time (merged with Kazakhstan CentralStandard Time) is 5 hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time (GMT+5).

electoral_rights.source: Articles 39 (1-1)  and 42 of of the Constitutional Act of the Republic of Kazakhstan on Elections.

government_functions.details: Kazakhstan is a unitary state with a presidential form of government. The President is the head of the state and is directly elected by simple majority popular vote for a 7 year term. The Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Ministers are approved by the lower house of parliament following nomination by the President.   Kazakh parliament is a bicameral system that consists of the 50-sear Senate and the 98-seat Mazhilis. 40 Senate members are indirectly elected by oblast-level assemblies and 10 members are appointed by decree of the President. Members of the Mazhilis are directly elected.   The highest levels of the judiciary are comprised of the Supreme Council of the Republic (44 members) and the Constitutional Council (7 members, including a chairperson).

government_functions.details:
Executive Branch: Headed by the President, who is the head of state and commander-in-chief of the armed forces. The President is responsible for implementing laws, directing foreign policy, and overseeing government administration through various ministries. The Prime Minister, appointed by the President with the National Assembly's consent, assists in coordinating government functions and can act as the President’s deputy.
 
Legislative Branch: The National Assembly is a unicameral parliament composed of elected representatives. It makes laws, approves the national budget, ratifies treaties, and oversees the executive branch. It also has the authority to impeach public officials, including the President.
 
Judicial Branch: The judiciary ensures the constitutionality of laws and delivers justice. It includes the Supreme Court, the highest ordinary court, and the Constitutional Court, which rules on constitutional matters like impeachment and political party dissolution.

voting_methods.instructions: Here are the steps for casting your ballot: 1. Show your Electoral Card/National ID card to the Polling Clerk. 2. The Polling Clerk checks that there is no stamp for this election on your Electoral Card. 3. The Polling Clerk looks for your name on the Electoral Roll and checks your name on both new (VES list) and old electoral roll (GVRS list). 4. When the Polling Clerk has found your name and has checked your identity, he or she will place a tick next to your name and number – make sure you are included successfully in the new Electoral Roll based on National ID registration, as this roll will be the only one to be used in future elections! 5. The Polling Clerk will give you an envelope and a booklet containing a ballot paper for each candidate. 6. Go to the Voting booth. – People with disabilities who cannot get to the polling booth or cast their ballot on their own can appoint a person to help them. This person must be a registered voter. 7. Look through the candidate booklet carefully and find the ballot paper of the person you want to vote for. You can find it easily by looking for their photo or their symbol. 8. Put the ballot paper of the candidate you want to vote for into the envelope and come out of the Voting booth. 9. Show the Polling Clerk that you have one envelope only. Throw away the left-over ballot papers in the closed bin outside the voting booths, or where the Polling Clerk tells you. 10. Put your envelope into the ballot box. 11. The polling Clerk stamps your Electoral Card with the official government stamp in the place that says “Date of Voting”. They add the date and sign. 12. Give the Polling Clerk your left thumb and get it inked. 13. Take your Electoral Card back. 14. Leave the Polling station

government_functions.details: The legislative branch consists of a single chamber called the Parliament, which has 52 seats. Members of the Parliament serve four-year terms. Under the legislative branch is the Malvatumauri Council of Chiefs, which shall be composed of custom chiefs elected by their peers sitting in District Councils of Chiefs. In the executive branch, the executive power is vested in the Prime Minister, who holds most executive authority and appoints the cabinet, is chosen by Parliament from among its members. The Head of State is the President. They are elected to serve a five-year term by an electoral college consisting of Parliament and the President of the Provincial Government Councils. The judiciary branch is composed of the Island Courts, Magistrates' Courts, Supreme Court and Court of Appeal. The Chief Justice is appointed by the President after consultation with the Prime Minister and the leader of the opposition; while the rest if the judiciary are appointed by the President on the advice of the Judicial Service Commission.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Single nationwide constituency; open list system; voters can cast up to four preferential votes for candidates on the list of the party they voted for.  Seats allocated using the Hagenbach-Bischoff system. Thresholds for allocation of seats apply. Members elected for a four-year period.

voting_methods.instructions: A special voter register of voters who do not have permanent residence in Slovakia is maintained by the Ministry of Interior. Out of country voters must submit an application, in writing or electronically, to the Ministry of Interior (for non-permanent residents) or to the municipality of permanent residence (for permanent residents) no later than 50 days before the polling day to receive a by-mail ballot. The Ministry or municipality must mail the ballot to the voter at least 35 days before the polling day. A secrecy envelope is provided with the ballot and guidance on how to vote.  All mail-in ballots must be received by the Ministry or municipality at the latest by the last working day before the polling day. By-mail voters temporarily out of country are marked on the voter register as having voted by postal vote.

No proxy voting allowed, identity card or other card proving identity required, ballot paper with envelope given to voter, voter signs voter list before voting, must vote in the polling booth, votes for a political party and may vote for up to four candidates on the party list, replacement of spoilt ballot papers allowed, ballot (envelope) placed by voter in ballot box, physically disabled voter or voter who cannot read or write can be assisted by another voter (not by commission members) , mobile (home) voting for health reasons is available, secrecy of vote guaranteed. Voters can apply before election day for a  certificate that allows them to be registered and to vote in any polling district if they are not able to vote in the polling district where they are registered (upon issuing the voter certificate the voter is deleted from their own voter register).

government_functions.details:
Executive power is exercised by the government led by the Prime Minister. The President is the head of state and the formal head of the executive, though with very limited powers. The president is elected by direct popular vote, under a two-round system, for a five-year term.

The members of the 150-seat parliament (National Council) are elected for a four-year term under a proportional representation system, within a single nationwide constituency, with a 5% threshold for parties, 7% for coalitions of two or three parties, and 10% for coalitions of more than four parties. Following National Council elections, the leader of the majority party or coalition is usually appointed prime minister by the president.

The Supreme Court is the country's highest appellate court, the judges of which are elected by the National Council; below that are regional, district, and military courts. The Constitutional Court rules on constitutional issues; its 13 members are appointed by the president from a slate of candidates nominated by the parliament. The 18-member Judicial Council nominates common court judges and is responsible for appointing a disciplinary committee in cases of judicial misconduct.

basic_data.electoral_system_other: Mixed system, combining FPTP and Block Vote constituencies with electoral threshold of 25%.

voting_methods.instructions: After voter registration, the ballot will be stamped with the elections stamp and the Supervisory Board stamp by the official responsible for registration and the Supervisory Board monitor, respectively. After separating [the ballot from the registration paper], the ballot will be returned to the voter. After obtaining the ballot, the voter will write on the ballot the first and last name and other specifics of his or her preferred candidate or candidates. In case the first and last names of the candidates have already been printed on the ballot, the voter will place a mark in front of the names of his/her preferred candidates, and after dropping the ballot in the ballot box, will leave through the exit door of the voting station. Needless to say, the election registration papers and the special supervisory section [of the ballot] will be kept after being stamped under the joint observation of the voting station staff and supervisors of the Guardian Council.

government_functions.details: Iran has a unique system of government known as an Islamic Republic, a combination of democratic and theocratic elements, as outlined in its Constitution established after the 1979 Islamic Revolution. The political structure is characterized by a dual sovereignty: the Supreme Leader, who holds the highest state authority, and the elected President, along with the Parliament. It blends aspects of a parliamentary democracy with Islamic theocracy, guided by the principles of Shia Islam.  The executive branch is headed by the President, who is elected for a four-year term and can serve a maximum of two consecutive terms. The President is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the country, including the implementation of laws, overseeing the economy, and conducting foreign policy. However, the President's powers are subject to the oversight and approval of the Supreme Leader, who is the highest-ranking religious and political authority in Iran. The Supreme Leader, appointed for life by the Assembly of Experts, holds significant influence over all branches of government, including the military and judiciary, and has the final say in matters of state and religion.  The legislative branch consists of the Islamic Consultative Assembly, or Majlis, a unicameral body whose members are elected by the public. The Majlis drafts legislation, ratifies international treaties, and approves the national budget. However, all Majlis decisions can be vetted and must be approved by the Guardian Council, a body consisting of twelve members, half of whom are appointed by the Supreme Leader. The judicial branch, independent in theory, operates under the influence of the Supreme Leader. It is responsible for interpreting the Constitution and Sharia law, ensuring that all legislation and executive actions conform to Islamic principles. The head of the judiciary is appointed by the Supreme Leader and oversees the court system, which includes public courts, revolutionary courts, and special clerical courts.

voting_methods.instructions: (1) Each voter shall, subject to the provisions of section 82, receive from the presiding officer a ballot paper on which such officer has previously put his or her initials so placed as indicated in the form set out as Form No. 11 in the Second Schedule that when the ballot paper is folded the said initials can be seen without opening it, and on the counterfoil of which he or she has placed a number corresponding to the consecutive number on the official list of voters and entered in the poll book opposite the name of such voter. [Amended by Act 11/1971] (2) The presiding officer shall instruct the voter how to make his or her mark, and shall properly fold the voter’s ballot paper, directing him or her to return it, when marked, folded as shown, but without inquiring or seeing for whom the voter intends to vote, except when the voter is unable to vote in the manner prescribed by this Act on account of illiteracy, blindness or other physical incapacity. (3) The voter, on receiving the ballot paper, shall forthwith enter one of the polling compartments in the polling station and there mark his ballot paper by marking with a black lead pencil and not otherwise a cross within the space opposite the name and symbol of the candidate for whom he or she intends to vote, and he or she shall then fold the ballot paper as directed so that the initials and the numbers on the counterfoil can be seen without opening it, and hand the paper to the presiding officer who shall, without unfolding it, ascertain by examination of the initials and the number appearing thereon that it is the same paper as that delivered to the voter and, if the same, he or she shall, subject to section 83, in full view of the voter and of all others present remove the counterfoil and deposit the ballot in the ballot box. [Amended by Act 11/1971] (4) A voter who has inadvertently so dealt with the ballot paper delivered to him or her that it cannot conveniently be used shall restore it to the presiding officer who shall cancel it by writing the word “Spoiled” across the face of the same, and the presiding officer shall then deliver another ballot paper to the voter. (5) Every voter shall vote without undue delay and shall leave the polling station as soon as his or her ballot paper has been put into the ballot box. (6) If at the closing of the poll there are any voters inside the polling station who are qualified to vote and have not been able to do so since their arrival at the polling station, the poll shall be kept open a sufficient time to enable them to vote, but no one not actually present within the polling station at the hour of closing shall be allowed to vote. [Previously section 70] 79. National identification cards and questions to be put to a voter. (1) The presiding officer at the time any person applies for a ballot paper, but not afterwards, (a) shall request that person to produce his or her national identification card; and (b) may, and if requested by a candidate or his or her agent, put to the voter the following questions: (i) are you the same person whose name appears as “A.B.” in the register of voters now in force for this polling division?; (ii) have you already voted at this election either here or elsewhere. (2) Subject to subsection (3), a ballot paper shall not be issued to any person who (a) does not produce his or her national identification card when required to do so under subsection (1)(a); and (b) does not satisfactorily answer the questions asked of him or her under subsection (1)(b). (3) A ballot paper shall be issued to any person whose name appears in the register of voters and who is unable to produce his or her national identification card, if he or she satisfies the presiding officer that (a) a national identification card has not been delivered to him or her; (b) the national identification card delivered to him or her is lost or destroyed; or (c) he or she has been duly registered to vote and his or her particulars appear on Form 3A; and that he or she is the same person whose name appears in the register of voters by producing a valid passport or other Government issued photo identification card.

government_functions.details: Executive power of the federal government is vested in the president, assisted by three vice presidents. The president serves as head of state and government and is directly elected in nationwide elections to serve a five-year term, renewable once. Each vice president serves a five-year term and represents one of the three islands.   The unicameral legislature consists of the Assembly of the Union; members are elected to five-year terms. Slightly more than half the members are directly elected, with the remainder selected by the islands’ local governments.   Changes brought about by the 2001 constitution granted the three main islands partial autonomy, and each elects its own governor and legislative assembly. The government of each island is free to administer its own affairs so long as its actions do not infringe upon the rights of the other islands or otherwise threaten the state of the federal union.
